reviewText: I am using this with a Nook HD+. It works as described. The HD picture on my Samsung 52" TV is excellent.

These work perfectly with my Motorola MR350 radios, also purchased fromAmazon. I got them (headsets) only as an after-thought. The sensitivity settings on theradios (for head-set-use) for VOR use are a little touchy. I prefer using thePTT button WITH headsets connected... No breathing or extraneous soundskicking in the transmitter. Still, a good headset.
I've been using these headphones for over a year now and they're simply excellent.I know some have an issue with the style, but all I really care about is the sound quality.It's terrific.

Oh Koss PortaPro, how do I love thee? Let me count the ways:This pair of headphones is my favorite pair of portable headphones I've ever owned (just barely edging out my Sennheiser headphones I owned for years). They're highly compact and yet still pack a punch, providing rich full sound and, *gasp*, decent bass output as well (something severely lacking in most headphones). The semi-hard case is also wonderful. I very, very rarely leave the house without these headphones. They fit snugly and are barely noticeable, even after hours of use.My somewhat trivial gripe with this product is that, as a male with short hair, the retractable metal band will pull out a single hair every now and then. Very painful and somewhat frustrating, but not worth taking a star away,My family's been using these headphones for well over 20 years now and I've yet to find much better for the price.

Very rich sound for the price.  Have owned this product for several years and the sound is spot on but the earpads flaked badly and fall off repeatedly which is a pain in the ass to deal with.  See many similar complaints.
I got this for my grandson to use on a camera you bought at a flea market he loves that thing so glad I could get it for them thanks

This is an engineered "macro lens."  One of the best of that type I've ever seen or used.  In addition it makes a dandy prime portrait or light telephoto on smaller sensor cameras like the Canon T2.  One the Canon D6 is fills the frame with sharp to the edge image. Rapidly becoming my 2nd favorite lens behind the 24-70L lens.
summary: Great lens for all sorts of photography

reviewText: After months of reading about this lens and saving up the money, I finally bought it. Wow - that's really all I can say to sum it up. Awesome photos, incredible bokeh and extremely sharp at F/2. I would suggest getting a three stop ND filter for it. If you are shooting on a camera with only 1/4000 shutter speed, you may not be able to shoot wide open in the middle of the day. Some gripes were that this lens has no image stabilization. Normally I would put that into the negative category, but it doesn't matter on this lens. You can open the aperture up as much as you need and still get a tack sharp photo. I recommend shooting with this lens on a full frame body. The length is perfect, but also the ISO sensitivity is much better on full frame bodies. Copy and paste the link inside the brackets. I shot this image at F/2.The macro on this lens is the standard fare of all lenses. I would recommend pairing this up with some Kenko extension tubes. You can buy them on Amazon for $199. I own them and they are amazing. I am not too big into macro work, but these tubes allow you to get some really close up shots.[img][...]]
My first L lens... great images, great build, not bulky, affordable compared to other Ls, No IS and low light poor performance, portraits in good light.. amazing. Absolutely recommended.

This is the second wallet I've purchased, and both have been very satisfactory. The handle on the outside edge makes it easy to carry, and the sleeves inside are of good quality -- I have not had any issues with tearing. We converted our entire DVD and video game collection into these, cutting out the covers to put in front of the discs in the sleeeves, and have been very pleased.
Colorful, holds a DVD, none broken, price is right.Good way to store my TDK DVD's, if you need some,these work for me, recommended...

Bigger than it looks on the picture. Bought this to pair with the Micca MB42Xes I also bought on Amazon. Those sound great, this does not. Voices/sounds sound like they're coming through a radio sometimes. Really not anywhere near as good as all these people are making it out to be on the reviews. Promptly returned.

I tried these with V-MODA Crossfades.  The sound from these was clearly not as good as the crossfades.  However, I did love the long cord and the padded top headpiece.  However, the ear pieces ended up putting pressure around my jawline, and after about 30 minutes it was really starting to hurt.

reviewText: I work in video production, and we use a Canon 50mm f1.2 lens on a C300 for interviews. I own this lens, the f1.8, and use it on a 60D for stills. My walk about lens is the 24-105mm f4 L, but it's big and heavy. If I want to have a smaller profile, this is the lens I choose. The build quality is fine, and the performance is excellent for the price. For anyone who bought a Canon DSLR with one of the cheap kit zooms, this lens is a must!

I love my 50mm lens, but it's only a f/1.8 and I'm hoping to get a 1.4 and work up to a 1.2 soon. I absolutely love this lens, but when I rented a 1.4 and a 1.2. they were just as amazing! If it's your first time getting this lens, you won't be sorry.

reviewText: Bought one used by the seller: ELECTRONICS PRO 21. CAUTION do not buy from this seller. The modem was damaged, dusty and all of the items were just thrown into a plastic envelope. I am decent with tech but I could not get the modem to properly send out the Wi Fi signal. I asked the seller if I could get a refund and he said I was stupid and he was not going to refund a broken item. Such a D bag, and I had to get amazon involved but any ways Linksys are good modems but the used ones typically have the most problems and malfunctions. I would recommend buying a net gear or a new router. I bought a new net gear for cheaper and within minutes had my wi fi set up with name and password.

A repeat purchase. Excellent sound and very useful for watching night time TV , when partner wants to sleep and not get disturbed by the TV sound. Very easy to connect and totally maintenance free.  Would be happy to recommend to others.

One member of my household has poor hearing...invariably the volume of the television gets higher and higher as time goes by. With this wireless headset, the volume can be set at a comfortable level for all. I am running these through a stereo receiver out of the headphone jack. The great part is that if I am not watching the television, I can turn off the speakers completely, while the headset can be cranked as high as needed.The signal is very good, no background noise. You can dial in the signal on the headset; there is also a three-setting channel changer on the base for optimum signal. Just teach the user to be careful when taking off or putting on the headset not to accidently turn the tuning dial.
I bought these for my boat. They work great. No issues with the lenses fogging up as others may have said in previous posts.

Bought it to photograph my daughter sky-diving. I was staying on the ground, had my fill of flying in the military, so I needed to reach up. Worked well but I photographed the wrong person. My fault not the lens'. It has a tripod adapter for a reason.
Works good. Plug and play. Plus these wires gives you about another 5-6 inch of length from the factory wires.

I bought this to install a Boss radio into my 2000 Chevy S-10. It is doing it's job so far. The quality appears to be good.I wish auto manufacturers would just agree to a standard, so these kind of adapters wouldn't be needed.

My son is an audio-recording major and is picky about his audio equipment.  One of his instructors recommended this, and he has used it at school, at work,  and at home.  He noted that others like the sound and have asked about the model so that they can purchase one.  The price was reasonable, and the quality is high.

Ok.  There's lots of back-and-forth on this grounded plug support topic.  I mistakenly listened to the reviewers who said that it supported 3-prong grounded plugs and bought this.  Those people who say it supports 3 prong plugs are 100% wrong.I think that there is some detail missing in the reviews regarding this.  If your US plug device (the device you need to connect to international power) has 3 prongs on the plug (aka. it's grounded) then ** THIS WILL NOT WORK AT ALL -- EVER **!  Why do I know this you ask?  Because I tried it and there is no 3rd hole on the 'female' side of this device for a US grounding prong.Now, whether or not this device will connect to international grounded power outlets (aka. on the 'male' side of the adapter) is another question.  I don't know the answer to that.  That might work.  I don't really care about that because my grounded devices are never going to use this adapter.Amazon, please update the description to save everyone the hassle!
summary: Absolutely does not support US 3-prong grounded plugs.

reviewText: Great buy over the other electronic stores. Never again would I look anywhere else for cords. I had bought a high priced one and there is no difference whatsoever between this one and that. Great buy...get extras

reviewerName: Curtis Adams "When in doubt, empty the magazine!"
reviewText: Pros: CheapNice colorPyle usually makes good subs and speakers, I said usually....Cons: Sounds like crapCan't hear a twinge of sound through the tweetersIncluded crossover's are a joke, use your amps built-in crossover insteadMUST use an amp if you are to get anything out of this cheaper bundle.Thankfully, you don't have to buy a very expensive amp to push these two small speakers. A simple $60 amp from Walmart will even get them to where they need to be. Throw away the included crossovers, they are crap.Other thoughts: Be sure you have the necessary tools on hand to remove door panels, etc. Nothing worse than having a new toy and not being able to play with it while you're waiting on the tools to come in.For the price, I would buy the subs again to use with an amp, but the tweeters are crap and you will never be able to tweak them well enough to get what ya paid for, all be it, it wasn't much to pay for.

this thing is awesome!! I recommend this over any other beginner telescope because of the controls, the reason behind this is the other models that don't feature these incremental adjusters are extremely hard to position for the higher resolutions and viewing anything other than the full view of the moon, plus they are much more easily disturbed.  I have made that mistake, and its very frustrating trying to center what your aiming at going back and forth until you just give up and put the thing away......an to make matters worst if you have an excited child who knocks it out of alignment trying just to take a look.......this telescope is very sturdy and pretty well made and the price is very reasonable. so don't waste your money on anything less than this one.

Seriously over-priced for two small pieces of plastic that are under-engineered and therefore lead to stability issues (they fold themselves up if you move your laptop or keyboard even a small amount). Will find an alternative and suggest you do, too!

As I rely heavily on Nikon Speedlights, I have been itching to get myself a designated commander for over a year.  Honestly, I didn't do a whole lot of research on the SU-800 as I thought it would have the same functionality of the built in commanders of the higher end Nikon cameras: this turned out to not be the case.I solely use Manual exposure on my camera and on my flashes.  To learn that the SU-800 only allows you to set the flash exposures in FULL STOP increments blew my mind.  Every other mode, mind you, allows you to compensate by 1/3 stops.Come on, really?  Anyways, I can live with that.  You merely move the flash a few inches, and you will wind up with a 1/3 stop difference, I suppose.

The pro is that it never gets hot because there's lots of room for heat dissipation.  Charges in same time frame as the other Maha charger.  No problem with it after a year of use.

Thank you so much to the reviewers who explained that some brands of cards do not work in every device, and that SanDisk was the most universal of all the brands. I ordered it for my 5-year old Kodak Easy Share Digital Picture Frame, based on the knowledge I gained from the reviewers, and it works just fine! What a relief. None of my 2G+ SD cards did work. It had to be a 1G. The only thing that threw me were the three parts -- large, medium, very small. After I figured out that the tiny card fit INSIDE either of the other two cards -- which one depends on the device used -- I had no problem. It was the tense 5 minutes when I had no idea what all those pieces were that stopped me from putting it to use right way. This item is actually a two-in-one card, to help explain it to anyone else who doesn't know. You can convert it to two different sizes to fit different electronic devices and use the music or photos you saved in both (not at the same time, of course). Sure wish that had been included n the item's description, but I'm sure it was assumed everyone knew that! :-)
summary: Perfect for Kodak Easy Share Digital Picture Frame

reviewText: This is a great TV.  I have had it since Feb. 2007 (so, 7 years now) and I have never had a problem with this TV.  I've had the bulbs replaced twice.  IDK if that was due to faulty bulbs or what, but the last replacement was probably 2010, maybe 2011, and it hasn't been replaced since.  TV works great, gives a great high definition picture and has awesome (loud, clear, distinct) sound.Granted, if I had known LEDs were coming out two years after I bought this one, I wouldn't have bought it.  The TV doesn't have built in Wi-Fi, smart apps, or even a variety of HDMI ports (only two), but for the size and performance over the years, I give this TV five stars.My only pet peeve would be that the replacement bulbs cost so much if not under warranty ($100 for brand name; and from what I've read, you're better off going with the brand name).

Bought to replace a Belkin Travel Charger that gave off this really high pitch whine when plugged in. Works great to provide piece of mind in places where I am not sure of the wiring (usually airports, cheap hotels). Can't write too much about a great little device. Love how the plug goes into itself for travel/protecting the tip. Cord is thick and feels sturdy for heavy use and 4 ports is plenty! The face on folks when you plug this in and have a couple spares at an airport is like you the savior! Priceless.

I bought this to keep my main video editing rig up and running. I also do a lot of skype interviews and such so I needed the computer to stay on.HERE'S WHAT YOU MUST KNOW:If you are plugging in a computer that uses PFC which is pretty much any computer powered by a non-OEM power supply, such as a Corsair powersupply, then you can't use this.You need a sinewave PFC compatible UPS device. I don't know how to explain it in tech terms, but basically, PFC power supplies which are high quality, require a real sinewave power supply. This one, is not.So if you are just keeping a cable modem online, or perhaps a mass produced PC, you'll probably be okay with this. I wound up using this one on a cheaper eMachine computer for about a year or so and it worked fine for that.  However, my main machine that has a corsair powersupply would simply turn off and cause an alarm on this everytime the power flickered.It's not a problem with the Cyberpower unit, it's just not the right device for the job.So if you know that - i'll say this is an excellent UPS and it works great. I also have to give huge props to Cyberpower's US-based customer service as I had a defective unit once that they replaced with no hassles.
summary: Cyberpower is great - but YOU NEED TO KNOW

reviewText: Amazon requires a certain number of words for reviews. I think I should be able to rate something without explaining why I feel that way. Sometimes, it doesn't require an explanation.

Whether this works or not depends on your area. In mine, we have stations of various power levels and this amp has no way to adjust for that. To get this unit to work required a separate gain control from R.S. to reduce the signal level going into the amplifier. Unfortunately, the stronger stations in our area overloaded the amplifier and blocked the weaker signals as well as the stronger ones, yielding no signal at all. This amp does not have a gain control to adjust for this. I consider this a design flaw, and the lack of this feature probably explains the wide difference in customer satisfaction. I do want to add that the suppliers of this product were very customer oriented in delivering good service and fast shipping.

The user reviews here speak praise of the PSW110: as it should be. I am a music fan, and have little need for 5.1 or 7.1 audio. At 1/2 volume plus the PSW110 will thump your chest. The back of the subwoofer has several adjustments. I found that they sound best in the 12 o'clock position. Audiophiles know that bigger is not necessarily better. The PSW110 has plenty of punch.Unfortunately I am going to dock the subwoofer one star for the cheery finish. After buying my 2012 Kia Soul, I was immediately excited to tear it apart and start installing aftermarket audio gear.My goal was to find an inexpensive component set of speakers that would handle at least 100w per channel, the amp that would power these speakers is a Rockford Fosgate 451S (115w x2@4ohm). After researching and listening to as many speakers as I could at local dealers, I settled on the Polk Audio DB6501. They happened to be on sale at the time and fell right in to my price range.I installed these speakers myself into my sound treated doors (RoadKill Sound Deadening material) and sealed the adapotor into place with window sealant.These treatments helped bring out the bass significantly, and I'll get to that in the following sections. For the price, these speakers deliver! The highs are clear and the bass is clean. Mid range gets a bit muddled.Tweeters:As I stated above, the tweeters deliver a nice clear, well rounded sound. May even sound too bright at first, however the supplied crossover has a built-in attenuator that helps. While they do sound bright, out of the box hooked up to my Pioneer head unit, a flat EQ delivers lack luster sound a heavily rolled off highs. Sounds lifeless. Had a hard time tuning these speakers. And perhaps that has more to do with the Head Unit then the speakers themselves, however the same head unit paired with a higher quality speaker (such as my previous Boston Pro 60's) had no trouble and required very little EQ correction. The best sound I've been able to get out of these speakers was surprising though my Nexus 5 over Bluetooth using Viper Audio.The biggest problem I had with the tweeters is clipping. Regardless of volume, both tweeters clip on certain piano, flute and electronica passages. The best example of clipping was the dripping sound effects at the start of Look at Me Now by Lil Wayne. This happened on both the stock head unit and after installing the Pioneer.Woofers:The woofers are solid for their price point. Bass sounds great, however it lacks in volume. Not a problem if you have a decent subwoofer system, preferable a sealed sub. The midrange over shadows the bass greatly and usually comes off muddy. Some EQ helps but music that has a lot of electric guitars suffers the most from this problem. However music with little mid range, such as electronica, R&B; and rap, sound fantastic, naturally because there are little midrange there to overshadow the bass. After about 14 months my right woofer started to cut out and over the course of a month went out completely. Some part inside the woofer that created the connection between the magnet and the cone failed. Although I was out of warranty, I called Polk and told them about my problem. The sent me a prepaid UPS label and told me to ship it to them. I did and 5 days later a brand new woofer came back. Popped it in and was back in business. So huge kudos to Polk's fantastic customer service!OverallFor a great value and decent sound quality and plenty of volume (they can play very loud without any problems, aside from the persistent problems like the twitter clipping and lack of quality mid range). The are a great upgrade to a factory system and a good foot in the door to car audio if your on a budget.I just ordered the Polk MM6501 from Amazon to upgrade from the DB6501.Previously Owned Door Speakers:- Boston Acoustics Pro 60- Focal (Mid-Range class; 10 Years ago)- Alpine Type S CoaxialPros:Price! Price! Price! Absolutely the best bang for buck in their class.Power Hungry and Bullet Proof.Ease of installation. All the brackets are included to make install a breezeCustomer Service from Polk is fantastic.Cons:Mid range suffers the most in this speaker.Tweeter Clips on some passages.Much EQ is needed to dial these speakers to their potential.
summary: A Seasoned Review: DB6501's After 2 Years

I bought this bracket to mount my 32" LG TV. It worked but it took some modifying and purchasing of additional parts to make it fully functional.The main issue is the size of the 5mm screws included to attach the TV to the frame. They're smaller than the holes drilled into the frame. There are included lock washers that slightly increase the diameter but they can still easily slip through the frame with even the tiniest bit of shifting. I don't want my TV face down on the floor, so I ended up going out and buying some washers. Easy fix but still, the manufacturer should be able to foresee this being an issue. Did they even demo this bracket before selling it? Apparently not.The next issue is the lock screws on the bottom of the TV portion of the frame. The wall bracket attaches to the wall and there is a separate piece that attaches to the television, which then hangs on the wall bracket via two hooks. There is a screw on each side of the bottom of this latter piece that keeps it locked to the bracket, preventing accidental lifting of the TV. The television part tilts slightly to allow you to angle the TV down; however, if you angle it down, it prevents you from getting to the screw that locks it into the bracket. Basically, there is no way for me to secure the TV to the wall bracket. Luckily, we don't have large pets,kids, or live in an earthquake zone so this shouldn't be an issue but it could definitely cause a problem for others.All in all, it works okay but I'd recommend you seek a better designed bracket. I certainly would not buy it again.Update: While the mount is not so fantastic, Cheetah Mounts' customer service is amazing. Apparently, the issues I experienced with the mount were a known issue and had been fixed; however, it appears I received one of the old models. They contacted me asking for feedback and helped me out with another wall mount that suits my needs and won't destroy my TV if we have an earthquake. While I still can't recommend this mount (I'm sure they fixed it but I have no experience with the fixed version) I CAN recommend the company. They stand by their products, are receptive to customer feedback, and will do what it takes to make sure their customers are treated fairly.
summary: NOT good for a 32" TV on its own

reviewText: I first tried with my daughter's AMD A8 and Windows 8, and there were a lot of artifacts regardless of the quality settings.  I then tried it on my work laptop with Windows 7 Pro and a 3rd gen i7 and the video was crystal clear.  I plan to get my own laptop with Windows 7 (because I hate 8) and an Intel CPU for video capture.
summary: Great quality with Windows 7 and 3rd gen Intel i7

reviewText: Bought these for rears to my surround system. They replaced two small Yamaha satellite speakers.System includes two Tsi300 towers, a cs10 center, psw10 sub, connected to a Denon AVR-300 receiver.I have to say I am very impressed running these as rear surround channels. The surround sound is so much fuller now. I would imagine these would be quite capable of being used as your front mains if you had a smaller room. Ported to the rear, they have great depth when in a corner of a room. I also use a rocketfish wireless speaker adapter to run the rears. Which was a concern of mine when buying these, that the sound quality or ability of the rocketfish to run them would be lacking. This is not the issue at all. They still sound great!  Well worth the 150$Only thing I would be aware of, is they are LARGE bookshelf speakers. Even after reading the dimensions, and seeing pictures, I was still surprised once seeing them in person.
All i  needed it to do was to get the local stations,,,,,,,,, That saved me the expense of cable service

reviewText: Depending on your criteria you will either love or hate this lens. First the negatives. This lens is soft at f/4 and improves little when closed. How soft is soft? Noticeably softer than the kit DAL 18-55 wide open even when resized to ~2MP (24" monitor). The extinction resolution measured 1600-1800 lph in the whole FL range, That's a dismal performance.The good news, everything else is very good about this lens. The colors and contrast are outstanding. The AF was flawless, very quick, no hunting in low light. The lens feels solid, zoom ring is smooth without creep.I also had Sigma 17-70/2.8-4.0 (prior to Art version). Compared to Pentax, Sigma is noticeably sharper, though it's not sharp at the long end either. But Sigma produces very drab, lifeless images, lacking Pentax vivid colors and contrast.Bottom line, if you can live with the softness, this is one great lens.

I'm clearly not a fan of the self adjusting headband, because the tension feels like it wants to pull the headphones off my head.  But otherwise, the earpad cushions are very comfortable.  I don't like the build quality since the self adjusting headband feels a bit creaky when you put on the headphones, not as smooth as vintage AKGs I own.  Also, these made in China models smell of plastic.  It just underscores an air of cheap build quality.Sound quality was disappointing.  I was expecting something in between a Sennheiser HD600 and a Beyerdynamic DT880.  I use the DT880 as my reference open headphone just for comparison sake.  The AKG sounded a bit light on the bass, it just wasn't there...  The soundstage was wide but the separation was so wide that is sounded almost unnatural.  Mids and highs were unremarkable, but I thought the treble could have had some more extension and punch to it.I really wanted to like it and based on the good reviews I was expecting something better.  Headphone reviews are ultimately very subjective, for me based on comfort and sound quality.
summary: Light bass, wide soundstage, not comfortable

reviewText: This is a lens I have been salivating over for a couple of years. I ended up getting the 18mm Zeiss last year because I do a lot of landscape work and wanted a wide angle more than anything at the time.But I've also been wanting a 50mm for some time, and have had my eye on this one. Every time I came here to Amazon, I'd take a look at the customer images posted with this lens and drool a little. Well, I finally made the decision a couple of weeks ago and I'm in love. This is an AMAZING piece of glass. The quality is perfect. It's rock solid, fast and beautiful.Distortion is nearly nonexistent. The colors are perfect.If you're eyeballing 50mm glass, I highly recommend this lens.

After buying a Panasonic 65" VT60 plasma when they went on super sale on cyber Monday, I got the warranty because my old Vizio LED TV crapped out after about 3-3.5 years.  I then read a bunch about square trade and warranties in general and decided against going with it, as it really didn't look like it was worth it after all.  I think I just screwed up when I bought my Vizio by getting a brand new tech (Full Array LED) in a large size (55", then their largest) got burned by Vizio having low quality (perhaps just at that time).  But here it is 3.5 years later and I buy the Panasonic TC-P65VT60 (one of the highest rated TV's of all time by CNET and many other sources) for less than I got the Vizio for.I guess what the point is, if you think you have a 1/4 chance of your TV crapping out on you, then get it, but with big name reputable companies like Panasonic, Samsung and Sony, you are probably better off saving your money.  If you are the unlucky one, so be it, but you would probably rather buy a new one ... put it this way, right now I could get a comparable TV to my old Vizio 55" for the $500+ that the warranty would have cost me back when I bought the TV.
summary: Did a bunch of research after purchasing and decided to cancel ...

reviewText: This keyboard and mouse works just great, I have had no problems.  It was easy to install, works well and I just love it.  The mouse is a little big but I expected that and it just works and fits well with my desktop computer.

These are superior to the HD280 model. I use these daily at work and my ears are in heaven. I'm an ex studio musician and film editor so I have a very well trained ear and wear headphones for long periods of time.The HD 380 are not harsh with clean highs and great lows, far superior to the HD 280's. Sennheiser took a little bit lower driver sound profile rather than the 280's higher treble and good mids. I personally like the sound much better and the 380's are much much more comfortable than other headphones I've tried.After using so many headphones over the years, these are definitely my favorite. I can wear them for 12 hours without discomfort. The ear cups no longer push the foam onto your ear, it's pushed back more and a little bit bigger so it cups your entire ear without touching the outer leather like cushions as the 280's did.One gripe I have is they do not sit well around the neck. Sennheiser could easily have fixed this by allowing the ear cups to fold all the way out at 180 degrees so the speakers face out which is good for if you want to still listen to music or audio and hear your sounds around you such as 7.1 dolby audio work.Overall these are superior headphones and under $150 are definitely worth the purchase. I feel sorry for consumers that pay 200+ for those 'consumer grade' headphones when they could have professional quality for less. A+ Sennheiser.
summary: It's like an eargasm... don't listen to the haters

First of all, I'm a guy that loves taking photographs. While not a professional, I'm becoming much more critical of my work and demanding higher quality. As a result, I'm finding myself looking at prosumer equipment to feed the need. Now that I've gotten the fact that I'm a wannabe photographer out of the way let's get on with the review, one that won't repeat the technical specifications that can be found under the, wait for it, technical specifications section of this page.A while back I wrote a review for the Nikon 70-300mm lens. While I love the lens for outdoor sports it left a lot to be desired for indoor sports photography. As such, I started the research process for a lens that would without breaking the bank. It didn't take long to see that the Nikon 70-200mm F2.8 lens came highly recommended. While much more than I wanted to originally spend, I figured I'd take the plunge and start saving for it. After collecting from football parents and saving for a few months I ordered the lens.Upon delivery the first thing I noticed was the size of the box. After the unboxing ceremony I noticed how the lens dwarfed my 70-300mm lens. Not only did it dwarf it, it outweighed it. But the weight was a good weight, if that makes any sense. The build of this lens screams quality and the golden band confirms it! The only plastic you'll find on this lens is on the lens caps, front and back and the lens hood. The zoom and focus rings are made of a rubber material that doesn't cheapen the look of the lens. The recurring theme for this lens is metal, metal and metal.After a quick inspection for defects I slapped on the B+W UV filter and attached the lens to the camera, a Nikon D7000. Hey, I'm saving for an FX variant as I type this review. With the lens attached and firmly in hand the first impression was how will I shoot a venue with this behemoth around my neck? After powering up the camera, I threw her in manual mode and pressed the shutter release button with the lens cap on. The lens flew through the focal lengths. For comparison I placed the 70-300mm lens on and repeated the process. While the 70-300mm lens performed adequately, there was no comparison between the two. The 70-200mm lens stole the show. I then removed the lens cap, found a few subjects and shot away.After downloading the photos to my computer for evaluation I was pleasantly surprised. But come to think of it I should not have been. After all, the reviews I read earlier should have primed me for the performance of the lens. I was satisfied with 85% of the shots I took. The 15% that didn't make the cut were not due to the lens. It was a result of poor composition, blah subjects, etc.The past few months since purchasing have been spent really learning the lens. To get the most out of it and minimize editing, I've modified my camera's presets to produce a more vivid photo straight from the camera. Once the sweet spot is found, the shooting experience is enhanced. Colors pop and the contrast brings a natural sense of complexity and depth to photos.Since purchasing the lens I've taken photographs of a youth basketball team and my son's wrestling team. Some gyms were well lit and other's not so much. With my camera's shutter firing at 1/400 an ISO of 2500 and an aperture of F2.8, I'm getting many more keepers. However, I have noticed that if I'm shooting basketball from the sidelines the lens can be a little long on a DX camera. While I may not capture as much of the scene as I would with my 50mm 1.8G or a wider angle lens, my next purchase, what you do capture will be razor sharp and crystal clear.Bottom line, if you're looking for a fast lens that allows you to shoot in low light environments pick this one up. I'm a happy camper and so are my customers. She's definitely a keeper.Oh, by the way, I've gotten over the weight.
summary: Perfect for Low Light Indoor Sports

The TV stations that Comcast sends my way have varying levels of audio. That is not a problem with a headset such as a Sony, for example. You simply reach up and adjust the volume using the single control. With this headset you have to remove it from your head and look for the correct button, of a group of buttons, to push the right one depending on whether you want to change the volume up or down. All the buttons of the group feel the same to me so it is a nuisance to use this headset.There are other nuisances as well such as turning the headset and the transmitter on and off, pairing etc. I have only myself to blame for making this purchase. Had I read the reviews, as I normally do before buying anything, I would have known this is not what I want.I had been using a Sony headset which is perfect for my use. No on and off or a bunch of controls. Just lift it off the charging stand and slip it over your head. The negative is that some of the black coating on the surface next to the ears comes off and sticks to the ears. Naturally I could not see the black specks but, by golly, my spouse could  and pointed this out to me in explicit detail and with unrelenting frequency. Her advice was what caused me to try a different brand. Now I have gone back to the Sony and black specks are welcome, at least by me..I have had the Sennheiser headset too long to return because I had a difficult time getting it installed and working. I had to refer to the Sennheiser CD and the TV manual numerous times before finally getting the right combination. The sound quality of the Sennheiser if just fine. It is all the nuisances that turned me off. Goodbye Sennheiser and welcome back Sony.

For those with limited time, see summary at bottom.Have had an Asus O!Play mini for 3 years, so am used to all of its features.  You plug it in, it works; have used on a good number of tv's (home, friends, travel).  But no longer produced, nor sold, so when I wanted another one for the bedroom's tv, had to look elsewhere.  I know Asus, and Micca, you are NO Asus.Plugged Micca in, powered it on, connection via hdmi.  It went through its initial setup fine, though tv reported received input was 720p.  Tv 1080p so went to Micca video menu, set its output to 1080p.  TV reported 1080p received.  Played several videos from a usb flash drive.  All well and good.  Given both the Asus and the Micca use the same Realtek 1055 chip, the Micca plays a LOT of video types, MANY more than a tv or blu-ray usb connection will.But then, made the HORRIBLE mistake of turning the Micca off.  Powered back on; it never got past its boot screen of the Micca logo.  TV reported received resolution as 720p.  30 seconds later, tv reported no signal, then 30 seconds later, a 480p signal with the EVER present Micca logo.  Repeated every 30 seconds:  no signal, 480p Micca logo, no signal, 480p logo...  A non-satisfactory solution was to unplug (as in NO power) the Micca for an hour, then plug back in.  Then it would work again until next time powered off (but left plugged in).  Still, order WAS important:  first you had to power on Micca, then tv, THEN plug in hdmi cable to Micca.  If tv was off, or Micca powered on with hdmi cable connected, would not work.  Perhaps clicking heels together 3 times while saying "I wish you were an Asus" also helped; regaining a functional player never a sure thing.Full disclosure:  I had these problems when connecting the Micca via hdmi to the "purchased for" location of the bedroom's Seiki tv (a no-name, off brand for sure, but has a good picture and is 1080p).  Another review, "HDMI Issues with Samsung TV, March 4, 2014", by Dylan Rothman, reported similar problem with a Samsung tv.  Will say, when Micca connected via hdmi to the living room's LG, Micca functioned as expected, except for the problem of several of its buttons also operating the (non-Micca) blu-ray player (Micca's return powers blu-ray on/off, Micca's setup opens/closes blu-ray tray).  While setup button is not generally KNOWINGLY pressed, return button is frequently used.  Never have had that problem with the NUMEROUS other remotes I have.  The Asus O!Play mini has NO problems with either of these tv's, no problems with Toshiba tv's, or several other no name brands found in various hotels, both foreign and domestic.  Asus remote has never inadvertently controlled other devices.--------For those brave enough to try, the Micca remote is proof that more is NOT more.  Excluding the [left, right, up, down, OK] navigation buttons (common to both Micca and Asus remotes), the Micca remote has an additional 26 SMALL dedicated buttons; the Asus has 16 dedicated on the SAME size of remote.  Guess which is easier to use in a dimly lit room?The rationale for some of the Micca's TOP-LEVEL buttons, rather than being implemented as menu/sub-menu options as in the Asus, is beyond me; e.g., buttons for Tv system (cycle 480p, 720p, 1080i, 1080p resolutions), Repeat and A-B buttons for setting repeat clips, Setup button (it also has a top-level Home button that with a sub-menu selection will take you to setup), Av output type (Composite or Component)...  All add to "congestion" on the remote for functions that should RARELY be used.  Menu/sub-menu, rather than dedicated buttons, much more user friendly for seldom used functions.Having said that, 2 added buttons on the Micca are appreciated:1.  A dedicated Subtitle button (also reached by Option button, then sub-menu, on both Micca and Asus remotes).  But a dedicated, top level button appreciated by those of us who watch a number of foreign videos.2.  Another addition is capability for slow motion via a dedicated button (sequential pushes provide 3/4, 1/2, 1/4, 1/8, 1/16 speeds).A display button very useful (same as Asus's info button) to provide a VISUAL representation of where you are in the file (thick line for what's played, thin line for remaining), along with numeric data (elapsed time, total time), audio and video codecs in file, etc.  Useful in deciding to finish video, or stop and resume (another VERY useful feature) next day.  What's not so useful is its position on the Micca - sandwiched between other buttons, rather than on the Asus, where it's easily found given the wider spacing and user friendly layout.Another advantage of the Micca is that it does sort folders/files as a human would expect (alphabetically), while the Asus uses "computer programer mode" for FAT32 drives, displaying files in order as found in the drive's FAT table, no sorting (on your computer, windows provides the sort for explorer), though there are free software programs to "correctly" sort those files on a drive before moving to the Asus (useful for say 64gb flash drives, would not like to do on a 1TB drive...)  NTFS drives don't have this problem.Finally, the Micca has 2 usb ports (his and hers?) compared to the Asus's 1 usb port.  Positioning is different:  Micca's ports are on its sides (usb on 1, SD card on the other), while the Asus has its ports in front.  Depending on your location, each has its advantages/disadvantages.  Micca's may be a bit awkward to get to if it's in a low bay; Asus doesn't have that problem.  On the other hand, a usb drive does protrude from the Asus, a problem the Micca doesn't have.--------SUMMARYI wanted to like the Micca, I really did.  But I'm not a gambler.  While the Micca MIGHT work on YOUR tv, it only works on 50% of mine.  I certainly DON'T want to be carrying along something that might/might not work when I visit a friend or travel, and it does NOT work on its target tv in MY home.  Perhaps a FUTURE firmware fix might fix the problem (just in case, installed the most recent, as of now, version, 11-2013).  Micca still does not reliably work on all tv's.  SAME problems described above.Back it goes; THANKS, Amazon, it's why I buy from you.=========WORKAROUND for hdmi hang in Micca logo:  During initial setup, it'll work, so manually set correct video resolution via video menu.  After initial setup, when put into standby, and it won't start again, just hangs with Micca logo screen:  it's trying to connect at 480p, will ENDLESSLY wait for tv response it can understand, which will never happen.  Leave Micca player on, leave tv on, then unplug hdmi cable from player, then plug hdmi cable back in.  This sends a hotplug detect signal over hdmi's pin 19 to player, allowing player to finish boot and enter home menu.=========5/12/14:  LIVABLE workaround for HDMI hang (no cable unplugging required):1.  To prevent problem from occurring:  Make sure TV is off BEFORE powering on Micca.  Wait AT LEAST 10 seconds AFTER powering Micca player on BEFORE powering TV on.  Micca will successfully boot into home (top level) menu.2.  If you're in the Micco logo "hang" (Micca logo displayed for more than a couple of seconds, nothing else happens; remote's keys don't work, not even the power button), then turn TV off.  Wait AT LEAST 10 seconds, THEN turn TV on.  Micca will successfully boot into home (top level) menu.10 second WAIT is CRITICAL.  Any quicker, and hang is not cleared.Be advised it can take the Micca player 5-6 seconds to actually turn off after Micca remote's power button is pressed (power light on player goes from on=blue to standby=red).  Easiest is to turn player off FIRST, keeping TV on.  TV will report "no signal" as Micca starts its "off procedure" so you will know it's successfully shutting down.Hopefully, a firmware fix for the HDMI hang problem will be provided.  Now, if they could only do something about the CLUTTERED remote...
summary: Asus, Oh Asus, why have you forsaken me?
