reviewText: This keyboard is pretty much my default keyboard.  I have two Microsoft keyboards which are larger and bulkier.  This keyboard takes a little getting used to, but once you do, it's hard to go back.  It takes up much less desk space, they tactile feel is fantastic for a touch typist, the interface has acceptable range, and it's not overly noisy when typing.  Batteries last a long time, even with continuous daily use.  The key markings are still as sharp and bright as the day this keyboard arrived.  I also like the way the keys are mounted.  Each one pokes through a square hole so I have never had to remove dust and hair from it.  This is not obvious from the picture.  The standard designs mount the cap which is like an umbrella almost, on the switch and all sorts of debris collects under the umbrella until finally you clean it or it won't work.  This design is much better.The keyboard makes a great accessory to a laptop, and fits in my laptop case easily - giving me the same keyboard at home or away, which is very productive.

Great sound - makes it easy to control DAC details and spectrum as the headphones are very precise. Joy to wear - wearing for 10 hours including an hour and a few short breaks is not usually a problem.
Very simple device. Plug it in and away you go! nice and small to fit in a pocket or to take with you when you travel.

Easy to load audio files. Good sound. Unfortunately, after about six months, it gave up the ghost. I replaced it with a 4.3" android from Odd Lots for $39. With a micro SD slot, I've got not only hundreds of songs and audio books, but loads of ebooks too. I'll never go back to a straight MP3 player. Thank you, Coby.

This bag is NOT a "pro" bag!!!  But that's not saying its not a pro quality bag.  The bag itself is well thought out and quality built.Now sizing, that's where you get a lot of complaints in these reviews.  Let's reiterate, this is not a "pro" bag.  This is a bag designed for your "everday" shooter, you "weekend day trip" shooter.  You have enough to carry the basics and a little more.  To be honest, too many just people just simply carry too much.I am not a "pro" in any way.  I am an "enthusiast" photographer that takes a lot of day trips, adventure vacations, and outings with my kid.  I shoot a D5100 mostly with a 18-200 or a 35mm fixed.  This lens combo pretty much covers everything from random friends/family photos to Costa Rican rainforest to kid shots at the playground.  Indoors, sometimes, I'll use a flash.  And just to be safe, I carry extra SD card, extra batteries(8 AA's) for the flash and the camera charger plus an extra battery.  I also keep the lens hoods and the A/V cable packed as well.  And it ALL fits into the bag comfortably.I'm not carrying anymore.  For what?  I may not even carry all the stuff in there now if im out for the day.  I have not EVER had to get to the second camera battery, or tap into the extra flash battery stash.  Go out and enjoy the day instead of lugging all the unnecessary weight around.  This well padded bag does get all the NECESSARY equipment safely from Point A to Point B.  And it is quite comfy to carry, if not overly weighted down.  Like any sling-style bag, coming across the chest is not always the most flattering look.  But sling bags does get you to the ready a lot quicker.I also have a Tamrac Velocity bag which carry about the same amount in a different configuration.  I prefer this one because it seems to swing forward less when I'm skimpering/crawling around rocks or trees.
I had a set already and need two more for the house, buying one was 40 bucks on here, found this as a set for less than two and now have another transmitter with a dock! Great deal.

I've been using the Kensington K72355US Pro Fit USB Wired Mid-Size Mouse now for almost 2 years and love this mouse. It's the perfect size. I don't think I'd ever want to use a full size mouse or go any small than this. I use this mouse almost every day for personal and work use. I work from home and after hours spend too much time on my computer. No complaints over the last two years. I ended up buying another one just in case this one dies on me, but it seems to keep going and staying just as accurate and easy to use.
I got these for my son for Christmas and he loves them! And he's kind of picky kid so that's I high a recommendation.

I've tried a lot of wall mounts. Some better than others. This, by far is the best one. The design is perfect, sturdy, and easiest to set up. The best on all levels. I will be buying these from now on, on all my TV installs.

This is a very well-made camera backpack designed for multiple-day trips.  Engineers, archeologists, scientists, etc who are outdoors studying and carry camera or laptop with them would benefit from this bag.  The exterior frame makes this comfortable to carry for the average person (I am 5'7")  It comes with a rain cover and extra padding.A 17" laptop fits easily in the back along the external frame.The camera section is big enough to carry two camera bodies and several lenses with accessories.  This part is well-thought out, as the many zippers keep the expensive gear protected should a flap or two remain unzipped.  There are multiple side pockets for other gear, and the top pocket is for personal gear like extra clothes or food.  There are also smaller mesh pockets for much smaller stuff, like lens filters and data cards.This is the kind of bag experienced photographers would need.  While no one needs to bring all the gear to the field, when one does, it needs to be protected from the elements.  I also like how the exterior looks like a plain backpack and not some camera bag promoting Canon or Nikon.The quoted price is a bit steep.  But you get what you pay for.  There are less expensive bags out there that do as well as a job, but this bag is made to last.
summary: Designed for rough outdoor exploring and traveling

reviewText: This review is for the: TP-LINK TD-W8980 N600Having used TP Link routers before--back when I had cable that is--I was very impressed by the simplicity in set-up, yet no lack of experienced perks. So when I was forced to return to the stone age of DSL, there was no question in buying TP-Link. I certainly wasn't going to use a Century modem. As usual, the modem/router combo has outperformed all expectations, and has managed to eke out some quality performance out of sub-par DSL service. I don't have normal television. I use an antenna for local stations and stream the rest thanks to Roku3 and Amazon Fire TV. I'm also a full time doctoral student where I spend most of my time digging through LexisNexis like databases. Both of these chores require a quality internet connection. So you can understand my apprehension of having to return to DSL.But, the TP Link's dual band has managed my demands well. Both Roku3 and Amazon Fire are streamed on the higher end of the 5.0ghz band, while the rest of the household items (4 Laptops, 2 Smartphones, 2 tablets, DVD player, laser printer) are running on the lower 2.4ghz band. Surprisingly I've not encountered any buffering issues with streaming--though at peak hours I have found internet surfing to be extremely slow--no surprise there really, and this is not due to the router/modem.Set-up was simple-ish in a manner of speaking. Powering on, plugging in, and connecting to the router was a breeze...It was mostly CenturyLink who was the problem. First off let me be clear, YES this modem and any DSL rated modem WILL work with CenturyLink service. Do not let a representative tell you otherwise. What they will tell you is if you do not choose a modem/router on their list, the will not provide technical support--big deal, I don't need them too. But here is what you will need from Century, and you need to be firm and clear in this demand.When you call CenturyLink tell them you need the following information:1. Username and Password--don't be surprised if the tech gives you the run around and says "let me try linking to your modem first..." just say there is no need to you already know what the problem is. And for that matter, CenturyLink is supposed to provide you with your account username and password.2. Next ask for the VPI and VCI. This will be different depending on region.3. Confirm Connection Type. Mine was PPoE, and is likely the same for others.With this information in hand, simply go to the router settings by opening a web browser and type in 192.168.1.1 Then in put the information by going to Quick Setup. Voila! You should be connected. From there you can make personal adjustments and changes to the various settings offered by TP Link to improve your connection even further.Hope this helps! So glad TP Link makes a quality, well-built product. Also, the included antennas are optional depending on need. I hooked 2 of the antennas to the modem/router and this extended my coverage to the backyard without issue.

It was very easy to install which is why I took the time to report my experience. I didn't even use the software to install that comes with the Print Server. I read the manual, notice the default IP address is 192.168.0.10 with default user name & password "admin" & "admin" for password. So I set my IP address to same subnet 192.168.0.20 loged into the TP-LINK TL-WPS510U via http://192.168.0.10 changed the IP to match my router/firewall subnet ->192.168.1.10 saved and changed my laptop back to match my router's subnet. Loged back into TP-LINK TL-WPS510U, went to wireless scanned for wireless access point, found my AP and joined using my wireless key. Finally I unploged the print server TP-LINK TL-WPS510U and pluged it to my HP LaserJet 3500 and it workd! I installed the printer afterwards on Windows 7, XP and Linux OS, using TCP IP 192.168.1.10. I also changed the default password from "admin" to something else. Done! I had to install a different print server for a friend, Hawking Technology USB, but it was more complicated and even thou it was almost a plug and play after installing the Hawing print server software.
Plenty of room for camera, 4 batteries and SD card. Nice well-done belt loop great for hiking. Zippers have soft rubber-like tabs.Love it !
summary: Excellent case for Canon PowerShot  A1400

reviewText: I live 35 miles west from the broadcast towers near Sacramento, with three hills in the way, some huge evergreen trees next to my house on the neighbors property, and my neighborhood is in a deep depression behind the last hill, which completely blocks my LOS.  According to my tvfool report, most of what I'm getting is 2edge, meaning everything is bouncing off of multiple obstructions.Just for laughs, I tried a Mohu Leaf Ultimate, since it advertises up to 50 mile signal reception.  I got one station badly and saw unusable signal on two others.  Fortunately bought at a B&M; store so it was an easy return.I then tried one of the compact "lava" antennas sold under 800 names, with an included amp and two way splitter.  This surprised me by pulling in all of the UHF channels, but it was useless for my application with the VHF Hi stations.  Its definitely a decent UHF antenna, but you'd better have short distance and something close to LOS for the VHF stations.The HBU44 was recommended to me by solidsignal.  Its a long antenna but has narrow elements.  I really wanted an attic mount because my roof would be challenging to install on and where my house is positioned is prone to extremely high winds at various times through the year.  Its a perfect attic antenna.  While quite long at about 11-12', its in two sections easily joined and all the longer elements snap in and out without much trouble, just a tab and swivel.  It went into my small attic opening and I extended the wide elements as I went and then snapped the two that go up and down into place after positioning the antenna between the rafters.  It weighs 9lbs, so easy to hang or mount to a small post or tripod.  In my case it just laid into the rafters and didn't need a hanger.Solidsignal told me I'd probably have to put the antenna outside, and in my first experiment I got all the channels but with low signal levels on a few.  The Lava antenna actually got better numbers on a few of the higher UHF channels, but the HBU44 got the elusive VHF Hi signals for me.  I added a Wingard LNA-200 amp from Amazon and that snapped another 15-20 points of signal into all the channels and made them very solid.  I'm getting high 80's to mid 90's for signal level.  The antenna pulled in about 35 channels during the day and went to 60 in the evening.  Daytime reception can be much more difficult than night time reception.The only two downsides to this antenna are that it doesn't receive VHF-Lo channels, which is how it gets to be so compact as the VHF-Lo elements are the really wide ones on some antennas that support those channels, and they shipped the antenna covered in what looks like that silver greasy stuff you put on your nose in the summer to keep it from getting sunburned.  I was covered in the stuff by the time I was done with the install.Highly recommended for difficult attic installs in problematic reception areas, providing you've looked at an antenna web site like antennaweb or tvfool and determined that your stations are either UHF or VHF-Hi.  I think I'd go with a DB4 if all my stations were UHF.  Price is also a consideration, as this antenna was less expensive than others that might have done the job and many of those have either wider elements, elements that can't be retracted once snapped into place, or are much longer.If you aren't as far away or have better line-of-sight, you can go with the HBU33.  If you have more room in the attic and a larger budget, the HBU55 might work.
summary: Great attic antenna, pulls in some tough stations

reviewText: I bought the Das Keyboard as I saw so much praise for it online. Having tried Cherry Blues and disliking them on another keyboard, I decided to get the Das Keyboard and try out Browns. So as it turns out, I do not like Cherry Browns either. There's just a gritty feeling with Cherry switches that isn't pleasant to me. Keep in mind my daily keyboard has been an IBM Model M for years. I needed to buy a new keyboard that had USB support to use with a KVM as they don't make one with PS/2 connectors like my old IBM use.The keys feel nice being blank, but the ABS texture if you've ever felt PBT just isn't as nice (Model M's use PBT keycaps, feel a bit more textured to the touch). While I'm totally able to type without looking at the keys, having a blank keyboard is a bit gimmicky. I was frustrated a few times when playing a game which uses a key on the right hand side of the keyboard for some less frequently used function in the game. When you're playing a game, it's nice to be able to just glance down for a second to make sure you're hitting the right key. For pure typists, blanks might be fine but if you game I'd recommend getting one with printed keycaps. Blanks really aren't as cool as you think.The other big thing that I despised about the Das Keyboard - glossy finish. As someone who frequently rests their palms between typing on the front lip of the keyboard, I detest the feel of a glossy plastic finish. I also sometimes rest my left hand on the left edge of the keyboard. Coming from an IBM Model M where everything is very textured, thick plastic - the thin slick feel of the Das is just hugely uncomfortable to me. Being a clean freak I constantly was wiping the edges of the keyboard down with the included cleaning cloth. Some might be fine with a glossy finish, but I had no idea how glossy it was and it smudges extremely easily.Overall a well built keyboard, but between my apparent dislike of Cherry switches, the blank keys, and the glossy finish this keyboard just really wasn't for me. I ended up spending even more and ordered a Topre Realforce with all 55g weighted keys and I would strongly recommend a Topre switch over Cherry switches. In this price range, I think a Type Heaven would be a much better choice. Topres cost more, but are totally worth it for something you type on every day. If you just can't spring for a Topre, you'd be better off to just buy a cheaper Cherry based keyboard from someone like Cooler Master as they have a thinner lip around the keyboard, have a non-gloss finish, and have good build quality. The Das is a bit overpriced for what you get. Of course a Model M is an excellent keyboard assuming you can use PS/2 and don't mind the old school looks and loud keys (Honestly I think it sounds pleasant, in contrast to Cherry Blues which I find way to clacky and plastic sounding), and you can buy one for a fraction of the cost of even cheap new Cherry boards. I love my Topre, but I will never let go of my Model M.Update 4/4/2014: Seems that the makers of Das Keyboard realized the glossy finish was unappealing to a lot of folks like myself, new version of the Das Keyboard is now matte finish. I think this keyboard would resolve most of the issues I had with the Das. The price is a bit high for what you get though, as I don't think the Das does anything especially better than some of the cheaper mechanical keyboards.

These are about half-way through burn-in and they sound great. I also have the HD681, which have a more flat response and a great image. The 668B has a definite bump in the 80-200Hz range, but not what I would call too "boomy" sounding at this point. The 668Bs still have a nice image, but are more of a good listening phone for me. I will likely use them at work to take the place of my 681s that I've decided to use in the studio.Minus 1 star for the design. I can't imagine the headband pads holding up for very long. It will be a big disappointment when they fail, which they eventually will. I'm going to try covering them in cloth to prolong their life as I will be wearing them for hours at a time for most of the week. They would be five-star if they had the same AKG knock-off design of the 681.

So I bought this in November and it sat on the shelf until Easter, when we remembered we had bought it and pulled it out for the group photo.  I quickly learned 2 Major negatives on this and wished I would have spent the extra few bucks for the Canon brand remote.1. The range is WEAK. For a wide group photo I placed the camera probably 15' away, and attempted to click the remote.  Nothing.  i walked closer and closer trying and trying it, until I was probably 10' away (which IS the stated range in the specs, I just didn't pay attention to that when I bought it) So I clicked the remote and ran back to the crowd and had to try a few times since the camera was on the 2 second timer. I could have put it on the 10 second timer, but it's hard to know when to tell everyone to smile.  So I immediately bought the canon version for literally $3 more on the market place here. It came in yesterday and although they claim their range to be 16' - it goes past 16 feet. I maxed out my room at about 20' and it worked.2. It won't immediately trigger the shutter.  The main reason we purchased the remote was so we could take our own family pics on our MK III without paying a hundred bucks every time we needed family photos.  and with our 3 kids it's hard to get them to hold a pose, so I thought great, I'll just actuate the shutter the moment we get them all smiling and looking ahead.  Not on the Amazon version, all it does is activate the timer so the minimum is 2 seconds on my MKIII.  The canon version actuates immediately which is what I need.  If I wanted to just trigger the 10 second timer I could do that and walk out to the group and try to coordinate the cute looks right at that 10 second mark, but that's not the application I needed a remote for.So take all this for what you want, some people might be fine with the amazon version.  I'll sell you mine for $5 if you want to try it.  For me this was a lesson learned. I love the amazon basics brand for many other things, I've gotten HDMI, tons of USB 3.0, and who knows what else and always have been very pleased.
summary: Please read this if you are thinking about purchasing.

reviewText: I don't pay for cable anymore, not because I can't afford it but more on principal because of the junk that's on and the final wedge was the little popups at the bottom of the screen advertising while you are watching a show. So it was a great decision and I really don't miss it at all. But now I'm engaged and my fiancee does like to watch TV, so I bought this as a compromise to get us something as my TV alone or with cheap antenna didn't pick up any stations well. Right after installling this antenna I was delighted to see my TV find about 40 stations (Altamonte Springs, FL). Now some didn't come good enough, others were spanish, and others were religious or shopping channels. In the end I got about 20 usable channels. I bought an 8' closet pole to mount the antenna on allowing us to twist it side to side if a station isn't coming in clear. Overall a good solid product and the price is probably fair, as I've used <$10 antennas and not received a fraction of the stations. Wanted to add I just watched the superbowl in HD on foxsports thanks to this antenna.
summary: from 0 to over 20 clear HD TV stations

reviewText: This radio is very clear to listen to.  The DC290 version played the ipod/iphone immediately upon connection.  This one doesn't do that.  It charges my iPhone fairly fast.  My last radio charged at a much slower rate.
summary: Works great, I love the dimmable display

reviewText: I bought this to use with a raspberry pi in my home alarm can.  Connected via USB extension cable to outside the can.  Works great, drivers are included in the debian distribution that runs on Raspberry pi and it all just works.

Works right out of the box. I just built a new computer and installed Win 8.1Pro OEM and I plugged this little gadget in and it automajically connected lol. Jk windows ran its own drivers to make it work so I could update the drivers.
I bought this to expand the capacity of my FIOS DVR.  Works great, plug and play.  No problems.  Have owned it for a year now.

While the Product looks cool the performance is not what I expected.It's very limited and has little to be excited about. Yes you can hookit up as an USB / Amplifer for Audio out for headphones but not muchbeyond that.Hooking up to my MP3 Player to get more of a fuller soundleft so much to be desired. You basically have 4 levels of BassOff, Low, Medium, High... When hoping for a more fuller soundwith some bottom end it's very minimal. You can't EQ anything elseother then bottom end and it's lacking a lot of punch.Supposedly the newer version has a lot of improvements but if yougot this one you might be Leary of trying a newer version. FromSony Ear Buds to Phillips Noise Cancelling Headphones the qualityof sound improvement is very little different.Your most likely going to be better off getting better Headphones orEar Buds then anything else.I'd suggest the Digizoid O2 if you can findone. Or one of the rare to find Sony SEQ-50 Mini Equalizer / AMP'smade back from the 80's good luck on that.The FiiO will probably make a 20.00 to 50.00 Mp3 Player sound a bitbetter. It will give you a means to use USB if you need Audio out.ON a more high end Mp3 Player like a Zune, iPod touch or newerit's not going to make much of an impression.The Device is also super slow charging. There is no way to changethe Battery should it not be charged for portable use. You have tocharge it up or have a USB power supply handy.The Kit will come with a way too short device aux cable for hookingup your Mp3 device or Mini Radio. About 2 inches in length max andwith only one 45 degree end and one 90 degree end. A USB Charging/Connection Cable plus A Cover for the device which is nice, a Felt Bagwhich is nice with a arm band.There is issues known about not charging/or holding charges,,,,

Arrived in a day or two which was surprising. I didn't read very much about it only that it was a discontinued model. It didn't come with a manual or any instructions, or remote. We found a manual online and our universal remote operates it fine. It has 102 inch /1081i HD projection. It is HDMI and connects to either the laptop or the smart TV . It is perfect for playing movies outside for the grandkids and we all enjoy the crisp, clear picture. I was surprised just how clear it really is. Great Product and even better price.

If you are in the market for a higher-end, Bluetooth speaker, the Belkin FUSIVE Slim Portable Bluetooth Speaker may be the one you are looking for.Inside the box you will find the speaker itself, a quick start guide, a, a USB cable, and a travel case.  A small gripe--in this price range I would have expected a usb wall charger, but this is a small issue. The case is deluxe, as these things go.  The stiff, vinyl pouch offers good protection, it is zippered all the way around, and even has a small velcro strap to secure the USB cable.The speaker itself is 7.9 x 5.3 x0.7 inches and weighs only 12 ounces.  This is a beautifully designed and finished piece.  The  speaker grille is brushed aluminum with the Belkin-man logo in the upper left corner.  The brushed aluminum covers the top where the buttons are located.  The aluminum front is framed with hard black plastic, which raps around the side, the bottom, and the back.  The handle is connected to the upper sides and can swing around the back.  It doubles as the speaker stand.The USB port is hidden on the left side of the unit on the handle hinge.  When you swing the handle back you will find the Aux in port and the button for Bluetooth pairing.  All other buttons are found on the top of the device.  The volume +/- buttons are on the right.  In center you have the play/pause button flanked by right/left buttons to navigate through songs.  Then there is a call answer button and on the far left the on/off switch.  There is an LED that indicates charging and low battery status.  There is also a small microphone to the far right for answering cell phone calls.The device powers on easily.  Pairing was quick, easy, and does not require any code.  You simply tap the Bluetooth button on the side and wait until the speaker shows up on your device of choice.For a device of this size, the sound is incredible.  It excels pretty much at any type of music I threw at it from bubblegum pop, to Jazz, to classic rock, to heavy metal, and to classical.  The sound is clear.  The bass is incredibly rich and much better than expected, given the size of the device.  As to the bass, there is never any buzzing or fraying.The sound is well balanced.  Quite wisely, I think, the sound designers didn't over drive the bass, as is quite common on audio equipment.This, of course, is often a bit of a dilemma.  Bluetooth speakers almost never come with an equalizing function (and this one is no exception).  Some people really want a bass boost.  However, if you are playing anything other than pop or rap, overdriving the bass can be very distracting.  I prefer to have a less in-your-face bass, but this is something that people have to decide for themselves.  Please note that there is plenty of rich bass here, it just isn't designed to predominate.The treble is clear and never tinny and does not overwhelm as it can in many tiny speakers.This speaker is a stereo speaker.  However, as you can imagine, anything this small is going to have issues with stereo separation.  You will get more than a hint of stereo here, but it can't give you the same depth as two speakers that can be separated.Cell phone functions all work as advertised.  The auxiliary port delivers the same sound as Bluetooth.For a lightweight and portable speaker, you will get a much higher quality sound than you would expect from such a small package. Kudos to Belkin for making such a handsome, well sounding speaker.  Recommended.
summary: A fine, higher end, portable Bluetooth speaker

reviewText: I want to like this but I am having trouble. This drive is not as fast in performance as Western Digital laptop 7200 RPM drives I have had in the past. It is however 7mm in thickness and that is what new laptops seem to require. It does not seem any faster in performance than the 5400 RPM drive that it replaced. The Windows score for hard drive stayed the same too. It did not increase.Each time I shut down my laptop or it goes to sleep there is a significantly loud grinding noise that comes from the drive as it spins down and the head parks. I can't imagine that any noise like that is good for a mechanical device but my drive has yet to fail after a month.This is an advanced format drive. It will require an operating system that is advanced format compatible such as Windows 7 and Windows 8.Advanced users that want to clone their old hard drive onto their new HGST will be disappointed to find that unlike Western Digital and Seagate there is no drive clone and backup tools available for free download from HGST. Their website simply says to "purchase acronis true image" to clone an old drive to the new HGST drive. At the time of me writing this acronis true image cost as much as this drive currently costs. With that software included in the cost of Western Digital and Seagate drives that makes this drive a no-go for people that need to clone. So advanced users that need to have cloning software to migrate their data from their old drive to their new drive and don't want to buy acronis true image should look at getting a Seagate or Western Digital.I am frightened about the longevity of the drive due to the grinding noise it makes. I regularly back up my data and have made a system image in Windows 7 to allow me to restore my laptop to a new drive it I need to.I was hoping for the same experience I had when I upgraded my last laptop to a 7200 RPM drive from a 5400 RPM drive. The performance increased and the Windows score increased. With this HGST any increases were so small that I cannot recognize them and Windows 7 cannot either.
summary: Noise on power down cycle and no software support.

reviewText: Whoever came up with this saved my life. This product (i could have made myself) is convenient and works flawlessly.

There are some incredibly detailed and helpful reviews of this keyboard, so I will stick to how I am using the review sample that I received, and a few of my impressions.First, this is not a bluetooth device (it was described as such to me when I was asked to review it.) The only weak point is the documentation, which is terse, but well illustrated. Had it contained specs and compatibility data it would have been significantly more useful. However, this is not a major flaw.I first tested it with an ancient ThinkPad T61 running Windows XP. It was immediately recognized and functional. My next test was to see if it would work with my Samsung Galaxy Note 3 phone running Android 4.4.2. I connected with wireless dongle via aMicro USB OTG Host Cable to USB 2.0 Adapterand it worked. To be honest, that arrangement is a bit on the clumsy side for me.My final test and where this keyboard shines is when I connected it to myKeedox Quad Core RK3188 Android 4.2 Smart TV BOXrunning Android 4.2. This keyboard made a lot of sense connected to that box because I rarely used it prior. I was using a corded keyboard and it was a trip hazard. Plus most of in interaction with it included few keystrokes, so this mini keyboard is perfect. In fact I find myself using the TV box a lot more frequently now that I have this keyboard. I think of it as a smart remote control - which it is - and have quickly grown to love it.As for prolonged typing, this would not be my favorite solution. However, that is subjective. I hated my Blackerry when I was required to carry one back in my consulting days too. But for occasional use this is wonderful.Bottom line: I would have never guessed that this would be the missing link between me and my TV box. Had I only tested this with phones and tablets I would have probably written a single word review: meh. Now, though, I see the wow factor.
I have not had to use this protection plan as of yet, thank God! But expect it to be just what it claims to be since it's promoted by Amazon whom I trust implicitly.  Let's hope I'm right here too...

This is a good keyboard and is affordable, but is not in the same class as a Max Keyboard Nighthawk X8.  Get the Nighthawk X8 if you can afford it and if (and this is a BIG IF) you can FIND one.  Otherwise, this is a good illuminated keyboard.
summary: This is a good keyboard and is affordable, but is not in the same class as a Max Keyboard Nighthawk X8 . . .

reviewText: This mouse is continually plagued by issues with their mouse click switches. It is a very common problem with the Omiron mouse switches that are used in this mouse. The symptom is a click and hold on the mouse doesn't register. You will be able to click, but the hold won't stay. So, for instance, when playing a First Person Shooter, you will try to right click to bring up your scope and it won't bring it up. It will act like it is, then will just return right to hip fire, even when holding down the scope mouse button.Don't get this mouse, it is plagued by bad internals. I would recommend using a newer version or different model that doesn't use Omiron switches. Do some homework before buying, I wish I had.

I set it up following direction and the reception was definitely improved and would have been a great addition.  Unfortunately, the person on the end could not hear well and it kept dropping out.  I think the signal coming in got amplified but the out going signal was no better than your cell phone and worse than my S3.  I returned the unit.  Amazon was very good about the return.
summary: Receives well but transmission is worse than my S3

reviewText: With the installation of this signal booster, we went from "No service" at my desk to 5 bars! We even have 3 bars in the basement, 1 floor below. On the 2nd floor above we have 5 bars as well. Previously we had 1-2 bars outside on the deck but not enough to make a call.  The outside antenna was mounted on a 30 ft mast.  We did not use the mini coax cable that comes with the unit but instead used quad shielded coax, partly because we have experienced interference in the past on other coax installations and we needed to install a lightning arrester because of the tall mast. The interior antenna is installed 6' above the floor in a central location in the office. We have a 24' vertical separation from the outdoor antenna. We are on US Cellular, but others with Verizon and T-mobile have used it as well. The only one that did not get service had a Sprint Boost phone, but she indicated she was not able to get service anywhere on our side of the state. We have not had anyone with AT&T; here to try it yet.At this point I would recommend this to anyone who has a little bit of service outside. If you have no service outside, don't expect it to be able to boost a signal that does not exist.

I installed this and had marginal improvement in signal. I called technical support and was not able to get any improvement. It does not even cover two rooms in my home. If you are withing 6 feet, it helps. It is not worth the cost. It definitely does not cover 2,500 sq. ft. here.

I love the way it looks and how it feels when using it.  I do not however like the compatibility issues with windows 8.  I have to manually start the software for the control each time I reboot.  It works but, not seamless.  I am sure if I added it to my startup programs it would work better but, how does it not come with that functionality?

reviewText: I bought this fan to sit on top of an Anker USB hub to cool my dual external RAID hard drives that sit in a Star Tech base.  The bare drives plug into the Star Tech base like slices of toast, and they are only cooled by ambient air as the unit has no fan.  With the little USB fan, I get plenty of air moving over the drives to keep them very cool.The fan is not very noisy, you can't possibly hurt yourself on the little plastic blades (although it did give the cat a fit once or twice).  You can easily stop the fan with your fingers.  There was a bit of vibration going to the desktop from the fan that were transmitted down through the USB hub, so I set the USB hub on a few small pieces of foam and stopped that problem.I have no idea how long this fan will last.  It has been in constant use (24/7) for a little over 6 weeks now and no problems to date.  Even if this fan dies after a year, for the price I'm willing to keep replacing it.''I did note that the fan stem doesn't like to bend and stay that way.  It kept trying to straighten up.  In my application there is no bend so this isn't a problem.

I know that there are a lot of positive reviews for this thing, that is why I purchased it in the beginning. I personally hated it. The speed of the fan is fine, it works. The problem I had is that it just would not stay in the positions I would place it in. The way the loom around the cable is wrapped/constructed, it constantly wants to twist and pull downward. Therefore I could not get the orientation to stabilized due to vibration under load. I tried several rigs to stiffen the loom so that it would remain in place - all to no avail.Remember, this will be plugged into a USB port (duh) and the orientation of that port will play a huge part in how you will be able to position this fan - a vertical or horizontally oriented USB port will great affect the final position the fan will be able to be placed in.And finally there is no guard around the fan and when it eventually falls out of position it will rub against something. I needed this for cooling ASIC chips and over long periods the fan would gradually fall over and end up bashing into something.Just not a well designed product - I imagine that the good reviews are based on very specific and "lucky" applications.Please see my review of the Thermaltake Mobile Fan II External USB which I really, really like and ended up purchasing. It is a great external USB fan and I can't imagine why it would not be great for most applications.

This is the Swiss-Army Knife of Pentax lenses.  When you can't bring the whole toolbox, this one you want.It can do almost anything well - or at least, well enough for the person who is only bringing along one camera body.  It has the greatest zoom range of any weather-resistant lens by Pentax, so when don't want to miss a shot, but don't want to ruin your camera by changing WR lenses in the kinds of weather that necessitates them - this is the lens to have.It's not a "macro" lens, but with it on my old K-5 I have taken shots of a fly so clear I can see the hairs on its back.It's not a "super" zoom with 15x, but it IS a true WR lens, with seals where they make a difference.  I have taken shots in the snow - as it came down.  I have taken shots in the spray of water.  It can take wide angle shots and then zoom in 7.5x and get a close-up.The "softness" in the corners is primarily at the longest end of the zoom range, so I use the normal-wide settings for landscapes, and that works perfectly.But if you're taking a people-picture, when you zoom in it is still very sharp in the center where the person's face will be - and so the "softness" in the corners is like a lovely bokeh treatment of a large aperture (expensive) lens.  And if I'm using it instead of a 200mm lens to capture something far away, I'm going to crop out the corners anyway and keep the sharp center portion.The focus is reasonably quick and delightfully quiet.  The build is quite solid, yet light.If you take photos at the beach, in the snow, in the damp, where the wind is kicking up dust and debris, water is dripping or children knocking over large tumblers of sugary beverage next to your camera gear - this is your lens, especially if you want to take landscapes, portraits, zooms and macros all with the same lens.  There will be times you are very glad you brought this one along instead of a bag full of the expensive, Limited-use limited lenses to ruin in the weather.

reviewText: Whew!  After a crash course in IP addresses, MAC's, SSID's, routers, WPS, and a lot of cursing and head slapping, I think I have my five camera home security system up and running.Initially bought three of the DCS-931L's, then accidentally bought two of the older DCS-930L's. They are for all intents and purposes the same in functionality, though I initially found the 931L's software easier to use. Stick with 931's.At first I had pretty good luck setting these cameras up with my old Buffalo Tech router. You hard wire them first, run the setup wizard (which you have to download as a zip file and is not real easy to get going), then you can WPS the cameras wirelessly. Move them and install anyplace. Range is surprisingly good.The MyDlink was ok to work with. This is the online portal to your cameras. The smartphone app counterpart was pretty good at sending me notifications of movement--at first. Then, suddenly, I started losing feeds from the cameras.  Pretty soon every one was dead. Must have uninstalled and reinstalled them a dozen times. And then I lost home WIFI. So, I assumed it was a bad router.  What luck.  So, I ordered a D-Link 855 model, more than anything because of "zero configuration" with their cameras.Installed the new router and everything seemed fine.  Then the same thing started happening. I could wirelessly configure the cameras straight from the router, but the IP addresses of the cameras were being assigned to other devices, and this caused all sorts of problems.  I kept uninstalling and reinstalling, trying to reserve IP addresses in the router...  Then I'd get them working only to find them slowly dropping out again. It seems to help to reserve the IP addresses of your other devices first, then install the cameras.I finally came to the conclusion that the way to install them is first to wirelessly WPS them from the router to the camera. Then I'd go into D-ViewCam (this is their proprietary PC program you use to record motion to your drive as evidence of trespass or burglary). In D-ViewCam I would manually "insert" the camera in the settings area using the IP address assigned by the router. Then I'd hop over to MyDlink and find the camera via "zero config" and set it up there online. That seemed to eliminate lost feeds, and for several days it has run with no problem. Most of the time the software couldn't "find" the camera during a scan, so I opted to key them in manually. It's easy. On a few of the cameras they still would not "connect". But if I walked away for a few hours, bingo!  It was as if it just took some time for the software to recognize them. One other thing, you need D-ViewCam to change the camera resolutions. I could not do this in MyDlink.There are a few quirks still.  MyDlink app has stopped giving me motion alerts. I can define areas of the feed to detect motion in D-ViewCam, but no longer in MyDlink web. It just shows a black screen. It will let you define a zone, but since you can't see what the image is it is of little use. I think this is why I'm not getting alerts via the app.  I don't know what happened and am looking into this. But the D-ViewCam does record motion to my hard drive. By the way, I am using a USB external drive hidden in the basement in case someone steals my computer!Anyway, to sum up, the cameras do work.  Picture quality is good enough to make out faces and cars coming up the drive.  I can keep an eye on the dogs quite easily using the smartphone app, though the latter does require a good strong fast connection. Otherwise, it just times out. I really like the D-Link routers.  Coming from years of the Buffalo Tech, they are much easier to configure with their outstanding web based portal. Five stars there. And setting up the cameras is nice because you don't have to use the MyDlink software, which I found buggy and hard to install, or a LAN cable.I have two cameras inside, three outside under the eaves, and one out in my carport. I have the repeaters on the 931's active, but even when they are off the range to other cameras straight from the router is good (about three walls, one brick, and 70 feet total). I plan on adding more cameras, including the IR versions for dark areas. So far the cameras have held up outside in below freezing temps and high humidity. They stand out like a sore thumb, but I figure if they get stolen it's too late. The video has already been captured. Because of this and their relative low cost, I have not taken measures to hide them. Hell, I want the thieves to put their faces in them so I get a close view!It has been a frustrating two weeks messing with these buggers. But once I got the flow down, I am happy.
summary: Steep learning curve but so far they work.....

reviewText: First, let's dispense with the hyperbole.  You're not going to set one of these on the floor next to your B&W; 801s, turn it on and walk away, and not be able to tell the difference between the two.  It's about as loud as you could expect a product with this size box to be, and it's actually pretty easy to bottom out the low end at high volumes.  But these are laws of physics.The product is simply outstanding as a tool to listen to music at a desk, at low to medium volume, when it is in front of you and pointing right at you.  In this situation the stereo imaging is spectacular and the depth of field really does sound like it's coming from somewhere other than this little speaker - especially with the "LiveAudio" feature activated, which has to be the only onboard "surround simulation" EQ I've ever tried and actually left on.The Jawbone's convenience can't be denied.  You can carry it around the house, pair it with anything, toss it in a small suitcase before a weekend in the mountains or a business trip, any of that.  That's not really a differentiator from any other small bluetooth speaker, but it's no less true.The speaker's high end is pretty directional.  You lose a lot of it very fast if you move away from a direct line of fire from the speaker.On the whole, this product plus an iPhone is about 50 times better than the "jamboxes" I carried around in the 80s, that had to weigh 30 pounds if they were to sound any good.  The problem is that Lloyd Dobler wouldn't look very romantic holding one of these over his head.
summary: Great, but buy it for sound quality and not volume

My kids love earphones, and have loved them since the creation of the 6th generation iPod in 2007. Unfortunately, they don't like the ones provided by Apple, as they are a cheaply made plastic, but they like the style of earphones directly in your ears. Fortunately, Brainwavz has made the Brainwavz M2 In-Ear Headphones as a mid price ranged earphones that have a good sound without absolutely breaking the bank.Package Contents:* M2 Earphones* Hard Carrying Case* 1 Set Comply Foam Tips S-Series* 6 Sets Silicone Ear Tips (S, M, L)* 1 Set Silicone Bi-Flange Tips* 1 shirt Clip* Instruction Manual & Warranty Card (12 months warranty)Accessories:As other Brainwavz products, these earphones get several accessories that many other earphone brands wouldn't get. The contents come in a very well made hard carrying case, with two pockets, that will protect the earphones and accessories, as long as the damage isn't intentional, such as running your vehicle over it. The silicone tips have a blue, green, peach, or black interior and black silicon exterior. I like that this includes several different colored and sized eartips that will work well with any ear size. This also includes one medium set of Bi-flange tips, that get optiminal in-ear sound, and foam eartips that tend to become damaged when removing them. This also includes a shirt clip that connects to the earphones past the Y connector. I love that Brainwavz includes every accessory that you would typically need for a standard set of earphones.Specifications:Drivers: Dynamic, 10.7mmRatd Impedance: 20 OhmsFrequency Range: 20 Hz ~ 20 kHzSensitivity: 115 dB at 1 mWRated Input Power: 10 mWCable: 1.3 m Y-cord; Silver-platedPlug: 3.5mm, gold-platedHardware:The entire length of the earphone wire is 50 inches long. At the base is a gold plated connector that is enclosed by a hard plastic at a 125 degree angle. I would normally name this a con, as this is a common feature from Brainwavz products that I dislike, but the casing seems durable enough to withstand some accidental tugging from my kids. From the connector, the wire, a unique rope-like texture, is 35 inches to the Y connector. I really like the texture of the wire, as it seems extremely durable compared to standard headphone wires, despite being so thin.  The wire from the hard plastic enclosed Y connector, a little thinner gauged wire, is approximately 14 inches. The earphones, themselves, have a metal-like casing, with eartips that go straight out. I am a big fan of earphones that go directly into the ear, as setup is simple compared to over-the-ear headphones, and the earphones almost are never heavy and bulky.Testing:I tested these earphones for approximately 8-10 hours on and off. During my tests I felt no irritation or discomfort. The silicon tips are very comfortable, as if I wasn't wearing any earphones at all. I heard different genres of music, including but not limited to: Rock, Classic Rock, Alternative, Pop, Rap, Classical, and Country. The sound is very clear without any distortion, and the bass is definitely good for low, mid, and high, but not the greatest. I find that theBrainwavz S1 In Ear HeadphonesandBrainwavz R3 Dual Dynamic Driver Earphoneshave an overall better quality bass, but those headphones are much more expensive, bulky, and are over-the-ear styled, which is very uncomfortable in my opinion. Overall, I am extremely satisfied with this product. I would definitely purchase this for my kids as a present.Final Thoughts:These headphones are probably geared best toward either young audiophiles, which tend to be more rough with electronics, and aren't difficult to replace, or audiophiles on a budget without breaking the bank. I would definitely recommend this product and is why I give this a rating of 5 out of 5 stars. The sound and bass are good enough to listen to good music and have a good time.Pros:+ Price is ideal without completely breaking the bank. Great present for kids.+ Very clear sound without any distortions; Good bass, but not great. (See cons)+ A direct to ear styled earphones with a unique rope textured (and durable) wire.+ Several accessories included; Headphone case and several ear tips+ A 50 inch cord that stretches nicely from my desktop.Cons:- Although the bass is good, Brainwavz S1 and R3 headphones have significantly better sound and bass, but are more expensive, bulky, and around-the-ear styled.I was provided a sample in exchange for a thorough and honest review.
summary: A budget friendly set of earphones that is a great present for kids! Great clarity and good bass.

reviewText: My kids love music, and have used earphones since I can remember. This is problematic though, as I’m always having to “let them borrow” mine. Thankfully, I can consider buying one of Brainwavz Alpha In Ear Headphones as a replacement for their lost earphones.▶ Package Contents• Alpha Earphones• Hard Carrying Case• 1 Set Comply Foam Tips S-Series• 6 Sets Silicone Ear Tips (S, M, L)• 1 Set Silicone Bi-Flange Tips• 1 shirt Clip• Instruction Manual & Warranty Card (12 months warranty)▶ AccessoriesAs other Brainwavz products, these earphones get several accessories that many other earphone brands wouldn’t get. The contents come in a very well made hard carrying case, with two pockets, that will protect the earphones and accessories, as long as the damage isn’t intentional, such as running your vehicle over it. The silicone tips have a blue, green, peach, or black interior and black silicon exterior. I like that this includes several different colored and sized eartips that will work well with any ear size. This also includes one medium set of Bi-flange tips, that get optiminal in-ear sound, and foam eartips that tend to become damaged when removing them. This also includes a shirt clip that connects to the earphones past the Y connector. I love that Brainwavz includes every accessory that you would typically need for a standard set of earphones.▶ Specifications• Drivers: Dynamic, 10.7mm• Rated Impedance: 20 Ohms• Frequency Range: 20 Hz ~ 20 kHz• Sensitivity: 115 dB at 1 mW• Rated Input Power: 10 mW• Cable: 1.3 m Y-cord; Silver-plated• Plug: 3.5mm, gold-plated▶ HardwareThe entire length of the earphone wire is 50.5 inches long. At the base is a gold plated connector, with pink rings, that is enclosed by a hard plastic at a 125 degree angle. I would normally name this a con, as this is a common feature from Brainwavz products that I dislike, but the casing seems durable enough to withstand some accidental tugging from my kids. From the connector, the wire, a unique rope-like texture, is 35 inches to the Y connector. I really like the texture of the wire, as it seems extremely durable compared to standard headphone wires, despite being so thin.  The wire from the hard plastic enclosed Y connector, a little thinner gauged wire, is approximately 14 inches. The earphones, themselves, have a cheap plastic and rubber casing, with eartips that go straight out. I am a big fan of earphones that go directly into the ear, as setup is simple compared to over-the-ear headphones, and the earphones almost are never heavy and bulky. These headphones are very similar to the M2 and M3 headphones in terms of size, length, and construction, but differ in the casing of the earphones. You will get better acoustics with aluminum or metal casing, than a plastic one.▶ TestingI tested these headphones for approximately 3 days, or 7 hours of complete listening time, with both my Nexus 7 and my Windows 7 x64 custom built CyberPower PC. I used different genres to properly gauge the quality of the earphones including: rap, country, pop, rock, classic and rock. If you are used to the Brainwavz M2 or M3 earphones, you will notice the significant difference in quality, as their aluminum housing provides better acoustics, though the overall sound quality and bass of the Brainwavz Alpha is still much better than your standard $20 earphones. If the sound quality doesn’t entice you to purchase the headphones, then the comfortable fit will. During my extended tests, I felt no irritation from the ear tips. I was overall satisfied with the fit, build, and acoustics of the device.▶ Final ThoughtsFor the quality, comfort, and included accessories, you aren’t going to find a better set of earphones. I not only recommend, but also find this the best option for the sub $20 mark, which makes this the perfect stocking stuffer, and is why I give this a 5 star rating. I honestly don’t understand how Brainwavz is making any profit for this device when the case, itself, is $10 separately; it includes several accessories and tips, and has a rope-like wire. You are getting a really good value when you are purchasing this device.Pros:+ Great value for included hard case ($10 when sold separately), silicon tips, and accessories. Great present for your kids.+ Very clear sound and OK bass without any dissertations. For $20, quality is superior to any other earphone at this price range.+ Direct to ear styled earphones with a unique rope textured (and durable) wire.Cons:- Foam tips may become damaged if you take them off.I was provided a sample in exchange for a thorough and honest review.
summary: Great bass and sound quality. Best headphones you can buy under $40.

reviewText: Solid power for an older machine that isn't running a crazy GPU, I use mine in an old Phenom X4 with a GeForce 9850 and it hums right along.
summary: Antec VP-450 450 Watt Energy Star Certified Power Supply

reviewText: Canon EOS Rebel T3 is an entry-level DSLR camera. More 'DSLR' than 'entry level'. Let me use my usual disclaimer, and admit that with so many good cameras around, it is more about what mix of traits or features you are looking for.On that note, the camera's trait mix is as follows. It is a DSLR with 12.2 resolution (megapixels). Probably the most important point for this class of cameras is the sensor size, which is APS-C. That's just one step below 35mm Full frame.It has an optical viewfinder, which works through a pentaprism. That is the classical SLR construction. You are using the properties of light to view the subject before and during the shot. The purists would argue this is the way it was supposed to be- that is, with minimal electronic intervention. The ISO rating is 6,400 which makes it work better in low light. This rating is below many other DSLRs, but you would hardly ever need a higher ISO. Really. The video is a HD- that is 1080x720 resolution. The camera gives you the option to control the exposure  manually. It does have an external flash option. You would need that for portraits, at least. The LCD screen is a slightly smaller 2.7 inch with 230,000 resolution. The sustainable burst rate- for fast action- is 3 frames per second. The camera also does RAW processing which is useful if you did not want to be limited by JPEG storage only. The camera body weighs 495 grams, which is light compared to DSLRs.The T3 lacks a self-cleaning sensor unit for dust. For all interchangeable lens cameras, dust removal has become an issue, because you only need a speck to spoil the picture. And unless you remove it, it tends to stay inside.A nice camera, but somewhat dated when it comes to some traits.
summary: Nice camera. Moving up in price gets better $value$

I know, I know, this is meant to be used on a tablet, most likely.  But I wanted a keyboard for my Moto X, since it supports HID bluetooth.  So here it is.  The function keys, I feel, are very smartly set up.  You have your volume keys, quick launch keys, forward/back and home keys.  You even have some keys that aren't normally in Android, but can still be used, such as the CTRL and ALT keys.  I use it to take notes in my Mobisle Notes program, and even to play my C64 emulator.  The reaction time on it is pretty good and actually makes emulators usable, more so than just relying on the touch-based screen controllers.As for the feel, it feels much like the bluetooth iMac keyboard.  In fact, it will work with a Mac or PC, so long as it's bluetooth compatible, except the keys don't include the Windows or Mac special keys.It has those nice smooth chicklet type keys.  The keyboard is almost precisely the same size as my iMac wireless keyboard, and almost the same layout, too.  The keys are smooth to the touch, with just enough texture to feel satisfying and substantial when you type.  Just the right amount of resistance.When I use mine, I occasionally am playing music with a worship group, and when I'm done playing, I'll just tip my music stand back a little, and put my keyboard up on the bottom of the stand, propping my cell phone up on top of it.  Works great, and is almost as good for such purposes as would be a laptop.  But it's also pretty much future proof, too, because when I do get a tablet, I can use this for full-blown office apps, rather than using some corny screen keyboard.Thanks Motorola, for a great add-on!
summary: Great!  Easy to use and works like a champ on Moto X

I really enjoy this radio and all the features it has.  I have an aftermarket antenna (Diamond SRH77CA) to help get a little more distance and clarity from some of the further out repeaters.  The radio looks small in the pictures and it is a bit of a small radio compared to my other radio.  It is almost wallet sized.  I found that after reading the manual while toying with it at the same time helps to learn this radio quicker.  I do not use the short cuts since there are so many for what this radio can do.  It is not too bad to use after that and is quite easy to use.  The stock battery that comes with the radio is only good for about 5 hours of use like the others have said.  I have the 1800mAh and it extends the operations time significantly.  The programming software will not work on Mac computers.  I recommend buying the MH-74 remote speaker/mic since that speaker is quite a bit louder than the one in the radio and the belt clips on the batteries are fixed and do not release your belt very easy.  If you use APRS like I do sometimes, you will only need the adapters on the radio if you do not plan to use the MH-74 remote speaker/mic.  The speaker mic has the ability to put the GPS antenna in the top of the speaker/mic.  Other than that, I really enjoy this radio and its ease of use.  I really love all the vast functions and features it has.  Highly recommended.

This power supply is definitely not a 550W power supply. It'll shut down on you at around 400W-450W draw. I bought this power supply when I upgraded my video card to a GTX 660TI, which requires a minimum of a 450W power supply. So I put the new graphics card in my computer, installed the new power supply, and of course I was eager to game. While I was playing Borderlands 2, the computer shut down. At first I Thought maybe it was a driver issue, so I made sure my NVidia drivers were up to date, checked my system log for any reported crashes (None), and when back to try it again. About 2 minutes after starting the game the machine would shut down.Then I started to consider the possibility that it was the power supply. So I decided to hook up my multi meter between the computer and the wall socket and measure the amperage the power supply was drawing when it shuts down. I watched the multimeter closely and as the game starts to have more complicated stuff on screen, the amperage draw goes up (My outlet puts out around 120VAC), and at 3.7A the machine would shut itself down, which is about 440W draw. So I went to local computer parts retailer and bought a new power supply to replace this one (This time a name brand and a more heft wattage), did the same experiment with the new supply, and the machine would not shut down.This power supply does not live up to the specs advertised. Although I was happy with the number of connectors and the variety of types it had, I was completely dissatisfied with the power supply. I gave it an additional star because size-wise it's fairly compact compared to some other "550W" supplies I've used in other machines, and because of the variety of connectors. Other than that I can't recommend it to anyone.

Bought these for hunting.  Seemed to work alright at first.  Powered up fine.  However; after a quick 'Hello' the battery started flashing.  No problem.  Went and bought brand new batteries.  Swapped them all out and tried again.  Immediately after hitting the transmit button, the battery was blinking again and would not transmit. Tried new batteries from another package and had the same problem.  It's hard to believe these things and drive through the batteries with one transmit of less than 5 seconds, but that's what the radio is telling me.  I tried to email tech support on the issue and they came back a few days later and told me to make sure I was recharging the batteries a full 24 hours.  That's after I told them exactly what I wrote here.  I guess you get what you pay for - both from a product stance and a support stance.

reviewText: I would have given this drive 5 stars, if it weren't for the poorly fitting cable others have complained about.  It's not on the drive side, it's on the computer USB side (and yes... it's the same on various computers).  This causes the user to have to disconnect and reconnect the cable several times until getting a connection.  Then don't even touch the drive or you could loose the connection once again (which is VERY frustrating half way thought a backup).  Does knocking off 2 starts because of this seem harsh?  Not really.  It's a well documented problem that the manufacturer could solve so easily, yet continues to be such a source of frustration for the end user.  Do yourself a favor... if you buy this drive, pick up a replacement cable for an extra $7.00 to $10.00.  Otherwise, you'll be frustrated.  Oh and yes... I borrowed a cable from another USB 3.0 drive, and it solved all connection problems.
summary: Add a replacement USB cable to your purchase

reviewText: I'm a network engineer by trade and have for many years always recommend buying Linksys products because of the quality and reliability they offered the home user.  The Linksys E2500 has without a doubt changed every opinion I've ever had.  I've owned the router for nearly 2 years now and I can assure you that this is the worst preforming router you could possibly own.  The range is absolutely horrific. If you live in anything larger than a mobile home the signal will not reach to where you want it to be.  In the rare occasion that you do have wifi coverage you will be treated to fantastically slow data transfer speeds that will have you fondly remembering the days of token ring networking (i.e. it's very very slow).It's likely that some of the issue this piece of junk have could be fixed by Linksys (Cisco) taking time to update the software.  Not that they would do that... I just checked and they haven't updated it (v2) in nearly 2 years.  Way to stand behind your hardware Linksys.In conclusion it's a horrible, cheaply made router that will leave you frustrated and wishing you had bought something decent.
summary: Terrible product from a company that used to be respected.

reviewText: Love the Playbook! The quality is amazing and I think RIM made a mistake in getting out of the tablet business.  There are plenty of good free apps at Blackberry App World but I also have every Android App I could want loaded on it. They are very easy to side-load. It has complete web capability and FLASH. The browser it comes with is good but download the Origami browser from AppWorld for an even better one. It does just about anything my laptop can do but is so much more portable, and the screen size is perfect. It does everything I need.  Facebook, Twitter, Kindle, GPS, YouTube, Instagram, radio, MP3s, videos, games, documents, calendars, planners, etc. The sound & video quality is awesome and I have all my mp3s & videos loaded on it. The front and rear facing cameras work great and there are free apps available for photo editing. It takes great videos, too. It does everything a $350+ tablet does but only costs half the price. Get 64GB, you won't regret it.
summary: This is a lot of machine for a small price

reviewText: This processor took my sound system from okay to incredible.It allows you to fine tune every aspect of your sound system. I have each individual speaker in my car attenuated, filtered, and time aligned. After I finished my initial setup and tune it sounded like a whole new system. This $450+ piece of equipment makes it sound like I have an extra $1,000 worth of equipment.The external dual knob control is one of my favorite features. I adjust the subwoofer volume depending on the song and this makes it a breeze. Also, having four different tunes avaiable at the press of a button is a life saver. My only qualm is that sometimes the knobs can be unresponsive. A couple turns of either knob gets it working again though.The software is great and tuning process is straightforward. You can do an inital tune in just a few hours. It's also easy to install.4/5 stars because of the issue with the knob and that fact that I need a Windows laptop to make adjustments.
summary: The most important piece of equipment in my vehicle.

reviewText: I am honestly shocked - shocked - at the difference between the average rating and what this product deserves!  The "star-writing-mills" must truly be in full swing!  So many minor defects that I have to give this a "ONE".a) no instructions, no manual, no "helpful hints card"b) not as advertised:  does not come in a cardboard envelope, but rather a syran-plastic like envelopec) not as advertised:  does not come with a "push card" (one of those light plastic rectangles, like a credit card) that help push the cover flat and get rid of bubble:  instead it comes with a rectangle of thin-film blue plastic, like the stuff that comes on new dishwasher to protect the metal finish - you could NOT use this to apply pressure, so I had to use my fingers (I thought an actual credit card would be TOO rough)d) not as advertised:  the small square of "polishing cloth" is about 2" x 2" - not useful for anything unless you're the size of a hamster!  I have a half dozen of these I've gotten for FREE at an eyeglass/sunglass store.e) I had to use BOTH of the 2 covers included because the first one had dozens of bubbles (and I'm a bit of a pro at installing these)f) I finally got the 2nd installed with only 4 bubbles, but it actually has a series of FINE SCRATCHES right in the middle (livable, but annoying).g) both covers came with 5-7  little round plastic shreds stuck to them, from the milling process where they cut out the small hole at the top for the camera and the larger hole at the bottom for the function button.  These left-over milling shreds were as sticky as the cover (think about it: 2 protection layers +the actual cover = 3 layers x 2 holes = 6 shreds per cover) and they kept re-appearing and getting stuck under the cover as I was installing it!!!And finally, and WORST OF ALL:  These DON'T COVER THE WHOLE iPad!!!  They leave 1/4" - 3/8" on each of the long sides UNprotected!!Buy at your own peril!!
summary: Where are all the FIVE STARS coming from?

reviewText: I bought these headphones from Amazon for $31, so my plan was to use them for beaters.Function: These headphones sound pretty darn good, with some EQ tweaking, these have rock solid bass that vibrates your head satisfactorily(I'm not an audiophile; I like my bass). The mids and highs aren't exactly super, but they're clear enough to not warrant any undue focus or attention to them. These sound better than Beats Solo HD which I bought for my sister.Fit: This is where these headphones fall flat. There is a extremely odd shaped fit on the ear cups that seems slightly too small to be comfortable. I'm a pretty average sized man, 5'9" 150lb, but these feel like they were made for teenagers (which they probably are). Kind of on that note, I had mentioned I wanted to use these for beaters, but quickly found that not only the physical fit didn't work, the personality fit didn't either. See the following section about "Form."Form: I am a 25 yr. male professional who works as a medical engineer, so these phones are definitely juvenile and pre-pubescent for someone like me. It's not necessarily the age, but the fact that I'm in a fast paced high tech industry that doesn't exactly tolerate fledgling types. So these cans don't exactly project the image I want. Aside from that, these have a hardy plastic body that glistens very attractively, but also attracts fingerprints like glass. The color scheme is nice, but pretty loud branding; this is probably what pushed it over the fence as far as juvenille for me. The way these headphones fold is using these puzzle fit latches; you have to literally break the mated sections from each other in order to fold. This is nerve wracking every time as it always feels like you're going to break the headphones.The fact that these physically and mentally didn't fit me, I have just had them sitting on my shelf brand new never used. I am now selling them, but for $31 I guess it is just a cheap lesson learned. Do not buy these at retail, and if you do, make sure they will fit your style.
summary: Mediocre on ear phones that will give you pleasant sound, but only buy if it is on sale.

This product will definitely get you there.  It costs much less than the Garmin nuvi 350 that cost  me $278 six years ago.  The LCD display is much better, high resolution and helpful at showing the correct path at complex interchanges. And it  includes free map updates.But the navigation is noticeably inferior to the Garmin nuvi 350, or the TomTom XXL 540TM that I  bought 4 years  ago.The way I judge efficiency of a  GPS is by asking it to navigate local roads that I know  very well, to see whether it comes up with the most efficient route.  This GPS does poorly  with this.  For example, when I asked it to take me from my home to a destination seven miles away,  and I started taking some back roads, it kept telling me to revert to my original route, even  though this would have been substantially slower.  In other words, if you deviate from the original route, it just tells you to go back to that route, rather than recalculating and finding the most efficient route from your current position.Another way of judging a navigator is how well it predicts travel time. In this respect this GPS  is seriously deficient.  For example, on a recent journey late at night with very light traffic  and no obstructions, it started out predicting 19 minutes and ultimately the journey took 26  minutes, even though I was exceeding the speed limit most of the time and there were no holdups.  This is what it usually does.  My 6 year old GPS, on the other hand, is usually within a minute or  two for short trips, and within 3 or 4 minutes for longer journeys in excess of 50 miles.  If you are like me, and phone  ahead if I am going to be late for an important appointment, this is a real defect.So, I am giving this product 3 stars, because it is significantly worse at navigating than older  navigators that I own, even though it will get you there eventually.I bought this product  because my nuvi 350 maps are increasingly out of date. But I am returning this product and looking  for a GPS that is good at recalculating efficiently if I take a wrong turn or deliberately deviate from the initially chosen route.

reviewText: It is great having the 2 usb plugs and the standard wall socket. It also stores nice and easily anywhere!

However, I will say i'll never order any other type of HD, unless i'm i'm building a cheap RAID rack for a small server or desktop, and only the because at wholesale and in bulk their about 50% of the cost. But, remember the old adage: YOU GET WHAT YOU PAY FOR!

I was looking for a storage drive with a large capacity and somewhat reliable where I wasn't going to loose my data after a few years of use which is exactly what happened with my old WD drive. I have always trusted Seagate and will never buy another WD hard drive. This drive is fast and reliable, I have been using it nonstop for the past year or so and has performed perfectly.

I have synology's 8 drive NAS and 8 of these drives.  In the 2 years I've had this, I've just had my 2nd HD failure.  Rebuilds so far have been not an issue, but since it appears these drives are failing on a 1-2 year usage, I've now switched my last failed drive to WD RED.  Not really sure if there's a difference, but it's suppose to be more NAS friendly.  It was $25 more, but for something that's housing all my media files, it's really nothing.  I'm replacing the failed 3 GB drive with the 4 GB WD RED.  http://www.amazon.com/Western-Digital-WD40EFRX-Cache-Drive/dp/B00EHBERSE/ref=pd_sim_pc_3?ie=UTF8&refRID=0M1JKQ42WWBC1SDRH1P3  Not really happy that the drives have lasted less than a year each. This GPS feels like a piece of outdated and crude electronics from the mid-1980's.  It is slow to respond, slow to process, slow to do anything.  The screen resolution and its ambiance resemble cheap kids electronic toys.  Sometimes it takes multiple taps for the touch screen to register and get on with it.  The LCD display quality seems to be old tech passive matrix.  My 2002 Lexus RX300's navigation system works much better and runs faster than this (yes, 2002.)  Even the old Magellan that we bought 5 years worked better than this.  Not sure why so many others give this unit such a high mark.It is also not very intuitive.  It took us 20 minutes to figure out how to turn down the stupid clicking sound, and we are both computer savvy.  And it took 2 hours to pinpoint our location for the first time, even though we put it on the deck with wide open view to the sky (no trees, no clouds.)Yes, it will get my wife from point A to point B, but it's frustrating to use.  It's 2014, we demand better.
