This wireless keyboard is compatible with Windows, Mac, and now Chrome. Smaller than a standard keyboard, with a track pad where the 10-key number pad would normally be, it's great for resting on my lap while lounging in front of the TV or on the coffee table top. The keys are smaller, more like a laptop keyboard. Great battery life. Note: the special function keys apparently are labeled for Windows, however the volume/mute, home, play/pause & search keys work with Chrome.
I've been using this at work to connect two computers to the same printer, and it's been working great.  The selector buttons light up to let you know what channel is selected.

The mouse worked so well on my laptop that I bought a second one for another Laptop.  Putting the batteries in the mouse was a little different because they insert at a angle,  but it wasn't a big deal.  The mouse has a good natural feel to it and works better than a lot of name brands that I have owned that cost more.

Lately, I've been buying more and more AmazonBasics products because they are definitely worth the price. It was time to upgrade my old wireless mouse since I was tired of its weight. The old mouse used two AA batteries and it had a large hump which didn't make it too fun to use. After browsing a bit it came down to two mice. This AmazonBasics mouse or the slightly more expensive name brand mouse. What made me decide to go towards this one was the amount of reviews and ratings compared to the name brand. The price sealed the deal.The size is perfect and cups in the inside of my hand just right. It feels slightly larger than a laptop mouse. It's a little lighter than my old mouse. The wireless reception is fantastic. The PC tower sits below the desk. Just now, I reached back about six feet and the mouse is still very responsive. The on/off switch is a big plus. The light rubber feel on the top is very comfortable. The clicks are very quiet and very responsive. I would recommend this mouse to everyone.
summary: Perfect size, great quality, and cheap!

reviewText: Like other comments on these cameras, mine arrived with a malfunction. It will not charge and does not work at all.

I originally was thinking just get a phone with a really good player since its about streaming music online these days.  However, it always takes forever for the phone to boot up unless you always keep it on and there are no physical buttons to skip tracks on the phone.  Basically, the phone tries to do everything and sometimes you just want a mp3 player.Enter this little player which is great sounding and easy to use.  It has the physical buttons and turns on immediately.  The only downside is back to the old-fashioned usb connection to grab songs from your computer but I figure I'll preview music at home first and then upload it to this player.  It's like an extra step but saves me from constantly recharging the phone.  Back to the basics.

The indoor heat sensor is inside the clock housing. If you're running your heater there's no place I could find to mount the clock on the dash or floor console  where the indoor temperature wasn't affected by this by as much as 30 degrees F. The outdoor temperature sensor has a short wire on it and you're stuck with mounting somewhere around the drivers door. I found even mounting the sensor at the bottom of the fender by the door and driving for 30 minutes at 70 mph in 20 degree weather the clock still would read 35 degrees. When I would stop at a stop light the temperature would rise to 50. So it must be picking up heat from the engine or exhaust. Using a laser type heat gauge I found the only place I could put the heat sensor to get away from this problem with the wire length you're given is to mount it is in the side window post. But I would have to drill a 3/4" hole to access that  area of the side post to attach it to the inside of the outside skin. I think that would weaken the structural integrity in that area to much. I would lengthen the heat sensor wire and move it somewhere else but I think the way electronic heat sensors work is to change the electrical resistance with the temperature change. So if I add to the wire length I think that would affect the temperature reading to.The clock stopped working after 2 months. I replaced the batteries with no luck. So in the garbage it went.
summary: Don't buy for a small car like a Honda Civic

reviewText: It came in and looked stealthy just like in the pictures and had a real nice feel to it. I popped it on and it didn't really feel secured but I shook it off because of how nice it looks. I soon noticed that the bottom piece is sharp and hurts your wrists after a short while of typing. After about two months two of the clips broke off and I take REALLY good care of my laptop. It's 11 months later and the bottom wont stay on, the top is chipped, and I have no clue why.If I had a due over, I'd pay the extra $20 for the name brand.
summary: I LOVED IT... For a day.

reviewText: These are 2-way speakers with a mid-range and a tweeter in the middle for the high frequencies. I installed these to replace the rear speakers in my 2000 Saturn SL1. They have 4 ohms impedance, the same as the original speakers. The mounting holes in my Saturn are 6.5" apart. The outside slots on the Pioneer speakers are 6.5" so the speakers mounted well.The reason I didn't give them 5 stars was that the holes in the grill were not 6.5" and I had to do some finagling to mount the grills. The rear speakers aren't visible because they are covered with a panel. I was going to leave the grill off the speakers but the tweeter sticks out above the rim of the speaker and could be damaged if I left the grill off. I was quite a bit more work and some contortionist activity.The sound of the speakers is considerably better than my stock speakers (especially the one that didn't work at all). I wish reviewers would stop rating these for their lack of deep bass quality. If you want bass, buy a bass speaker or a sub woofer. I think they sound great.These come with wires and spade connectors that slide onto the speakers. You will most likely have to cut off your original connector and splice the wires. That was not a problem. Just be sure you attach the minus to minus and positive to positive.I would recommend these and would buy them again.

Just what I needed, great replacement usb 3 cable and I mainly bought it for a longer length on my fire/waterproof external drive.  Nice fit, tight and not loose so it won't just fall out like some cheap cords.

I was given an Anker dock for an SSD with no cables. I usually go to AMZ for anything first and sure enough, it was here for a price I wanted. I have yet to hook up to my PC as I am in the midst of replacing the ACER junk I have. You can't beat the price or delivery time.

The title pretty much says it all.  These cables are excellent quality for 3 foot USB 3.0 and ya get 2 for under ten bucks.  The fact that they're 3 foot cables is way more important than most people realize, longer cables exponentially reduce data transfer speeds, which, to me at least, is way more important than the convenience longer cables offer.  There's really no downside here, they're cheap and high quality.
summary: cheap but high quality USB 3.0 SS cables

reviewText: Quality is fine. Appearance is fine. Functionality is acceptable. However, as a one-star reviewer has pointed out previously, the "TSA-friendly" feature is poorly designed. Reason: The iPad pocket is located within the laptop compartment; it is situated so that when opened for security scanning, the laptop is not isolated in the compartment as required by TSA. Therefore, TSA officers made me remove my iPad . Of course, I quickly learned to plan ahead and moved the iPad from the laptop compartment to the main compartment before going through screening. Luckily, the laptop compartment zipper is convenient, so removing it and temporarily slipping it into the main compartment is not a major inconvenience, assuming you have room for it there. But this negates one of the major reasons I purchased the bag; shame on me; I should have noted this design as soon as I opened the package and returned it. However, billing this bag as "TSA-friendly" is certainly, and clearly mislabeling. The solution I guess is to get qualified for the TSAPre program so that you don't have to remove either your iPad or Laptop. Other than this, the bag is fine; looks, good, works well, high quality. If you do go with this product, I recommend purchasing the deluxe pad strap; it's longer, wider, more comfortable, and doesn't as easily slip off the shoulder.
Its ok,  it is small and works well when working but only works for 6 to 12 months and battery dies out,  I wish there were some way to replace the battery then this will be a rely good product
summary: I wish there were some way to replace the battery then this will be a rely good

reviewText: i got it for my 10 year old he says its to slow and does not have a camera he gave it 3 stars

I consider myself a novice when it comes to photograph although I've been taking pictures as an amateur for decades now. So, I  wanted a nice DSLR (smart) camera that can take nice pictures and videos without  having to do too much in terms of adjustment in the process.  After some extensive research, I decided to settle for the Sony A65V for a couple of reasons, first, the price has stabilized in the past year or so compared to other cameras on the market with the same features, second,  it supports all my old Minolta lenses which means that I won't have to dish out hundreds of dollars more to buy lenses ....sweet.When I received the camera I  immediately charged the battery for about 6 hours straight, then affixed the a Minolta lens to it while I study the different features in the menu.  Once I had enough knowledge of most of the features, I took it outside and started taking pictures using different settings including the use of the GPS which is a nice feature to have to impress your friends (lol). I found this camera to be light, easy to carry, and ergonomically fit for my big hands which means that I can reach  any button of the camera while looking through the viewfinder. The pictures are crisp, colorful, vivid, one might say they are of Post Card quality.  I also took a 30 minute video at Epcot Center of a Choir performance which turned out quite well.  As we speak, I am still evaluating the camera, but as of now, I must stay that I am very pleased with its performance. I'll upgrade this review if I experience anything negative in the future.  Would I recommend this camera to a friend?  YES.  Absolutely.

summary: If there is a better monitor in this price range, I'd be shocked

reviewText: i like these headphones because they have the small earbuds which work well for people with small ear openings.. the sounds good.  works well for me  would recommend to anyone

I am a long-time user of WD media players having purchased the original one they came out with in 2009 (WD TV HD Media Player), followed by the WD TV Live Plus and finally the WD TV Live Hub.  When Western Digital first came out with these devices they were targeting individuals who wanted to stream their personal video (DVD, etc.) collection.  They got better and better up until the WD TV Live Hub.  They then began expanding their online streaming services more with the WD TV Live Hub, but still did a fairly decent job (after jumping several hurdles of "buggy" firmware) until they arrived at the last version of firmware that seems fairly stable just before ditching the WD TV Live Hub and going with this new WD TV Live Media Player.With this device they seemed to have lost their vision and focus which seemed more oriented toward those who wanted to stream personal home entertainment from USB drives and/or their home networked devices.  They, instead, have tried to make this something that both competes with the Roku 3 for online streaming video services.  In the process, they've neglected and done a lamer job with the network share support for personal home entertainment users that have networked storage from to stream their personal video collection.  It even falls short of the previous WD TV Live Hub.  With the WD TV Live Hub, I can select "Windows Shares" and it finds my two WD Live Duo Cloud Storage devices on the network and allows me to add them to "My Media Library" as well as the shared USB drives attached to each of these networked WD cloud storage devices.  With this WD TV Live Streaming Media Player -- even after installing the latest firmware 2.01.86 -- when I select "Windows Shares" it just clocked endlessly and never finds them, even when I made sure the workgroup name was the same for all devices.  Ironically, out of desperation, I selected the "Mac Shares" option. To my amazement they were detected with that option.  However, with the "Mac Shares" option, it only detected the shares directly on the two WD networked storage devices and failed to detect the shared USB drives attached to the network storage devices (huh?)!  I experimented and tried all kinds of different things (and I'm not a novice at troubleshooting this kind of "geeky" stuff).  Just in case some "bug" may have been introduced into the newest firmware, I even tried rolling back the firmware to the version it came with (the "Mac Shares" option that only got me part way there did not show up on that version 1.16.13).  Unfortunately, that did not work either.  If I keep jumping between my "Local Storage" (USB drives attached to the WD TV HD media player) and "Media Server" option under "Videos>Content Source" it finds them that way, but I do not like to keep jumping back and forth between those options and prefer permanently adding them to "My Media Library" under "Settings>System>Media Library>Media Library Manager for Network Share" and then using the "Add network share to media library" option to permanently add them to my video content list under "Videos" so they are there whenever I boot up -- no fuss, no muss.  I follow this exact procedure on my WD TV Live Hub and it works flawlessly (all on the same network as I place this device on, mind you, but not on this WD TV Live Streaming Media Player.The irony in this whole scenario is that this "WD" branded device could not find the other "WD" branded network storage devices.  Don't they even test this with their own product?  Apparently not.  Strangely enough the user manual states:  "Windows Shares display shared computers and network attached storage devices(such as WD's My Book Live personal cloud storage NAS drive) connected to your network via the Samba protocol."  -- Oh, really?  Maybe they forgot the part that you have to rub your belly and pat your head while selecting the "Windows Shares" option?After endless frustration, I concluded that this device does not properly live up to what it claims to do, which is to support networked storage, even when it is the WD brand!  As a result, I returned it to Amazon and instead am jumping off the "WD ship" when it comes to a media player for personal home entertainment and have decided to purchase the "KDLINKS HD720 Extreme FULL HD 1080P 3D Media Player with Internal HDD Bay, Gigabit Network, Built-In Wifi."  That product has rave reviews and appears to be far superior for this type of media application than the latest WD device.  With this new WD TV Live Streaming Media Player, WD has not only fallen short on network share support personal home entertainment (while maintaining support for the attached USB drives), but they also fall short on the online streaming video services.  I own a Roku 3 and it is far superior for online streaming video services than anything WD has come up with.  I would even go further by stating that it falls short of their previous WD TV Live Hub as far as support for networked (NAS) devices.  Having both devices at my fingertips, I can confirm that what works on one (WD TV Live Hub) doesn't work on the other (WD TV Live Streaming Media Player), noting that the menu options for doing what I attempted is exactly the same on both the former (WD TV Live Hub) and this newer WD media player device.To me it seems like WD is trying to make this "all things" to "all people" when it comes to streaming video and has fallen short of competition all the way around.  If WD wants to "carve" out their place in this market and make it with their media players, they need to get back to "basics" and focus on what used to be the strength of their media players (playing personal attached and network storage of home entertainment).  They need to do a better job of debugging their firmware and curtail the addition of so many "bells and whistles" while neglecting the proper functionality of already existing (and essential) features.If my experience is good with my new KDLINKS HD720 Extreme FULL HD 1080P 3D Media Player, then WD has just lost this media player customer for good.  Maybe WD will wake up before it's too late and get back on track with addressing the interests and concerns of the niche market that purchased their media players to begin with.  As for this former customer, for now anyway, "good-bye WD!"
summary: Western Digital has lost its focus with this device

I use these to mount my GPS and iPhone and find them versatile and easy to adjust.Stays in the adjusted position even in bumpy roads.

reviewText: I have found these features to be most useful:Partial metering, spot selected focus, exposure compensation, bracketing, ettl 2 flash control, full manual control of shutter speed, ISO and aperture, the ability to shoot in raw format.  It still has fully automatic settings for those that just want to point and shoot.There is also a  live view function which works great for setting manual focus while using a tripod.  You can zoom all the way in and move anywhere in the frame to focus exactly where you want to.The body is very light, made from what feels like a very durable smooth plastic.  However this plastic is very slick- use the strap so you don't drop it!The LCD is very large, with good image quality.I found the menu system fairly intuitive to use.Now what it is lacking:There is no mirror lock up. This is not a problem if you have a good tripod, but is worth mentioning if this is a deal breaker for you.It also does not have spot metering, but instead uses partial metering.  I have very little experience with spot, but have had no problems getting the exposure I want with partial.This camera does not shoot video in 1080, it is limited to 720.  I personally could do without video all together, I bought it to take pictures.There is no built in remote sensor.  You will need a cable release or to buy a third party wireless solution.The cache is somewhat limited.  This is only an issue if you want to shoot continuous action in raw format.  It will bog down after 4 pictures.  If you shoot in jpeg you can shoot continuous all day long without delay so long as you have the proper sd card.Lastly there is no auto sensor clean, just a manual function that flips the mirror up so you can blow the dust away, or clean it physically.These really have not been issues for me and for $279.00, I am not complaining, just pointing it out to help you make an informed decision.If you are looking for a new hobby, want to learn your way around a dslr, or expand your subject capabilities without breaking the bank, this is the camera for you.  With a little bit of learning , experience and the proper lenses you can still get professional looking results with this body.  If you are a landscape purist, action/sports photographer, professional photographer, want to make fully detailed poster sized prints, or are looking to make 1080 videos then there are better options out there, but you will pay a lot more for them.
summary: Great entry level DSLR value for learning your way around manual photography.

reviewText: I was shopping for a low-budget amp to power a pair of Pioneer  SP-BS21 (which just dropped to around $60). The thought of spending $400-1000 for an amp to power $60 speakers just wasn't sitting well with me. Pretty much all the online forums pointed to looking for something used. The problem, is that where I live, I didn't know of any second hand electronics places, and I didn't relish the thought of spending weekends scouring the yard sales to try and strike gold. But as I read more and more (and more) online forums, I started reading about Topping amps. There are other brands at this (or even lower) price level, but Topping would even creep into sites and article aimed at the "audiophile" crowd, as the caviar taste on bologna budget. And Topping was even specifically mentioned along these speakers as a good combo on several audio forums. And I am so glad I went with this combo. Fantastic sound for $160 coming from my computer. I play iTunes, and even bought a few titles in FLAC, and play those using Foobar player (free download).I originally selected Topping TP20 for only $70, but the TP22 was just $30 more, and had quite a bit more power. I can say that the TP20 was rated (and reviewed) to be more than enough power, but I wanted to get the 30W per channel version to test out my other bookshelf speakers (Aperion) that I bought years ago. These are more power-hungry and I wanted to make sure I had just that little extra.The sound from this amp and the BS21 speakers is warm, which is fine with me. I haven't used any other amp, so I can't offer a comparison. Consider this review just another data-point in your search.

I am somewhat a connoisseur of small amplifiers. The Lepai name is at the top of the heap in the small amp game. I think with this purchase, I now have every single amp Lepai offers. This is not the best one, but it is #2 or #3 out of about a dozen, which are all good products. I could do without the "bass boost" option; so I just don't use it. In fact, I am a purist who does not alter the sound from the source at all: even treble and bass controls are left at 12 o'clock.  I like to experience what the talent & producer put down on tape as accurately as possible. That's why I love these little digital amps. Nothing added or subtracted from the audio: just the facts, ma'am.This thing, hooked to the proper speakers (4ohm preferably,) can fill a room no problem. Compact, accurate, loud. What more could you want?I did audition it for a good 18 hours straight at medium high volume and it got a tad warm. Not hot. Not dangerous. I actually would have expected it to be hot, not warm, after the paces I put it through.Everything came in perfect working order.
summary: I love Lepai amps, including this one.

I have used Magic Jack as my outgoing line for three years.  As far as phone service, it's pretty good.  I haven't had any issues.  If this review were based on just the phone service, it would be at four stars.  Regardless of how good the phone service is, the billing is a NIGHTMARE.  If you do decide to buy the product and try it for a year, please do yourself a favor and buy it through a retailer.  incidentally, with Magic Jack Plus 2014, you only get 6 months of service.I started with the regular magic jack and when MJ offered me a "deal" on Magic Jack Plus last year, I went ahead and got it.  Despite the fact that I cancelled my old MJ account (without a refund, I might add), they went ahead and billed me for it anyway.  Fortunately, I disputed it and got a refund through my credit card company.Well, a year has gone buy.  I have had to replace the USB adapter, but other than that, all was well -- until recently when I went to dial out and got a message "Service error, please try again later.  Well, after 2 days of that, I finally contacted Magic Jack spending well over an hour trying to get some info.I was told that my account has been de-activated They would not say what the problem is. .  In order to renew, they are requiring me to buy a whole new devise (at $49.00) even though my unit is only one year old.Now, if they had given me some advanced notice, things would be a little different.  I only use MJ for long distance calls, but until this gets resolved, I'm stuck with no way to call out.  (Pretty much every call I make is long distance).Supposedly, they have filed some sort of report to bring my account into review, but would not state what the problem was or how long it would take to resolve the issue.So, I'm going to try Net Talk instead.  Same cost and has same features.  Goodbye Magic Jack -- I'm really glad I didn't opt in for the 5 year plan.  I could handle the 50% increase in yearly cost, but requiring a new unit for a renewal is more than I am willing to do.
summary: It will cost you more than you think!

reviewText: I have been in search for a great bookshelf speaker for a reasonable price and have been buying and trying many inexpensive highly rated speakers for some time. Inexpensive means different things to different folks. In the audiophile community inexpensive means less than a thousand dollars a pair. These are on the high side of budget pricing. The recent $369 pricing on the Studio 530 made these a screaming bargain and I bought a pair here without ever hearing them. That is always scary as everyone hears things a little differently. It helps that the speakers have consumer great reviews there are not that many pro reviews. The American pro reviews are noticeably absent. Then British site WhatHiFi gave it 5 stars and described the speaker as great fun.  I have to agree.Horn loaded speaker such as inexpensive Klipsch speakers are often harsh and fatiguing. These speakers are very smooth with great detail, superbly tight bass and present very balanced overall. The horn tweeters on the Studio 5 series are marvels. Although there is a rising high frequency with these speakers it is very well managed with slight toe-in.These are exciting speakers to play and they really suck you in. I have Usher, PSB and NHT here and I like these a lot. Sound quality compares well with the NHT Classic 3 overall which were once called the best speakers under a thousand dollars. At the price difference I strongly favor the JBLs and the very tight bass helps make these speakers way more exciting and fun than the NHT.The 530 just has better base than the NHT. Just plain amazing bass for a 5 and 1/4 woofer. You can run them without a subwoofer and not miss it. If you do use a sub I suggest a good one. They will make cheaper subs sound bad. I think the NHT Classic 3 is a smoother speaker overall but not as open and seems carved out of a single piece of stone. The cabinet on the 530 is solid but other than looks is not remarkable in any way.  More importantly than looks or heft this is a very musical speaker. Voice, strings, percussion and piano are all very realistically rendered and the speakers have a big dynamic sound, These are very revealing and you will hear flaws in your recordings but you will be playing everything in your library just to hear these speakers sing.The cabinets are pretty strange looking but hey, form follows function. If these go one sale again just buy them. They are crazy good at under $400. If you need speakers now, they are worth every penny of the retail price. I never thought I would own horn loaded speaker but JBL's trickle down technology from their high end speakers really paid dividends on this one. JBL has not been a star in home audio over the last decade or so and have largely been ignored by the audiophile and enthusiast community. JBL did these right and they are the real deal.In summary the real surprise to me is how good these are and how they managed to fly under the audiophile community's radar so long.
summary: No audition needed. JBL take a bow!

reviewText: Errant, unwound, unwrapped cords drive me up the wall.  I've tried so many solutions and this is easily the best yet.  My only disappointment is that they don't come in even bigger sizes for unwieldy cords (like kitchen appliances).  Otherwise, highly recommend.

I'm writing this review as the Motorola SB6141 sits on my kitchen counter with the return shipping label, waiting to be dropped off at UPS.I will try and make this a lot shorter since I'm coming back to edit my last review in which I gave the product 4 stars and titled it "The jury is still out..." Well the jury is in with its verdict. Keep in mind, I'm no internet tech, and my experience is based solely on how the Zoom 5341J performed compared to the Motorola SB6121 and SB6141, *with my specific service provider (Comcast), in my area, and in my home*. All of these factors can have a significant effect on your own experience. Here is a rundown on my experience with each of the aforesaid mentioned devices. If you only want my comments on the Zoom 5341J just scroll down to it.All devices were used  in conjunction with Comcast Performance Blast service with 50 mbps download, and 10 mbps upload bandwidth speed. I measured the speed using speedtest.net. Each of the test results were reported to me using a server based in my city, so all of the results are best case scenario.Motorola SB6121To this day, I am still convinced I either bought a defective device, or Comcast did not recognize this device from the jump properly. From the moment I activated this modem, my bandwidth speed would jump from 58 mbps down and spike wildly all the way down to about 2 mbps, the upload speed would never eclipse 3 mbps, and usually hovered around 0.9 mbps. I tried restoring the factory settings online. The only result was the modem updated to a newer firmware, but that did not solve any of the bandwidth speed issues. The pings were very high as well about 70-160 ms, which is way too high for a test using a server in my own city. I also deactivated and reactivated the modem multiple times in hopes that whatever the issue was would resolve itself. I would get the same results over and over. I also tried a slew of fixes that I researched online. Nothing worked and internet was basically unusable.Motorola SB6141This device worked much much better than its predecessor, it just didn't perform as well as I felt it should have. Hardwired to the modem the SB6141 would get me 58 mbps downstream / 14 mbps upstream, which was beautiful to behold. In my bedroom (where the device was set up) over wifi, I would get a steady 55 mbps downstream and 14 mpbs upstream. I was living the dream for a few days. About 2 or 3 days later the Netflix streaming out in my living room would start buffering, and this is something that never happened with my previous DOCSIS 2.0 modem (Motorola SB5101), so I started doing speedtests again HARDWIRED to the SB6141. This time, although I was still getting relatively good speeds, the mbps would jitter up and down. Sometimes one test would start at 58 mbps and end at 35 mpbs downstream. Others would start at 30 mpbs and go up and down and end at 45 mpbs. Like the internet was struggling to get through at a steady rate. Pings would range between 14-40 ms. Not the vision of consistency I envisioned. Again, I know these results can depend on a lot of things besides the modem, but I've come to the conclusion it was the modem based on how the Zoom has been performing. I did the same things I did to the SB6121 to try and remedy the SB6141. Sometimes the speeds would be great, sometimes they would be ok, and sometimes they would jitter, all within a few minutes of each other. I kept a hold of the SB6141 to see if the Zoom (which I actually purchased before this device) would suffer the same issues.Zoom5341JFrom the moment I activated, to right this minute as I write this review, this device has worked flawlessly. I actually bought this device after the SB6121 failed me, and because I did not trust the brand name Zoom as much as I did Motorola, and the device seemed to run a little warm, I went and got the SB6141 just to make sure I was getting a quality product. My experience with the SB6121 should have taught me Motorola wasn't going to work for me in my situation, but I wanted the certainty of the name. Through primetime internet using hours, over wifi, hardwired, using multiple internet devices simultaneously, this thing has been an absolute beast for me. It gets me 58 mbps downstream 14 upstream hardwired, over wifi in the same room it gets me 55 mpbs downstream 13 upstream, out in my living room over wifi it gets me 21-30 mbps down/ 11 mpbs up. Although the distance from my bedroom (where I set up my modem/wifi) to my living room is not very far (roughly 75 ft), there are 2 walls, an AC unit, a water heater, and a patio between them. I know a lot depends on the wifi router, but the 5341J has been making sweet sweet love with my Netgear N300 WNR2000v3 (which is very far from a great router nowadays). The most impressive thing thus far is that I haven't had to do any research to get it to act right, my internet speeds have been steady as a tank, and it has not disconnected one time throughout the period I've been using it (roughly 2 weeks). If Zoom keeps this up, I may have to start purchasing more devices from them.Sidenotes: The Zoom 5341J runs warmer than both of the Motorolas I purchased. I wouldn't call it hot, just warmer than other modems I've had. If anything happens with the modem, I will be back here to report it. Also, the LEDs on the 5341J are BRIGHT. They can light up a corner of a dark room. At night it serves as a nightlight to keep monsters away and if I have to get up and use the bathroom haha. Its not "burn your retinas bright," its just "3 x brighter than the SB6141/6121 bright." Its not a problem for me, just something maybe others would want to know about.
summary: Better than Motorola SB6121 & SB6141 *In my experience*

reviewText: I bought this for quicker charging of a Kindle Fire 8.9" HD and have used this product for approximately 2 years.  Plenty of time to see whether it works or not.  It does work, very, very s-l-o-w-l-y.  It regularly takes approximately 24 hours to recharge the Kindle with this adapter - a far cry from the advertised approximate time of 5 hours which is stated in the item description.  Very disappointed in this product and feel that it was misrepresented by Amazon.  I love the Kindle Fire and have been a loyal, long time Amazon customer but this item is pure junk.  Surprising that Amazon would sully it's reputation with such a cheap piece of 'imported' garbage to sell to it's good customers.  An adapter that actually works should also have been included with the purchase of the Kindle Fire.  It's an insult to be charged for such a low quality, ineffective item.  Steer clear of it.

reviewText: I bought this iPad Mini for my wife because the grandchildren keep hogging my original iPad and my wife's iPad 2 (I got for her last year.).  So far, my wife has been able to keep her hands on the new Mini without the grandkids hogging it.My wife likes the Mini because:It runs the same apps as the iPad 2 does.It is smaller and fits on the table beside her chair better than the iPad 2 did.It is lighter than the iPad 2.  This is important because the OtterBoxes add significant weight to the iPads.  (We would never have an iPad without a case because of the risk of the grandchildren dropping them.)It works very well for what she does: FaceBook, Pinterest, searching the Internet and simple games.I like that it runs iOS 7 and the cameras are better than on the iPad 2.Much has been said about the low resolution of the screen on the original iPad Mini.  That is not a problem for us with the way we use our iPads.  I suppose if you used it for viewing a lot of videos, that might matter.  But, that is what we use our TVs for.The iPads have been very appreciated by the members of this household.  The grandchildren do use the larger iPads for videos and have not complained about the low resolution of the screens.  We currently have an iPad (1st generation), iPad 2, iPad 4th generation and the iPad Mini.  What we like about the iPads are the wide variety of apps available (many free ones) and the fact that they actually work.Prior to getting into the world of iPads, we had 3 different Android tablets which had a variety of problems:The Android tablets:Did not use Google Play.  Two of them required downloads from a PC to install apps.One had a resistive screen, which was hard to use.Two frequently froze up.  One had a reset hole an ear ring pin could be placed in.  The other simply had to be left alone for the battery to run down.While people complain about the iPads not accepting SD cards, we had problems with our Android devices not allowing all of the apps to be installed on the SD cards.We are very happy with all of our iOS devices (including 3 iPhones and 3 iPod Touches) because they work as they should.UPDATE:I forgot to state that I also especially like the new Lightning connector the Mini and the iPhone 5 has.  It is much easier to connect to the device than the old 30 pin connector or a mini USB connector that so many devices use.  With the Lightning connector, either side can be placed up when connecting to the device.  The old 30 pin can be difficult to connect without actually looking at the connector and device.

I bought mine through Apple and received a 20% Vet's discount.  Once you go from beyond the stock  order to a little more RAM and SSD, well, it's worth it.  My AirBook went from Shaghai to Anchorage to Chestnut hill in but a few anxiously awaited days.  Like other Apple products, all I did was give it my ID and it integrated perfectly with my Mac mini's keychain, safari bookmarks and all of the email, contact and calendar stuff.It runs fast, it uses a low power Core i5 chip and SSD to make this happen, no painfully slow I/O to drain battery, generate heat or slowly fetch data for buffering.  This laptop can actually sit on my lap for hours without any meaningful heat buildup.  There is so much to say about this laptop, especially in light of my last laptop (generic Windoze machine).Totally worth the money, a really nice piece of engineering and a pleasure to use.
summary: Finally a laptop I can live with

reviewText: My last LCD TV by Sharp lasted almost 6 years and it cost me $2,500.  It still works by the screen started to show vertical lines and noises.  Finally decide to spend $600 and get this SmartTV by Samsung.  I can say that I am extremely happy with the TV.  However, I am unable to give this 5 starts for a few reason.First are a few pros.  The TV is very easy to setup and it is quite heavy for its size.  The TV stand is strong and compact to hold its weight.  It comes with 3 HDMI ports, and a few USB ports.  There is a PC port and regular analog port.  I attached Xbox 1 to the TV and it worked flawlessly.  I tried to play Blue Ray movie on my XBox 1 and only HDMI 1 allows the move to play.The remote that came with the TV works fine but trying to navigate and type on the SmartTV is futile at best.  I suggest that you get a USB keyboard (about $35) and it works well with the TV.If you have a Samsung smartphone, you will enjoy the way the phone interact with the TV.  You can easily share photos and videos from your Samsung smartphone by beaming it to the TV.  My family love this feature.Now, on to the negatives.  On initial boot up, Samsung requires updates on the SmartHub.  That takes a while if you use wireless network.  Once all the updates are done everything works fine.  One of the thing I noticed about SmartTV is the internal memory is quite small.  You cannot install a lot of apps on the TV.Another negative is using the internet to watch web videos will work for the first 10 minutes until the internal memory is full and the internet app will shut down.  I also tried using the Vevo app.  The SmartTV can play the app videos for the first 20 minutes until the videos start to stutter.  If I am not mistaken, this TV is unable to clear its cache quick enough to continue with the videos.

I have a big screen Samsung HD TV in my living room but we wanted to replace the clunky floor model in our bedroom with a wall mount.  This one works as good as the bigger Samsung.  We use it for internet TV and had no trouble mounting it.  It appears compatible with a wide variety of wall brackets.  We chose an inexpensive bracket, due to the light weight of this TV.  I am totally satisfied.

It is working great, I have no problems charging my original battery. It is a rapid charger too and charges faster than the one I lost. Also love that this package come with 2 extra batteries which is very helpful. Definitely recommend.

I just want to say that I love this receiver. My roommates and I have a fair number of video game consoles, plus a Blu Ray player and a Chromecast and a million other things, and we got tired of constantly switching devices back and forth on our HDTV's two HDMI inputs. I also tend to be a big fan of having good speakers for listening to music and watching movies, and our TV's speakers were killing me. I bought this receiver so we could plug all of our different stuff into one central hub, and so I could use some legitimate external speakers for all of our media consumption.First off: the setup was easy. As others have noted, this receiver doesn't come with a full paper manual in the box. It comes with a quick-start manual and a CD with the full manual on it. The full manual was also easy to find on the Onkyo support website. So, slightly inconvenient, though not exactly the end of the world. It connects to a TV via a single HDMI out port, and has 4 HDMI in ports for different devices. It also has a variety of Component and Composite video in and out ports, as well as analog audio, optical audio, and others. The full list is above somewhere. The speaker connections were well labeled and easy to set up. For me, getting the receiver ready consisted of plugging my various devices into the different inputs, plugging in my speakers, plugging in the receiver, and turning it on. Of course, you can spend a lot of time tweaking all of the different settings if you want, and there are plenty to choose from, but going from "just arrived," to "playing on the big screen" really was a snap.The sound coming out of the receiver is great. I've got pretty good speakers hooked up to it, and I was pulling all my audio from good sources through HDMI, and the overall sound quality was awesome. There are a variety of different listening modes you can choose from depending on your setup and how many speaker channels you're using, so you can optimize the receiver to your surroundings. There are of course plenty of more sophisticated audio settings you can choose from in the device's menus if you're going for complete customization.It's easy to switch between different inputs and assign them to different sources. However, keep in mind that the receiver can only output the same type of video signal it receives. So if you have a device hooked up to the receiver via component cable, the receiver has to be hooked up to the TV with component cable. The same goes for composite and HDMI. So I actually have the receiver connected to my TV twice, with a set of component cables as well as an HDMI. Not quite ideal, but it works.My roommates and I have found that 4 HDMI inputs isn't quite enough for us, and we still have to do some cable switching when we want to use a different source device, but whether or not you experience that problem depends on how much you're planning on plugging into the receiver. Also, the thing really does tend to get pretty hot. I'm told this is normal for this model and for A/V receivers and general, but it can be a little surprising just how warm it gets. It probably won't ever be an issue, but I'm keeping an eye on it.Otherwise, the thing works great. It suits my needs just fine. If I was going to buy another one, however, I'd likely spend more money to get a receiver that has more HDMI inputs, that can do video conversion, and has some wireless capabilities for syncing with online services. But if you're looking for something basic and not too expensive, this one should probably do just fine.
summary: Works great, but you might consider spending more for a better device

reviewText: I bought this product so I could VPN in to my office from the road - no other reason, really.The initial product setup was very easy and I got connected to the net after replacing my other router within about 5 mins.Troubles came when I tried to VPN in via PPTP.  I could not connect.  After an hour or so of troubleshooting, I determined that the PPTP service was highly unstable and would crash after a simple port scan.  So I figured I'd return the router and get something else - probably more expensive.Then I figured I should check for a firmware update, and sure enough, the latest firmware update addresses the PPTP bug.  In the release notes, it says, "Optimize the stability of the PPTP connection".  I downloaded and applied the firmware update, and all seems good.The PPTP service now seems stable, and has survived several nmap port scans and a vulnerability scan with Nessus.Note:  This router does not come with PPTP client software, but it's very simple to setup a PPTP connection on Mac OS X (Mavericks) natively, so that's nice.  It's simply a matter of opening system prefs, network, and adding a VPN connection.  You can even have a VPN icon in the menu bar.Connecting securely to the office is now easy, though I have not done exhaustive testing.  For the price, I recommend this product.Edit 1/3/2013----After some basic performance testing, it appears that throughput via PPTP is limited to 1Mbps up and down, so this may not be suitable for large file transfers or other bandwidth intensive activities.  The router supports 16 connections via PPTP so I imagine that it reserves 1Mbps for each connection...or something like that.In my opinion, it's still a great router for the price, but I would not rely on it for anything mission critical or in business environments more than a couple of users.
summary: Great Price and Easy Setup, But Some VPN Issues

This is nothing more than a cable ground device but because of the name, they stick it to you on the price. The device itself is pretty straightforward. It is a sleek, compact fuse protected surge protector for the Wilson cellular antenna systems. You put it in line and run your ground wire to either a ground post or a water pipe and your investment is protected from static discharge. Its not gonna protect you if you have a direct hit, but then nothing will. But a nearby jolt will pop the fuse, you replace the fuse and you are back in service. I HIGHLY recommend if you have one of these systems.
summary: Very expensive because of the name but does the job.

I purchased this drive so I'd have something rugged and safe to store my pictures on that I could take with me.  Something I could throw in my carry-on luggage and not worry about it getting banged around like you would with most hard drives.  From that standpoint, it's been good.  The thing has always been fine getting thrown in a bag and knocked around a bit.That said, there is one MAJOR flaw in the design.  The short USB3 cable can be unplugged from the drive, and it is very loose where it attaches to drive itself.  Because of the direction of the cables tension, it puts stress on this connection and causes it to get looser and looser over time.  After a few months I got to the point where now, any time I plug it in, a slight bump of the drive or the table it is resting on will cause it to wiggle loose enough to lose connection with the drive.  Of course, this is akin to unplugging the drive from your computer with out properly ejecting it first, and puts your data at risk every time it happens (which is often).In the end, you're left with a rugged drive that can take a beating, but can lose your data with the slightest bump or nudge to the surface it's resting on.  It's not even usable on plane rides anymore (the primary purpose I purchased it for) because the vibration of the plane alone will shake the the cable loose of the drive, causing an improper ejection from the computer and sometimes corrupting the data.

When I was buying this at my local Apple retail store, the rep told me it could play directly from my NAS (network-attached storage). When I got home, I realized she had either lied to me or simply hadn't got a clue.  The Computer part of Apple TV only streams from iTunes software on Mac or PC.However, with the help of a free app called MoliPlayer HD -- I first used this app last year on my Nokia Windows Phone -- and the wonderful AirPlay, it's a cinch to network-play my files on my NAS, a Diskstation product.  MoliPlayer HD can access any server or computer on your LAN (local area network), and play pretty all the video and audio formats out there.  The free version doesn't allow you to password-protect the app, but otherwise has all the major functions.  I just launch MoliPlayer HD, go to Nearby on the left, and it accesses my DiskStation as well as my Windows workgroup immediately. I then turn on AirPlay to send the media content to my Apple TV.The Apple TV is truly simple and elegant, and it just works.  I went through several Android-based media players but they were all difficult to use, froze frequently, not to mention anything from Google is reported to spy on you and your family.  On the Apple TV I can rearrange the app icons just like on iPhone or iPad. I can easily get rid off unwanted icons through the Restrictions settings. For instance, I don't have cable at home, so I remove things like HBO and ESPN and Disney channels.  Everything just works so well and so smoothly, even the screensaver is so well done.  AirPlay is indeed awesome!!  I plan to get an AirPort Extreme and AirPlay-ify all my media hardware.
summary: Now I can play from my NAS

reviewText: I have a PXC  450 wired Senn. cost about $360 through Amazon and is great. Wanted more portability ,ability to move around , ergo Bluetooth . Shopped a lot  , went back to the best , Sennheiser and debated between the MM 450 & 550 . Got the 450 for smaller size on ear and smaller carrying case footprint. Could not be more pleased. Compact , solid construction , very easy connectivity .Compared to the PXC 450 wired , I cannot tell the difference  in sound quality, and now I have no cable/cord to deal with.To those that have expressed disappointment in the lack of base tone , I do not see it . Same thing to those that feel volume is lacking. I had it playing way too loud ,and was not near max. Set your device at about 3/4 , then fool around with the Senn. volume and you will get all you need or want. .I will use the wired Senn . when listening uninterrupted to great music ,alone in the evening. But for everyday portability ,and use in an area where others are doing there thing , this product cannot be beat for the price.I have tried ,and considered other headphones ,wired and Bluetooth . None of them , including the "perceived " leader , come close. Buy this product and you will not be disappointed.The reason it got four ,not five ,stars is the battery . Works fine and has good life. However hard to remove if yo want to insert a second one while charging original.Room for improvement on this issue .

A few observations follow:* Setup was a breeze on windows 8.1 though I did have to go online to download a driver* Display now effortlessly spans two monitors and one television* Instructions are brief but unnecessary if you've dealt with hardware before.  If you have difficulty there is a 1-800 numberIn summary, I was exceptionally gleeful that this device managed to dig me out of a pretty significant failure in my vetting process when buying a new computer.  Now I'm the proud owner of a heck of a lot of screen space.

reviewText: It works however I dinged it two stars due to the fact it's very cheaply made, the plastic is flimsy, the remote is a joke and button on the switcher itself is but a small dot that you really have to press (if not using the remote). The IR sensor is not attached to the switcher but comes with a bit of 3M adhesive to install wherever you'd like it however.

Bought this at the same time that I purchased a new DSL modem, together replacing an aging modem/router combo that came with the DSL service from the ISP.  My ISP is only able to offer me a maximum 7Mbps connection where I live out in the sticks, so my impression of the speed improvement that I've experience after upgrading to this router would be almost entirely through the addition of the dual band function that this one gives me.  What I am impressed with, are all the options that this router offers.  I have a removable hard drive connected to the USB that gives me access to the drive anywhere in the house, without having to go find it and plug it in.  Plus, with two computers, now the files can be shared.  Access to the removable storage can be password protected, so you aren't giving access to your personal stuff to friends and family when you want to give them access to the WiFi.  You can set-up a guest account, with a password or not, to give people access to your WiFi without having to give out your own password.  That way, you can maintain your own password, even if you have to cut someone off at some point.  Lots of features for the price.  I'm very pleased.

summary: Confusing Benchmark Results : ATTO vs CrystalDiskMark

The Logitech K360 Wireless Keyboard is one of the least expensive units that has one of the unifying receivers.  That was a requirement for me since I already use a mouse that came with the receiver.  I like being able to connect multiple devices through a single USB port.  The size is compact, but it is still a “full” keyboard - including the 10-key pad.  It is one of those things that I don’t realize how much I use until I didn’t have one (as with the K400 model).  All of the keys are where I expect them to be (another contrast with the K400 model).  The keys are a little on the small side, and they are also a bit stiff.  It is not a big enough issue to make me want to look for something else.  However, the saying is true.  You get what you pay for.  I know that I could have gotten a better experience with one of the higher models from Logitech, but I didn’t want to spend a lot.  I would say that the K360 is a serviceable, budget-minded keyboard.  It is good enough for me based on the price and the unifying receiver.
summary: Budget Keyboard Is Good Enough For The Money

I bought it in Ink Blue, and it is really so much closer to Black than to Ink Blue that I was disappointed.The good things about this cover are:- the leather shell is hard, which protects the Kindle Paperwhite- it is sized only for the Kindle Paperwhite, so you don't need to use straps to hold the device in a one-size-fits-all cover- it has a magnetic closure, so you don't need an elastic strap around it- it is designed to put the device into Sleep and Wake Modes by just opening and closing it- it has a space so you can charge it without opening the coverThe worst thing about it (apart from the color discrepancy, which is quite annoying) is that the price is high. reviewText: I use ASUS boards for all of my computer builds.  I find that ASUS builds a quality product that they stand behind.Great performance from this form factor.  Four slots for memory. Works every time out of the box.I have built this board with a i3 3240 processor.  Added 8 GB of Crucial DDR3 memory and a Kingston Hyper X SSD.You really don't need the faster processor when dealing with solid state drives.  This combo for me produces a computer that customers love at an affordable price.Negatives:  Not that it is necessary but it would still be nice to have the option to add IDE devices to this board.  As well I think there should be at least one more 6GB SATA connection.
This product may work, however it only goes one direction, so it was useless to me. I have a laptop that outputs VGA and a tv that accepts HDMI, and this product does NOT work for that configuration.

I use aNexus 7 from Google (7-Inch, 32 GB, Black) by ASUS (2013) Tablettablet as a video/camera monitor for FPV (first person view) when flying aDJI Phantom 2 Vision Quadcopter with Integrated FPV Camcorder (White).This sunhood fit the Nexus 7 nicely. It fits in front of the face of the tablet, rather than around the outside edges. It took me a little experimentation to get it mounted properly, but once I did I was quite happy and it was a stable, snug fit.  I'll add some tips in this review in case it helps others who purchase this monitor sunhood for a Nexus 7 or similar-sized device.I used this sunhood in combination withKaysCase X-Shape TPU Back Case Cover for Google Nexus 7 inch Tablet Android 4.1 Jelly Bean (Black)and mount it to my TX controller with anAmazonBasics Universal Windshield and Dash Mount for Smartphones, GPS, and Tablets including iPhone and Samsung Galaxy. The tablet case, universal mounting bracket, and sunhood all fit and work together perfectly.To fit the sunhood to your Nexus 7 or similar monitor or tablet:1. Set the hood with the back edge of it on the table, so the hood faces up. The three sides of the hood should be standing on their edges with the large top piece away from you, and the two angled side pieces extending towards you. The two attached velcro strips should be laying flat on the table extending from the top section towards you.2.  Place the tablet on its back on top of the two velcro strips. Set the three edges of the sunhood on top of the edges of the monitor.3. Fold the left velcro strip over the bottom edge of the monitor and upwards across the bottom left corner of the monitor. Slip it between the face of the monitor and the left edge of the sunhood about halfway up the left edge of the monitor. The loose end of the velcro strip will now be extending out the left side of the sunhood. Wrap it up around the left back corner of the sunhood, folding it around the top left edge of the hood and attach it to the velcro tab on the top left side of the top of the hood. The left velcro strip should now come up from behind the bottom left edge of the monitor, across the bottom left face of the monitor and out the left side between the face of the monitor and the hood, then wrap around the outside back left corner of the hood and attach to the velcro tab on top of the hood.4. Repeat with the right hand velcro strip, bringing it under the bottom right edge of the monitor, out the right side between the glass face and the sunhood, wrap it around the outside right edge of the hood and around the corner to the top of the hood, and attach it to the right hand velcro tab on the hood top.5. Take the free velcro strip (the one that isn't attached to anything)  and put the soft side against the lower back of the monitor about 1/2" from the bottom edge, and wrap each end around the sides of the sunhood and attach it to the velcro edges of the hood sides.The three sides of the sunhood should now be facing outwards from around the top and sides of the monitor. You can adjust the strips to get it snug. The strip across the back will keep the two sides from flopping around.I added a small velcro self-sticking tab to the lower back center of my monitor case, under the free velcro strap. That keeps the free strap attached to the back of the monitor so it doesn't get dropped, so all I have to do it bring the two ends of that strap around the sides of the sunhood to attach them to the monitor.Overall, I am quite happy with this sunhood for my Nexus 7 as an FPV monitor for my quadcopter.
summary: Great sunhood for my Nexus 7 tablet while flying a quadcopter!

reviewText: As with several others here I didn't buy this as an automobile audio amplifier, but rather to experiment.This item does exactly what it claims to do:  12v input, 4 watts per channel output.  Note that in reality this isn't very loud.  It's okay for a small room or a personal radio project.  But as far as being a "car amp"... that's a bit of a stretch. This at best should be considered a "hobbyist amp at a low price".THE EXPERIMENT.  Knowing (at this time) almost nothing about electricity but not afraid to try something off the wall, I wondered, "How would this work as a guitar amplifier?".  The answer:  lousy.  Apparently a guitar, whether passive or powered pickup, simply doesn't kick out enough power to register any volume on this device.  A preamp would be required,which kind of eliminates the purpose of the project... to amplify a guitar signal.  What I did was hook up a small rechargeable 12v 7Ah "scooter battery" as the power source, attached a decent external speaker, used a 1/4" to RCA adapter to plug in the guitar, and tested.  Tried it with 3 different guitars, ranging from passive to powered pickup.  Barely audible.  Experiment requires more information; at this time has met with failure. (Note: the small 12v battery powered it just fine.  That part at least I had figured out.  It is a bit heavy though. : )WHAT DID WORK: Instead of a guitar I hooked in my cell phone.  That worked great; the phone cranked out enough earphone power to source this amp quite well.THE FIX:  I connected both black leads together and both red leads together (output side) and sent it to a single speaker for a total of 8 watts of power.  That seemed to do a bit better.  The trick is if you use a speaker small enough to be in the 4 watt range, it doesn't have much voice.  If you use  larger speaker, you have to up the watts.MY OPINIONS OF THE PRODUCT ITSELF:  Running my cell phone through it, it did just what it was advertised to do.  The sound was very clear, had good, crisp results, and was pleasant to listen to.  I heard no distortion.  I really like the control setup on this:  large power button, huge volume button with base and treble to the sides.  A nice addition is a color-changing light ring surrounding the volume control.  Some may find it distracting (especially while driving) but I enjoy it.I find this to be a good value, especially for the money.  It didn't work for my intended (experimental) purpose but for its actual intended purpose, it seems to work fine.  (I'm not giving up on my experiment though.  Still gathering info...)NOTE:  This comes with a bare-end power connector, so all you have to do is connect it to a 12v line.  That is very convenient and a nice added extra with this item.  On the other hand, this unit is VERY low wattage (4 watts per channel). If one needs more power there are 15w and 20w similar items available on Amazon.  They cost double of course, but have the potential to produce considerably more volume through larger speakers.
Decided not to use it.tablet OK w/o it.

reviewText: I can't express how pleased I have been with this device. I got it over a year ago (for my birthday, I believe), and have been using it happily ever since! Typically, I listen in my office during work, anywhere from 2 - 8 hours per day. I've also used it in hotel rooms, at the beach, on cruises, and outside for summer parties! Never had so much as a hiccup with it! Sounds is as loud as it needs to be (I'm not expecting room-filling, surround sound with a portable speaker), it's crisp, and distortion is basically nonexistent, even at high volume. That range is also quite good. The bass isn't going to room-shaking, but it holds its one for a compact portable speaker. The battery life is as-stated and then some. I typically can easily get over 7 hours out of one charge. Fully charging doesn't take very long either, though I've never actually timed how long it take. It's small enough to take anywhere, as it doesn't take up much room in a bag or suitcase. It's durable, as I've packed it in everything from a suitcase to a plastic bag and never had an issue. It's been in damp environments and to the beach numerous times, and still works flawlessly. If I had one complaint, it's the strength of the BT signal. Unobstructed, the signal can cover 30 feet or so before the signal starts getting spotty, fully dropping out at around 40 feet. Not bad, but not great either. It gets worse with obstructions though, as even going around the corner between rooms can create interference. The signal won't completely drop, but it will get spotty quickly. However, I never expected it to pick up a BT signal much further than that, so this is a very small issue to me. Aside from that, and based off the other glowing customer service accounts, I have no complaints!

I just received this case after reading through dozens of measurements. My Nikon Coolpix 9300 fits inside with a little space, but not enough for the camera to slide about.It seems pretty well-made, and my wish was granted - to get a bag for a silly price. For a few bucks it will keep the camera from marks and scratches.So I sold my Canon A570 and my Panasonic FZ3, because the Nikon exceeded the specs of the two put together. and the Nikon, as a refurb clearout, cost as much as what I got from selling the other cameras.So hopefully the Nikon will remain pristine and keep its value in this case.

I purchased two of the HGST Travelstar Hdd for use with an Atomos Ninja-2 monitor/recorder. This particular model is one of the preferred drives for use in the Ninja. You should be very careful when installing this unit in the drive carrier provided with the recorder. The drive carrier is made from plastic and if you tighten the attachment screws too tightly you will not be able to remove the carrier easily. (My advice is to snug the screws to just even with the plastic surface...this  IS  a big deal if you do not want to disassemble the Ninja to remove the drive)

No issues mounting to the camera.  The only complaint is the thickness of the screen protector is not just a film.  It is a film/sheet with a thicker silver (not black as pictured) frame that has sharp outside corners that are not rounded or friendly.  Time will tell regarding other marketing features.update 21 June 2014:  Have to down grade the rating to 1 star due to the film no longer sticks to the screen.  Even with proper screen cleaning prior to installation I have to stick it back on the screen to use it a little while longer before throwing out.  Waste of money!

I have this kit running in Quad-Channel at 2333 MHz 10-12-11-30 1T @ 1.65v with some other timings adjusted manually.Performance is very good, read 65 GB/s, write 67 GB/s, copy 64 GB/s, with very low latency scores in AIDA64 (top of the chain at 52.5 ns on latest version)..Don't go buying these expecting your system to run at 2133 MHz or higher, it all depends on if your CPU can handle it in some cases. I'm using a Ivy Bridge E 4930k @ 4.5 GHz on a Rampage IV Gene and it works flawlessly.Able to prime95 blend test all of the memory for more than 8 hours with no errors...Overall happy that i've maxed out my system board and have plenty of bandwidth and capacity to feed all 6 cores on the CPU.
summary: High quality memory with iconic design.

reviewText: This is the second Netgear AC router I have had I had one step down from this before.  Both of them I get constant drops ont he 5g side.  I don't know what it is that Netgear can't get control of on there 5g technology, I thought stepping up on the router would maybe fix my problem but it doesn't the router is not far from the things that are running and if I switch to 2.4 it functions correctly but if I am laying in bed on my iphone connected to 5g and watching a movie streaming on my tv running off 5g both will interfere. and cause each other to drop.  So if your looking for something where you can get the best internet you can out of it I would recommend looking else wear until Netgear figures out there problem.  And this is coming from a big netgear fan everytime I buy something that has to do with networking it is netgear.

I got this Netgear AC1750 (R6300v2) to replace a Netgear WNDR3700v2. The WNDR3700v2 has treated me well for a few years now. At some point during its use, I swapped to a 3rd party firmware, and it has been running smoothly and with strong connections since then. So, replacing it wasn't a requirement, but the swap was in hopes of getting better range and faster connectivity from a newer product.Right out of the box, the Netgear AC1750 shows off a sleek, modern look. While it's good-looking hardware, the concern I have is that the grooves and air holes in the case will collect a great deal of dust. Dusting is not my strong suit, and I keep my router out in the open, so this should be fun.Of course, the guts are what matter here, so I went to plug it all in. Everything is simple to setup and configure. It even recognized my USB drive quickly and without fuss.The process consisted of the following:-Jotted down some of the important settings from my old router that I wanted to carry over (SSID, static IPs, etc.).-Reset my old router to set everything back to factory settings. Since I had 3rd party firmware on there, I had to use TFTP to get it back to factory firmware and reset everything.-Unplugged the old router and plugged everything into the new one - 4 network devices, the internet "in" cable, and a USB device.-Set my wired laptop to a static IP of 192.168.1.2 (just to avoid any complications configuring the new router).-Opened my web browser and went to 192.168.1.1 (the router's address). I was presented with a congratulation screen which gave me the default login and SSID information. I clicked on the option to "Take me to the Internet".-Went back and typed in 192.168.1.1 in the browser again, so I could finish configuration. This time the setup loaded. I logged in with the default username and password, and then started making changes.-In the Advanced section: 1) set the Wireless Setup to include my SSID and passphrase; 2) set the LAN Setup to limit the IP range to 100-187 (just to limit how many devices connect to my network) and set a few of the old static IP allocations.-Rebooted the router, and then changed the admin password. At that point, I was done on the router.-Changed my laptop back to auto-DHCP (instead of the static IP I set on it earlier), and everything was done.I plan to leave it with this firmware for now in hopes that it suffices without the need for 3rd party. 3rd party firmware has just been much more stable for me with past routers. So far, this router has held a stable connection.Range is greatly superior to the former router. I get strong signals through all 3 floors of my house and well beyond the boundaries of my yard.While I haven't run official speed tests, the speeds I witness browsing and sharing files are at least as good as the previous unit. Saying they are better would be speculating at this point though. Speed tests usually mean little to me anyway, as I only really care about what I see in real-world usage - transferring files from machines on the network, streaming data from network drives, gaming, etc.All of my devices are working great along with the router - without modification. It is handling multiple gaming systems, a multitude of streaming boxes, an assortment of laptops and desktops, smartphones, and network drives.I haven't found a need for the Genie app yet, as I make most of my changes via the browser, but it does seem like a nice addition for those that like to keep an eye on things and make changes while on the go.Overall, I am very pleased with this router, and I hope it will keep me happy for years to come.

Got this to use in the bathroom while I shower and it certainly did that well for a few weeks and then I gave it away as a gift to someone who saw me with it and said "Oh, I've been thinking about a radio like that so I can listen to the news." Presto, hers.Takes D cells so it will go forever on one pair of batteries! What you see is what you get: On/Off Volume, tuning. NO tone controls, lights, jacks, etc.Reception could be more selective, but I'm in a high-RF urban setting, so it works as expected, complete with sloppy feeling tuning, of course, just like 40 years ago!Good, cheap, classic radio, perfect for great-granpa so he can listen to his baseball!

I bought the 3TB Thunderbolt version for my iMac. I like the design of the drive and the rubber outer shell, it feels like a quality product.It's much faster than my old USB 2.0 drive and it's so quiet I can't hear it at all.Like others have said, I don't use the Seagate software, I use Time Machine and do manual backups or else Time Machine will fill up the drive quickly with a lot of redundant data. I also make sure my iMac and my drives don't sleep while I'm backing up so the drive doesn't get disconnected.It's also amazing how much the price fluctuates here on Amazon. I'm glad I caught it at a fairly low point of $229.

My Western Digital MyBook died and my Mac Mini was left without a Time Machine drive. The choices for drive replacement were daunting but I finally settled on the Backup Plus 2TB. My Mini has a 1TB Fusion drive so 2TB is more than enough space for Time Machine.Setup was a snap: plug in the wall wart and USB3 cable and it immediately mounts since it ships pre-formatted for Mac. To be on the safe side, I used Disk Utility to reformat the drive as Mac OS Extended (Journaled). I erased the WD utilities, i.e., bloatware, since they're not needed and often cause conflicts later. I opened Time Machine and selected the drive and I that's it. Auto backups on the hour!There is no power switch so Backup Plus isn't a good choice if you prefer to manually power on and off. But for auto Time Machine backups it's perfect. The included USB cable is short so you'll need an extension cable if you plan to keep it further than a couple feet away. The drive case is plastic fantastic but with a rubber-like finish, making for a sure grip if you're prone to moving your drives around. And, while I thought the silver stripe silly at first, it actually looks good and matches my Mini. The drive activity light is a tiny white LED similar to the LED on the Mac Mini, making it less intrusive than the all too common blazing blue LEDs. Finally, the Backup Plus runs cool and quiet so the only sign of disk activity is that wee LED.I've detected no compatibility problems and Time Machine backups under Mavericks 10.9 are fast and seamless. In between backups the drive spins down but quickly wakes when needed. All in all an able backup drive, easy setup and good deal.

Love it! Feels very sturdy and makes the iPad Mini Retina look more like I book. Which is great in my honest opinion!The only thing that is kind of a pain is setting up up horizontally. You have to slightly pull it off of the latches. I think I just need to get used to it.But I really enjoy this case and hope it lasts a long time!

reviewText: I purchased two of these 1 TB drives after looking for a couple portable drives to serve two different purposes,  For 65 bucks for 1 TB of space, it made sense to get this as opposed to smaller, even though I didn't quite need this much hard drive space.The first drive I got to use as an external drive for storing video from my security camera setup without straining the main hard drive on the pc server setup that I have.  Although this particular drive gave me a little issue with being recognized at first but once I disconnected it and retried it worked with no issue.The second drive which for me was most important was one that worked very well as a music drive that is compatible for my Ford Sync.  I have a lot of music as I am a huge music and movie fan but realistically I didn't really need all this space.  However, it was cheaper to buy this 1 TB drive than to get a smaller USB drive or even go with a music player such as my venerable IPOD.  I first tried using this straight out of the box only to find that the Ford Sync doesn't recognize a NTFS formatted drive.  So after reformatting the drive to make it Fat 32, I then connected to my Sync and found that it recognized right away as a USB player.  One small issue is that I noticed not all my music was syncing properly, so I used the Sync my ITunes program to fix any issues with that and also made sure I had my older ITunes with DRM fixed so that these could also play.  So far so good as this drive is working as it should permanently attached to my Ford Sync in my car.  I really didn't need all this space but for the money, it is worth getting this drive even if you will never use the space on this drive.
summary: Works ok so far as a usb drive and a Ford Sync music drive

Aside from the quirky installation issues which others have noted, the unit ran well...for a while.I had 2 WD Red 3 TB NAS Hard Drives installed.Early on, there was an unknown glitch that degraded my RAID1 setup, but I recovered from that.However, 4 months later, while no specific activity was occurring, I returned to the system to find that the RAID1 had degraded with BOTH drives becoming unallocated and unrecoverable.I lost 2Tb of data, again BOTH drives!The whole point of RAID1 is redundancy to preserve data in the event of one HDD failure, but if the controller destroys the data, well, so much for RAID.The other 5 drives on this system are fine, no system errors, no intrusions. Only the data stored on this Vantec RAID was lost.I have been working with various recovery methods for 2 weeks now, but there is little hope for ANY of the 2Tb of data on BOTH drives to be recovered. Not happy.

I knew I should not trust CNET review and still I bought it.  Well, the router is ok. It is still working after one year. However, the range and connection is just ok. Moreover, I have to reset it every several days, because my computers loose internet connection. This router was hyped so mush by different  reviewers, I feel like I was cheated.

I can't believe the difference between this router and my old one.  The external antennas alone make it worth the price.  I bought some "extension cables" for the antennas and mounted them up in my attic -- my WiFi signal is AMAZING now, all though the house!  And it sped up ALL of my wireless devices -- even the older 802.11g devices that can't see the dual-band 5GHz signal.  It's not a cheap router, to be sure, but in this case you definitely get what you pay for.The only caveat, so far, is that the firmware updates are VERY important, and they're NOT automatic (or at least the auto-update feature doesn't seem to work for me.)  So go to Asus's web-site as soon as you buy this, and make sure your firmware is up-to-date.  And don't forget to check every month or so for a new firmware update.  The good part is that updating the firmware is quite easy to do manually.The fact that this router conforms to the 802.11ac means that you're "future-proofing" yourself by buying it -- even if you don't have any 802.11ac devices yet, you will soon enough, so go ahead and buy this router.  Like I said, it even speeds up your older 802.11g and 802.11n devices a good deal, so you will see some benefit even if you don't yet own any 802.11ac devices.
