Pros: Works with PS3. 7200 RPM and big cache. 3 Year warranty. Passed bad sector check. Good price.Cons: None.Other thoughts:I got this because I needed a bigger HDD for my PS3. The max size usable with the PS3 is supposedly 1 TB. It worked fine for this. I imagine it would work with a PS4 too, but I don't have one to try it out.I have to commend Sony for making the drive so easy to replace. The biggest hassle was moving the stuff from one of my external HDDs so I could reformat it to FAT32. The backup of the PS3 took quite a while too; The data files were heavily compressed. The only problem I ran into was an error that said the backup operation could not be completed—it went away when I restarted the PS3 with the external drive already attached and powered as opposed to hooking it up when the PS3 was already running.The drive passed the Western Digital Lifeguard extended test. I started using the HGST drive tool, but it was quite bare-bones and didn't even have a “Time Remaining” on the test window, which bugged me, so I switched to the WD software. HGST is a division WDC now, but whether they would accept the results of the WD software test is anyone's guess. Something tells me they would give you a hard time about and make you re-run the scan using the HGST software. The warranty is 3 years. I have RMA-ed several WD drives without any problem. I don't know if HGST would be as easy despite being part of WD. Again, anyone's guess. Hopefully I don't need to find out.As far as performance, I'm not really sure. I didn't benchmark it when it was attached to my PC. All I can say is it doesn't seem any slower than the drive which came with the PS3, a Toshiba 320GB, I assume 5200RPM.All in all, I would recommend this drive if you need a bigger drive for your Playstation.. It's specs are better than comparably priced WD drives, and it has a better warranty.

I picked up two of these and was a little nervous based on the reviews, but I'm generally pleased with the purchase.  I've been using Xbox 360's (the 'slim' model) for several years (after briefly testing a Linksys DMA-2100; horrible), but started looking for a new solution because of the size, noise, power & heat that are part of the Xbox 360 bargain.  The Echo is literally 4"x4", totally silent, runs basically at room temp and uses very little power.  The Echo also has some extra capabilities, like being able to boot directly to live TV which was important for my set up.First thing to know when reading the reviews -- many of the are pretty old and outdated.  For example, you'll see lots of complaints about the bright glowing Ceton logo on the face of the unit... well, you can turn it off.  Also, a lot of people complain about things that are more broadly related to WMC, like the lack of wifi... well, WMC extenerds doesn't function well on wifi (try it with an Xbox 360) and this is a Windows Media Extender, so what are you going to do?Xbox One & Ceton Echo; no problems.  One of my Echo's is connected to the TV via an Xbox One using the HDMI pass through.  It works perfect.  For this type of set up, you really need to boot directly to live TV to play nice with the Xbox One's TV capabilities, so the Xbox 360 extender solution fell short.  Keep in mind, if you do this and you're components are in a cabinet, you'll need to connect an IR out to the back of the Xbox one and connect the IR eye just to the left of the "Ceton" logo.  All of the voice command/channel change stuff work great.Pros- Small footprint.  Low power, heat, etc- Easy to set up.  I was up and going in about 5 minutes.  Probably about the same complexity as connecting a new wireless router.  I did have a set up issue with one of the unites, where it was cycling between "Connecting" and black screen.  I just removed the extender from my computer and re-ran the set-up.Cons- Price.  $180 is ridiculous for this devices capabilities.  I think $80 to $100 seems like the right range.  I was able to get 2 for about $220 during a promotion. It was a little high, but in the range.- Performance is ok.  If you turn off the transition animations, you should be fine.  If you've used the old Linksys DMA-2100 extenders, don't worry, it's not like that at all.  For reference, navigating the menus feels similar to a Roku 2.- The remote is garbage, can confirm.  Throw it away and buy any other Xbox 360 remote.  Even better, there are some really great Windows Media Center remotes floating around on the internet.  If you look hard, you might find a few.Overall, I would recommend if you can buy for around $100.

This radio is very good, and its WIFI range is as good as my iPad Air.  The tone is good, but of course, it isn't an audiophile's dream.  It has very good volume, but if you crank it to full volume there is some base distortion.  Who wouldn't expect that from a small speaker in a small desktop radio.  It isn't as easy to use as an FM radio, but it doesn't take long to master the controls.  Of course, an internet radio offers more than an FM radio also.  If you already have WIFI in you home or office, this is an excellent choice for a smart radio without having to use your tablet computer or smart phone with a bluetooth speaker as a radio.I don't know about the reliability of the radio yet, but so far it seems to be most of what you would want as an internet radio.  I do wish that Logitech would make a choice of colors other than basic black.  I have never liked black radios, DVD players, stereo components and TVs, because their dials and indicators are so difficult to read from further away than a foot.  A while case with black lettering and indicators would be much better to see.

Second seller, second perceivably different product being sold. Both sold the same "HAYLCYON" Carger which works. However the batteries:HALCYON NP-FM500h do NOT have the same physical size or layout as a NP-F of any kind. They have 3 contacts( vs 2 on the NP-F ) and a much shorter body which will not fit into hardware designed for the NP-F type battery which is LONGER.The first order I was able to print out a return slip for, THIS one is telling me to contact amazon about the return due to what I assume is the 'hazardous' lithium.Be careful about buying this. It will NOT fit a regular NP-F I bought it for a F&V; 300 led light which it was  listed under regularly bought with.....
summary: DOES NOT MATCH PHYSICAL SIZE OR SPECIFICATIONS OF A NP-F, IT IS A NP-FM ( SMALLER )

This device pales in comparison to other HDMI WiFi devices out there. I have tried the Chromcast, Tronsmart, and the Cheerlink. Chromecast is complete garbage. Tronsmart is a strong device with multiple compatibility modes. Cheerlink is simple and easy to use. This product does only Miracast mirroring and nothing else. It does not support DLNA, EZCast, nor any other UPnP protocols. If you only want to mirror your device this will do it. If you are looking to cast movies or other media from your device to a TV, this is an expensive and terrible way to do it. Since mirroring leaves your device display running while also casting to a TV, it will drain your batteries very quickly, compared to Tronsmart or Cheerlink which can display to your TV and leave only a remote control on your device. I can not justify the price they ask for this device for what limited functionality it performs. It's also rather bulky, does not include a HDMI short cable, like Cheerlink does, for TVs with an obstructed port.

reviewText: Pros:+ Absolutely beautiful buttery bokeh+ Sharp enough for me+ OSS is a really nice addition+ CompactCons:- Autofocus is really poor. Hunts even in good daylight and is slow to do so.- While being a "metal" shell, I'd prefer if it were high quality plastic. I've only had it a week and it already has notable scratch and a small ding in it. I have done nothing but baby the lens and keep it protected in my camera bag. The metal, I'm guessing is aluminum and is very thin.Maybe I got a lemon with the AF on this one. It's pretty bad. I'm mostly shooting MF these days, but I wanted to have one AF lens for the times I just need AF. For being my only AF lens, this doesn't do me any good if it's not zippy.

I bought this camera to Upgrade from my Oly e-pl1 which I purchased at a closeout at Costco for $380 with the two kit lens.  I bought this camera for $254 as it was discontinued and dealers wanted to eliminate stock.The main feature I was upgrading for was the 16mp sensor which is the same as used for the top of line Oly cameras now; I like to make posters.  The em-2 only has a navigation pad and no dials so everything is done from there or the touch screen and you need to enable the SCP for efficiency and with that feature you don't miss the dials too much at all; don't forget to setup the highest resolution too.  I was really pleased with the touch screen for focus location and snapping pictures or even picture setup which is very responsive.  The 8 frames/sec is also great for action like kids.  I found the two axis stablization the same as my epl1.  Low light performance compared to the epl1 is an order of magnitude better but I don't due much low light picture taking.The body is smaller than the epl1 and almost too small for some people.The main issue I had with the system was the kit lens which has nothing to do with the camera.  Because I was looking for better resolution I did not find it using these lens which means they cannot really fully utilize the 16mp sensor.  I have an adapter for my old Nikon Nikormatte film camera and mounted its 50mm prime lens and then used my kit lens at the same aperture priority and zoom.  The old prime gave me significantly sharper pictures compared with the kit lens but of course is all manual focus and aperature.So the net is that I would have to invest in new 4/3 glass for hundreds of dollars  to really utilize the 16mp sensor as opposed to my epl1 12mp sensor which seems to be in perfect balance as a system.  As you can sense I'm an extreme shopper looking for maximum value for the dollar.I personally am returning it for this reason but for those who don't have 4/3 system you can get this camera with the two kit lens now for about $400 which is a really good deal.  For this price you cannot beat the total system value and if you add better new prime glass later you can produce some spectacular pictures in the smallest system package now available until Oly announces the pm2 replacement....................

First let's get the fact that this is not a Pentax lens out of the way. This is optically the same lens that Tamron markets in Canon, Nikon, and Sony mounts. In other words, it is a Tamron lens in Pentax clothing.I think the best way to rate this lens is to look at the pros and cons.On the pro side, I would list convenience as the main reason to purchase this lens, because it does not have much else going for it. We all want a lens that will go from a relatively wide angle to a fairly long telephoto in a small compact package. This lens fits that niche in you camera bag. It is an all-in-one walk around lens which is good for travel photography. Here I am talking about snap shooting, not serious photography. The only other plus for this lens is it's build quality, which is very nice.Now to the cons. First this lens is way over priced. I would never pay the MSRP for this lens. Right now Adorama and B&H; are both listing it at close to $800.00. The Amazon price is lower, and depending upon the seller, can be much more or much less than that price. I paid about $300 less than the Adorama and B&H; price. Folks, this is not $800 glass. It is not what I would rate as very sharp at any focal length. Although it is fairly sharp at the short to mid focal lengths, is somewhat soft at the long end. Plus, it is slow. The f3.5 at the short end is not too bad, but f6.3 at 270mm is not very good. I found the AF had difficulty at the long end finding anything to focus on, so it just quit trying. Otherwise, the SDM focus was smooth, quiet, and fairly fast. There is a AF/MF switch on the lens, and a zoom lock for storage. There was no zoom creep on the considerable zoom extension, which was quite smooth.This lens is not weather resistant, something you would expect in a Pentax lens, especially at the suggested price. Nor does it have the Pentax Quick Shift focus system we have all come to expect in Pentax lenses.I bought this lens for the convenience of not having to carry more than one lens when traveling, and not having to change lenses when visiting crowded places. I think I will continue to carry at least two lenses, because the IQ is just not there with this lens. I would recommend that you consider purchasing the PENTAX DA 18-55mm f/3.5-5.6 AL Weather Resistant Lens @ $145 and the Pentax HD DA 55-300mm f/4-5.8 ED WR @ $411 instead of this lens. Yes, you would have to changes lenses occasionally, but both of these lenses are Weather Resistant and both have the Quick Shift focus. Plus they are both better glass than the DA 18-270mm.  Both of these lenses are also available in non weather resistant versions at considerable savings.

Got this to use with Dell Venue 8 Pro, which is a 8 inch tablet PC running Windows 8.1.I wanted a keyboard that connected via Bluetooth (required), and had PgUp/PgDn/Home/End keys, or at least has them mapped to arrow keys, since when editing text in Windows and Google Docs you use these ALL THE TIME.And I wanted it to be easy to type on.  That means no missing/shoved-over Shift key, no missing row of Fkeys, no teeny-weeny scrunched together letter keys (hello, Ebay cheapo tablet keyboards), no Command key where the Alt key should be (hello, Apple mini wireless keyboard and clones), and no Fn keys mapped by default to system-specific functions like brightness and volume (hello, Android and Apple clone keyboards).  This one seems to have it all.  The key spacing is awesome.  Plus backlighting, one of the Ultrabook/MacBook Air features I love.Now the real surprise bonus.  I can finally map CapsLock to Ctrl, and map it back to some other key.  Meaning, I still have CapsLock when I really want to shout at someone.  Somehow this has never been possible with the standard keyboard remapping software out there (which twiddles some registry settings).  But, with Logitech's SetPoint software (required to get the Fkeys to not map to things like media keys by default), you can also remap three of them (F4/task switcher, F11/Home, and F12/Calculator) to a variety of other functions, including a keypress of your choice.  Well, it turns out that if you map that to CapsLock, and then use a remapping program (I used SharpKeys) to remap CapsLock to Ctrl, you've still got your CapsLock (only now it's Fn+F4).  Done!  Awesome.By the way, their SetPoint software (which appears as an icon in the tool tray) also took over management of my Dell bluetooth mouse, and remapped the wheel button to "Scroll" (which I promptly un-mapped back to "Middle click"), but also let me remap the side buttons and wheel left/right.  So that was a second surprise bonus right there.  (Presumably it will do similar things with other mice, though I haven't tried it.)It also monitors both devices' battery condition, which I'm sure will be useful.  So this is one 78 MB download that seems to be worthwhile (unlike some -- hello, HP inkjet printer driver).So there you have it.  Highly recommended.  There's a Mac-specific version also  (presumably it has the usual Apple keys in the bottom left corner), the K811.  Maybe there'll be full-sized ones as well.  I'd buy those, too.Wishlist for the next version: Include real PgUp/PgDn keys so I wouldn't have to use two hands to navigate documents.  Have some kind of kickstand that folds out at the bottom rear so I don't have to lean it on a pen to get the right angle.  Make a full-sized (full-width) version including the keypad.  Include (or offer) a neoprene carrying case so I don't have another laptop one flopping around in my backpack.
summary: Surprise bonuses for the very power user

reviewText: This enclosure presents all drives to the OS as the device name 'asmedia ASM1053E' instead of passing the full drive manufacture and model, like every other enclosure out there.  This makes it less useful in our IT business, as we use these on our workstation for data recovery and backup imaging.  If we run multiples of these on a workstation, we need to know the exact information for each drive on a machine, which is impossible with this device.  We can get by for now with pieces of paper of the client name and drive size stuck under the enclosures, but when taking backup snapshots prefer to pass the entire name plus the client name to the server instead of just the client name.  i.e. SAMSUNG_HD321KJ_Joe_Smith_date instead of joe_smith_date - because we like to track that info.  Still - the drive does move data at a good speed so there is that.

In this day of SSD (Solid-State Drive) devices, it's hard to get worked up about performance with a 5,400 RPM conventional SATA hard drive, unless one takes a closer look at price vs. performance. And then there's capacity and reliability to consider.ThisTOSHIBA PH2100U-1I54 1TB 5400 RPM 8MB Cache SATA 3.0Gb/s 2.5" Internal Notebook Hard Drivehas respectable performance numbers, but it's no SSD screamer... and for the price, it's an excellent product. From past experience, there is not an astonishing performance difference between 5,400 RPM and 7,200 RPM hard drives. The SSDs will probably boot up and shut down faster depending on your equipment and configuration, but the cost difference to get a 1TB SSD is substantially higher.I personally looked initially at this Toshiba hard drive as a replacement for the original HDD in myApple MacBook Pro 13-Inch Laptop, effectively doubling its existing capacity. It's not a difficult process for those who have done it before and are already running the built-in OS X Time Machine backup utility. In any case the Apple forums offer plenty of how-to advice on this topic.For now this Toshiba hard drive is being used to back up my upgraded Windows 8.1 PC notebook, and it's almost effortless. Had earlier purchased aPlugable Storage System USB 3.0 2.5" SATA Drive Dockalong with the extraPlugable Storage System 2.5" SATA Hard Protective Case (2-Pack), and this combination makes it all quite simple. One mounted in the case, the Toshiba HDD was recognized immediately, and it was simple to set it up for backups in minutes.If you're looking for performance on the level that gaming enthusiasts desire, this is perhaps not the right drive for you. It has a respectable transfer rate of up to 3.0Gb/s, but with notebook SSHD (Solid State Hybrid Drive) products that offer rates up to 6.0Gb/s, this one may disappoint. Its strengths lie in low power consumption, adaptive (variable) power modes, internal shock detection and ramp loading technology (vibration reduction) to help protect your drive and your data. And these are just the right features to make this an excellent backup hard drive.Perhaps the best things about thisTOSHIBA PH2100U-1I54 1TB Internal Notebook Hard Driveare that it is fully compatible with Windows 8.x, Windows 7, Windows XP, Vista, Mac OS X and Linux, as confirmed by Toshiba. It runs very quietly, and having a 3-year limited warranty makes this a good one.JW ▪ 1/26/2014
summary: Toshiba 2-inch Notebook Hard Drive: Quiet, great backup HDD and a 3-year warranty

reviewText: If you know how install a SATA drive into a desktop computer you should have no problem at all with this drive. Installation was simple, straightforward. You will need a SATA data and power cable and free space in your desktop computer. With that, installation took all of 10 minutes. It would have been nice to have the cable included like in a recent samsung drive that I purchased and installed. Access time is quick, a no louder than any of my other drives. My experience has been for just over a month, so I cannot speak to drive longevity.The primary concern that you must be aware of when purchasing this is that it is advertised as a 3 TB drive and I received and am reviewing a 2 TB drive. I received my drive as a review version. But it looks like some who have purchased the drive received 2 TB drives as well. So if 3 TB is a must for you, I might stear clear of this, or at least be prepared to return it if you do indeed receive the 2 TB drive.
summary: 2 TB Drive: Easy To Install, So Far No Problems

reviewText: This is like my old English Jaguars, so I bought two.  One for use, the other in the shop being fixed.It's no exaggeration to say that when I handle my M240 it makes me better than Cartier-Bresson.  After all, that poor fellow used film, was clueless about Photoshop and had to manually set everything. He must have snapped a lot of images to luck out with the few grainy, blurred ones that sadly pass for art today.  I mean, that guy jumping the puddle?  Hello, motion blur.  Had he used an M240 he could have cranked up the ISO and shutter speed and bingo!, a sharp snap.  Why, he could have taken 9 in that one second and chosen the best.  Boy, would the old man have killed for the high speed motor drive in my M240s or what?  Goodness knows, he really needed it.As for the Leica 'glow' in the images, they are instantly distinguishable, though I find I get less glow after I clean my new $8,000 Asph Summicron with a pocket handkerchief to remove the residue from my Romeo y Julieta Cubans.  (I have a man who works for the embassy here …. embargoes are for the little people)  I accidentally spilled some Cristal on the front element the other day at the Greenwich estate but, with typical Leica reliability, it soldiers on, though the focus movement seems a bit sticky and I appear to have some deposits in the lens.  We Leica users call that ‘character’. And the glow improved, so I recommend this treatment to all Leica lens users.My Noctilux cannot seem to nail focus at f/1.0, which is a bit disappointing as I paid $20,000 for it on the black market to beat the queue, so I generally use it at f/5.6 or lower, but it's worth it for the rendering and depth of color alone.  And even when it’s out of focus, which is much of the time,  the Bokeh renders those defocused blobs like nothing on earth. In fact my first attempts at f/1.0 were all badly out of focus, but I kept them anyway, and fellow Leica users are all astonished at what the lens can do.  That’s the sort of 100% success rate only Leica can deliver.  And, let's face it, the Nocti and M240 scream success, once others see that huge front glass and the red dot.  This combo delivers a frisson no Canon or Nikon using poseur will ever experience.  Only a Leica says ‘photographer’ in that special, indefinable way.And what makes this so much better than all those years with my M2, M3, M4, M6, M7 and MP (yup, all in my China cabinet, with the original boxes, under 6 rolls of film put through each) is that my $150,000 of Leica glass has never been happier, even if I do have to pull the battery now and then when the M240 freezes just as I press the button for another capture of a dozen Decisive Moments.  But the fact that I only missed a hundred or so great images in my first month of ownership is nothing compared to the thrill I get just holding the M240.  I can't wait for the gold plated special edition which should match my Rolex collection nicely.  And with the gold limited edition at least you won’t find all your close friends using one also.One final benefit.  When my M240 locks up and fails to respond to the battery thing, I put it on the mantlepiece and just admire it, while enjoying a glass of Courvoisier L’Esprit.  Just like my Jags, it's actually nicer to look at than risk using among the hoi polloi which litter our world.Let's face it.  You either appreciate and own the finest that the world has to offer or you are never going to take a good picture.
summary: You either get it or not

reviewText: I have wanted a professional photography studio and this one fits the bill. I transport it to client's homes and it is an easy setup. I have been looking for an inexpensive IPS display to replace my crappy Acer TN monitor. Around a week ago, I purchased a Dell S2340M from Best Buy for around $170 (after taxes and an Amazon price match). I figured that it wouldn't hurt to share my opinion of it; perhaps somebody will find this post helpful.First, this is a well-made monitor. I considered getting the Acer H236HL bid because it was slightly cheaper, but I quickly changed my mind when I saw it side-by-side with the S2340M. The glossy stand looks professional and does a good job of keeping the monitor stationary; knocking the sides of the display causes minimal juddering, and the base does not move. The panel's glossy finish looks very nice, but you should take care to avoid setting the monitor up near bright lights. Also, the plastic bottom lip of the display does not look or feel cheap, unlike the lip on the H236HL. I find the S2340M's dim white power indicator to be much less distracting than the blue ones on most monitors; I think that the subtlety of it contributes to the monitor's attractive design as well.I have been very happy with the performance of the S2340M. I mostly use it for gaming and movies, with a bit of Photoshop periodically. With this being my first IPS panel, I was very impressed with the vividness of the colors. I love being able to lean back in my seat and not have any colors suddenly wash out. I made some changes with Windows 8.1's color calibration tool when I first hooked up the monitor, but the default configuration didn't look that bad. When it comes to gaming, the S2340M has a response time of 7ms, compared to my old monitor's 5ms time. I am not a hardcore/competitive gamer, so that is not a big issue for me. I did notice some ghosting while playing Titanfall, but only when I made a point of looking for it.This monitor does have its faults, but none of them are bad enough to make me regret my purchase. First, it only has VGA and DVI inputs. I only use DVI, so that's not an issue for me. It might be a problem if you connect multiple devices, since the VGA input will look noticeably worse than the DVI one. By the way, the monitor only comes with a VGA cable, so make sure you have your own DVI cable. Second, there are no VESA mounting holes, and the stand only allows for vertical tilting. I did a little bit of searching, and you can actually buy custom VESA adapters for this monitor on Ebay if you want to mount it. Speaking of the stand, I had a hard time inserting the monitor into it. Pushing it in 2/3 of the way was easy, but I needed to apply much more pressure to completely secure it. I was afraid of breaking something, but it eventually went in.If you're looking for an IPS monitor under $200, you should get the S2340M. Its impressive design and beautiful display make it a great deal. Although you might be able to find the Acer H236HL bid for slightly less, the superior build quality of the S2340M justifies spending the extra money. There are better dedicated gaming monitors in the same price range, but the S2340M's rich colors make for a better experience in more usage conditions.
summary: Great monitor at a great price. Better than the competition.

With nearly 4000 reviews for this Chromebook, I don’t think I could really add anything that hasn’t already been said.  Still, with all the attacks on this convenient little computer I did feel the need to add my two cents.  Our Samsung Chromebook has served us well over the past 8 months.  I used it for the first 6, and then passed it to my son when I purchased an Acer C720.  We have had absolutely no problems with the Samsung, and it has been fun watching Chrome OS evolve and improve over time.  The Chromebooks have shown me that I really don’t need an expensive Windows machine for my home computing needs.  In fact, within a month of owning this computer I had totally abandoned my Windows laptop.  We use the Chromebooks for all manner of web surfing, Netflix, Hulu Plus, Amazon Instant Video, chatting and video calls with Hangouts, creating, editing, and printing documents with Google Docs,  listening to music with Google Play, and I’m even going to use a Chromebook for my taxes this year.  Even though some of the next generation Chromebooks are offering improved speed and longer battery life, this little machine is still an excellent choice for many users.  I also believe that this Chromebook will be remembered as the first affordable Chrome OS device that really brought Chrome computing to the masses.

Went back to college, wanted something light and compact and NOT Windows based.  Been using it for almost a month now and I love it.  Built in virus protection and it automatically updates Chrome so you always have the latest version.  Tons of apps, too.  I also love that it boots up in less than 10 seconds, I put in my password, and it is loaded.  No waiting for Microsoft Windows to load, which seems to take forever.

I noticed a obvious and significant difference immediately in sound and picture quality! excellent unit. Easy to use, quick set up, wifi capable. The only disappointment is no Amazon Prime.Very happy with this purchase.
I really believe that this product compares favorably with the biggest brand names available. Incredible sound. Incredible performance. Incredible comfort.

The Motorola S11 Flex does everything it says it does.  It has an awesome style, the volume level is sufficient when biking fast, the button layout is easy and intuitive, and it is comfortable over long distances.  The ability to receive and even make calls using voice commands is a great addition.  I have noticed that when biking at high speeds, it may not recognize your voice command, but I was pretty much expecting that.I have an average size head and although I do notice that it fits tightly, I think that is almost essential, especially when playing sports, because you don't want it falling off on you.  I have not noticed it being overly tight (as some reviewers have said) to it being painful or uncomfortable.Overall, I love these headphones and think that Motorola did a great job in the design and functionality.  I would certainly recommend them for music / receiving calls while running, biking, rollerblading or playing any other moderately active sports.
summary: Works Great, Good Sound, Great Style, Stays On Your Head

I got the 512 GB model.I was using a different brand SSD and even though it was fast, my Windows 7 score was only 7.3.  I'm using my old SSD as a data drive and this drive as my system drive.  This drive raised my score to 7.9 and it's a noticeable speed increase.  I have a little over 200 GB on it and creating a system image of it to my old SSD took about 10 minutes.When installing the drive, I used a system image from a 300 GB hard drive and it worked good.  Soon as I started Windows 7, I used Administrative Tools / Computer Management / System Storage and extended the size of the drive up to it's full capacity.I also like the Magician software that comes with the drive.  I think using the software made the drive even faster.If you register your drive at Samsung, it adds 3 months to your warranty.

I installed this drive in my Macbook Pro. It boots up in about 12 seconds with Safari ready to connect to the internet. Since Apple does not support Trim, I have installed a patch to allow for longevity of the drive.My only concern is warranty. Before buying this drive, I suggest you try calling customer service...just to see if they answer...I have INTEL drives too. I called them to be sure that I had the latest Firmware and I was surprised to get a live person on the line to talk to. With Samsung drive, I got the latest Firmware information from the web. The support is scant.So far the drive has been reliable and the performance is wonderful.

I finally decided it was time to upgrade from my 60GB Agility 3 boot drive.  Not only does this drive have a better capacity, but it also boasts better speeds.  So far it has not failed  to deliver.  I can now install a few games on the boot drive without worrying about filling it up.  I have no measured either SSD I've used in terms of benchmarks, but there is a noticeable difference in cold boot time between the two.  My only regret is that my budget didn't allow me to get an 840 Pro with a larger capacity.

The application went on smoothly without any bubbles. However, due to the thickness of the screen protector, touch sensitivity was reduced. My Bamboo stylus does not write as smoothly as it did without the protector shield. Ended up taking it off. The removal process was effortless though and did not leave any streaks.
summary: Great protection, but touch sensitivity is not as great.

reviewText: It is very very difficult to put the tip into the kindle.  It broke within one week of purchase, not recommended.
summary: Very hard to insert into kindle. Broke in 1 week.

reviewText: Best purchase I have made since my snow tires. I use it all the time snowboarding. Takes amazing video. GoPro is above and beyond anything on the market as far as these type of cameras go.
I tried getting three of these working with my Macbook Air and they simply do NOT work.  I also tried one of them on a Macbook Pro, and again, NOT compatible.
summary: Not compatible with Macbook Air or Pro laptops

reviewText: Links well to my Kindle and Samsung Galaxy, and gives me a BIG sound, good enough for a family reunion or backyard BBQ.  Definitely excellet value.  Its dual function as a handsfree unit is a big plus, too!
summary: Big sound in a small unit

reviewText: If you only need to have basic horizontal adjustment and angling inward for a dual monitor setup this work well. I'm using it with two 24" Asus Monitors from 2013. I think heavier monitors (by function of age of size) might be better suited to a sturdier stand. The Asus panels are rather light.Setup was pretty easy but it might help to have 2 people. I found it easier to just attach the monitors to the mounting plate and then attach it to the vertical bar (hence the need for 2 people, it's a bit awkward to carry once the monitors are attached).
Works great with my macro lens.  Love the feature of the two leds to help focus my lens.  I use with my Nikon D7100 and Nikon 85mm lens.

I bought this as an extra cable as all of our iOS devices have moved to Lightning.  It's about 35% cheaper than the official apple cable, so I thought I would try it out.It properly charges my iPhone 5s while plugged into a standard Apple 1A charger.As others have mentioned, the Lightning connector is slightly larger than the Apple connector.  However, it fits my iPhone 5s with a lightweight back-only case.  It fits my iPad Mini with a smart cover.  It also just fits my wife's iPhone 5s with a Lifeproof Fre case.
summary: Great cable for less than Apple

reviewText: Overview:These R1's are dual driver in-ear earphones. Dual driver earphones are like 2 way speakers for your ears. They're better than the usual single driver earphones because 2 drivers can cover the audio range much better than 1. In this case, the two drivers are 6.8mm and 9mm.Sound:I found the bass to be very good, it's strong and the first thing I noticed. The dual drivers aren't a gimmick and the woofer really does its job well. The 6.8mm driver covers the high to mid range pretty well. In music without much bass, I found the mid range to be best. Overall, I found the sound to be balanced more to the low end.Extras:As with most of the Brainwavz products, I found this set of earphones to be loaded with extras. I won't list them all here as they can be found on their website but they include loads of extra tips, airplane adapter, hard case and a 1/4" audio adapter.Thoughts:Price wise, these dual driver earphones are at the low end of the spectrum and their performance far exceeded my expectations. They are not cheapo dual drivers, they really perform. And the design is full of little touches. The drivers are side by side and if you look into the grill you can see that the drivers' output is separated from each other by a divider for better frequency dispersion. Furthermore, the cable at the earpieces have a stiffer covering that will retain its shape so there is no need for ear hooks. It's these little touches which make this brand stand out for me.Summary:You can find dual driver earbuds at much higher prices, but these R1 earbuds at this price is an absolute steal. They perform very well and the ton of extras that come with it make it an excellent value. Sample provided for review.

This is a great device. Lots of features. 5 Ghz range is bad, but I've found 5 Ghz to be bad on all access points I've used. But that's the nature of 5 Ghz. Anyway, the only device I could recommend that's better than this is the Cisco Aironet access points, but they start at twice the price.

This monitor is not exactly cheap for its size and quality. I bought it because it is just beautiful. But, while I'm happy with the quality of the picture, I'm not happy with the monitor overall and would not recommend it.The good:1) It really is a beautiful monitor, and the picture quality is great as well.2) It comes with an HDMI cable, an audio cable and a nifty microfiber clothThe bad:1) The screen itself wobbles on the stand. It's on there firmly and won't fall off, but it just doesn't feel secure. It tilts a little and I was able to position it in a way that it's more or less level, but I really shouldn't be able to tilt it at all.2) The audio stinks. One of the reasons I bought it was because it had HDMI audio, but it really is pretty bad. And I'm not an audiophile.3) The controls are just awful. It should be way more intuitive. I'm still trying to figure out how to turn down the brightness while blindly fiddling around with buttons on the back of the monitor. They should be easier to access and power\brightness need to be EASY to manage.4) The image is not edge to edge like you might imagine. The pictures show it correctly, and other reviewers have mentioned this. The image does in fact have a black bezel around it, there is just no physical plastic bezel. This is still way more attractive than most monitors out there, but it is not edge to edge picture.Overall, I would not recommend this product. I fell in love with its beauty, but am disappointed overall, especially by the inaccessibility of the controls. I just want to turn my brightness down, please!
summary: Wish I had gone with something else

reviewText: I really like the quality of this leather cover. It is exactly as it is described. As a new iPad mini owner, however, I did not really realized the full extent of my own 'needs' from/for a cover/case.Several weeks after owning this Kavaj case, I realized that it does not really suit my functional needs, because it simply cannot display the iPad in "movie" mode - which is to say support it at a decent viewing angle horizontally oriented for viewing something like Amazon Prime movies or shows, or Netflix or whatever.It has a great typing angle - and it is made of excellent, beautiful leather that is thick/thin in all of the right places. The fit and finish are excellent and it's way better than pleather.BUT - I am probably NOT going to use it 90% of the time - at least at home - because in the end the Moshi Versacover is FAR more functional, lighter, and simply does everything that a lightweight cover should do in providing a stand that works at a reading angle, a movie viewing angle, and even a portrait view angle.So - that is why I cannot (for me) give this case 5 stars. Unless someone can tell me HOW it CAN be used in movie angle (which Moshi describes as 60%...whatever that exactly means).
summary: Like it a lot except that I had to buy a different brand in the end to get a movie viewing angle (Moshi Versacover)

reviewText: It's okay for a kid. Piece of crap if you ask me. I would get a better one for my kids when they are older.

This iPad is simply amazing,the picture it is so clear. The controls are all very convenient. I like all the features it has too. Just another great apple product. I have a iMac  too. This is just for traveling with me everywhere I go. It matches up with my iMac and my iPhoneyou could say we are an apple family except I also have two laptops that are not apple. I enjoy computers and the technology they bring.

I had a iPad 1 and needed to upgrade because many of the current apps are being written for IOS 7. I expected an iPad having minor scratches or slight indications of wear, especially on the back metal case. The iPad arrived in a fully packaged retail package and I'm hard pressed to find any wear. After using several months, still very pleased.
summary: Purchased this reconditioned iPad but not sure if it's an actually previously used.

reviewText: I would recommend this product to anyone looking for a cable modem. I bought  to replace a rental from a cable company. This on works better that their so called high price model.
Finally a technology that my wife is comfortable with. We have Windows 8 on the PC and Windows cell phones, so this fits seamlessly into our life.

I needed a smaller, lighter and more compact tripod. This one looked to fill the bill for going on holidays rather than carrying my tank of a tripod I typically use. I found it to be acceptable, but folding it up over and over to return it to it's carrying case made the swivel locks get loose and harder to control when unfolding it again to set up. The legs get loose and "flop" and constantly require tightening with the 2 allen wrenches supplied.I am using a Canon 60D with a Canon 18-200mm lens being my longest, heaviest lens. It holds up OK for weight and balance, but the locks for the legs are not so easy to lock in and feel safe,There's 2 ways to lock the legs into place with the narrowest being a bit too close and flimsy for oa heavier camera. I use the 2nd lock (wider stance) and it stands better but IS flimsy when the legs are fully extended. If the locks were better I would give this a 4 rating. The ball head is not bad for a small tripod and the quick connect is OK, but small for a larger DSLR.All in all OK for trips, but I'll use my Slik 500 Pro for the most part.

I upgraded from a sound card to this external dac/amp and its outstanding compared to my old setup. Absolutely no fuzz what so ever, the only downside being the white LED they crammed below the tube amp it is really not needed though I don't really care. Another downside would be cellphone interference; I didn't notice it at first but soon caught on to a slight funny sounding crackling noise when I sat down after a day of work, I eventually noticed that it happened increasingly when I was receiving text messages so I just put the amp/dac off to the side and my cellphone on the other side of the desk and I have had no further problems.

After reviewing all projectors up to $2,500.00 , This was the best rated on the market by C-net and they were right ! The 3D and HD  is the best .The price was very good ( $900 +- ) and very easy to install and set up .

I needed to replace a ViewSonic Pro8100 projector that served me well for 4 years, but after a thunderstorm, the HDMI ports on the ViewSonic stopped receiving a signal (side note: be sure to ground your main input coax cable.  Verizon did not do this, hence I lost HDMI functionality on a projector and a receiver during a thunderstorm).I was hoping to replace with something that gave me at least the same performance as what I had, and I was thrilled that this projector exceeded my old ViewSonic in each and every category.Even in Eco mode, this projector delivered a much brighter, clearer picture than what I had before.  Also, the throw distance on this projector is quite short, which is a huge advantage even if you have the space for a long throw (since you can get a larger projection size for a given throw distance, or reduce the zoom level for a given projection size and given throw distance).  For me, I was able to significantly reduce the zoom level to almost the minimum in order to keep my 150" projection size.  As a result, i was able to get an incredibly sharp, and bright picture.My unit shipped with the 1.07 version firmware, and I have not found any handshaking or HDMI detection issues when used in conjunction with my Denon receiver.  I believe there is a 1.08 firmware version out now, but I will pass on attempting to update the firmware since all is working perfectly.  I have heard that units that are below the 1.06 version may experience HDMI detection issues, but it looks as if the new units are shipping with 1.07 or later, so you should be good to go right out of the box.I also ceiling mounted this projector with the same universal ceiling mount as I had my previous projector, and I think that most universal ceiling mounts should work just fine using M4 screws to attach to the projector.
Nice compact unit with ample signal strength to service a laptop, 2 Kindles. Easy to set up/install within several minutes

wow I have had a history of having problems connecting router and other network stuff. But this one was really easy I followed the instruction and it was up and running in about 5 minutes from pulling it out of the box and haft that time was unhooking are old outdated router and old slow wifi router no more bottlenecks
This router was very easy to install and it worked like a charm right away.  Very light weight and compact.  I haven't had any problems with it and would highly recommend it.

I really think that invokes the Streisand Effect whenever companies go after things in the wrong way.  A legitimate business would try to make better products and offer better service and move up in the world.
summary: I don't like when companies threaten reviewers

reviewText: Used to have a piece of junk modem/router combination from my cable provider; finally decided to get my own modem and router. Glad I chose this one. Very fast, very reliable, all my devices connect instantly and are handled very well.UPDATE - 5/30/14I noticed all the recent negative reviews for the product...not seeing why; I've had this router for over half a year now with no issues. The router was very easy to set up and my signal has always been strong; I've constantly got my laptop, tablet, phone, and PS3 sucking bandwidth like crazy and I've never had any issues.

I have to say, after learning what this router is, learning how they treat their customers and reviewers, and reading the high number of 5 star reviews, I want to tag every 5 star review on the router so that I know that those people are shills who can not be trusted to have an honest opinion.  Amazon should do something about this.
summary: apparently trying this router and reporting on it causes one to break out in lawsuits.

reviewText: This really throws the signal in our house - and I was worried about the "internal antennas!"  Turns out there's nothing to worry about - the Wireless-N is fast - and it's easy to set up and maintain.  And the price. Great.

First off, I would like to say that everything works as advertised. Some reviewers have mentioned Wifi connectivity problems but there are none. I suggest them to read the instructions carefully and try again.This being a class 10 card, is fast as compared to the previous generation. I have successfully set it up in Direct share and hotspot mode on an Android handset. Also setup in both modes from laptop. Next up is hacking it to enable root access :)This card has IPhone and Android apps to do most of the stuff. But even without them, same things can be done in any browser by visiting card's IP address.Excellent card. Definitely recommended. Only downside is the price,  $30 - 35 should have been good.

These headphone work pretty darn good considering the cost.  All the adapters are super helpful.  I use the 9" 3.5mm to 2.5mm adapter for the house roam phone.  I just leave the 9" pigtail in the roam phone at my desk.  When I get a call that needs a headset, I plug the headset into the pigtail.  If I need a headset for my cellphone, I unplug it from the 2.5mm adapter and plug the headset directly into my cellphone, which is a 3.5mm phono plug.  And for the computer, there's an Y adapter that plugs into the two PC plugs, one for headphone and one for mic.  The sound quality is pretty good considering the cost, OK for occasional use, however it's not mean for listening to music.  Good for skype calls.  Good buy, so far it's great, but I've only had it a couple days.

I put this stereo in a party bus.i gave 4 stars because It will not let us bypass the video to play while in drive. Kinda disaponted.  Customers have to put the movie in and out 2 times to get it to work right. Other then that it's does the job and is sleek.

The naming scheme on these are way to similar to each other. Amazon is awesome and took this back with just a $5 shipping charge. I ended up having to get another one that only had a difference of one letter in the name. Be careful!!
summary: Make sure you get the right one!

reviewText: I tried this unit and the Brookstone. I kept the Brookstone because for my needs, it's better. The view sonic is brighter, so for anything but dark rooms, it wins. It does create a lot of heat. I'm in a small office and that was not acceptable. They both are a little noisy, but if you can sit far away from the units, no problem. The picture on the Brookstone, though darker, looks more like a movie should look.The Veiw sonic, even with it's adjustments still looks less cinematic. I returned the Viewsonic. It's not bad, but I did prefer the Brookstone of rite's small size, lack of heat, and more cinematic picture.
summary: Brookstone DLP preferred by me to this unit.

reviewText: This is exactly what I needed.  It holds my Fire  securely, doesn't obstruct the plugs or buttons.  Connecting to bluetooth is effortless because the on/off button is right on the keyboard.  The color is rich and I love everything about it.  Can't say enough, can you tell? I've bought cases for my other Kindles and for iPad's and this tops them all.

I type here with my moko keyboard: it's, small, convenient, relatively easy to use once you figure out where the backspace key is going to be without looking... overall the case is great, and the keyboard is relatively good.  I did have once concern... the "t" key started being less responsive today... it felt kind of heavy, so I hit it a bunch of times and it seems to be better now.  But the concern is that I don't know if I can replace the keyboard... I found nothing on amazon implying I could buy just the keyboard.  It looks like it will probably die in 4 months, which seems rather short for the purchase price.
summary: Nice Case, Like Keyboard, Concerned about Replacement Keyboard.

reviewText: This music receiver is small but has a strong range, and just because it is compact doesn't diminish the quality of sound. It pairs to both phones and tablets very easily and automatically reconnects when you come in range. It is compact and requires no external powered adapter because it's all in one. It allows two (mobile) devices to be connected at the same time. One aspect that is not often mentioned is that it has both 120 and 240 voltage - handy for trips. The connection is fast, the manual is more than adequate and it includes a 1amp USB charging port so that you can charge your phone while listening to music programmed.  Another example of marrying design with function - both are tops here. Grady Harp, January 14
summary: THIS is a very handy device

reviewText: This writer does the job well...simple to set up... after being plugged in using usb it recognizes it, on my computer it doesn't recognize and set up the cd programs... I have tried this on windows 8 & 7, same problem. Good thing for me, I don't need the cyberlink program because I use sony to edit & make my videos. After I make & render my videos I run the bluray off my sony program, and it recognizes the LG bluray writer right a way... so I put a blank copy in & start to burn... sometimes I use the LG to render & burn, but either way it does a great job making 1920 1080p videos... I use large files with plenty of chapters, and inserts of other video on video scenes... only thing is it takes forever when burning large files like this, one video that lasts about 1hr and a half took almost 24hrs. to render & burn, but the quality was perfect... just had to be patient. I like it, after making the first master, I can make copies that take approx. 6 to 10min. each. I can make approx. 60 high definition pictures using raw files that had been edited with music, this can be rendered & burned in about 20min. So I recommend this writer... works for me without using it's Cyberlink program.

These headphones would just not connect after a little while. We tried and tried but they were just a pain to have to keep removing them and re-adding them to my computer. We did not try to contact the manufacturer about this issue.

I try it on my old XTi with a sigma lens before put it on my 6d. After few test, the 13 mm focus fine, but the 21mm cause some problem on focus. It keep move back and forward around the focus point. I thought it not too bad, I can use the manual focus as work around any how.The worse part has not come, while shooting with the macro on, I try adjust the aperture  to in crease the deep of fields. After few shoots, I notice the aperture was death. It was never closed while capturing.I know for sure it failed because I did try the "DoF test button" few times while shootings, then it suddenly stop working. Carefully remove the extension, and try on directly, no hope. I have tried two other lenses with my body to confirm the body still function normally.Got to say good bye to my lens after many years. Directly focus still work, but the aperture failure. It could just be the day has come for the lens, but it came when I put on the extension which make me so nervous to try the extension on my other lenses.
It may have been a waste of money, but after spending a wad of cash on the Dragonfly, I wanted the best chance of improved audio.
summary: Pricey but no proof of improved function.

reviewText: Very speedy shipping, got it in the mail about 3 days after I ordered it.  It was partially charged as another reviewer noted, so I charged it up to 100% and then drained it.  Cycled it twice so far.  Have been able to get over 5 to 5 1/2 hours of life on one full charge, this is with my Macbook Pro mid 2010 running a couple of applications, without the screen dimmed for energy saver, and playing videos on and off (probably for at least an hour or so).  That's good enough for me, considering the Apple store was going to charge me $129 for a new battery.  I ordered a tri wing screwdriver from Ebay that was for the Nintendo but it was a tad too small and stripped one of the screws.  Went to Fry's Electronics and found another one that was labeled size 00 (although I think 0 might actually be the correct size from googling the internet), was able to remove one of the screws but the other one was too stripped to unscrew, so I ended up taking a flat head screwdriver and breaking off pieces of the plastic being held down by the screw (it was part of the old battery so didn't matter to me if I broke it).  This worked, after the plastic was gone, I used a pair of small pliers to turn the screw and unscrew it.  Was able to put in the new battery with no issues and didn't tighten the screws as much this time! Aside from this little challenge, this purchase was well worth it.

I don't know why I never noticed this before, but annually, I was paying more than the cost of this modem in rental charges to my cable internet provider.  Worse, they never bothered to let me know that my rental modem was at least one DOCSIS standards out of date and not able to reach the speeds I was paying for.So, I bought this and returned the rental.  First, verify that your internet provider is compatible with this modem, which mine was.  In fact, it was specifically listed on their web site of compatible devices.Has been working great since 8/13.  Setup through my cable internet provider was very simple and required zero interaction with them.  That is a bonus for the cable internet provider, I suppose.
summary: Works well, saves cable modem rental charges

reviewText: Great router add on. No issues at all. You'll make 840 in ten years if you're charged 7 dollars to rent a modem, this will allow you to buy up to 8 new modems or 4 high end routers in the future or even help towards a new computer. This is a must if you hate Comcast fees as much as I do.
summary: Saves you money in the long run.

reviewText: Finally decided to but my own modem as I was tired of paying TWC a rental fee.  It took a little time to set it up as I was on the phone both with the cable company and my  router company  for assistance but once all the information was given I was up and running just fine.  I definitely recommend this modem.
Great item and seems well made.

I'm relatively new to the world of external hard drives and just learning about RAID etc.But I hear you should have three units that are all the same brand and size to make RAID work effectively.I've been using these LaCie d2 Quadras for a few years now just to store precious files and photos.But recently I've begun video editing and require more storage and a faster drive.I don't really know how this one compares to other more expensive and industry standard versions,but as a newbie, and for the price, it seems fine for now.I have three of these (two are 2 TB) in a Quadra tower. Very neat, they stay cool, and so far even my much older fourthLaCie with only 1TB seems to be working fine.very good product.Just whatever you do, do NOT accidentally unplug their USB plugs unless you properly unmount or eject them from your desktop.  I had a Rugged LaCie (portable, orange exterior)  lose all it's data from it accidentally coming loose from my laptop.The was much teeth gnashing and wailing that day, I assure you.
Selected this unit from determining the amount of power that will be used now and in the future from expansion and the price.  Expect no problems and pleased with warrantee.
summary: Selected item for first PC build

reviewText: I purchased this as a gift for my cousin. We tried it when he opened it, it seems to be of a sturdy build quality and the view were very crisp and clear. He seemed to enjoy it. I haven't followed up with him on using it yet and how he likes it.
Easy to use.  Lots of megapixels.  Fantastic selection of scene modes. I love the scan panoramas!  Small enough to fit in my wife's purse!

I love this camera.  I spent 3 weeks deciding between three brands but the reviews of the Fuji sold me. This is not a DSL with interchangeable lenses but the supplied lens is amazing.  It is a little hefty, which I actually like, due to it's aluminum internal case and big lens vs. plastic for all others I considered.  The 22 mm to 1000 mm zoom lens is phenomenal.  A quarter turn of the barrel goes from one extreme to the other.  The photos taken are top rate and this camera has so many features it will take me 6 months to try everything.  The instruction book is less than 10 pages with tiny print but you can download a 132 page manual that is actually pretty well written.  The camera can easily change from a point and shoot mode to a sophisticated bridge digital camera with a twist of the selection dial. The way the vibration/movement dampening works especially at 1000 mm is awesome and the burst modes go from 3 to 11 frames per second.  All pre-programmed menus which are detailed, extensive and all very good require 3 clicks or less to activate any mode.  If you manual set your shooting conditions you can save those setting for later use.  You can shoot normal, fine, or raw images.  Video record for up to 25 minutes and you can change zoom and take individual shots while recording with it's intelligent auto focus system.  The camera starts up very quickly and responds and auto-focuses quickly as well. If you want a point and shoot look elsewhere and save a few bucks but for a serious sophisticated camera that rivals DSL's a half the price you can't go wrong.

I am a long-time Fuji point-and-shoot fan in addition to my Nikon D7000 (which replaced my D70), so I was especially excited about the x20. It takes great photos, is stylish (not that important to me but still a nice point), and is small and easy to carry. I'm a bigger guy and this fits in coat and sweatshirt pockets easily, maybe not jeans so much.  The battery life isn't as great as the smaller older Fuji cameras I've used but its adequate. I'm glad I bought an additional battery though and recommend carrying a spare.At this point, the quality of this camera is well know so I won't elaborate the point here. I paid $600, happily, for this camera and think it's a steal at $500 now.  If you're thinking about it, fret no more and just buy it. I can't imagine you'd regret it.

I purchased this to replace a very old "brand K" aftermarket head unit that was overly complicated and lacking in features.Installation was straightforward, but anyone who hasn't installed a head unit before should take note that the only instruction provided is a simple wiring diagram. I don't have steering wheel audio controls so I cannot comment on that aspect of installing or operating the unit.The unit has a surprising number of nice features and inputs/outputs, although navigating through the menus can take a bit of getting used to.Pros:The radio and disc player both work fine. Radio display when screen is open is particularly good looking.Seems to have plenty of undistorted audio power.No problems with the operation of the touch screen. A calibration routine is buried in one of the setup menu items.The physical screen can be closed during operation and has a feature to adjust the open angle slightly to minimize reflections (in bright sunlight this isn't going to help much at least in my car).Navigation works amazingly well, but as other reviewers have noted (1) it's very talkative with no option to curtail the excessive verbal warnings about upcoming maneuvers, and (2) it mutes the source completely when talking (Nav volume can be adjusted independently however).BT pairs with my Galaxy phone and will stream music as well as handle phone calls.Video input for backup camera works great with the cheap $20 camera I purchased. Installation recommendation, connect the 12 volt trigger to a switch, NOT the backup lamps. In my unit, the screen opens and retracts each time the car is placed in reverse. If you're a bad parallel parker like me, the screen will be going up and down several times each time you park. Quite a good show but also annoying.Haven't tried the separate output for video screen, seems like a nice feature to have.Cons:- As previously noted, the display is very hard to see in bright light. This applies to the LCD on the face of the unit as well as the screen. I you have a choice of installing in a high or low dash location, or if you have a double DIN opening and a choice of top or bottom, I would recommend the lowest available spot, otherwise you'll never see the screen during the day.- Limited user menu and screen customization with photos etc, as far as I can tell you must select wallpaper and backgrounds from those supplied by the manufacturer.- Mostly I've been pleased. I've subtracted a single star for the unit's inability to read more than the first 1Gb from the user micro SD card slot. Technically I believe the description is correct since the original SD spec was limited to 1Gb cards, and this unit makes no claim to read SDHC or SDXC size cards, but I still suspect that most users would expect at least SDHC capability in 2014. Ditto, I can only get the unit to read the first 1Gb from a 32Gb USB drive.- No user adjustable graphic equalizer, just bass/treble/sub and some presets.- Dubious future availability of firmware and map upgrades. Maps that come with the unit appear to be fairly up to date in my area (Chicago).

This was very easy to set up.  I put the unit in the attic facing the nearest tower and didn't have a an issue with channel clarity except for one channel.  I ordered the Mohu Amp Booster to see if that will help.  The HD is very clear and looks better then comcast or verizons HD.ProsNo More Cable CostsClear HDEasy to Set Up and I didn't have to mount on the roofI didn't have to turn to find the perfect signal spot since it's omnidirectionalIts very lightweight and easy to handle when installing.  I suggest putting everything together before mounting it.  Especially in a attic without a floor.  I didn't even have to screw it into the studs, it was light enough where I just used two wood clamps to hold the mount in place.ConsLag Time Between switching channelsOne channel would be blocky in some areas, the mohu Jolt amplifier should fix that though.  We are almost 40mi from the nearest tower.Other then ABC, NBC and PBS the other stations you get aren't high budget channels so they are a little lame.  We still use Netflix and Huluplus.$150 is an investment but after a few months the $ payback starts.

As others have said, you just can't beat SONY for picture quality and this 55" is no exception. Yes, it's pricey compared to the competition, but it's worth every penny in my honest opinion.Pros:1) Easy setup - plug it in and it seeks the WiFi signal; a couple of clicks, enter WEP and you're connected.2) Remote - took a little while to figure things out, but once you do, it is extremely functional, very well thought out by SONY. The "return" button is exactly where you want it and it will back you up from one page/screen to the previous one perfectly.3) Streaming - streams movies from Amazon and Netflix without any buffering (pauses) at all, but obviously you must have a strong signal, if you don't, you can't blame the TV.4) Picture - this is the most amazing picture I've ever seen, I'm sure only a 4K could be better. To save time in the beginning I searched for settings that other people used, a few of them worked but most of them didn't. My picture settings are down-right PERFECT, maybe I'll post them for you to try at a later date.5) Speakers - they are probably the best you can get in a TV like this, but I'm using a Denon amplifier and Klipsch speakers (highly recommended for a theatre experience)6) 3D - the 3D rendering is astounding, but watching it has always been a chore for me. The glasses are comfortable and work well but sitting through a 2-hour movie is very hard on ones eyes. I believe this is why 3D never took off like the industry hoped it would. Some 3D movies are simply too intense to look at for a couple of hours and leave me with a splitting headache.7) 2D - this is why you will not miss the 3D, when you get a great movie or TV station, it looks like 3D without the eye-strain. 2D to 3D is an unnecessary feature IMHO because of the quality of the 2D picture.8) SmartTV - the SONY SEN smart hub displays all of the apps and scrolling through them is a breeze. "Home" page gives you the current input options as well as "History" of recent apps for quick selection and a "Settings" menu. There is also a built-in user manual which is ideal if you get stuck with anything. Also, the TV knows when I'm watching TV or streaming anything and will change the "scene" setting automatically. The TV remembers all of your picture settings so you don't have to change them when going from the internet to a Blu-Ray player, X-Box, or Cable-TV.9) Web-browser - compared to the competition I think it is excellent with the ability to have bookmarks right at your disposal10) Gaming - I do not play games but if the 3D is any indication, it must be awesome on this TV11) NetFlix/Hulu promotion - finally got it going, one year FREE for each, close to a $200 valueCons (all minor):1) does not work with generic mice and keyboards, so you must use the remote to type2) a little pricey, but I did not like some reviews of the Samsungs where the panel just died after a year or two. SONY's should last a lifetime.3) the NetFlix/Hulu promotion app did not work, but SONY tech-support came through with an activation code after 3 or 4 days4) as someone else pointed out, you cannot delete some of the apps on the SEN screenNo doubt about the 5-Stars, purchase this TV and you won't regret it for a minute.Thanks for your time.

For my intended purpose this is ridiculous. So cheap for exactly what I was looking for. I have several hard drives and disk drives and ran out of SATA ports to use on my mother board (only has 6). Was looking for a adapter that would make use of my unused pci-e 2.0x1 slots on my board (or even the pci-e 2.0 x8 and x4 slot since I only run 1 video card these other ports just collect dust) but give me more SATA ports. This fit the bill perfectly and for much less than several other brands adapters on the market. Not only do you gain 4 SATA III(6gb/s) rather than most other adapters only give you 2 SATA ports and are not always SATA III. I followed instructions but if you are even slightly schooled on computers and computer parts you could just guess what to do fairly easily. Unhook everything, power cord disconnect and install the card in the pci-e 2.0x1 (or x4 x8 x16) or pci-e 1.0x1 (or x4 x8 x16). With the pci-e 1.0 it will just run at half the speed if you have an ancient board but is still compatible. Also I didn't seem to find anywhere in the description about the SATA cables so I ordered some.... It comes with 2 and they are both SATA III capable. I had no issue with the drivers, didn't even need the disc. windows 7 x64 recognized the device and downloaded them.FOR PEEPS WITH WORRIES ABOUT POSSIBLE COMPATIBILITY PROBLEMS- This is my system setup and install and use went without any issues. (I doubt there should be any unless the pci-e slot you are trying to use is malfunctioning on the Mobo....)--Intel I5-2500K (Sandy) Processor--EVGA Z68 ATX DDR3 2133 Intel - LGA 1155 Motherboards 130-SB-E685-KR--EVGA GeForce GTX760 FTW with ACX Cooler 4GB GDDR5 256Bit Dual-Link DVI-I DVI-D HDMI DP SLI Ready 04G-P4-3768-KR--2x--Kingston Technology HyperX 8 GB (2x4 GB Modules) 1600 MHz DDR3 Dual Channel Kit (PC3 12800) 240-Pin SDRAM KHX1600C9D3K2/8GX--Windows 7 Home Premium SP1 64bit (Full)--Samsung Electronics 840 EVO-Series 250GB 2.5-Inch SATA III Single Unit Version Internal Solid State Drive MZ-7TE250BW--Western Digital 500GB and 1TB Blue HDD (7200rpm) SATA III---Pioneer Electronics USA 15x SATA Internal BD/DVD/CD Burner with 4 MB Buffer BDR-208DBK--Sony AD-7280S-0B 24x SATA Internal DVD+/-RW Drive (Black)I have swapped all my HDD's, SSD, and Optical drives to this adapter and ALL OF THEM WORK on ALL SATA PORTS.SO to sum up..... This thing is an absolute STEAL if you are trying to make use of some pci-e 2.0 or 1.0x1 slots and would like some more SATA ports :)I actually may buy another one of these in case my motherboard SATAs decide to fry and then I won't have to get a new motherboard.I hope this helps you in your decision, if you have any questions or comments please ask!
summary: Wow. What a steal this is....

reviewText: When I get a new camera -- which I do fairly frequently since I teach photography -- the first thing I do is put a BIG memory card in it, but the second thing I do is get additional batteries.  The Fujifilm S1 is a really nice camera, but it comes with only one battery, of course, and also without an external charger.  You plug the camera in to charge the battery inside the camera.  This kit adds two batteries and also an external charger that plugs into either 120 volts in the house of 12 volts in the car, so it fixes both issues, and for less than a single Fuji brand battery alone.  The batteries seem to work as well as the one which came with the camera.  It's a good deal.
GREAT

Review for Etekcity 4 x 1 HDMI Switch/Switcher with Audio Support:I just could not get this switcher to pass DTS 5.1 to my surround system.  It would only down-convert DTS to 2-channel PCM, which is a problem because many blu-rays only contain a DTS soundtrack.Here is my setup: My blu-ray player's HDMI-out goes into this switch, with the switch's HDMI-out going to my HDTV and its optical audio out going to my sound system.From what I can gather from researching this issue on the web, it appears this switcher will only output formats that the HDMI-connected device supports, regardless of what  formats the connected sound system supports.Since my TV only supports Dolby, for DTS soundtracks the switcher would only output 2-channel PCM to the sound system.The description of the item does not make clear how this unit determines its output format.PS - As many others have mentioned, the lights on this switch are ludicrously bright! If that was the only problem the switch had, I wouldn't mind too much because I would just cover them with black electrical tape.  But I had to mention it since they actually made me laugh out loud the first time I fired the switch up!
summary: Sound output is determined by the HDMI-connected device.  Could not get it to output DTS

120hz is something that you just have to try, from the get go the desktop even is noticeably different. Everything is just extremely smoother and more pleasant to use, especially gaming.This monitor is really awesome, it exceeded my expectations for a TFT monitor. I have it right next to a 22 inch IPS screen for my second monitor. The blacks aren't quite as deep but they are close, the viewing angles aren't as good but honestly I don't notice much picture deterioration even when looking from fairly large angles, it's barely noticeable.Brightness is the first thing you will notice when you turn it on, seriously whites like zapped my eyes like the lightning of Zeus. Turn the brightness down, and change some of your computers brightness controls and it will even out (though still bright).Just make sure to use the dual link DVI and not a normal DVI cable. Also I tried to get lightboost to work with my ATI card and i constantly got stuck on 30hz whenever I tried it, nothing I did was getting it to go so i settled with my normal 144hz which is fine with me.
summary: Once you go 120hz you don't go back, would be perfect if it weren't so bright.

In the last 3 months my computer was freezing a lot of times and sometimes I saw windows blue screen of death.My Plextor M5P couldn't login in windows. The drive was showing in Bios but was failing to initialize.I made the HD slave and saw the drive in explorer, but when I tried to read the files, the HD disappeared from Windows.I checked the Plextor Forum and found these were common problems.I don't know why, but after I bought a new case and I sent my machine to install in the new case, the HD started to work again.It now passed 3 months without any problem...Strange.

reviewText: Unfortunately, there are 2 very different cases in this Amazon listing, and the reviews are all lumped together.This review is for the "IVSO Slim Smart Cover Case for ASUS T100 10.1-inch Edition Tablet with Stand Function".Think of this one as a "folio" case, much like some that are for an Ipad. It is made of nice semi-hard plastic, covered inside with grey microfiber. It is thin and light, much lighter and smaller than the average 2-piece leather cases that cover both the tablet and the keyboard, such as the other case in this Amazon listing. The tablet snaps into the plastic securely. You can attach the keyboard with the case attached, but it's a tight fit because you have to get the keyboard dock flange to go between the tablet and case when you attach it. The keyboard is easy enough to detach, however. You CAN close the tablet/keyboard with the case attached, but that leaves the case folded open, as the case cover isn't large enough to wrap all the way around both the case and keyboard.This case really shines for using the T100 as a tablet. It's thin and light, nice for using while relaxing on the couch :)It's a keeper and I would definitely buy again.
summary: Review of "IVSO Slim Smart Cover Case"

My daughter wanted a camera. "A real one," she specified. I wasn't about to get her a film camera, and I wanted something small and tough that took decent pictures. After months of research, this was the winner.It took her only a couple of days before she had gotten the hang of taking good pictures (even using a tripod when warranted), and she has since moved on to the camera's fancier features —animated slideshows, special effects like "mirrored" images, and the like. I would never have selected the camera for these abilities, but she loves them all.The camera isn't perfect; it's impossible to create a slideshow except by showing all the pictures taken on a particular date. Some functions are oddly greyed-out and can't be selected. Others can be selected but don't do anything (the faux-tilt-shift in particular). But the camera is in all other respects so excellent that I'm giving it five stars.

I received our new UN32F6300 LED TV yesterday morning, and following the instructions on the quick start guide, safely took it out of the box, assembled the stand (4 provided screws), attached it to the  screen (3 provided screws), and used 3 connections: AC power to a surge protected outlet; HDMI to our AVR and RCA Composite Video (yellow) to our AVR (yes, our DirecTV box is not HD, and has analog outputs) it was all set and ready for configuration. Which is also very straight forward using the menu from the provided remote. It is WiFi connected to our home network and through it to the internet, and this was perhaps the longer process for having to enter the WiFi data (SSID, security type and password) using the scroll button in the remote to work with the on screen keyboard. The configuration process is actually very friendly an intuitive, and uses graphics in the source and connecting ports configuration, that look very much like what you have on the back and side of the TV as connection ports, so it's difficult to make a wrong choice.During the setup process being connected to the internet, it detected a new firmware update and I let it perform the upgrade (it takes a little while, from 20 to 30 minutes). That went without incidents, and the configuration parameters didn't change in my case.By early afternoon we were already watching content from the internet (crackle, Netflix, and some other stuff available through the menu). We also watched an old DVD movie (1080p @ 60Hz) and the image was very crisp, we haven't yet bought any Blu-Ray movie (1080p @120Hz) so I'll update on that some other time. The analog signal coming trough the AVR from the DirecTV box is very good for a Standard Digital TV signal.So far, we are very happy with our purchase and If anything changes, I'll adjust my review. But for now I would definitively recommend this product to anyone with a small entertainment space (ours is 130 square feet)', that doesn't need a larger screen, but still want a great quality pictures from Satellite TV as well as BD and/or DVD. We don't play video games, so I wouldn't dare to make any comments on that aspect.
summary: Easy installation, great picture, beautiful design

Got first one and after about 10 hours of use it died on me. got a blinking red led light but no tv. contacted amazon and they replaced it for free and shipped the old one back for free. its been 3 days sense i got my replacement and all looks good so far.now onto the tv itself.The picture: 10/10Amazing!
