I have a 50" Pioneer Kuro.  If you read videophile reviews you may find the Pioneer Kuro is "the" reference TV of many of them.  This TV is in the same ballpark which is kind of sad given that 2014 seems to be the year the plasma TV is going to rest in peace.  If you are a gamer like me, I would seriously think about buying a plasma TV before they are gone because the display of the different shades of black (which can really help killing zombies) and the 600 Hz (critical for a fast moving game like Rayman) are really critical to a great picture when gaming and even OLED can't match the Hz rate for $5000+.  Plus on a game like Mario Kart 8 that you can split the screen four ways, the size really matters.  The brightness is amazing.  The 3D is amazing.  It is a beautiful TV.  The resolution actually blows my Kuro away.  I will say I still think that the Kuro has deeper, richer colors but it's a close race and I may be biased (me and my Kuro have been through a lot, it was even stolen from me once and found it's way home unscathed).  The smart TV functions work very well.  When I have streamed Netflix it has been buttery smooth.  I will be honest and tell you that I have not messed with and don't plan to mess with this TV's goofy voice recognition/motion recognition features.  I learned my lesson after yelling at my Xbox One for a week or two and then throwing the kinect in a drawer.  You have to be really patient and super interested to make those features work and that is not me.
summary: As close to Kuro as it gets, perfect TV for gaming

I have owned all of the PS systems, and each new generation never fails to impress.  We use it for gaming, watching movie discs, and streaming from the usual sources.  At this point, my only wish is that there were more games available.  Though, from what I understand, there will be over 100 new titles released this year.

Might be kinda early for me to review this product since I only had it for a week but let's go.1. HardwareAs it stands it is the most powerful 8th gen console. It plays games from 720p - 1080p in 60FPS if you care about those. 500GB of space, but you only get 407 GB in reality. The rest goes toward the OS I guess. If you want to upgrade the HDD you can but I recommend waiting. A 4 TB 7200 RPM HDD will cost 200$ and so will a 256 GB SSD. More space is nice, but for half the price of the system? And SDD's load the game quicker but I'll wait for the price to be reduced.2. Software/OSMany times faster than the PS3's OS. Pretty simple as well. That's it.3. ControllerMajor improvement over the PS3's. Bigger, concave thumbsticks, trigger R2 and L2 buttons. Light bar and touchpad are borderline unless in my opinion, the light bar more than the touchpad (unless you have the PS camera). Thumbsticks might be cheaper than the PS3's. Mines already has a small scratch on the right stick on the top, but that might be my fault. I had the controller and the system in a small bag and yeah...4. GamesNot a ton of exclusives or even multi plats for that matter. May take a couple of months for lots of games to come on the system. I'm playing BF4 currently. Took a while to learn the controls from BF3 on the PS3, but I got it. Looking forward to Watch Dogs next. Deep Down maybe. Capcom is Capcom.5. AppsNot many either. Netflix, Hulu, Crunchyroll and Amazon Prime video might interest you. NO YOUTUBE APP STILL!6. OnlineNow you have to pay for plus to play online. I think it's worth it. You get free games across three platforms monthly. And they arent bad and old. They're good and fairly new games. You "lose" these games when your membership expires, but you can either become a member again to play them or just buy them (most likely at a lower price). Look up PS Plus for more details.7. Future FeaturesGaikai will supposedly allow you to play PS3 games on your PS4 and then PS3 games on your PS Vita and so on, but Sony haven't said anything about pricing. Will it be free, part of plus, separately paid for or do you have to repay for games? I don't know. Hopefully it will be either free or included with plus.8. ValueThe parts are 381$ for this 400$ system plus testing, labor to make (although it's cheap Chinese labor), shipping and packaging. This system is fairly priced and Sony may be losing money from every PS4 sold and making money from PS Plus and software sales. 400$ for the system is fair.Overall enjoying my ps4 and looking forward to the Japanese exclusives (mainly RPGs and JRPGs). Might want to check amazon every now and then if you want to buy a 400$ ps4. Act fast. They sell out quick. Have a ps3? I say keep it. Still games coming out for it.Will update soon.

Nothing's really changed between the PS3 and the PS4, with the exception of the controller (which has improved! Kudos) and the shape of the console.Are the graphics better? Yes. Is the share function cool? Yeah. Is there anything else? Not really - at least not to me.I purchased both the PS4 and the Xbox One at launch from Amazon (both verified). I've had the opportunity to compare the two and both have their shortfalls, but Sony seems to have gotten into a comfort zone and stuck with it. It's just not my cup of tea for a "next gen" console.

The graphics on PS4 are life like, far better than PS3 or xBox360 both of which we have. Games load quickly and we've had no glitches after 100 hours of play time. At first I thought the reason to buy the PS4 would be just the graphics and that alone makes it worth the price but Sony did a great job on other improvements too such as load time, ease of use etc. If you enjoy gaming you want this machine. I love it and so does the wife. If you have the PS3 or xBox360 it's definitely worth the price to upgrade to the PS4. Another big benefit is Sony made the PS4 where it will play PS3 games which xBox intentionally did not do with their new xBox One. I really hate that and decided we will not buy the new xBox as they did the same thing when they launched the 360. So we sticking with just the Sony machines going forward.The PS4 is worth the price and worth upgrading if you have the PS3; you'll love the graphics!

For 399, you can't go wrong.  This has become the centerpiece of my entertainment center.  All of my blu-rays get played through it; Verizon's Redbox Instant, and Amazon Instant Video services are great; and I use the NHL App to stream live hockey games almost daily.  The last movie I rented streamed at 1080p and 5.1 digital audio without a hiccup.  The gaming graphics give my 2500 dollar custom PC I built a run for its money thanks to the massive amount of dedicated video RAM; my PC actually has less.  Every game will likely be 1080p.  I can't wait to try the remastered The Last of Us!!  It runs at about 1/3 the temperature of PS3.  The only real gripe I have is the required PS+ subscription to play online (only 49.99 per year, though, which is less than 5 a month).
Launch edition PS4, not many exclusives at launch but enough to keep me busy over the holiday season. Sony listened to and delivered a knockout.
nice console
Absolutely love this console. Yes there are not a ton of games out for the PS4 yet but give it time and it will come into its own.

I've been using it for a little over a week now and still learning about.  I'll bypass the praise, you can read those on other reviews.  Went from 5.1 to 7.1 and soon to be 7.2 Used the automatic speaker setup (works great for my room) but couldn't find the 7.2 selection as the menu only went up to 5.1.  What?  Went online line (not in the user manual) and found that I had to select the 3.4.1 speaker setup.  Okay, now I get it, 3 front, 4 surround, subwoofer.  Seems like a dumb idea since they advertise the unit as being 7.2.The controller does not have a back light - bummer.Using a speaker switch to go from high fronts to back surrounds depending on the movie.  Neat!  I recalibrate the speakers each time I switch setup because I haven't found a way to save the different settings.  That may exist, but I haven't found it (yet?).Not that it matters (I hope) but this doesn't weight much (seems well built though).  The Sherwood is heavy beast and built like a tank and still going strong.As I use this unit, I will write/modify my comments.Would I buy this again - absolutely!  Love the sound, automatic speaker setup and the look.(Still keeping the Sherwood - Need the AC-3 RF for my laserdisk collection - Cats Don't Dance anyone?)
summary: Nice, inexpensive upgrade from Sherwood Newcastle R-745

reviewText: I bought this camera from the experience of my friends camera Samsung WB30F. We traveled all throughout Europe for over 3 weeks and she took some great photos. Sent our friend photos every night via Wi-Fi. Just love the camera she was using I bought one too from my return trip home. My camera died shortly with NO USE at all even after I charged the camera for approx. 3-4 hours. Then I thought I should charge it again. I did. The flash wouldn't work. Then the camera died again. I tried to hook it up to the computer but the camera wouldn't turn on again at first then again it turn on. Unplugged it from the computer and it died again. My guess is the battery isn't charging from inside the camera. The only way to charge the battery is to hook up a USB cable to camera using a plug at the end. in other words there is NOT a separate charger. You use the camera to charge the battery. I cant say that is the problem with the camera. It just kept dying. I didn't want to fuss with it anymore nor do I think I should for a Brand New camera less than 12 hours old. Sending it back. Maybe a bad batch but I wanted to keep it but now I am Leary about the camera performance completely now. I own more cameras then I would like to disclose and NEVER had this problem. Take your chance I guess but this is my review. Maybe I got a Lemon but I am not a gambling person. I even ordered directly from Amazon if that helps at all.
summary: My friends Camera work the best my Camera died.

reviewText: The rave reviews really make me wonder: what is wrong with people's ears? Using with my iPad, at max volume on both devices via Bluetooth, these speakers don't put out much volume and the bass is simply pitiful. A lot of the sound spectrum is simply missing (even wired directly). I have a Boston Acoustics 2.1 rig that came with a Gateway computer in 1997 and it blows this product away. I thought a newer set might have some tricks but apparently not at this price point. Was mainly interested in wireless connection and I will just buy a Bluetooth receiver to hook into my BA speakers.I would barely recommend these for a desktop PC. Look elsewhere if you want any kind of volume or subwoofer bass. I returned them.

Below is my original review with some updates.Despite my first good impression, my wrist started hurting again.So I have decided to return the product.------------------Suspecting carpal tunnel on my right wrist, I got this mouse thinking it may solve the problem.Pros:* It is definitely easier on my wrist than the normal type mouse. (<<< Update: On the 3rd day, my wrist pain started to come back.)* Pure plug-and-play. Load batteries (AAA x2, not included), plug in the receiver on a USB socket, turn the switch (on the bottom) on.* It looks and feels nice in that matte finish silk touch coating (which might peel off after a while,,, I don't know yet)* The middle wheel works as the scrolling wheel AND as a 4-direction scrolling pointer.* It has an automatic shut off after not being used for a while. I believe this prolongs the battery life. All you need is to click a buttononce to wake it up.* No software to install. The windows (mine's XP) mouse setup is good enough for all basic things.* Wireless seems to work fine (but my mouse and the receiver are in a close distance so it may not be a good test.)Cons:* The mouse too light and too slippery on my desk making it more difficult to target the pointer. My previous mouse was heavy and thus very easy to navigate WITHOUT pad. Now, I have to get a pad which I hate about using a mouse.* Designed for hands bigger than a certain size. My hands are not big. A bit difficult to use. For small handed (or short fingered) people, this mouse may not be the one to like.* Buttons much harder to click than normal type mouse. On the normal type, your fingers press the buttons against the support from desk. In this mouse, you're gonna need your thumb as the counter-support. All of a sudden, a simple clicking is rather a tricky task. Especially for small  handed people, it might be not as easy or comfortable.* It is high from the desk surface due to the purpose of the design. Thus, when I move your right hand between the mouse and the keyboard,  I kept knocking down the mouse until I finally learned the clearance. Some people might find it frustrating.* Not much of a manual however, not much of assembly required either. It is a very basic mouse. I discovered the middle wheel does more than vertical scroll by accident. I have one button I don't know what it is for. (<<< Update:Turned out it is a "DPI" button. However, I didn't see any diffrence..., the inner package box have a button explanation.) No direction calibration available (which is a minor CON)SummaryI thought it was definitely easier on my wrist first but on the 3rd day, my wrist started aching again.And this product is not all so easier to use as a mouse for me so I have decided to return. I'm againsearch for a easy-on-your-wrist mouse. I tried trackball type but didn't work either...I give 2-stars to product + 1 more star because;* Anker vigorously tried to contact me in response to my original 3-star review including an email apparentlywritten by a human who had actually read my review. Isn't it better than those that never pay attention toreviews on their products?* I can not deny my review involves some subjective observations, which might not be a problem for other people.So, good luck in finding the best mouse for you, everyone!

I use this flash on the NEX-6.  It give you about 2-3 times the power of the built in flash, so it's not's super powerful, but works well for what it does.  I would say it is good out to about 40 ft and I actually used it for a few shots in a wedding and it worked well.  The bounce feature in a fairly small woom works great and creates a nice rich well lit look without the harsh shadows you get from direct fill flash.You are paying a premium because it is made by Sony for Sony cameras.  I also have the ProMaster FL160 for Sony Cameras and while it is much more powerful, the TTL just doesn't work right on camera.  The HVLF20M will give you constant shots every time.

I needed a keyboard for my iPad Mini as well as wanted to provide my iPad Mini with some sort of protection for the screen when it it on my bag.This is a great solution. The magnet keep everything in place so the screen is protected when in my bag and when I need a keyboard - one is ready for use! Mind you, I notice that the new iPad Air Ultrathin keyboard by Logitech does also offer variable tilt of the iPad Mini when using the Keyboard verse this keyboard which only offers one tilted position.Battery is great and built quality is awesome - feels solid but not too heavy. This is the 2nd set of Sony headphones I'm buying. Bought the 1st as a gift for a friend and they're still using them. Bought the second set as a gift for my bro and he loves them.

I was in the market for a professional level monitor for 3D rendering (architectural visualization) and did a lot of research before buying.  Nearly every forum I visited had this monitor (or the older 2410) ranked as one of the best.  It was hard to see all that money leave my wallet but it has been worth every penny.  The reason I wanted to upgrade is simple, I wanted something that accurately reproduced colors, in the past I have struggled to get my work to look good on a variety of screens.  It was so bad that I actually didn't want to send my work to the clients as I never knew how it would look.  Luckily, that has all changed.The first thing that immediately struck me while I was unpacking it was the weight, this is not like the ~$100 monitors I have been using my whole life.  The build quality is absolutely perfect, it is obvious that they have not cut corners to reduce the manufacturing cost to pad their profit margins.  Then I plugged it in, wow the monitor looks just as great as you would imagine.  After a few minutes messing with the settings to get it to match my workflow I took a look at some of my older work to see if they colors were off.  They were off, a lot.The monitor is just a joy to work with. The stand allows you to move the monitor up and down approximately 9" or so maybe more, the base swivels so you can rotate it to show someone what you are working on, and the screen can actually rotate to be in a portrait orientation rather than landscape (haven't found a need to use that but it is there if you need it).  It has some USB ports on it (very handy) and I think the other one is a card reader but I haven't had a chance to check that out yet.  The screen finish is also very nice, it is matte but not to the point that it is annoying if that makes sense.  Just the right amount to cut any glare or reflections without altering the look of whatever is on the screen.  Really great if you have windows behind you, some of the other monitors I have used are like a mirror.The only downside to this monitor is that you will never want to use a cheap $100 monitor again...I plan on buying a 2412m for use at work, cant stand that horrible monitor I have any longer.
summary: Great High End Monitor For Photo/Video Work

reviewText: I have been listening to this sub in a Subaru Forester paired with my Hybrid Audio Unity speakers for a couple of weeks now, and I am satisfied with it. I am now blown away - and don't expect to be - but the very noticeable gap in my audio spectrum is no longer missing.I chose this sub because I did not want to sacrifice any trunk space and I didn't want to do any battery modding to support some giant thumper. This sub fits cleanly under my passenger seat with room to spare, and comes with a handy remote that I velcro'd to the side of the center shifter area. The remote gives you control over sub power and low-pass frequency, which is great for tailoring the amount of bass you want for the track of the moment. It also glows high-tech blue -- albeit uselessly, since the light goes through two strips on the sides of the remote and not anywhere that makes the controls visible.As other reviewers have pointed out, the audio spectrum from this sub does cut out on the low-end. It does not hit very deep, which means those vibrations you get from really fancy setups that make your heart tremble are not to be found here. It does stay relatively clean though, and for the most part it is not boomy (although I do have to turn it down from time to time when boomy occurs).I set the low-pass frequency to cut off at 63 hz and set the high-pass for my mid-woofers to 65 hz. This makes the two blend nicely and keeps the sub from getting boomy and my mids from getting muddy. I keep the low-pass on the remote at 125 hz so the head-unit can stay in control and vary the sub power from 50-100% depending on what I'm listening to.I installed this sub myself, and it was the first time I really took a car apart. That made a fun (but nervous) experience, particularly with dealing with the battery. For those who are interested in doing this themselves, here are some things that I've learned that I hope can help you too.The videos on Crutchfield are a good start and cover most installation basics. Google 'Crutchfield Powered Subwoofer Install' to see.1) The manual that comes with this thing is very hard for a beginner to understand.But Google can answer most of your confusion. One thing in particular was that the blue P.Cont wire means Power Control -- it connects to the blue/white wire in your head unit sometimes called remote antenna.2) The connectors on these wires generally need to be removed and replaced with other terminals. Coming from building computers, I thought everything just snapped in place. Not really. Make sure you have all the tools you need going into this.3) These are the tools / parts:- RCA male to male cable (the 6ft HOSA sold on Amazon is a very good deal)- Wire cutter / stripper / crimper- Heat-shrink circular terminals for your ground and battery (get large, good ones rated for automobiles)- Heat-shrink connectors for splicing the sub wires to your head unit- A lighter or heat gun- Gloves when dealing with the battery- A decent ratchet set- Screwdrivers- Plastic no-scratch panel removal tools. In reality you just need a small set like http://www.amazon.com/No-Scratch-Audio-Refit-Panel-Removal/dp/B005909KWA- File, sand-paper or power grinder for exposing bare metal to your ground connection- Wire sleeve for protecting your power cable to the battery- Electrical tape (weather rated, >200 degrees f)- Google / YouTubeIt will also be good to have some light-duty zip-ties or velcro ties to organize your wires.4) Make sure you disconnect your battery any time you are dealing with live wires. I got lazy at one point and kept the battery connected when I moved my grounding cable and did some changes to my power line, and it ended up blowing the fuse.5) If you do something dumb and blow the fuse, at least fuses are cheap.6) Do not take your car's interior panels off without knowing exactly what you're doing. Google and visit online forums or find videos on YouTube that explain how to disassemble your specific car model for head-unit access and running wires to wherever you need to run them. It is very easy to break the clips or mess up something that will be expensive to replace if you don't know what you're doing.7) Heat-shrink terminals and connectors will work with a lighter - just use low heat and keep the flame as far as possible while still melting the plastic. You just don't want it to burn.8) Once you get everything installed, it's a great feeling to know how your car works and how to take the interior apart! I spilled a shake into my shifter a while ago and paid the mechanic over $100 to clean it out. I could have done it myself if I knew what I do now (and done a better job).
summary: Very compact, relatively simple setup, decent sound, affordable!

reviewText: Hooked it up and got to work right away. I like the slim profile - it never gets hot like some of my other external drives.

reviewText: I bought this 200mm fan for my NZXT phantom and alas along with several other reviews, it does not fit. So I clicked my way over to NZXT.com to check it out. Upon reading the specifications, I came across "True 200mm Wide Diameter (Opposed to 193mm)."NZXT created this fan for "New Standard 154mm Spacing Compatible With Phantom 820, Phantom 630 and Future NZXT Cases."I hate to give it two stars, but fans should be universal for all cases. The Philips Fidelio S2 are exactly what I have come to reliably expect from Philips:  good quality, accurate sound reproduction from a well-designed pair of headphones.Five sizes of silicone tips are included for the best possible fit, which is so important for comfort and audio quality, plus samples of Comply active and comfort series foam tips.  The stems are angled and after inserting the earpieces, rotating them forward slightly seals off the ear canal and puts the casing in a comfortable position.The 48 in. (1.2m)  linguine-style cables almost entirely eliminate tangling, although microphonics is average.  Strain relievers and sliders are minimalist, as is the 90 degree cylindrical 3.5mm audio jack.The copper-alloy housings are vented and the 13.5 mm layered drivers are designed for use with mobile devices without an amplifier.  They give a very natural and uncolored response, with well-balanced bass, middle, and treble frequencies.  At normal listening volumes, I don't detect any distortion or sibilance.  Soundstage is unremarkable.  Overall, the audio is very faithful and enjoyable and conveys the personality of the music without trying to affect it.The in-line microphone works well for phone calls and the control bar is nicely textured.The glossy white or black, metallic gold, and taupe color scheme comes across as fairly flashy compared to the otherwise-restrained visual design and cries out for matching shoes, belt, and bag.  A coordinated softshell zipper storage case is included.

DISCLOSURE:  Pyle provided me with this product to review.This is a very rugged (and quite heavy) portable wireless bluetooth speaker. It's in an attractive and sturdy casing, and even has a big metal hook to hang it from things. It is rather heavy so those looking to lighten their pack load might want to look for something lighter.But what I can't get over is that sound only comes out of one side of the device (the left size when looking at the label). I contacted Pyle support and received no response on this issue so I'm assuming this is how it operates.  The speaker is stereo, so there is left and right separation from the side of the device which the sound does emit from.Audio quality isn't bad and is about on par with other devices in its class. These are not audiophile devices but more utilitarian in nature.  Sound is loud but could be louder, especially given the outdoor nature of the device.UPDATE - Pyle got back to me and stated this is how the product is supposed to operate. The speakers on the silent side of the box are bass coils.
summary: Sound only comes out of one side of the device

reviewText: This is the Yong-nuo 560III and we are testing it to use in a project we are working on, so far the item has performed admirably and meets most of it's promised (advertising tends to bloviate a bit) targets.But:  Two things buyers need to know:1-  It is a totally manual flash unit. NO I-TTL, P-TTL ,D-TTL, power steering or power brakes...this is totally in car terms a stick shift which many pros feel is preferable in commercial work.2-  It comes complete with a warning not to use lithium based ion batteries in it. On a yellow tag in the battery department.  Owning a battery company I know why, the open architecture of the Lithium battery cab exceed the units margins.For those who have ventured forth and taken their cameras out of the "P " mode this is a value packed good piece of merchandise.
Buy this if u dont need ttl this flash is soo cool for what it costs.  powerfull one and great features

I love this compact usb 3.0 hub. Most laptops are very handy computers but the lack of usb ports for me has always been a shortcoming. My desktops usually have 12+ ports and not all are usb 3.0. One is certainly not enough. One of the great qualities of this one is that it is powered if needed, Non-powered hubs are useless when extra power is required. So being powered and four ports for me is really great! HooToo happens to have put these desirable qualities in it. Also it is slim but not to small. The indicator lights are a plus and the short pigtail type flat style interface cable is as it needs to be, short for reliable data transfers but not to short. The whole thing is compact for easy carry. It has been very reliable and everything plugs in just like it should. I have absolutely no complaints. If you need a usb 3.0 hub this is the one to get!
summary: The UH005 is a great addition to a laptop!

reviewText: This display takes some tuning, Use the Menu 0000 secret code to get to the "Curve" settings so you can really dial in the colors. By default it is over saturate. Run the backlight down a bit as well.Once you have it dialed in your best looking movies will look amazing. But the worst ones will look really bad. Shows like "Walking Dead" will really show the noise and film grain. On the other hand the Ice scenes in Game of Throwns look amazing.  Video games will "sparkle" more because single pixel holes in the 3d don't get blended out.  Basically thing that you want to hide the blemishes look worse, and things that you want to see all the detail look better.
summary: Not For Everyone, But Great for some

However, after having my GPS stolen twice from it being on the windshield, I decided to get one of those dashboard mat thingy (which works great), however, I should have taken into consideration that mat and the clips that goes with the GPS. reviewText: I like this mouse..I unchecked the" allow the computer......."  and improves the connection 90% still loses it when you put the laptop to sleep...I have a Sony BMS55 mouse that does the same.I have a Samsung laptop with windows 8.1 Can anyone please tell me if it would make any difference whether your turn the mouse off when the laptop goes to sleep and turn it back on when after the laptop wakes up ? both my sculpt and Sony behave pretty much the same ;I assume that it must be a "normal" blue tooth thing to lose temporarily the connection;I am not a tech (in fact my wife swears than I am an idiot!). Any answer would be appreciated it. actually the connection now is 100% as follows:Click Start, and then click Run.ENTER: services.mscDouble-click the Bluetooth Support service.If the Bluetooth Support service is stopped, click Start.On the Startup type list, click Automatic.Click the Log On tab.Click Local System account.Click OK.also: uncheck "allow the computer to shut off device " from bluetooth properties on " device manager"....right click:  intel wireless bluetooth.Now....it works full time !!!

(Disclosure: I am an audiophile, I have owned many pairs of headphones, including Sennheiser IE80's, Etymotics ER-4Ps, Bose OE2s, Klipsch S4, S4i's, etc.)I was looking for a new pair of headphones after my set of IE80's had a broken cable and itwould take a while before I can receive a replacement. I originally wanted active noise cancelling (ANC headphones, due to living in a college dorm, things are never quiet in there. So I did my research and found that ANC headphones really leaned toward having a poorer sound quality than headphones without. I went to the Apple Store and tried on the QC15's and the H6. The QC15's have wonderful ANC, but my music sounded somewhat distorted. In addition, it felt my brain was getting sucked by both ears when the ANC was on and that was unbearable. The H6 sounded balanced but with less bass.So I settled with the H6. And I'm absolutely pleased I did.I listen to much more music with more bass,such as JPop, JRock. And while these headphones don't bring out the bass to a very high level, there is enough for me to accept. The clarity of the music is phenomenal with these headsets on! The sound isolation is enough for me to block out my roommate's keyboard (which he has Cherry Blue switches).Distortion? None that I can hear even at near full volume. Wearing glasses, too, and they do not press on my glasses. Very comfortable leather. Can wear for hours! Gorgeous looking headset.The cable with sound and song control is a huge plus and it works well on my iPhone and my rMBP.The audiophile is satisfied. If you looking for this pair of headphones to be bass-heavy, look elsewhere. If you're looking for the headphone that will ensures the maximum amount of clarity and precision in your music, I highly recommend these! $400 is a bit steep for a pair of headphones, but it is worth every penny.
summary: Clarity For The Audiophile, Look For Bass Elsewhere.

reviewText: Was very happy with the product and has a ll the features I was expecting. Very nice options and excellent quality

This is it. This is the monitor you always wanted at the price you thought was reasonable. Apple Cinema Display? No thanks--reflective nightmare. Lightboost TN? Meh--Colors are boring. Eizo Turbo240? Expensive and filled with flaws (I kept one for giggles). No sir, for those of us that want the fastest, prettiest pixels currently on the market, look no further.Pros: These monitors are better than anything you can buy with a standard namebrand on it for anything like normal money. This is a $1000 display, to be perfectly honest. The housing isn't even bad looking.Out of the box, the color is pretty much already neutral calibrated as it should be. Adjust the brightness to your liking and away you go. The lack of an on screen menu is a GOOD THING (it is a part of the reason the monitor has no input delay)Same goes for the single DVI-input--this also allows the monitor to overclock to 100Hz+ (works on modern AMD and NVidia cards)Very stable pixels. I've ordered 2 Perfect Pixel units from Ecomade Arena and both were 100% PP. No stuck, bright, dark, dead. Most people will tell you that even though they ordered a non perfect-pixel Qnix they ended up with one anyway.The 2 panels I received had very little IPS "glow" (this is a Samsung S-PLS panel, fewer quality issues than LG's IPS).Coating: Pleasant semi-gloss. Heavier than Eizo FG2421, but doesn't reflect much at all, while still being very very clear.Easy to Vesa mount, Easy to disassemble. Can get backlight bleeding, 1 of mine had almost none, 1 has a little but they are easy to adjust and fix the bleed completely almost if you disassemble. If not, it's really not an issue. I've seen worse bleed on pretty much every monitor I've bought in the last 2 years (and I buy a LOT of monitors).Even if these could not overclock, they would still be a tremendous value. *But* they can. So what does this mean? Wellllll the 8ms GtG pixel response time is usually a lie in the manufacturer's favor. In this case, it's in our favor because we can essentially overdrive the pixels in these displays to respond at about 4ms (for real, yo) which makes a huge difference for tracking objects in motion on the screen------like your mouse cursor or scrolling text. For me... it's a lot less eye straining, and a lot easier to see what I'm doing while happily wasting time shooting things in computer games. But it's also just great all the time, I prefer browsing at 100Hz, I prefer watching YouTube at 100Hz. It's just better.Amazon resellers are not making a huge amount of money per unit. These are very inexpensive displays. Don't cheat yourself out of a good unit by trying to get the absolute rock-bottomist price on one of these possible; even going the route I did, you are getting enormous value.Cons: It's DUAL LINK DVI only. If you don't have dual link dvi it's a no go. Some people can get them to work off Macs and some can't--it's about what you have specifically hardware wise and you need to do some research to make sure it can be used. I've even heard about some success with a certain kind of active adapter so who knows. Now, I have DVI-D and DVI-I on my Nvidia cards, and they both work with these monitors because they are both dual link versions of DVI outputs. It's important to make sure your card has dual link DVI-D or DVI-I *because* there are single link DVI-D and DVI-I outputs on some older cards and those wont work.Depth of dark detail: Not bad, not great. I had a brand new AOC Q2770PQU sitting next to my Qnix and even though the Qnix had a better contrast ratio, the grayscale was quite a bit better on the AOC. The AOC is at least 200 dollars more and is stuck at 60Hz though, so that was an easy choice.Stand: K, this is weird, I bought two of these and they weren't the same height. The stand isn't as wobbly as I had heard, but it leaves something to be desired. It can also be easily replaced, but I like it just fine. Just not clear why they are not the same exact length here lol. Anyway, it does actually tilt, and it holds itself up just fine. My desk is solid heavy oak and it doesn't budge when I bump it, so the monitor doesn't either, but the stand has rubber pads on the bottom that are good at sticking to lacquered desks; it's a much better stand than I expected, actually.Other thoughts:Seriously consider buying an accidental coverage plan along with a squaretrade warranty the moment your purchase goes through, even before it arrives. I scratched the screen on my first Qnix slightly (right after I got it) and I will regret it for much of the rest of my life. I sold it to a friend for a big loss. :(The replacement, like the original, arrived in less than 2 business days from when I placed the order. There must be some sort of startrek wormhole from Incheon, SK to Texas.
it did feel good after wearing it,the screen seems more comfortable to look at,amazing. the only thing I want to mention is that it's for a small face.a bit tight for me
summary: it did feel good after wearing it

reviewText: Since I have the VIZIO E601i-A3 60-inch 1080p 120Hz Razor LED Smart HDTV in my new man cave, and when it came time to get a killer 5.1 sound system to go with it, the best choice for me was the VIZIO S4251w-B4 5.1 Soundbar with Wireless Subwoofer and Satellite Speakers.Installation was a breeze. I just connected the optical cable from the TV to the soundbar, then on the opposite side of the room I plugged in the wireless subwoofer and connect the two satellite speaker to the subwoofer. I turned everything on and viola! everything automatically connected. And best of all my Vizio TV remote also controls the soundbar. I also connected my DirecTV remote to control both the TV and the soundbar so now I'm back to using just one remote to control everything.Oh yeah, the soundbar also can connect to my iPhone as well as my iPad via Bluetooth so I can listen to Pandora without turning on the TV.The sound it phenomenal. When I listen to a 5.1 surround sound movie or football game (like the Super Bowl) I'm totally blown away. It's like being there - but only better!It did take a week before I received it.
summary: Another item needed in the man cave.

reviewText: I got my first keyboard in it's flimsy plastic container and stuffed into a manila envelope. The plastic container was smashed. The keyboard worked fine for a few days and then individual keys began to stop working. I contacted the seller and they graciously offered to send a new keyboard and did not require that I send back the old one (since it does not work properly there is no benefit to me in not shipping it back). They did send a new keyboard but in the same manner as the first so that the container was damaged again. They need to ship the device in a box, something with rigid sides to protect the device. The keyboard works perfectly, pairs up via Bluetooth quickly, charges up quickly and lasts for a long time on a single charge. The keys are very small so it is hard for me to type very quickly but I am sure there are others who would be able to type much quicker on it.Overall; Packaging needs improvement, device is small but that is known by the description, Bluetooth works perfectly, charges quickly, holds a charge a long time. Not for everyday use but very handy for use with a phone or tablet.

This product was advertised to work on the iPad and iPad mini.  It is okay for the full sized iPad but does not fit the mini at all.  I kept this to use on my old first generation full sized iPad I keep on my reloading bench but it is really more of a pain in the butt to use than a stylus.
I added these two batteries, which came at an unbelievable low price to the one that came with my Pansonic Lumix camera and now I can shoot for days and days without recharging.
summary: Never run out of battery again

reviewText: I can't believe that I have lived with bad sound for so long!!  I bought this from the warehouse deals pages as it had been an open item.  I love the sound it produces, love that I can connect my PC and phone to it via Bluetooth and that you can adjust the background noise vs. the speech.  This is a winner.  Wish I would have ordered earlier.

I bought this case as a replacement for an older Belkin case. The old case had elastic enclosures at each corner of the tablet which had started to wear out. This case is form-fitted to the tablet, including a cut out for the S Pen and a cut out for the power and volume keys. The case fits perfectly, keeping the tablet much more secure than the old elastic ever could. This case is also a lot thinner and lighter, so it feels far less bulky on the tablet.  This case secures with a magnetic closure that also (through the settings menu) can be used to turn the screen on and off. All in all a huge step up from any bulkier case, and it's hard to beat the price.
Tronsmart MK908 Google Android 4.1 Mini PC TV Box RK3188 Quad Core 2G/8G BT Black Tronsmart MK908 Google Android 4.1 Mini PC TV Box RK3188 Quad Core 2G/8G BT Black
summary: Tronsmart MK908 Google Android 4.1 Mini PC TV Box RK3188 Quad Core 2G/8G BT Black

reviewText: This is a bigger power supply, check your dimensions to make sure it will fit your application space.Pro: Fully modular so you only use what you need and have a very clean install. Awesome cables that are sleeved very well. Very flexible wires for easy manipulation.  Comes with every kind of connector you will need.  Evga has awesome customer service, and it has a very long 10 year warranty!Cons: only size limitations and it is not really a con.This power supply is a beast, it handles my high end gaming system with 2 R9 290's with no problem, I was able to push it to over 800watts with overclocking. Unfortunately my video cards generated too much heat inside the case, and I decided it would be better to split them into 2 systems. Now my sytem is super quiet, efficient and has plenty of GPU power to run whatever I want.Here are some facts you need to know when picking out equipment for a build.1) Never exceed 400 watts of (video cards) power, which translates directly into heat produced, in an enclosed case with air cooling. Your main PCIE16 card will be hotter because of radiant heat from the second card. This will make card 1 throttle more to control the heat, which will equal bad performance. (This exponentially multiplies with more cards.)  It will also lead to all your fans running at 100%  2+ high end video cards (above 200 watts each) I reccommend liquid cooling the GPU's.  Reference "hamster fans" are extremey loud and sound like a hair dryer running, I do not recomended them.2) It is fine to overkill your Power supply! Honestly you should double the wattage of the PS to what you think you will use. It allows for growth and overclocking if you want.  Power Supplies run most efficiently at 50% of thier rated wattage and once you hit 70% efficiency goes down fast, while heat increases.3) One 24vdc rail is the best, and most versatile for multiple video card setups because you do not waist power.4) Fully Modular is the ONLY way to go5) Spend the extra money on a GOLD standard power supply, you will have a super stable and reliable system because you did.6) NEVER use power supply cables from ANOTHER power supply, because they can be wired different at the PS. USE ONLY THE POWER CONNECTORS THAT ARE SUPPLIED with this POWER SUPPLY.  I know this because I have fried components before.

The vendor's documentation is inconsistent. Online it reads that it is supported on Mac. Documentation in the box says no. I said I wasn't going to jump through hoops fixing it but went ahead and did so.  Here's the recipe which works on 10.7 and 10.6.8:01)  Turn it on and say some stuff.02)  Turn it off.03)  Plug it into your USB port turned off. It should mount at NONAME.04)  Open the RECORD folder. There should be one or more *.WAV files.05) Do not bother opening with Itunes, Quicktime, or GarageBand. They will not work.06) I downloaded MplayerX which works just fine and is free.07) Open a WAV file and play back. Works for me and played back really well including my swearing over getting the thing to work.I'm leaving this at 2 stars because you have to hack it to work it and you cannot set the time on files. The files to do that are Windows only.

I want to like this little box. It does work...mostly...with XBMC which was included and is the only real reason I tried it. I did have to do a firmware upgrade and, as with a lot of Android devices, it pretty much wiped out everything in the box and I had to reload and reconfigure XBMC (once you're experienced doing that, it's not a big deal - but the first few times!!!)The remote that works with it mostly works too. I ended up using a logitech keyboard with a touchpad with it. XBMC has lots of things you just can't do with the remote (any remote I've found so far).That said, this box played HD very, very well. The audio through it was excellent and the wifi worked fine for me AFTER the firmware update. I used a Seagate Backup 3Tb USB3 drive with it and it found the drive easily, read it very quickly and had no problems pulling music and video from the external drive. When the MX2 shut down, so did the external drive which is exactly what I wanted (be aware that not all external USB drives will go into hibernation when the USB goes dead).If you want a simple solution for playing videos from your NAS or external drive, this may well be your answer. BTW, Matricom support is great. They were quick to help with problems I was having as was their forum - a plus for newbs like me. However, I redid an old Intel dual core machine I had sitting around and replaced the MX2 with it (for reasons that have little to do with the MX2).

Everyone here is giving positive review for this tiny box but no one mentions thatThis box is for pirates only. That is all XBMC is good for. Allow the add-ons that lets you watch FREE movies and TV Shows. Even movies currently in the theaters show up here after a search.This is a pirate paradise and nothing more.You want free moves, buy the box. install the add-ons to xbmc which is very easy and you will be watching movies.Now, if you have surround sound - you are out of luck. even the 720 files have 2.0sound. some, have 5.1 but hey, you are not paying for any movies so don't be pushy now.
summary: You want free movies and tv shows ? get this box

reviewText: I purchased this monitor to replace a DELL 30" monitor that went out.  There are not many 30" 2560x1600 options out there, but I came across this one on Amazon, and it had great reviews.  At this price, it was worth a shot, and I am happy with the decision.  The monitor is bright, crisp, and seems high quality.  Only time will tell if it lasts, as my previous two 30" monitors only lasted 2 yrs each.  I hope this one lasts longer, but so far, I love it.  Highly recommend.

As others have said the picture is really nice. The 3D jumps out at you and is very clear. The motion is smooth and for my eyes perfect. The start up from power off takes some getting used too. It is slow and sometimes makes me think I didn't get it turned on. Since my Sont surround sound STR-DH520 communicates with it the picture goes black for a second or two as the amp queries the TV. I used my Sony amp to manage the HDMI inputs and only have 1 cable going to the TV, this clears up the cable mess behind the TV. The only other cable is for the Wii which has a composite output. I use my Directv remote as the primary control device for all 4 of my devices. It works for all of the most common functions and was the easiest to set up. I have an old Sony Commander that is dated and I could not get everything to work so I abandoned it to the junk pile.I was a bit disappointed in the smart end of the TV though. The apps are slow and the interface for some of them is clodgy. Amazon doesn't work yet. If you do not have a computer hooked to the system using the remote to navigate is a bit cumbersome. I stream all of the same apps through the Sony blue ray BDP-S470 which works 2 times better than the TV for those functions. It has all the same apps available and is faster. I was thinking I could connect direct to the internet using a browser but I guess I didn't read enough or didn't understand enough.Overall it is a great TV and I am very satisfied.

We have a few cameras in my household and they're all to small to fit in this case. I think this case is for a specific camera type and you should really pay attention to the dimensions to ensure it will work for your needs. Otherwise it's well made and looks like it would be useful.

The range extender connected to my 2gig controller quickly and easily.  I used the extender to connect switches located outside to my controller inside my house.  The switches are located in my outdoor kitchen away from the house about 15 feet and in a wall that is not connected to the house.  I placed the extender outside but in plug that is on the house wall.  It worked perfectly and the switches connected to the network without issue.  I had previously been unable to connect them.
I am always a little Leary of aftermarket chargers and electronics, but this shipped fast, works, and has a nice little led blue light to advise it is plugged on. Works fine with my PTD200

Quality product form D-Link, packed with features such as sending video clips via email or ftp when motion detection is activated.Don't like that it needs java (yuck) to view live stream straight from the camera and the software they provide for PC is far from being close to useful.Edit 06/14/2014 After a few months with the camera it turned out using it as a security camera is pretty inconvenient. Motion detection triggers recording when it switches from daylight to infrared, infrared to daylight and on random occasions. The DVR software they provide lowers the security settings of your computer by disabling UAC, it is very slow and does not work in virtual machines. Oh, and the manual focus makes up for the cherry on the (sorrow) cake.
summary: You could build your own security system with it, when d-link fixes it

reviewText: LOVE love this speaker! Bought it to take with us on an extended vacation abroad, which was great!, and have used it mostly every day since we got back, too. Definitely not those tinny little computer speakers you might be thinking of. I compared it to the JamBox and Beats Pill in a store, and thought that the sound quality and volume range was much better on the UE Boom. We ended up camping a lot on our vacation and would listen to music or watch a movie on the iPad using this. I really appreciated the fact that I could turn it down - a lot of speakers focus on turning the volume UP, but the ability to maintain great sound quality at lower volume levels was a definite selling (and keeping) point. Bluetooth is easy to set up, and the option to plug in 3mm to 3mm is very helpful. Also LOVE that it's compact, lightweight, sturdy, and uses the same USB cord as my Kindle and the husband's Samsung Galaxy phone so we didn't have as many cables to lug around. Lasts a long time on a full charge. I look forward to using this for a long, long time.

I bought these headphones for running and they work great. They stay on my head the whole time. I have purchased cordless Bluetooth ones before but they broke quickly. These are cheaper so I won't care as much when I have to replace them. They sound ok for the price.

Got this for the home use as it had good reviews.  My initial config is with two 4TB Red drives mirrored, will add drives later for fault tolerance later.Me: I've used Windows Home Server - home built RAID 5 (no DE as it was a bad idea from the onset) - as my NAS device. Backup and restore were dead simple and as a file server no complaints. I ran it using Hamachi VPN to connect remote computers. I've worked in the internet security industry in development and know my fair share about network setup and config. I liked WHS because I know Windows the OS and could always augment it services if I needed.Synology Disk Station is more of a closed OS - if it doesn't do what you need, you can't add an app to the OS itself, even though it is built on a Unix Core. That worried me until I booted it up. It will take a while to explore all of the dynamics, but this baby looks like it can do a whole lot.Right now, I'm left with more questions than answers. It will take a while to work my way through the device. From what I've seen of the docs - some are helpful and describe why you would use a function, others are the generic click this button to turn X feature on or off and no explanation on what the feature even does or why On is better than Off in the first place.Streaming - You can add media server, but I'm still trying to figure out what that is better than using it as an attached drive?Development - I see how I can install Wordpress and run a website - but as a developer, I don't see how I can install 5 Wordpress instances and use a vconf file to differentiate between them.Backup - Still not there yet. WHS had an awesome backup program built in that could easily be installed to each computer. Synology has several options, but I haven't tried them yet.What this means for the average home user?  Well, it is easy to install the drives and get it up and running if you just want to share drives. Still, you will have to know a thing or two about Users and Passwords to get your family to see it.In the end, the best thing about this unit compared to my WHS is the size. The case is tiny and pretty quiet (though you will hear fan noise if on your desk) which means its great for those looking to downsize their desks and workspace without downsizing performance.
summary: Initial Setup is easy - getting everything out of it will take a bit.

reviewText: My choice was paying off government-bonded student loans, buying this television, or paying for my uninsured mom's dialysis treatment.  Making easy choices like that are the reason I went to college in the first place!  None of my frat-buddies are paying off their loans, either.  And even-though my dead-beat mom co-signed mine, the banks can't chase her because she's broke from medical bills.  The hospitals can't refuse her, either.  So everybody wins!  Am I right?  This is why it's a 'smart' TV, because if you're smart enough to avoid your other bills, you can buy it!
summary: Paying off student loans is for suckers

reviewText: We were saving up for this TV because we heard so many good things about it.  Finally, with $40k in the bank we got online to order it and coincidentally came across an ad for a girl named Amanda in her early teens for only $10K.  Her parents were trying to purchase the same awesome 4K TV and needed the cash.Now, let me clarify a few things here.  First, the last time we had a daughter she cost a hell of a lot more than $10K...As a matter of fact, her college expenses this year alone are more than triple that amount.  So, Amanda was a bargain!  Second, since our daughter is away at college we kinda missed having the attention of a young one in the house.  And third, my wife isn't that much into TV, house cleaning, cooking, grocery shopping, laundry or other chores and when she saw we could have another daughter "slave" for only $10K her mind was set!  Oh, but here's the main selling point...We only have to keep her for a year!!!  Then when those teenage hormones really start kicking in - she's her parents problem again.  What a deal!!!*******Due to an overwhelming response to this review I've have no choice but to add this amendment:First, Amanda is a sweet, kind, fun loving, young human being and should be treated like one.  As soon as her year is up in our servitude that will no doubt be the case.  But, due to the contract we made with her parents she is to be returned to them at the end of the year.  So, conversely we are not allowed to sell, sub-rent or lease her out to anyone else.  Please understand and stop requesting.We are saving up again for the TV.  There were a few hidden costs in receiving Amanda that we didn't plan for.  The plane ticket alone was close to $700 - and we still have to look at the return flight.  Hopefully we will book it much earlier this time now that we know when she is to be returned.  And, Amazon is trying to get us to pay an online sales tax on her purchase.  We are currently disputing that because this is more of a rental than a purchase.  And, even with Amazon Prime and the cost of Amanda being more than $35 we still had to pay for shipping ourselves ($700 plane ticket).But, the good news, we are now only $5K away from a new 4K TV!  Cutting our daughter's college funding really helps us save!********What a sad day!  Quite emotional for all of us.  Our year with Amanda is up and we just dropped her off at the airport.  She's heading back home to her parents.  We are really going to miss her.  She made such an impact in our lives.  Our dogs loved her, we enjoyed watching our 1080 HDTV with her, and we got to really enjoy having Amanda in our home and part of our daily lives.  Amanda was a little chatty at first but we took a few measures to quiet her down.  My wife and Amanda began to get close - she even showed Amanda a few makeup tips.  My wife is still crying in the living room - she really got used to it being cleaned everyday.For myself, I really miss the way dinner was prepared every night when I got home or that I never had to get up and get a beer for myself.  Now I have to get used to walking the dogs again, too.  Nothing is going to be the same around here now that she's gone.  Darn, I just realized it's trash day - haven't worried about that for a year!But, the good news is after we finally saved up $40K we found a refurbished 4K TV for only $30K.  Unfortunately, though, James and his wife didn't want to extend our contract.  Looks like we may be paying for our daughter to go back to college and finish her degree after all.  She'll appreciate that a lot!Thanks for all the hard work Amanda - you were the best "daughter" we ever spent $10K on!Oh, and the 4K TV is AWESOME - it takes up two walls!  We saved the box, too.  Right now I'm using it as a storage shed, but we figured it might make a good starter home for our daughter after she graduates from college.
summary: We couldn't afford this TV because we paid $10K for a girl named Amanda.

reviewText: The 3D on this TV is so incredible the images leapt right off the screen and then went to my bank and drained my entire checking account.Which brings up an addtional feature not previously mentioned: after getting this television I lost 40 pounds, because I can no longer afford food.But I still believe that this is the very best thing you can do with your life's savings, other than making a big mountain out of cash and setting it on fire.Daughter needs an operation which I can't afford, but I'm OK because now when I watch Golden Girls I can count Bea Arthur's pores.This TV has more definition than a dictionary.I now know how many nasal hairs Rutger Hauer has.I'm going to get a second one for my bedroom, right after my kidney sells on eBay.

I was looking for a basic, small receiver to power a modest 2.1 setup in our apartment.  We had pretty tight size requirements, and the H/K 1510 was one of very few receivers that would actually fit.  It was also the least expensive, and H/K has a decent reputation in quality audio so I took the plunge (granted at this price it's not much of a plunge).For the money and size, we absolutely couldn't be happier.  It looks beautiful, takes up very little space, and sounds great.  I have it hooked up to a pair of Wharfedale Diamond 10.2 speakers crossed over at 80hz to a subwoofer, and the combination sounds fantastic powered by this receiver.  Better, in fact, than my much more expensive speakers powered by a much more expensive (and powerful) Pioneer Elite receiver (stating opinion here, but I loved that more expensive setup too).The good: Inexpensive, small & light, beautiful, sounds great.  On-screen menu is straight-forward and makes sense to navigate.The bad: Not as full-featured as some other receivers, not as powerful as some other receivers, cheap non-front-channel speaker connections.The bottom line is that I can't imagine a better-sounding receiver at this price, and the fact that it's small, light and stylish is icing on the cake.  You could pay more and get some more features, but if you're looking for some simple amplification and video switching you'd be hard-pressed to do better.  I've had some terribly buggy H/K receivers in the past, but this one works perfectly and beautifully.
After reading all the reviews that needed internet connection all the time to do ANYTHING with this console.I didn't even open it, returned it and kept my PS4.

I bought this for my Coolpix. L820.  The tube attaches easily and has a perfect fit. The tube is very good quality and the threads are perfectly done. All the lens filters go on and off easy. They all worked great and are made in Japan. I'm very happy with this purchase. A terrific bargain.

I guess i did not do enough research on this product because i have one with the old firmware which out of the box, does not work, you need to do a file modification on a ini file to get their own updater to work properly. Amazing how things like this get by QA, which seem's more like none was done...See:[...]And note on newegg here[...]then have fun even trying to register on their forums since they ask you a question i certainly don't know the answer to.
summary: Buffalo too incompetant to update their own firmware

reviewText: Just fixed up my son's new computer with this chip. It's very fast and temperature is amazingly low. Tired overclocking it and it was stable. However, to be on the safe side, I prefer to run it in the original clock speed.Would have given it a 5 star if not for a new version i7 4790k (below ) ! Slightly higher in price but definitely much faster.http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B00KPRWAX8/ref=as_li_tl?ie=UTF8&camp;=1789&creative;=390957&creativeASIN;=B00KPRWAX8&linkCode;=as2&tag;=travguid0ca-20

As most ham operators know, it's the little things that can make you nuts or happy.  This is one of those happy things.  If you have a Baofeng hand held and want to try different antennas it's best to have a short coax going from the radio to the normal coax end.  Keeps things from getting pulled apart, dashed on the floor, generally make the use an headache.  This adapter and jumper works like a charm.  I now can hook my 5R up to my 2meter "J"e antenna or my handheld 2meter Yagi.  It's nice to sit on the deck with the Yagi on a camera tripod and hit the repeater with a bit more signal.

This is a fantastic computer, but the WiFi card it comes with is terrible (the only reason I didn't give it 5 stars).  The range is about half of my last one, it drops the connection regularly, but it is an easy fix.  I replaced the WiFi card with an Intel 7260HMW wireless AC card for about $30 and presto it was awesome!  Just be careful with the T6 torx screws so you don't strip them.Overall the computer is quick, responsive, and well made.  The entire chassis is aluminum which makes it light and strong so it should stand up to being toted around.  The 5200rpm hard drive leaves something to be desired, but anything faster (other than SSD) would sap the battery life.  I get about 4-5 hours of mixed use on the battery and that is perfect so I won't likely upgrade the hard drive.I have been buying ASUS products since the 80s and I swear by them.  I highly recommend this to anyone looking for a well made desktop replacement laptop computer.

For the price, the hardware is really good. Windows Phone takes some adjusting to, once you become familiar with the paradigm it has a number of nice features and advantages. The Live Tiles can be really useful for putting information right on the home screen.If you primarily use a phone as a phone, and don't have to game or have the latest most amazing features, this is a good phone. But don't expect it to be iPhone, or Android, its just different.

Full disclosure: I have had to return/exchange phone twice, but I still give it 5 stars.  Here's why:-Love the way Windows phone's OS is set up.  Very easy, convenient, manageable and easy to set up the way I want to tailor it to my needs.-I've had excellent battery life with it, although I carefully manage WiFi, Bluetooth, location services and usage, etc.  It's easy.-I used Nokia's complimentary "set-up service," where you make an appointment and they call you (preferably on a separate line) to discuss things you don't understand with the phone.  I waited a few days to explore the phone myself, so as to hopefully have some "intelligent" questions, and it was a pleasure.  Although you categorize the areas you want to discuss, you're free to ask whatever you like, so you can effectively use your phone.  The Nokia representative was efficient, knowledgeable and friendly - i.e., real customer service.  And they said I was free to call any time as a Nokia owner.  Nice!-Although the 521 lacks a couple of things that would be nice, such as a magnetometer for true location services, a front-facing camera, etc., with my provider, T-Mobile, it has several advantages, such as WiFi calling.  I bought this phone specifically to replace my old Nokia E-series and to use with T-Mobile's so-called "Wal-Mart Plan."  $30/month, 100 minutes of calling, unlimited text and data (up to 5gb at 4g) - perfect for me.As for the returns, the first was likely not the phone but the SIM card.  Nonetheless, T-Mobile suggested returning all and starting fresh.  I considered that solid advice.  Second, probably a battery, but again, with the sane advice of Nokia, they suggested a complete reset.  I will say this, the recovery was much less painful with Nokia/MS Windows phone's OS than I expected.  If you log in via an MS account, and allow them to save/update your system, such occurrences (which happen with all variety of phones!) is not so painful.I recommend, but again, I'm NOT an apple fan, nor much of an Android fan, either.Bottom line: Find another phone with this much functionality and utility for this price point.  You can't, in my book.

I got this A6-6400K in a combo deal with an MSI FM2-A75MA-E35 motherboard for $118.98.I was building this for a basic internet surfing/word processing/e-mail system for my sister. For that it is a great.I have put it through testing video's, audio quality and general surfing speed and everything works great without lag.From what I have read the GPU part of this APU benefits greatly from high speed 2133 ram. I am using G-Skill DDR3 1600 in my build because I already had some and the gaming graphics are better than I expected.My sister does not game but I do and had to install a few just to check out the graphics. They are all older games so I can't say how more modern games run.Doom 3; butter smooth gameplay with max graphics selected and the 1920 x 1080 hack.NASCAR Racing Season 2003: butter smooth gameplay @ 1920 x 1080 with 2xeq AA and 16x antistrophic with max graphics (FPS never dips below 55).Call of Duty 4: with max graphics gameplay @ 1920 x 1080 was NOT butter smooth but was playable; @ 1440 x 900 gameplay seemed very smooth.H.A.W.X.: this is a direct x 10.1 game, I had to lower the resolution to 1280 x 720 with max graphics and it was very smoothI am impressed with the performance of this APU and would recommend it for a budget build without a discrete GPU.If you plan to run a discrete graphics card this is not your best choice for a gaming rig.

Nice cover for the price.  I've had it for a couple of months and it has traveled well.  I took it from the east coast to Hawaii for a 3 week vacation and I was pleased overall.  The only drawback I found was the design of the hard plastic allowed the tablet to slip out of the groove and resulted in the tablet falling flat.  I would give it a 5 star rating if it had a more secure way to maintain the tablet in it's propped up positions.  I will consider buying another of these when it wears out.
summary: Nook HD Plus cover - Black vinyl color

reviewText: This Lap top seems to be a good prices and works as good as our acer and Hp we have had in the past.

Note: The product description says the resolution is 2560x1400, but I am able to display 2560 x 1440. Details are below.Picture quality is great. Thin, light, sleek and the monitor looks great. Inconspicuous built-in speakers are great (disclaimer: my expectations for monitor speakers are low). VGA, HDMI, DVI, and DisplayPort for input. What's not to like? Read on.This monitor can support 2560 x 1440 resolution. What is the point of a big monitor if you don't utilize the full resolution?I believe HDMI 1.3 standard supports 2560 x 1440 resolution. However, I couldn't see that with my setup. I don't if it is the computer or the monitor, but the resolution maxed out at 1920 x 1080. Very disappointing.I have a HDMI to DVI cable and when I tried that, I was still limited to 1920 x 1080. Unfortunately I don't have a single computer with DVI port to test that out.VGA connection gives slightly higher resolution, but leaves a thick black border around the desktop.In order to utilize full 2560 x 1440 resolution of the monitor, I had to buy USB 3.0 to DisplayPort adapter:Ableconn USB3DP00B USB 3.0 to DisplayPort Display Video Adapter up to 2560x1600 (DisplayLink DL-3500) - External Video Card - USB Multi-Monitor Graphics AdapterWell, this is satisfactory, but (1)I had to spend extra, (2)there is additional hardware on my desk adding to clutter, and (3)I lost a USB port.Realize that these are not faults of the monitor; if your computer comes with DVI or DisplayPort built-in, you can probably use this monitor as is.It does have VESA (I think 100mm) mount, and the stand utilizes the mount. So, you can mount it on wall if you are willing to remove the stand. My current ViewSonic monitor has VESA mount, but the stand doesn't use it. I made a bracket, hung it over the VESA mount, and kept my laptop in the bracket. That with wireless keyboard and mouse allowed to keep my desk tidy without cables running all over. However, I can't do that with this Planar monitor.I didn't see any flicker or hear any noise while using this monitor.
summary: Planar 27" monitor is great, but can your PC handle it?

reviewText: Giving this MB a 2 star for now... may change it higher later, but we'll see.Here's why the low rating. I have purchased other MBs (and other products) over the years from ASUS and this is the first one I can say did not work as advertised right out of the box. First of all I noticed the main PCI slot had a broken tab on it (I should have boxed it up right then), but figured what's a piece of plastic. Then I noticed it was missing one of the SATA cables, it was supposed to have 4 (I believe), there was only 3. Hmmmm.After putting everything together (fans, CPU, memory, etc.) the board posted good. Opened the bios, and all checked good. Had a new HD I wanted to use so I started loading Windows 7 (64bit)onto it. Halfway thru the installation Blue Screen Of Death (BSOD). Shut it down; retried it and at the 3/4 portion of the install ... BSOD. Here's a long story short 'cause I troubleshot this thing for many hours with no success... I have multiple HDs, so I tried them all to make sure it was not the new drive I had brought. Same exact error at different points during the Win 7 Install. Even ran memtest86 at one point to make sure the RAM wasn't bad. Finally I had to borrowed a friends computer and I downloaded ASUS most recent BIOS for this board and updated it. Same errors... no change. (Why this didn't come with the latest BIOS is beyond me. Anyways)Called ASUS tech support just to get confirmation of what I thought was bad. (WOW... 3 times waiting on hold for over 10mins each time and then I get the "please leave a message and one of our reps will get back to you". "Oh wait you can't because all mail boxes are full," goodbye.  REALLY ASUS!!! Really?)  Anyways, I finally got thru the forth time after waiting OVER another 10 MINs for a tech. He confirmed my thoughts that I had a bad motherboard (probably the SATA controller).Now I'm waiting for Amazon to ship me a new board. (BTW... Amazons return/exchange process is A1 so far.) So besides all the above here my main reason for giving such a low rating. The inconvenience and hassle this has caused and the time wasted troubleshooting a BRAND NEW PRODUCT. Nothing should be so much hassle. I understand that sometimes things go bad on items, Especially when it comes to Electronics (I have over 30 yrs experience in the field), but the QA process is supposed to catch most stuff. I'm actually starting to believe some of the BAD REVIEWS Others have recently written about ASUS MBs. I have come to expect the BEST from ASUS in the past, but this experience so far has left a really bad taste in my mouth.I'll update this review after I get my new board, and we'll see. If the new board works like this one did, I'll take my business to another MFR.UPDATE 14 Jan 14 - This ding is on Amazaon. Above I said they have been A1 on this issue... Well I'm changing that. Come to find out it's going to take over 2+ wks for Amazon get a replacement MB to me even though there are 13 instock shown on amazon at this time. WHAT? Their reason is because they have to get the new MB from their suppier (not out of their wharehouse) and it's no longer 2 day shipping because of that also. I don't care about their suppier issues. I brought a MB with 2 day shipping... not 2 + Weeks shipping. What if I was running a business and could not run my business without a computer. (Which I'm without right now) I'd have to shut down for 2+ weeks till Amazon fixes their supply issues. I'd have to lay off my workers and possibly loose my customers.... Ridiculous!!!! Amazon should be getting this replacement board to me ASAP to close out this issue. More to come on this review I'm sure. Shame on you Amazon!!!!!!UPDATE 16 Jan 2014 - Decided to cancel the replacement MB and cancel this order completely. Just not worth my time and hassle. 2+ weeks is too long to wait for a replacement MB. Unacceptable! Taking my business to NEWEGG or TigerDirect. Oh ya down grading this review to a 1. NOTHING/NO PRODUCT should be this much hassle.

could have give it a 5 star, but decided there are still some minor flaws. the factory default settings does not allow you to record ch 3/4. either does it allow you to monitor in-cam or ch 3/4. you have to go to the rec setting to change. right now, i only used the product for 1hr.put the minor flaws aside, this field recorder is my first recorder. reviewText: I had previously purchased a Satechi, but then found it hardly worked with any devices even with having external power. The EasyAcc hub, however, works perfectly with my 2013 iMac, powering ALL external devices, including all external drives: SuperDrive, external HD, and Lexar Pro reader! the Satechi would not even recognize my Lexar Pro card reader. Transfer speed is awesome!Pros: 100% compatibility with all devices. Excellent transfer speeds.Cons: Does not charge iPad4, but does allow synching. Does not match the iMac "look", but the extreme functionality makes me overlook that minor caveat. Power is supplied by a "wart" type power supply which limits where it is plugged into your power strip or wall outlet. Power cord is a taste short.

I've owned and used several pair of headphones over 25 years and use each pair for different reasons. For super clear hi fidelity listening, I whip out my Bose Quiet Comforts or V-Moda Crossfade headphones. When wanting to travel light or do activities outdoors, I'll use my Beats Powersports or Rockford Fosgate Punch Plugs. (by the way, if I keep a pair of headphones for longer than a few weeks, they are good headphones. otherwise I sell or return them) I bought the Skullcandy Crusher's after demo'ing them in Best Buy. I immediately had to have them after feeling the bass response. I used to have a pair of cheap headphones that had this effect, but they eventually broke and I found out no headphone manufacturer was doing this "trick" any more. Having a driver vibrate the headphones in time to bass frequencies fools your brain into thinking it is hearing massive bass. In car audio competitions, they used to sell vibration "amps" that mount under each seat to fool people into feeling/hearing the bass much harder than the speakers are actually playing. The same thing is happening inside these Crusher headphones. The main reason people keep buying higher and higher end headphones these days is to upgrade the bass response. It is very tough to get massive bass from smaller speakers. Skullcandy has figured out a way to "cheat" and the results are incredible. I'm surprised more companies aren't doing this same trick. I never thought I would say that headphones can have too much bass, but these can hit a ridiculous levels. It isn't ever uncomfortable or too distorted, but you can make these headphones have an over-powering bass response to where songs sound almost comical. These were made for dub-step. Most users I know will play with the novelty of turning the bass slider to max when they first get them, but eventually you will want to hear all of the song and not just the bass end by keeping the slider at 1/2 to 3/4 settings. The mids and highs are very acceptable too. No distortion unless you are blowing up the bass slider to max. The sound you get out of these headphones is worth FAR more than $99. I can't imagine the amount of bass these will have once the speakers reach their prime "break-in" period. To keep this review simple... if you want the most bass you can get from headphones and don't want to spend $500+ to do it, buy these now. The only reason I didn't give this product a 5 star rating was that after an hour or so of listening, it felt like it was crushing my head. They seem a little tight, but that might get better over time. If you have a small/medium head, they might be fine for you. One of the other great features of these headphones are the auto-on/off circuit for the bass driver. Stopping your music or unplugging the cord will turn off the battery powered amplifier circuit. This insures you get the max battery life. I never liked headphones that had a manual on/off switch because you'd always forget. Also, considering what is packed into these headphones, they are rather light. They don't dent your hair like other heavier headphones. If you have a specific question on these, message me. I'd be glad to answer back.
summary: Hands down, the MOST bass you can get out of headphones.

reviewText: I have the RCA DHT235A 3.5-Inch LED-lit 720p 60Hz TV which I like a lot, but feel the antenna is so flimsy it will break at some point so wanted a back up antenna.  You must have an adapter to use an external antenna & I was worried from some of the mixed reviews on whether it would fit or not.  I'm happy to report that it DOES fit perfectly & I'm glad I didn't have to pay the higher price on another website when this one works great.

With an understated and simple design, this set of speakers are inconspicuous and can complement most decors.  The wide but thin design makes placement relatively easy in a small footprint.  It is relatively lightweightPairing the device utilizing an iPad 4 and iPhone 5 was simple.  The ability to control volume, pause, play and replay/forward music is a standard function.  Having the convenience of the charging port helps when power to your device runs low.For the sound quality, this has a more discernible and wider range compared to compact sized Bluetooth speakers.  The base, treble and mid-range levels are excellent.  Unfortunately, it cannot be adjusted with the exception of the built-in equalizer in your electronic device.  There was no distortion with regards to maximum settings on the speakers AND the iPad/iPhone device.Overall, I am pleased with the performance, design and features for this set of speakers.
