reviewText: I'm all good with this product and I have first one case it's look great because I have hard time to open the notication, so I decided bought this case and easier to side the notication also it's lighter weight without bulking.

This is the mount for my 8500 that I've been waiting for. Sticky, sturdy, adjustable, easy to mount/dismount. Everything the little two-cup mount was NOT.The assembly is significantly larger than the original two-cup, but holds 10X better. Some complain about the size, but in my truck it blends in nicely. From outside, it's only slightly more visible than the old mount. Doesn't block forward LIDAR reception - just got a hit last week. Luckily, I wasn't speeding (much).Holds great so far. Temps below zero did not affect it. The giant potholes in our area don't faze it. Very stable while driving, hardly any movement. The old mount would bang the RD against the glass, none of that here. It just plain works. I've yet to confirm summer performance, but I'm impressed so far.This should be included with every detector. But 25 bucks is a decent price for what you get, so no complaint there. Have you priced a BlendMount lately? This is a huge improvement, but I have to ask Escort: "What took you so long?"UPDATE: 20 July 2014No problems with summer heat - cabin temp has been as high as 130 degrees. I don't remove the mount, and this seems to help maintain the stickiness. I'm ordering another for a 2nd vehicle, will just swap out the RD between the 2 mounts.

This is so much better and more secure. I've had my radar detector for around five years now (Escort Passport 9500i, which I love and has saved me from speed traps more times than I can count). The original suction cups had lost their suction long ago and I was on my third set of OEM replacement suction cups.They, too, started to give out and my radar detector kept falling off the window. Time to replace them. Tired of the one to two year lifespan of the mount and wanted something better, I purchased this mount from Amazon. What a difference! The mount is very adjustable and rock solid secure now. The detector is just locked into place. It doesn't bounce around. It doesn't fall off the windshield. It's soooo much better. I haven't had any loss of GPS signal, like some were complaining about. My only criticism of this mount is that it isn't as discreet as the original, but I much prefer the ability to adjust the angle and vastly superior security of this mount over the crappy suction cups that came with my detector. The extra real estate it takes up is negligible in light of that. Well worth it.
summary: WAY better than the OEM suction cups

reviewText: I have no use for any of the Windows 8 stuff! That aside, this is a nice set. There are a bunch of Win 8 function keys on the F keys. There is a switch to turn them off and just make them F keys. Great! The installation is basically automatic. Just install the INCLUDED batteries for the mouse, pull the blue tab to make the batteries in the keyboard work, make sure the mouse is turned on (there is a switch on the bottom), and plug in the USB transmitter. The is a configuration screen that comes up. You can make changes to the buttons and so on.The mouse worked on all surfaces I tried. My old mouse would not work on my desktop but this one does. The palm rest comes off and makes a lot smaller footprint. I will leave it on in my application. I did not try a range test but so far it is fine.  I would like a little more key travel but I think this is a nice replacement for my old wireless desk set.
summary: Nice wireless keyboard and mouse set

reviewText: Bluetooth pairing was easy and flawless to my computer, my cell phone and even my DISH Hopper receiver!I've always shied away from over the ear headphones due to them hurting my ears when I had them in my younger years, so I've always used ear buds since then.  Not any more!  These are extremely comfortable and I can wear them for hours.I read some of the reviews that indicated that these headphones had too much bass for their taste.  This didn't bother me because when listening to music, that is what is lacking in most headphones and earphones.  It does have great bass response and I find that it's perfect for music and it does not overwhelm the sound when talking on the phone or listening to the TV.I would definitely buy these again and recommend them to anyone looking at buying them.  Especially for the price.
summary: Excellent product, would buy these headphones again

reviewText: I purchased two headsets so that my husband and I could use them with our iPads.  We love them for listening to music, audio books and streaming TV or movies.  They are comfortable and very convenient for listening at home, or for travel--and they come with a handy little storage pouch that is large enough to hold the headphones, charger and the charger for my iPad.  On our last long trip, they were good for more than 10 hours of continuous listening without needing a charge--I wore down before the battery did.  Overall, we are very happy with these headsets.  Definitely recommended.
summary: Comfortable and convenient with great sound quality!

reviewText: Coming from 2 x hd 6950 crossfire.the performance compared to my crossfired 6950 is about the same in all games. I do get slightly better FPS in all games.Now, you have to understand that 2 x 6950s were pretty darn powerful for any games out there. so you can imagine how fast this gtx 770 is.i game at 1440p, so i needed something REALLY fast to play all games maxed out. And this card does not dissapoint.however i was experiencing about 20+ degrees more in my case because of the 2 cards heating up.This single gtx 770 lowered my case temp by about 15-20 degrees.And also lowered the noise by about 50% (no i'm not kidding).
Big improvement over the GTX 260 I had for years. Plays everything I've thrown at it in high settings well, and I'm sure two of these would be awesome for those that SLI.

My new Tab 3 is amazing. The images are so much better than Tab 2.About the delivery, got home earlier than I expected. Good protective packaging.

reviewText: This is my 4th pair of active noise cancelling headphones over the last decade; the 20i is the first one of the in-ear type and also the most expensive. I've had them for several weeks and my review is based on using them on a couple of flights and while doing noisy yard work.Fit: not impressed with the fit; they don't feel secure. A behind-the-ear cord style works better for me.Without music: sometimes I just want silence on a flight while I'm reading. First thing I noticed was an increase in white noise as soon as the ear pieces are inserted, I don't think this is a trick by Bose. The shape of the earpiece just seems to reflect ambient noise into the ear canal. Anyway, after switching on the phones, after a second or two, the noise cancellation kicks in and the harsh engine noise is dramatically replaced with a soothing sound rather like a distant waterfall. Some people report complete silence - that was not my experience.With music: when I played music I was able to listen at a comfortable volume. Voices stood out clearly above the "waterfall" background noise.My rating is based on my view of price verses performance. IMO, one can get most of the performance for one third of the price with competing products.
summary: Is the high price justified by the performance?

reviewText: I purchased these after using the over the ear type for years with great satisfaction, other than the bulk. I fly a lot, and really need to have noise canceling function.I may just not be an "in the ear" kind of guy. I tried all three sizes of ear buds, and none felt more or less comfortable than the other. Turning the power on produces about a 20% reduction in noise, but more than that almost seems to change the pitch of the noise.I am not an audio expert. My music sounds good, but not worth the price compared with other headphones.Lastly, recharging needs to be done fairly frequently, unlike the over the ear models. I just wish they had used a button battery instead.Sorry, Bose.
summary: What am I missing? Very disappointing.

reviewText: I have used several noise cancellation in ear and over ear headsets.  These are the best in terms of noise reduction, comfort and sound.  On my last flight I compared the Bose QuietComfort 15 noise reduction headsets they give you in First class with the tablets for watching movies to my 20i.  20i wins.

Been a Bose fan for fifteen years.  Have never been disappointed.  The active noise cancellation works as advertised and the sound reproduction is good, but not at the same level as a pair of Shure 535SE earbuds, which use passive noise cancellation (buried to my eardrums.)  Will be interesting to see if the active noise cancellation works on snoring.

Packaging, Build quality and Accessories:Packaging is quite good, they come in a squarish box with a picture of the IEM's on the front and details on the back. This is just a sleeve, you slide out another box which has a magnetic flap to show the IEM's sitting in a plastic intray. I think they could have used a better intray as the plastic feels a bit cheap. Below the IEM's you'll find the carry case and underneath the intray is the manual and warranty papers.Overall quite nice packaging but could be better.Build quality is good on these, the housing is all metal with great strain relief on both the jack and entry to the housing, the iPhone Mic is metal with a good quality button and i have no real complaints about the build quality, the cable does tangle a bit and has a little memory effect.Accessories included are also great, with a semi-hard clamshell case, 6 pairs of different silicone tips and a cable clip (useful to keep cable noise down).Comfort, Isolation, Cable noise and Driver flex:Comfort is good once you get a good seal, the shape of the housing lets you get quite deep insertion but they are more comfy with shallow insertion, and you do have to adjust them from time to time, it is very important to get a good seal with these, they are very seal dependent and it took me a while to get a good fit.Isolation is not a strong point of the M-DUO, it is below average and i suspect it is because of the vented nature of these IEM's and also the housing maybe.Cable noise is present, not too bad but i would recommend using the cable clip to reduce cable noise.Driver flex is also present but not a big problem and adjusting them solves this.Sound:Lows:With a dedicated woofer for the lows i was expecting big bass, but after listening for a while, that was not the case. The bass is definitely north of neutral but it's not overpowering. Superb punch in the mid-bass with it extending effortlessly down passed 20hz, these have amazing capability in the lows. You can feel the rumble in the sub-bass but it's never too much, neither does it drown everything out, I guess that's due to the dedicated woofer. The lows are not the fastest or the tightest, but they certainly are fun.Mids:These have a slight V shaped signature so the mids are behind the lows and highs, but the mids are clear and detailed, never sounding veiled or muffled. There is a spike in the upper-mids which can lead to some sibilance and harshness in female vocals but its not too bad and should only affect the most sensitive of ears.Highs:Highs are good in general, they have good presence and sparkle but extension could be better. Because of the spike in the upper-mids you get the perceived extra detail, but real extension leaves a little to desire. The highs are not particularly airy and they become a little splashy sometimes but for the price they fair well.Soundstage, Imaging and Instrument separation:The soundstage is good with it being both fairly wide and with good height.Instrument separation is fairly good but there is not much air between the different instruments.Imaging is very good though giving off great spacial queues and sounds are easily pinpointed.Conclusion:Slight V-shaped sound sig with an overall fun and enjoyable sound with no major faults. Isolation and fit could be better but for the price you get a well made IEM with a fun, full bodied sound.

I purchased this card for my samsung galaxy s5 to record the high definition video but more importantly to utilize the photo editing studio. This is important because I need an extremely fast read/write speed as I have my photos saved on the memory card by default to free up space on the phone, so when I edit the photos they are technically editing on live on a memory card. I am noticing no lag in the photo editing process even know they are fairly large files. I'm completely satisfied with this product. reviewText: I was sent this power bank by the manufacturers for review.  I have tried a few of their products now and, like the others, I think this one excellent. The unit has a good capacity of 5200mAh which is enough to charge most mobile phones 2 or 3 times or a tablet once - although it depends on your individual device, of course - which makes it a really useful thing to have around.It is very simple to use. Just plug the micro-USB lead supplied (or any other micro-USB lead) into a USB port and the micro-socket on the power bank and it charges at a slightly leisurely 1A.  (There is a US-style SSB charger supplied with the power bank).  It takes about 6 hours for a full charge and the level of charge is shown by the normal 4 small LEDs.  Using the power bank to charge your device is just as simple. Just plug your device's USB lead into the power bank, switch and your device will charge at pretty well the same rate as if you charged it in the normal way.The unit also has a little LED flashlight which is pretty bright and a handy thing to have in your bag when fumbling for keys on a dark night or the like.  It's a nice little bonus.This seems like a very good-quality product.  Leakage rate is very low and if the claims of 500+ charge/discharge cycles are true (which they usually are for this type of battery) that's a good long life.  It is light at 125g, robust and elegant.  It's a compact and slim at 9cm x 4cm x 2cm so it will slip pretty easily into a pocket or handbag.I really like this power bank. My one complaint is that the English in the user manual is very poor.  Fortunately it is so simple to use that this doesn't really matter, but it doesn't do justice to what is a very good product and I hope the manufacturers put this right very soon. Minor instruction niggles aside, I am very impressed. I'd baulk a little at the full list price of fifty dollars, but as I write it's offered for under eighteen, which is very good value and I can recommend it warmly.

2014 0719I have tested the AC with the Macbook air 2013, at the same spot in the office, with the 2.4Ghz N, I have 120mbps, once I swapped to the 5Ghz AC channel, it dropped to 39mbps...And I am not that far from the AP... within 20ft, no mirror or wall between us.With the Airport Express, I do have better mbps, but I do like the management software.Overall, I will try to return this AC  even it has been more than a month and go for the lower version because there is no point to spend 300 for the AC when the coverage(with speed concern) is even slower than the 2.4Ghz.2014 0715Finally... I see the 5Ghz SSID, because we have to change the SSID name for 5Ghz manually, not like the Apple, there is an option to check to activate the 5Ghz channel at the page where you create the SSID/password.In my case, I created the SSID/password... etc under wireless setting, then I will have to go to the AP configuration(this is in another tab) --> WLAN --> n/a(problem here,  why there is no "ac" there? I wish I could post the screenshot here) --> change the name to something else, like 5Ghz then connect to it...But the result is very bad... I was asking one of the staff there to use the iPhone to connect to it, with N@2.4Ghz, he has 97% signal, with AC@5Ghz, it dropped to 57%...I will go there and check the actual mbps speed.I will still get Unifi AP but not AC... I though the Apple AC is bad because we don't get the real giga-wireless speed and this is even worse.2014 0624The technician Adam said that the maximum speed is 450mbps...I am lost... I am really lost...Did I buy a AC router? I have a AC ready laptop...I wish I could give it 0 star.2014 0621Dropped to 1 star.After few email with the Unifi technician-Adam(with screenshot of the 50-100mbps, connected to N only even with 2013 Macbook air-AC ready, less than 10feet away from it.), he said I am connected to the UAP-AC, but I am connected to N... I am very disappointed with the speed(mbps).I would rather go for the lowest version since the AC is not in function, why would I spend 300bucks for just b/g speed.I have the Time Capsule(AC) at home, and I am connected as AC with 867mbps.If someone can point out the correct AC setting for me, please help.==================2014 0615Finally, I have time to do testing with it.I am testing it with a 2013 Macbook Air(AC wireless ready).The coverage is really good with this one, I am always with 90% and back then I have around 50% at the same spot.BUT I can't get AC working?! The wireless speed that I have is only 145mbps, even worse than the N@5Ghz.I will contact the support regarding the 2.4 or 5Ghz and also the AC?!==================2014 0601Windows server 2008 R2Windows xp SP3Cisco SG 300-52Cisco SF 302-08MPFIOS 100mbps/25mbpsThe server already have Java 7 update 25 installed with 32 and 64bits, but the installation file still download an older version and do the java installation, of course it is failed.Then I tested it on a XP computer with no java installed, the Unifi installation file still failed with their own Java installation somehow?!Anyway, I installed the same Java that I have on the server manually then do the software installation, then it is good...Since I did the installation remotely, so I haven't test the speed yet, the coverage seems pretty good, I really like we can upload the floor plan map and locate each AP.I have it connected to a Cisco PoE instead.Will test it with Macbook Air(AC) and Lenovo x240(AC) next week.And I am not really looking for speed, since this is more like a guest wifi and for the boss's laptop. I hope it can run stable like those 2 Cisco switches, I haven't reboot them for more than 1 year(since I first boot it up).
summary: Software installation is not easy?! Because of the Java.

reviewText: Plugged it in and worked great reading CDs.  I haven't tried to burn anything yet.  Very lightweight which is great for travel.

reviewText: I saw reviews from folks with Windows 8 that were not good so I was worried about any of these units.I have a new computer with Windows 8.1 Pro.  Needed a DVD drive to load Office 2010 and printer soft wear.  This was absolutely "plug and play".  I'm very new with Windows 8 but it only took me a few minutes to located my drive on the computer,  Loaded my disc and everything worked like magic. I didn't have to add anything to my computer. I will try to play a DVD movie and see what happens and will add to this review later. I primarily wanted to use this for soft wear and writing files.  No problems with that. I find this unit very quiet.  No whizzing and whirring.  Just a smooth very soft hum.  No clicks and clacks as others have described other units.  It is very sleek and does not look cheap.
summary: Worked perfectly right out of the box.

reviewText: Was not sure about this item when I bought it but when it came it placed it into window [got trees out there too] and it picked up 19 channels right out the gate on an overcast day. Picture quality is sharp just as it would be paying for cable. I am an amateur photographer and my new 70D that I purchased a couple months ago at B&H; has been doing the same underexposure stunt that so many others have experienced (For example, see in depth discussions by searching the internet for Canon 70D bounce flash underexposure).This occurs whether I'm bouncing the flash off a white ceiling that's about eight feet high or using a Sto-fen diffuser attached to my Canon 430ex II in E-TTL mode.Whether the lens being used is the Canon 15-85 or the 55-250 STM, all low light indoor photos with the diffuser attached and with the flash head tilted 45 degrees, or 180 degrees, or direct facing are very underexposed. Same results with bouncing the flash off the ceiling. The photos are even more underexposed when I'm zooming in on the subject.However, If I use Flash Exposure Lock(FEL) before snapping the photo, they all come out looking great, zooming in or not. Without using FEL, the pictures are way underexposed.If I use the same flash setup in the flash's manual mode, without using FEL, and adjust the power down to say 1/2 or 1/4 or somewhere in between, the photos seem properly exposed (as long as I dial in the correct flash power adjustment). With a zoom that has a variable aperture, it's a hit and miss approach and quite cumbersome.Also, I tried the same lenses attached to my Canon T3i taking the same photos as I did with the 70D using the same flash and diffuser without using FEL. The photos all came out looking perfect with no underexposure whatsoever. Then I tried using FEL with the T3i. There was no difference between using FEL and not using it on my T3i. All photos with and without FEL were properly exposed and looked great.I use bounce flash indoors a lot for our one year old granddaughter. I never had this problem, or any other issue, with my T3i. I guess I'll have to resort to FEL use, but that amount flashes takes a toll on an infant. She begins to cry after a few photos if I'm using FEL for each one. Plus, it's hard to get candid shots when an FEL pre-flash is being used.This isn't what I bargained for when I "upgraded" my camera body.I'm now wondering if this will negatively effect exposures on outside fill flash photos with a diffuser attached.The fact that Canon hasn't addressed this yet is disconcerting to say the least. Unless they come up with a fix fairly quickly, I'm not sure I'd ever buy another Canon camera after this.
summary: Huge defect in the 70D; Extreme underexposure using bounce flash

reviewText: OK, this is a first for me when dealing with Amazon.  I received an obviously used camera.  Yes, I bought it direct from Amazon and not from a third party.  I took it out of the box and the Live View mode wasn't working reliably: I had to reset the camera twice by pulling the battery out in the first few hours of use.  I asked Amazon for a replacement.By comparing the original to the replacement, it became obvious that I was shipped a product that someone else had already used, and possibly returned due to the problems I saw.  Here are signs you can use if you suspect similar:-The USB cable and neck strap should be sealed in individual plastic bags.  Mine were loose.-The manuals should be sealed.  There should be a CD and several errata and warranty cards loose.  Mine were all loose.-The used camera had the battery fully charged.  The replacement started charging from 0-49%.-The rear lens cap on the kit lens was marred noticeably.-The shutter would click when the live view button was pressed, but the LCD screen would stay blank.  The only way to recover from this was to remove and reseat the battery.-The first camera was set up to shoot RAW.  The default out of the box is typically jpeg.-Images taken with the camera were numbered starting at 2561 instead of 0001.-The date was set on the first camera.  The replacement asked me to set date and time.To their credit, Amazon made it right quickly and without cost to me, but the fact that it happened at all is a bit of a shock.  At the end of the day, trust the glowing reviews of this product.  It's a great camera with an outstanding feature set.  Just don't unknowingly get someone else's problem.  My guess is an unscrupulous 70D owner bought a second camera from Amazon and swapped them rather than just sending their camera in for service.  Not cool.
summary: Got a used camera from Amazon

reviewText: than having any of my Nikon speedlights hit the floor because I didn't quite get the mounting correct.Admittedly, I have a pea-sized brain and need all the help I can get when shooting.  The Frio is well-designed and is fabricated from what appears to be nylon.  I may not get six of these cold shoes but then again, any one could save me from an expensive event.This product - or something similar - would make a great open-source/licensed 3D file for printing. I have to say I was very disappointed with this Adonit stylus, after using other Adonit styli and be happy with their performance.  This product is good in theory, but falls well short in Execution.The good:  nicely weighted and comfortable in writing with.  Pairs easily with Bluetooth on an iPadThe bad: tip scores screen protectors; significant lag in signal from execution of a writing stroke to translating that on-screen, which has tendency to mess me up in what I'm writing; does not write well in most programs, with a fair amount of imprecision from too large to too small from the stroke made; shuts off too often while being usedWhile it writes decently overall, it doesn't work better than it's not Bluetooth brethren, and certainly not against it's cost.  Frankly overall this product doesn't justify the expense in my mind, but might have if it worked much better.I don't recommend wasting money on this product
summary: Nice concept, needs major work, waste of money

reviewText: Taking Forever.  Isn't this a piece of paper?  Why does it take weeks to receive?  Not happy and getting a bad feeling.

The first thing I noticed, and felt, was how nice this case looked.  It's almost like holding a good leather-like book.  There is also a strap on the edge to make it easier to carry.  However, I actually didn't use the strap at all, so I removed it.The entire case is well constructed, and especially the zipper.  It feels nice and secure and not at all flimsy like some zippers can be.There's an inside pocket that is nice for tucking away a few papers or what-not.  The price is compatible with most other cases and since you get such great quality I think it's a good deal.

Ok, just got a new HDX Kindle and my 7 year old will be using it most of the time, so need a really good case.  It was easy to get onto the Kindle and its very sturdy.  Looks like it can handle all my son can throw at it or the kindle.  A very good case.

I was disappointed to discover upon receiving this item that it was white with purple accents which I found to be a bit unattractive.  Nevertheless I wanted to try it out and put my Kindle in the case.  As I did so I realized how really watertight this case was.  It seals up completely if all the plugs covering the outlets are secured.  This is a tough case that sheaths the Kindle in thick layer of material (plastic?) that provides excellent shock absorption and protection.  The screen is the only more vulnerable part and that is necessary in order to be able to see it.  There is a raised ridge around the screen which provides protection if the Kindle is face down.  After using it for several weeks I still see no vulnerabilities and have found it to proved excellent protection from water and bumps.  I have not tested it by immersing it but I think it would survive the experience.I have a more attractive case but have not used it because I find that protection trumps style for my Kindle.  I certainly cannot afford to damage it, and as I have killed a few Kindle's already I am very protective of my current edition.  If only it was more beautiful. . .

I have last year's version of this cover in several colours and finishes and just love it. So, when I ordered the newer version of the Kindle Fire for myself, passing on last year's Fire to my granddaughter, it was a "No Brainer" for me to buy this type of cover, again.I've read several reviews that down-mark it for how THEY read, which is to fold the cover back. Their viewpoint is legitimate and I honour that viewpoint. However, I only read with the cover held like a paperback, with the cover held in both hands. IF you read like that, then the very light weight and nicely textured cover will work for you with no problems. However, I can't speak to the alternative way of reading with this cover, since I don't hold my Kindle that way.I love how this cover has NO SHARP CLIPS OR CORNERS, like other covers I've tried. After several hours of reading, I am forced to put my Kindle down, because I actually have red welts where the clips dig into my hands. :( The stand portion is also very stable for video or web browsing and has never slipped from it's position.All in all, how I use this case, it works well in all applications for me. :D

This little cover is just perfect for my new Kindle Fire HD! I love the look and the feel; it holds my Kindle firmly in place and allows me to adjust the angle with ease. I had ordered a leather cover for my Kindle when I first got it, but this one is by far nicer and simply better looking. Ideal cover!

I have a Kindle Fire HDX so this doesn't really fit all that well.  I couldn't use the buttons inside the thing.  But it would make a good carrying case to transport it in since I can zip the Kindle inside.  I like that it has a little loop for my stylus and some pockets for other stuff.  One little annoyance is the chain for carrying it ends up right next to the zipper, so naturally I reach for the wrong thing half the time.  And the gold color looks like someone used a can of spray paint, kind of cheap.Still if you have an older model Kindle it's an OK option.That is all.

They keep bragging about the design but it makes it so every time you go to read the origami thing opens. I actually returned it when when Kindle fell right out of it. Good thing I was reading on my bed and not somewhere that it could have shattered the front.  If you are not concerned about your kindle falling out, which I am not the only one that has had this happen, then whatever. I personally don't want mine ruined as they are not cheap and the case is way too expensive for the quality.

I love my Origami case; it only folds one way but stands horizontal and vertical without problems.  The only drawback is that the Kindle Fire HDX is a beautifully lightweight little tablet by itself, and the case makes it heavier and bulkier.  The case compensates for this added weight and bulk though by being actually useful in holding the Kindle in any horizontal or vertical position without slipping, collapsing or falling, and that compensates for the added weight since I don't have to hold the Kindle.  It makes reading in bed or watching a movie in bed easy and hands off.  I do think when I play games or surf or do other things that are more "hands on", it is too heavy.  Otherwise I would give it five stars.Keep the design, but hopefully, come out with something lighter but still with the rigidity of the original cover and you have a real winner.  It's definitely better than any other case I've tried, and I've tried several, but it's not perfect yet because of weight and bulk.
summary: This case would be perfect but it's a little too heavy

reviewText: I got the Chromecast a few weeks ago, and returned it in favor of a NetGear Push2TV Wi-Di/Miracast device.Chromecast, as advertised, was outrageously easy to set up. reviewText: I had a Asus TF300T and love it but with all I do I needed something with more ram. Being a Google girl and Asus fan, I went with the Nexus 7. It is all I wanted with the exception of expandable memory.  Would recommend to any one!

I just had to buy both of these tablets for a new job and was happy to finally have the chance to test both, head to head. There are an exhaustive number of great reviews on both already so I'll keep it brief.The iPad mini simply doesn't compare. This Nexus has far better hardware. It runs faster than iPad mini, by far and the internet loads far more quickly. AppStore loads way slower than Google Play on Nexus and downloads are much faster on Nexus even though both are on the same network.Cosmetically, I prefer the wide screen format of Nexus over iPad's older screen dimension.  The clarity is clearly better on Nexus too. Also, the text on iPad is minuscule to the point of being annoying. I enabled large fonts and even went into the Accessibility options and activated the largest text and bold, and still the fonts are about 6pt at best. Very inconvenient. Nexus isn't like that and I find it much easier to read. Activating the dark background on iPad did help some though. The screen just isn't as vibrant as Nexus. iPad does have a decent 3 finger tap zoom feature, but it sorely needs to be improved in this arena.  Nexus also has zoom features, but I find I don't really need it, where as, with iPad, it's an absolute must.Graphic intensive games play far better on Nexus than iPad, though I will say the overall game quality seems to be a tad better on iPad.  Angry Birds is Angry Birds. It renders faster on Nexus, but iPad seems to have a more interesting selection of apps I've never seen before. But I'm new to iPad so maybe the App Store is just more of a novelty right now.  I will say that I find Google Play far easier to navigate and more pleasing to the eye.  And generally, App Store's free apps seem to be riddled with heavy handed advertising. You see that on some Google Play apps too, but not as aggressively as iPad.I have always considered myself an Android guy, and in all honesty, I don't see that changing.  I have an 8.9" Fire HDX for personal use and this Nexus and my iPad for work.  I'd say that iPad has done nothing to sway me over to iOS. I like it, but it just doesn't hold a match to either HDX or Nexus, as far as user experience and power.  If I had to pick just one, I'd say this Nexus is the winner, due to the specs and form factor.I got my iPad mini for a great deal at 230 brand new. But it's only 16gb and has less than half the computing power of Nexus.  I paid 221 for my Nexus and it's 32gb. This Nexus just offers way more for the money than iPad, which typically can't be had new for under $270.Having used both iPad mini and Nexus on a daily basis for work -- hands down, Nexus is the clear winner in price, function, usability and quality. Not even close. Sorry iPad.

The system is affordable and useful, yet there are some areas that can use improvements.Pros:- The system is expandable, in case you live in a large house with many windows and doors, the sensors can be bought separately.- It's not exactly a breeze, but it is relatively easy to setup once you view the videos on their website.- Ability to use either GSM or landline to get notified of an alarm.- Multiple numbers can be stored on the system.Cons:- The Zone names are not customizable. Zone is just an area of the house which can hold multiple sensors. They are pre-set to a certain description that may or may not match the actual area. Zones are labelled as window, door, fire, hall etc. It's doesn't interfere with the functionality of the system, but I like to have accurate descriptions of the zones such as Kitchen, Bedroom, Living room etc. This makes the system more neat if I could tell where exactly the break in/ false alarm happened.- The main console doesn't tell which sensor triggered the alarm. So each zone can have up to 10 sensors. It would be very convenient if the main console identified which sensor sent the trigger signal. It would be even better if I could label each sensor separately (such as kitchen door, backyard door, bedroom window, hallway motion sensor). It does identify the zone, but that doesn't tell me a whole lot in terms of preventing false alarms. I have had a few false alarms, they were mostly due to family members who were roaming around the house, but one or two false alarms happened in the middle of the night when everyone was asleep. I have a theory that it was the motion sensor that picked up something like a bug crawling over it, but I can't confirm it because the main console doesn't tell me which sensor was responsible for the alarm.- The key fobs are old fashioned and very basic. The system can be controlled by a keyfob that comes with it (this one comes with three). The four keys on it can disarm, arm at home, arm when leaving, and sound the alarm. The keys have to be pressed with a bit of pressure. I advised all the family members to press and hold it for at least half a second to let the system disarm/arm. The keys can be pressed really quickly and the red LED lights up as if the signal was sent, but it doesn't send the signal. A quick tap almost never sends the signal. The key has to be pressed down for at least half a second with some pressure for it to work. And when it does work, there is no way to tell if the system is disarmed unless you are next to the console and hear it say "system disarmed". I have a few people who live in a part of the house that's on the opposite side of the console. For them there is no way to tell if the system is disarmed in case they need to get to the bathroom or something in the middle of the night. There is no feedback on the keyfobs to determine the state of the system. Personally I rather have an app to control it, which brings me to my next point.The connectivity is archaic. Yes the fact that there is GSM connectivity on this alarm system is not that impressive. It can send and receive text messages, and make phone calls and can be armed/ disarmed with a text message, but that is simply not enough in today's world. We live in the era of Nest thermostats and smart phones. I would like the system to have wifi connectivity and be able to communicate to my smart phone over the internet. I would also like to get an app that can do everything that the main console does (ok not everything but things that I do on a daily basis such as arm/disarm/ check logs and reports). I like to get notifications if the alarm has been triggered. I know I can get a phone call or a text message through GSM, but that requires additional monthly fee for the cellular service. I also know that a call can be made via the landline as well, but I rather get notifications on my phone instead. Having a configuration page for the alarm system (like printers do) would make configuration setup much easier as well. I don't see why it still cannot be done. They can simply introduce a wireless IP module that can program the main console wirelessly. Once the IP module is up and running it can use the internet connection to communicate with the phone.These are just some suggestions and ideas to improve on this system. I am personally happy with the purchase so far and the system works as advertised. It's just small things that can be improved to make the user experience even better. I am still giving the system a four star rating which means it's a pretty decent system.
summary: Decent alarm system with a lot of room for improvement

reviewText: This is a great starter kit for Canon PowerShot SX510.  It contains:(2) Vivitar batteries for the SX510(1) Charger with USA plug, Car charger plug and European plug.(1) Empty spray vial for lens cleaning solution.(1) Soft lens brush.(1) Bulb duster with silicone bulb and removable tip.(1) Microfiber dusting cloth.The batteries I have tested and they work well.  I charged them with the included charger and the charger works well.  It has a light to let you know when the battery is charging and when it is fully charged.  The charger has a flip out plug that folds back into the unit for storage.You CAN get two of these batteries by themselves, without the kit items.  However, for only $5 more you can get this kit and the charger itself is worth more than those $5.  So, if you don't already have some of these items, it would pay you to get this kit.You will likely be satisfied with this item.  This kit contains good quality items you will use for years.  I highly recommend this kit.
summary: Great kit for Canon PowerShot SX510

reviewText: I have to echo the views of the "most helpful critical review" to date. This device comes with software suitable for utter novices, but the transfer speed is so bad as to render that advantage completely moot. I have gotten mainly 0.5MB transfer speeds or so. Pathetic. Takes an eternity to transfer anything for storage. I tried Wireless, Ethernet, and USB, and all had the same result. Once you've got it all stored, you're not going to want to change it, because it will take another decade or two.

When I ordered my new "trash can" Mac Pro, I knew I needed more screen real estate.  While there are plenty of 27" monitors that look good, I was after monitors that had color depth and fidelity.  It came down to Asus vs ViewSonic.  Both were highly-regarded for their price range, but ViewSonic was back-logged until forever.  So Asus it was.I broke the monitors in on my older Mac Pro (DVI).  Single-channel DVI won't carry the full resolution of the screen, but results were encouraging.  The new Mac showed up a couple of weeks ago and I hooked it up with Thunderbolt/Display port cables. My-oh-my! They're certainly quick enough (I'm not a gamer, so I don't drive that aspect particularly hard) and the color fidelity is excellent.  These are factory calibrated.  I do wonder what will happen as they age.  I have a colorimeter, but I don't know if it has enough resolution to help with these monitors.  I suppose we'll see when the time comes.  At the moment it looks great and detail on my photographs shows up crisply.  Gradients look very nice.Most monitors these days also provide USB ports.  In the majority of cases, those are USB-2.  The inclusion of USB-3 on these Asus monitors is a nice bit of future thinking.  Hoods are also included (I didn't notice that part in the writeup) so it's easier to control glare from room lights.  There are also cables for every format supported by the monitor--on the short side to be sure--but most people keep the computer fairly close by their workspace.Another review complains about this monitor on Mac, but he/she was using HDMI.  Don't.  HDMI doesn't carry the full resolution of this monitor, so anything you see will be upscaled from a regular HD resolution.  Be sure to use either Display Port or Dual-Channel DVI and you'll be a happy camper.
summary: Nice monitor that works nicely on new Macs

reviewText: Bought this for mother to replace an old laptop.  It is taking her some time to get used to it, but I was so impressed with this tablet when I helped her get it set up.  Really feels like quality, easy to use, great display, great value! Would recommend.

When the drive was working it was great averaging around 70MB/s during transfers.  However, now I have a problem with frequent disconnects during transfers.  I will get a pop up that says file not found or busy and then a Try Again or skip....Try Again usually works, but it gets annoying doing that time and time again.  There is a new firmware update available from 12/12/13 that seems to fix that problem, but the firmware update software can not find an internet connection...tried on three different networks: work, home, and cell phone.  No problems browsing the internet or downloading software.  Disabled Firewall and Antivirus still does not work.No way to download the firmware manually.  An internet search turned up that they have had this problem with their Firmware software since as far back as 2010, granted this drive hasn't been around this long, but perhaps they need to spend some much needed money on a competent programmer to fix their train wreck of a software package.  If I had written this review two months ago, I would have had high praises for this drive.  Unfortunately, I find this drive to be to unreliable to trust with my backups.  I will be going back to the Seagate drives, which I still have three 500GB drives from two or three years ago still working great.Edit (June 2014): modifying my review to a 4-star.  It appears the cable was the culprit of all my problems. However, it would be nice if the cables lasted a little longer. I haven't re-attempted the firmware updater.
summary: WD Firmware update software does not work

reviewText: Cards stays cool even after hours of gameplay will get another soon to run SLI. Price wasn't to bad seen higher priced cards not perform as well.

I was excited to receive my new Samsung Evo 250GB SSD and use the Sabrent to clone my laptop HDD. All worked perfectly until I tried to remove the drive. Stuck. Tried to nudge the drive. Stuck. Tried tweezers. Stuck and scratched (only minor). Tried a teflon spatula. More stuck. Finally, I ended up having to basically perform surgery on the opposite end with an exact-o knife. The case itself is incredibly well-constructed, which made it nearly impossible to get the drive out. Be very careful with this case, guess mine will have to go in the trash now since one end is destroyed. SSD did survive (go Evo!), in case you were wondering.-- Update --Sabrent customer service was proactive and mailed me a new case. I definitely appreciate the effort but I will also never put an SSD in there again. At least it's a nice case for my old laptop HDD. So in summary, my review should read:HDD: 5 starsCustomer Service: 5 starsSDD: 1 star (at least for one of the most popular SSDs on the market, you're welcome to try your own brand if you're feeling adventurous!)
ONE DAY AFTER RECEIPT IT WOULD NOT TAKE WD REGISTRATION.  IT APPEARS THIS WAS SOLD AND REGISTERED OVER A YEAR AGO.
summary: NOT ABLE TO REGISTER AS NOT IN WD SYSTEM OR INVALID SN

reviewText: I just use this to back up my data and my wife's data from our passports and going to use it to back up a mirrored raid system when I set that up.  A little noisier than passports due to the open vent system and larger drive, so that is to be expected.  After transfering files to it, it made a lot of noise and ran constant even when I wasn't accessing it for anything, don't be alarmed by this.  I thought something was messed up and did some research but apparently it is normal because the drive has to sort out information for the files you put on it (technical stuff that I don't fully understand).  After a couple days of this constant activity it finished doing what it needed to do and went to normal with no activity unless it was from me accessing it.  All in all a good drive and I have never had a WD drive fail on me yet (knock on wood).
summary: It does everything that I need it to.

reviewText: Got this as an upgrade to an older SSD I had, and it is as big of a difference as when I switched from HDD to SSD. It says 540/520 R/W and I got about 520/500 on a quick test I did, not a single complaint here these are awesome speeds.

I installed this unit as my boot drive for Windows 8 in my y510p. The drive is very light and power efficient. Neither of these really matter for my implementation. Durability seems good as I had to install Windows and all my apps twice as I forgot to remove my UEFI from the second hard drive. The drive handled this well.Rather, I was after the raw speed of an SSD. I haven't benchmarked R/W speeds, you can find those all over the net. It is noticeably faster. Applications start from cold instantly. My form of benchmark involved starting windows, typing my login ( which is very consistent by now ) and letting steam finish starting up. I repeated this three times for consistency. My mechanical drive alone was  75 seconds. Mechanical plus the 24gb mSata SSD in Express Cache ( this is the stock configuration of this computer ) accomplished this in 56 seconds. The EVO SSD cold boots to Steam in 34 seconds.As for capacity, I have all my apps installed on it and it's really only half full. Overall I highly recommend this drive to anyone who thinks their computer is too slow. Chances are the processor is not your problem, just bloat and storage speed. If it doesn't work then buy and new computer and stuff this in it anyways and join us in 2014!
summary: Awesome drive for an awesome price

reviewText: I had an intel i5 laptop with 16 gigs of ram on it. The laptop would still freeze occasionally and application boot up time was over 30 seconds for memory/processor intensive apps like photoshop. I decided to do some sleuthing and figured out that disk reads were the bottle-neck!Got on amazon and ordered myself a Samsung 840 EVO 750Gigs. The transition from my old 5400 rpm to SSD was smooth, it only took about 2 hours to completely image my computer (used USB 3). Popped in my SSD.. and volla! the computer runs like a beast! Application boot times down to 3 - 5 seconds. restart happens under 15 seconds. everything looks great now, the way it should be :)

reviewText: Very impressed with this film. However, I thought I knew what I was doing and spent quite a few minutes trying to push out air bubbles that wouldn't go away. When I FINALLY read the instructions I realized there are 2 "coverings" protecting the film. I had only removed one. Once I realized THAT everything went smoothly. the film goes on great and has the proper openings on front. It was put on my 10 yo's tablet and so far it's been great!

This is a good inexpensive 2 meter/440 radio. Sure there are better radios out there, but they can be and most often are a bit pricey. But, if you're looking for something that you keep in the car and aren't to worried about losing or having stolen. Or just looking for back-up, then this little radio can fill the bill. For me it has had no problems hitting the local repeaters around town and has a pretty good transmit signal on just the stock antenna and fair receive audio. It does pretty good as far as battery life. I get a solid 6 to 8 hrs of use out of it. I recommend getting or using the optional programming cable and software. Programming from the keypad is a bit tedious. I use "CHIRP" rather than using the manufacture's software.
summary: Baofeng UV-82 Dual-Band 136-174/400-520 MHz FM Ham Two-way Radio

reviewText: Skylanders SWAP Force Sheep Wreck Island Adventure Pack opens another level in the game Skylanders SWAP Force like Tower of Time. Sheep Wreck Island is a fun level but it is a little short to me. Sheep Wreck Island also comes with a character Wind-Up and two magic items Platinum Sheep and Groove Machine. Wind-Up is a tech Skylander that is a little different then other Skylanders. Wind-Up has to be wound-up or he will slow down and move very slow. Wind-Up is a great character and in my opinion worth buying the Sheep Wreck Island Adventure Pack just for him. The magic item Platinum Sheep turns any character you are playing with into a sheep for a short period of time. This helps you go by enemies without fighting them. The magic item Groove Machine plays music that makes the enemies dance so you can go by them. At least that is what happened to me in the game.
summary: Sheep Wreck Island Adventure Pack it's a Keeper

I came back from a photo trip with 2 big Canon DSLRs, one full frame, the other an APS-C sized sensor, a number of lenses, filters,, flash equipment, etc. in a large camera bag and backpack. Must have weighed close to 60 pounds. Figuring I could get at least 85% of the quality with my Lumix travel camera and probably 95% with the proper mirrorless system I decided it was time to downsize. After much research of reviews, trying the ones I could find locally I decided on the GX7. I have not been disappointed. Much of my prior work which involved tedious routines almost become automatic with this machine. The thing that swayed me over others like the  Sony and Samsung, Canon and Nikon units with interchangeable lenses was the viewfinder which those other choices lacked. The camera will require a lot of work on my part to get back to my prior level of expertise but that is due to the amazing electronic capabilities built into the camera; it takes some practice to become automatic. Why not 5 stars? I would have preferred a larger APS-C size sensor or full frame rather than the micro four thirds system of this one but the few cameras with the larger sensor and a viewfinder are almost double the cost. For the more advanced photographer, this solidly built camera is a great choice.

I recently bought this to extend my wifi router at home, I know it's a first world problem "My house is too big!" Anyway, so this extender works wonderfully when it works, occasionally it gives out and doesn't work, and I have to reset it.

I have a new TP router and even with the ability to use the WPA button push between the two, it didn't connect. The ethernet method was quick though and frankly, I preferred to do it that way anyway. I was only giving the push button a shot to see if it worked. I put the extender in my den where signal to devices was very low most of the time and right off the bat, signal was now excellent there and everywhere in the house in fact. The problem though is the signal on it was only two bars which is not recommended, and a speed test showed that to be true- horrible at DL 3.09 and UL at 4.44. So I moved it to my laundry room, where the signal remains high showing full bars. Even though the extender is in that closed room and not out in the open in the den, the signal on all devices is very good to excellent and speed tests now show DL at 17.41 and UL at 5.29. This for me is respectable. So be advised, the extender will show excellent signal to devices even if the extender itself is showing only 2 bar signal, which is sub par. Do not call it a day with that. Move the extender around until it shows good signal itself. THEN you're really getting the benefit. And don't let a wall stop you from choosing a location for it. If the signal is strong to the extender, it'll still be optimal in other rooms as well. In my den now where signal was very low, it's now excellent and web pages and videos, hbogo, netflicks, chromecast, etc is WAY better. Excellent!UPDATE- It crashed my network once, so the next thing I did was to update the firmware right away. All has been solid now. It was one firmware rev behind, out of the box. Updating it was very easy. So I think it's a good idea to update the firmware if you have any issues. Wireless is blazing now at 20/5.53 speed tests. Love it so far! Will update my review if I need to.UPDATE 2- Network crashed again today and my netbook drops connection and recovers quickly, but still drops out frequently enough to be a bother. I've since moved the extender to a spot where it's at full strength and it provides great signal to the areas that need it. Speed tests are great too. But I'm afraid the inconsistency of my wireless network because of this extender will ultimately make me pull this out of line entirely. I enjoyed a solid wireless network with a new router in line recently, albeit with some parts of the house with low signal. I'd rather have that than suffer through frequent wireless interruptions. I'll update again with my final findings, but the next one will be to drop my rating to one star and tell you to avoid this product. I'm leaving my initial review really liking this thing as a lesson- what happens in the first 12 hours using a product means virtually nothing. It's all about longevity. I'm using this product exactly as I should, even coupling it with a brand new TPlink router and it's been problematic. If two TPlink products can't work well with each other, than I don't know what to say. Will update again shortly either way.FINAL UPDATE- Not one minute after writing the second update, another wireless disconnect. So that's it- done. I wanted this to work in the worst way but it doesn't. I can only advise that in my experience, just plain avoid it- very sorry to say. Those who gamble like I did, good luck to you.

reviewText: This may provide extreme protection, but installing it is also a bit extreme, since you have to unscrew 15 screws with an Allen wrench, and in my package, it was not provided.  Fortunately, I had the correct size, and was able to unscrew all 15, pull the case apart, cringing the whole way since it sounded like it was tearing, installed the iPad, and screwed all 15 screws back in.The ports are all defended by plastic/rubber pieces that pull out, except the volume control, which is really difficult to use, especially for a child, if that is your intended use.  The charge port is finicky, and will not accept all charge cords.  We have a few of the AmazonBasics usb to lightning cords, which are, in my opinion, better than the Apple cords, but will not fit.So, I had fun removing the iPad from the case again, and 15 screws after beginning that project, I discovered it is quite a challenge to get it open with the iPad inside.In the end, I discovered no iPad Air owner in my household wants to use it.

reviewText: Wow.  This is a truly amazing little camera.  I bought this to replace my Nikon Coolpix.  I had my coolpix for just over 12 months when it broke, due to no fault of my own, and it was going to cost $150 to repair.  Rather than repair a camera that I liked but didn't love, I decided to make a new purchase.My initial intention was to purchase a Canon Rebel, I have used my mom's in the past and really love that camera.  I loved using the interchangeable lenses and the ability to manually focus.  Seeing the cost though ($500+,) plus the cost of additional lenses, it just wasn't in my price range at the moment and I needed a new camera urgently.  If you're looking for a DSLR, do not expect this to function the same.  It's a powerful little camera, but it is NOT a DSLR.  If you're an amateur photographer and have no intention of taking a class to learn how to use the functions of a DSLR, this is a perfect camera for you.So began my research.  It became a toss up between the Canon SX510 and the Nikon L820.  Reviewers were split between the two, some preferring the Nikon, some preferring the Canon.  They seemed to come out about even except in a few minor categories, and having been very pleased with the Canon Rebel, I decided to go with the Canon despite it costing about $30 more than the Nikon.Pro's-*30x Optical zoom - awesome, no more grainy pictures of kids on stage during performances*Built in wifi - go ahead and upload your pics to facebook, send them to your phone, or directly to your wireless printer.*Manual setting - can do your own iso settings, white balance, shutter speed etc.  The auto setting works fabulously in most cases, far better than any camera I've ever owned, but the option is there for those times it's just not adjusting quite how you want it.*CMOS sensor provides for a clearer image, especially on the macro setting, than my own eyes give me.*Zoom assist - for when you use your 30x zoom but lose your subject*Size - for anyone that has gone hiking with a DSLR and multiple lenses, you know what a pain that can be.  This lighter camera is perfect for running around and still has a lot of the qualities that you'd look for in a DSLR.  So unless you're out taking professional shots, this comes in really handy*Discreet mode - This is a setting on the dial, great for those events when there is no flash allowed.  In this mode, the camera doesn't make noise when turning it on, nor does the flash go off.  Even if the camera goes off and you turn it back on, because it is set on the dial, it doesn't reset itself.  I've accidentally had my flash turned back on so many times that way on previous cameras.Cons -*Very poor manual - A lot of skipping around to get one thing done.  IE Looking through the start up manual, it says "for instructions on attaching (the lens cap cord and neck strap) please see the user manual on the canon website"  Granted, it wasn't difficult to figure out, but there was no clear spot for the lens cap cord, and it is something that should have been included in a "start-up" manual.  Another example of a poor manual, referring to the downloadable pdf manual...say you want to learn how to use the miniature setting...so it says "miniature setting, pg 48"  You go to pg 48 and it says to follow steps 1 and 2 on page 46....okay back to page 46, got that down, back to page 48.  It seems to be this way when trying to learn how to access any of the features.  I can't fault the actual camera for this, but definitely Canon.  I actually made up my own cheat sheet for accessing my favorite features until I have it down.*No ability to manually focus - Being that this camera is not a DSLR, I didn't expect or really even hope for this feature.  I would have liked it, but for the $$, I definitely can't complain and will upgrade in the future.*Mirrorless - I would definitely prefer to use a viewfinder, I am used to going without though, so it's easy to work around.*No Raw Shooting - this feature doesn't apply to most people, but sometimes I prefer to use it*No Touch Screen - This is taking time for me to get used to, I find myself constantly tapping the screen.  My last 2 cameras, going back to 2010, have been touch screen, so I'm surprised to find this camera doesn't have one.Some reviewers have complained about the difficulty of accessing the wifi, this was fairly easy for me and took about 15 minutes max.  It's a little more work than it typically takes to connect a device to wifi,and you have to use the computer to do it, but it's still not overly difficult.Despite the cons, I'm still incredibly impressed with this camera and it has definitely earned 5 stars when taking into account the type of camera, the construction, and the value.  I'm very happy with this purchase despite the fact that I was hoping for my next camera to be the Rebel.  I never imagined I'd get a camera of this level of quality for under $400.  (I paid $229, could have bought a slightly cheaper one, but wanted one that was Amazon fulfilled and prime)

Makes the foray from automatic cameras and point & shoots almost effortless. (RECENTLY UPDATED BELOW)My background, i have been a Pro gamer for the past 10 plus years, i have owned over 6 pairs of turtle beach headphones ranging from PDX21's to PX5's and even the PX51(Also P11 i think its called) and now i have this the PX4, one thing i noticed about it is the sound, it just does not have that strong-ness of sound erupting thru my ears like the PX5's had, while of course there is different tech beside the 2 (The Px5's are 7.1 which are why better ofc) but even then it hardly stands up Vs the P11 or Px11 i cant remember the name, I got a pair of the P11's rebuild for 41 dollars and they are just standard 2.0's and i can say they sound just as good. If you notice with the Px4's you have the ability to change the angle at which sound is coming in at you using the "Surrounding Angles" however for me i couldn't tell anything was happening at least to a degree of notice. There is no chat vol control for the Mic on this headset, as well the paperwork is lacking in that its just not enough to explain how everything works, there is no chart that explains what Beep number sound means what for sound settings on the left side of the headset.So here it isPros:-It works on the Ps4 (Only with the 3.5mm / 2.5mm double jack from headset to controller)-It's price can be cheaply bought if you don't go to GameStop (they are selling these for 159.99 and upwards here in VA)-The 5.1 dolby digital system is not that bad for the price.Cons:-Blue Tooth as of and before 2/28/2014 still is not working for the Ps4 system even tho it says you can connect (maybe its my system only i don't know)-There can be a lot of Fuzz when you connect the Jack to your Ps4 gaming Controller sometimes which for me means i have to leave a chat and reconnect or turn off the headset and or system which it to much lol.-Only reason we're buying these is all headset companies asked the Nex-Gen system producers to hold out so they could create a whole new line of headsets to sell us, why not? Everyone loves money. This is why a simple problem such as blue tooth couldn't be setup from the start of 2013 when Ps4 and Xbox one were being created and tested, they set it up to change the connection codes so your device won't connect nor show up.-Having to buy a new headset such as this one in the 1st place.-No pre-sets on this one, and cannot be connected to a computer (PC) to be upgraded.-Less wireless range then the others (Which may not be a bad thing since i don't want to get brain cancer).-Brackets will most likely break just after your warrnty is up lol.There is a lot more wrong with it but can't cover it all Lol, hope this has helped and maybe you might want to go with a different company if i were you like Triton, I have been hearing good things about em i might also.---------------------------------------------------------------UPDATE!Recently the price has dropped insanely, i bought mine at 159.00$ plus shipping, now i see they are around 100 - 115$, I bought these not 2 long ago, but amazon lies about how if the price changes they will give you the difference or something, idk what ever they are talking about. I can understand if its been like many months because items drop in price its a standard thing, but i don't think i got mine but 2 months ago at most, i should return them because i don't even need them now.New fact about older headsets, if you did not know it, you can use the older headsets for PS4 now, so don't buy this at all its just crap, there is no instructions in the paperwork that comes with this headset that explain what eat beep means, so what does 2 beeps mean, or 3,4,1 ? wtf!? i have no clue!!! Now they drop the price, this is because no one is clearly buying them, their plan failed, i may send mine back, these are trash. For god's sake and your own don't buy these.Any Turtle Beach headset such as P11's PX5, PX51, PX500 Ect... will work using the correct wire connect from the headset to the controller, if you don't believe me look it up on youtube.Post Script: I don't even use this headset any longer, i just hook up my PX51's i got a year ago to my controller and im golden lawlz, we got screwed by turtle beach up the as*.
summary: Px4 Another reason to make money off us!

reviewText: To begin with, if all you have is a flat-screen TV with the built in speakers, this will sound so much better!  The sound is much more rich and powerful than the built in speakers, and the sound bar looks really cool.  Unfortunately, if you are looking to replace a 5.1 or 7.1 surround sound system with this, you will be sorely disappointed.First off, it isn't "surround sound."  All the speakers are in the front.  Calling this "surround sound" is like saying the defensive linemen "surrounded the quarterback" at the line of scrimmage.  It just isn't possible.  It doesn't even sound like simulated surround sound.  It just sounds like a pair of stereo speakers.  I wouldn't mind so much if they had at least included outputs for your rear channel speakers.  Unfortunately, the only output is for an external subwoofer.Second, while the sound is an improvement over the built in speakers in the TV, it is not even close to the sound quality from an actual surround sound system.  The sound is much higher pitched and flatter than the surround sound receiver (I tested them side by side).  The internal subwoofers are weak enough so as to not really be noticeable when playing a movie.  When I connected my external subwoofer, it was much better.The third issue comes from controlling the sound bar.  My surround sound system uses Sony Bravia Sync (HDMI control) to run everything.  This sound bar only connects to the optical audio output from the TV.  As a result, it has to be programmed to respond to your TV remote.  The procedure to program the sound bar isn't very complicated, but it fails most of the time.  You have to program the mute, then volume down, then volume up, then power on.  If you don't do all four, and in the right order, it won't work.  If volume up fails to program, you have to clear them all and start again.  To make matters worse, it would not learn properly from the DirecTV remote that is programmed to work with the TV.  I  had to use the original remote from the TV to program it.  (When using the DirecTV remote, it learned that mute, volume up, and volume down were all "mute.")  OK, so I finally got it programmed and working, after 30 minutes of doing it over and over.  It was responding to the remote perfectly, even the DirecTV remote.  About an hour later, we lost power for nearly an hour.  When the power came back on, the sound bar would no longer respond to the TV remote nor the DirecTV remote.  I had to program it all over again.  Needless to say, at this point, I re-connected my original Sony 5.1 surround receiver and set this up in my kids' bedroom with their TV.  (It does wall-mount very nicely.)In summary, it sounds better than the internal speakers in a flat-screen TV, but nowhere near as good as a real surround sound system.  It isn't a surround sound system anyway.  The remote learning function is really bad, and it loses what it learned if the power goes out.  I'd only recommend this if you cannot set up a proper surround system in your room and you have a lot of patience to program it to learn your remote.
summary: Sounds Better than the TV's Built In Speakers

reviewText: I have owned the hard drive for about 6 months.  It was purchased to be the primary drive in the computer I use for audio recording and production.  The drive requires no drivers to install, and was easily installed into my pc case.  The price was very good and the amount of storage is great.  However, where the drive really shines is in its raw speed.  Solid state drives are fast, however they tend to corrupt files that stay on the drive for more than a year.  My pc is for audio production so it needs to be extremely stable and reliable--and as fast as humanly possible.  Because file corruption is not an option for me, I found that this was the fastest drive I could get that would also provide the reliability I need.  The price is also GREAT!  If you are using a slow drive now, you will be stunned and the performance boost that this hard drive will give you.  I can not recommend this drive enough.  If you are on the fence, just buy it.  You will love it.  I am sure of it.

This Eagle box works great.  It is easy to connect and sync with the power company.The Bidgely software is lacking.  At first glance it looks promising.  They claim to be able to see the telltale signature of your home devices like furnace, washing machine, refrigerator, etc., and itemize the energy usage of individual devices.  This is a great feature - if it worked correctly.  They say it takes some time (a couple weeks) to figure this out and that is fine but they have so far shown my refrigerator to use several times what it actually uses, it has not recognized my washing machine which we use all the time, and it lists devices we don't own.Also, there is no means to "help" the system identify devices.  For instance, it would be very simple to add a button to their software which says "Washing Machine is running" then "Washing Machine stopped".  This would help the system know what device just used x amount of energy.  Then the user could set up most all the big energy users in a household situation and actually have some useful data.  As is, it doesn't give me much more than the power company gives me.The other concern is that on their website they said that this improvement was in the works.  That was over a year ago.  Doesn't inspire confidence.  And will they be around in another year?  I hope so but they really need to improve their software.
summary: Works well and connects quickly but features are limited

I have to say that this is the best USB 2.0 powered hub available that I know of. I have used many different USB 2.0 hubs before, but every single one could never handle all of the ports being used simultaneously - NEVER. But, this unit handled all ports being used at the same time like a champ!I had a keyboard, mouse, three external optical drives, two external hard drives (and they did NOT have their own power supplies - they only were powered from the USB ports), and three flash drives. All ten devices quickly powered up when I plugged them in, and I have been using all of the devices for two days straight without a hiccup. I have never been able to get three optical drives and two external hard drives to work all at the same time from a USB 2.0 hub in the past - not to mention the mouse and keyboard and flash drives as well. I am using this hub with my laptop (and the laptop is plugged in via AC power when I use the hub and all ten devices connected to it). As a side note, when each device in plugged into one of the ports (and it is turned on if it has a power switch - like my external optical drives have) there is a blue light that lights up on the hub letting you know that that device/port is active.I highly recommend this AC powered USB 2.0 hub for anyone wanting to add lots of USB 2.0 ports to their computer, and who wants ALL of the ports to be simultaneously available and operational. This is a tremendous product!

I bought a Wacom tablet a few years ago (I think it was a Bamboo model), but I returned it immediately. I wasn't happy with the way it worked, so I was a little timid about buying this one.I decided to buy this after watching a video on Lynda.com about using brushes on Adobe Illustrator. The instructor used a $300-or so Wacom tablet to draw using different pressures. That's the feature I most wanted to get out of a tablet.I wasn't about to spend $300+ on a tablet, so I researched them and settled on this model as my "starter tablet." Within minutes I was already using it on Illustrator and creating brush strokes far more elegant with the pen than with a mouse. My daughters (both young adults) have used it and created some amazing artwork with it. In fact, my older daughter plans to purchase one in the near future.My only "gripe" about it is the button on the side. I find that I'm constantly clicking it and causing unintended actions. I haven't researched it yet, but I'm sure there's a way to disable the button as I don't think I personally have a need to use it. I've already disabled the "finger touch" capability and use it only with the supplied pen. This gripe, however, is not serious enough to drop it down a star. I still love the product.I highly recommend this tablet, especially as a "starter tablet." If I get really good at illustration and start to make some money selling my creations, then maybe I'll spring for a more expensive model. Until then, this one is perfect.

I had a Bamboo and wanted to get a better tablet - this one seems much larger than the Bamboo even though it is listed as small.  The problem I had was that the cable was way too short - I can't imagine why they made it that way.  I tried a mini USB cable and that didn't fit.  Neither did the micro fit, so I bought a USB cable extension.  I emailed Wacom for the exact name of the cable so I could try to find a 6' one and one also that didn't have the right-angle to it.  I got quick responses but essentially not too much help.  I was told the mini should work but it definitely doesn't.  She did offer this - "What I can also do for you is create a manual order for the item STJA316 which is a USB replacement. The price for this cable is $9.95+ shipping."  I decided to stick with the extension but perhaps anyone with the same problem could do that - it is 8' long but still has the right-angle.
summary: Love it but problem with the cable.
