I bought this card to replace my on board sound and drive my 7.1 surround sound headphones.. Sadly this card isn't true 7.1 surround.... I have the Razer Tiamat 7.1 headphones and the card won't drive all 7 speakers because it's missing one input for the side speakers. Sadly it only does 7.1 surround sound with specific creative speakers!! Very annoying....If your running a non-creative 7.1 speaker system OR a Tiamat headset.. Skip this card it won't work for you.. Back to Amazon it goes!
summary: Doesn't do 7.1 with non creative speakers!!! Beware!!

reviewText: To level set, I've been using BitDefender for close to a decade.  I've always found it to be a very good program for detecting things, a bit heavy on the resources, and a bit twitchy on the system.  The version i have is the same as the one listed, however it's a free upgrade from the previous version to run out the remainder of my license.  If you want the short version, I've already purchased Bitdefender Total Security to use once this runs out, so it's safe to say I recommend with minor reservations.They did seem to listen to customers with this new version.  Gone is the "You don't need scheduled scans." stance they took and it's replaced with an ability and recommendation to run them.  First thing, people like to see it running so as a marketing gimmick it's probably a good idea even if it's not strictly speaking required.  Second, given the software may be disabled at certain times, it probably is a good fail safe to do a run from time to time.  Nice to see that back.  It also doesn't seem to be quite the performance hit that it once was, though to be fair the only computers I'm running it on are an i5 laptop and an i7 desktop, which both have quite a bit of RAM so I can't say how it will run on a low end system.  Given past versions, not well.You can run in either Autopilot mode or user mode.  I personally like the latter because the former will ignore any custom settings you make and I like to do a fair amount of tweaking.  Compared to some other programs, you can't tweak a lot, but you can do things like make it ask instead of automatically scanning all removable media.  I usually disable the vulnerability scans since I run Windows Update often myself anyway.  One nice feature, it will do very limited credit monitoring for you for free.  They're not exactly doing it to be nice, the trick is it will give you a scary warning "Something has changed!", but you have to pay to figure out what.  Last time I saw it, it was that I'd opened a store credit card.Otherwise, some of the same old problems remain.  Expect to have to do a "repair install" (uninstall the program as normal and it's a choice) to restore it to working condition every few months.  It's not a huge deal as it recalls the programs you set up to automatically go to Game Mode (closest you can go to disabling the resident protection), but it will lose any settings you have in the secure browser.  Oh and that brings me to my major complaints, the secure browser is incompatible with Acronis True Image that manages my system backups.  Guess which program wins out?  So yeah, useless to me when it worked find in the last Bitdefender.  The other truly awful thing is the new Wallet.  It's intrusive password manager and you can't turn it off without disabling startup items in your registry (msconfig) as well as disabling in program.  Really, my biggest turnoff.Update 05-16-14---------------I found out a very important piece of information.  If you try to do a SystemRestore (not a reformat/refresh) in Windows 8 (Windows 8.1) while Bitdefender is installed it'll very likely perpetually fail.  If you uninstall Bitdefender, Windows System Restore should work.  However, once you successfully restored your PC, Bitdefender will probably be 1/2 way installed and not work.  I can't post a URL here, but if you go to their base website and just add /uninstall at the end of the address you should get to their uninstall tools.  Download one of those and it'll clean up the mess.  Then you'll have to reinstall the antivirus from scratch which is annoying, but at least there's a workaround.
summary: Mostly Good But Can Be Twitchy

reviewText: I have always used the older JASC versions and have been quite pleased.  After reading reviews I had doubts but needed a program to work with windows 7.  So I took the plunge and I'm very satisfied.  If you've worked with PSP before moving up to 6 is not a big adjustment and a lot fasted in the 64 bit mode.  Would recommend.
After proper installation and scanning antenna received a total of two channels. Customer service was quick to make excuses. Reinstalled old ugly antenna and will be returning this.

I have used many professional panels and crts before, I'm not going to say this is the best I have used but the price:performance ratio is outstanding.I was able to OC this up to 85Hz using stuff built into Nvidia's drivers. No problems at all using DisplayPort.Bioshock Infinite looks absolutely stunning on this screen, oh the colors! In DayZ and CSS I get more horizontal image and that provides advantages over opponents who are at 16:9 or 16:I enjoy the fact the stand tilts vertical as I am a coder and this thing fits a TON of code on it, it is a little bothersome the amount of effort it takes to get the panel flipped 90 degrees, I have an ergotron arm coming next week to fix this problem. I will definitely be able to reuse the stand in the future, something similar goes for about $50 and I can't stand to not have a vertical monitor.Viewing angles are wonderful and I get very minimal color and brightness shifting as the viewing angle changes.This is the first step in replacing my  four monitors with two. I plan on throwing a 30" 1600p on a Ergotron 30lb mount.

I was looking for a professional drawing tablet when purchasing this product, and did not do enough research. For $80, I expected a higher quality pad with many more capabilities. I am a huge fan of Wacom and all of their products, so I assumed it would be perfect for my more serious artwork. This product is perfect for the casual artist and doodler, but by no means suitable for any professional artwork.PROS:-easy to setup-sleek-comfortable-comes with stylus-allows for basic and simple drawing/doodling/sketching/etc.CONS:-expensive ($80)-no pressure sensitivity-stylus does not function perfectly-no driver providedWorth the purchase? I would not recommend this product to a serious artist, but for the casual artist or doodler, this is an enjoyable product!

I can say it is very hard to compare at a brick and morder store due to all the setting changes they put on the TV.  From all the reviews I decided on this TV. We hooked it up yesterday and I have been playing with a few setting based recommendation from message posts. I can say I am very very amazed on how good the picture quality. The blacks are as deep as the Panasonic 65VT60 (I had one), and but the colors are more vibrant. Every time I watch the TV I keep saying to myself wow. I also compared this to the Sammy 65H7150 and there is no comparison. The 65H7150 blacks are not detailed. I just see a blub. Picture details is not there and the colors/contrast seems off. Picture does not seem to be natural. When I saw the Sammy 65F8500 plasma, its was a comparable to this TV.  Again I am just amazed on the design and quality of this TV. You get the best of both worlds. The best blacks from plasma and best vibrant colors. I sure hope that Sony will keep this level of superb refinement in PQ in the new models. I initially thought the TRILUMINOS thing is another gimmick from typical manufacture but its TRUE. The colors are very beautiful. I never saw colors this AMAZING! The reality Pro is also true related to picture detail. Good luck on your selection!
summary: Amazing TV! The Colors are vibrant (Blues, Greens, Blues, Orange) and Deep blacks!

reviewText: I purchased the 100' to use in multiple projects by cutting and putting ends on.  I am sure this is good cable if used without cutting into shorter lenghts.  The shielding is double foil with very few actual wires, so its very hard to put ends on.

I knew I was taking a chance in ordering BELKIN STRIPE TAB COVER/CASE FOR IPAD AIR (IPAD 5) (INK). My teens are very picky. My youngest was the first to spot, and use it. And she loves it.The case fits, well. The magnetic tab makes opening and closing, easy. The stand is a must for watching movies. As a mom, I love the added protection.Product Information:K-Frame Keeps Tablet Securely in PlaceA built-in K-Frame keeps your tablet securely in place. When you need to remove your device, simply bend back the corners.Quality Materials with a Stylish DesignThe case's durable material makes it ideal for travel and its pinstripe adds an extra element of color and texture for a stylish look. The soft, smooth inner lining helps protect your iPad Air's touchscreen from potential damage.Accommodates Multiple Viewing AnglesThe inside of this cover is set with grooves, so you can stand your iPad Air up in different positions. This allows you to find a comfortable angle to watch videos or scroll through screens.Folds for Comfortable TypingThe Belkin Stripe Tab Cover for iPad Air can be folded down to a low position that makes typing easier. This means you can comfortably type emails or documents for extended periods of time.Magnetic Tab Holds Cover in PlaceWith the case's built-in magnetic tab, you'll have a simple but secure way to keep your cover closed. When you need to use your iPad Air, that same tab reverses to keep the cover out of your way as you work.Available in Three ColorsThe Belkin Stripe Tab Cover for iPad Air comes in Black, Ink, and Burgundy, so you can choose whichever style best fits you and your tablet.

Edited...After having borrowed these several times and listening to them, I still say the quality is "good," but it's not $200-good.  I took the opportunity to compare these to some $70 headphones I own, and quite frankly preferred mine. Now that Apple has bought the Dr. Dre line, I KNOW they are too expensive and if you buy these, you are paying for the "b" on the side, not the beats from the inside.  My downgrade in starts is based on quality for your buck.  They are just not worth it............................................I was not impressed by the costs of these, but my daughter had to have them.  But after listening to them I have to admit the sound quality is among the best I've every listened to in a headphone.  I would prefer the over the hear version more, but these are comfortable and sound great.  I especially like the way the cord plugs in right at the earphone, so less likely to have a damaged cord at a strain-relief going into the headphones.  The cord is durable and of better (more robust) design, than say some of the Bose headphones I've owned.
summary: Good headphones, but too expensive -- find something cheaper!

reviewText: Well lemme just say I was BLOWN away by the sound quality of these fantastic headhpones. I have a pair of Shure 940s, but I wanted something with some color. I got these and now I realize that my very expensive Shures don't adequately represent the bass correctly.  Also, compared to my Shures, these do a great job of masking out the mid and high frequencies, probably so that they can be more accurate on the low end.In fact the audio quality is SO good, that I now realize that all my life I have been hearing music the WRONG way.  All music really contains mostly bass, and other headphones are just too cheap to represent it correctly.As far as build quality, these fell rock solid. I don't detect any cheap bits in the folding joints, cable, connectors or the ear pads. They seem like they will last a long time.  I would have thought these were made in the USA!But now let's be serious.  Come on people, you cannot be serious with these ratings. I got a pair for Christmas (not bought on amazon) for some strange reason (I'm 43!) and I listened to them for about 3 minutes.  I immediately thought they were defective. The bass is completely inaccurate and boomy, to the point that I was going to return them for a replacement. However I went down to the local target and listened to the same model in the store and they sounded the same. My conclusion is that they are crap and should be meant as nothing more than a fashion statement.Now, there's nothing wrong with being fashionable, and there is no denying these are fashionable. But I'm 43 and I don't spend 200 bucks on crap.  My advice would be to only buy these if they are on super-sale and only get them if you want the fashion, and not necessarily the audio quality.
summary: Fantastic audiophile headphones, totally worth the high price

reviewText: The nootle ipad air tripod mount works as advertised and is very easy to use. The reason I haven't given the mount a 5 star rating is because the hold by the mount on the ipad seems to diminish slightly after several uses where the ipad is removed after each use. Overall, I have been pleased with the nootle ipad air tripod mount and would recommend it to someone who is not worried about objects knocking the ipad out of the mount or someone who is going to leave the mount on their ipad as a case.

This product has good sound.  The fact that there is no zoom feature seems odd to me even though I know this is a "music VIDEO recorder" I think it should have a zoom feature. I do like that it is small and compact.  I wonder how the mics will sound in a windy situation since they are so exposed, but I haven't had a chance to test that out....like as say an outdoor concert.  As A Vine customer, I received a nice soft sided case and an SD card, so I didn't have to worry about purchasing those separately.  My other issue is the battery life...seems short to me.

I have this connected to a switch and the USB connected to a hub.  The hub has two large drives connected and I'm able to reach both drives, over the cloud without any issues.  The drive is slow initially when you're updating large number of files.  It seems the drive wants to scan your uploaded files for the purpose of accessing them over media servers.  Not a problem once the scan is completed.I'm not seeing the issues others are talking about.  I bought the 2tb unit and have used about 75% of it now.  I plan to purchase the 4TB unit as well and have both on my system.  Music and Photos take a bunch of space today.  To me,  this is a great solution to very large files.I'm happy with this.  Most of these problems seem to be issues with lack of patience.  Let the unit do what it was designed to do and it will work very well.

reviewText: The board is well laid out and it was easy to install.  Love the BIOS app, which let's you setup the computer and overclock.  One of the apps provided on disk is "Live Update."  It automatically goes out and finds updates for the board and installs them all at once or one at a time.  You can also select which updates you want.

reviewText: Here is a best value Amazon folks. For $12 bucks you get a very decent hard case (with soft feel) for your valuable MacBook Air. You'll see some reviews about them not fitting properly. I bought two, Clear/White and Black Both fit just fine, but I did have to "fit" my white one (SEE BELOW). They also have a small cut out so as NOT to block the second mic on the left side of the new generation MacBook Air's. NICE TOUCH MOSISO.Now on the fit: You do need to make sure you have it on just right. The directions are good, but use you common sense and don't force it.  The Clear/White one seemed to fit OK and stayed on just fine, but I noticed the bottom wasn't fitting exactly right. There are small tabs on the side that come up and just barely clip to secure BOTH sides. I had to pick which one would clip since both wouldn't. Naturally I chose the left side so the 2nd mic wasn't blocked. BUT I FOUND AN EASY FIX. I've worked with various plastics before. The expand and contract pretty well and when cold hold their shape perfectly. Charging & using the Air didn't create much heat, but CAREFULLY using a hair dryer with the MacBook Air bottom up on a towel, I heated up the bottom plastic (on the machine) slowly all over. Before I quit, I hit the side that wasn't going all the way a little more. Without much force it clipped right on exactly where it was intended. The heat was just enough to make the bottom expand so it would make the trip. Once cool it's on there nice and tight. Word of warning - don't heat it fast or too hot. You don't want to chance warping the plastic anywhere. Just make it warn to the touch, not hot & it should be enough.Long review for an inexpensive item, but isn't this what we are after. Good w/o being expensive.
summary: MOSISO Hard Cases for MacBook Air (Clear/White)

reviewText: I’ll say upfront that I’m not a huge gamer. I got these for my sister because she needed a pair of headphones for music production with a passable microphone built in. Since I’m not really the target consumer for this sort of thing, I just wanted to explain this before getting into the review. I do have a great deal of experience with a wide range of headphones from mid-grade options like the Corsair to very expensive Sennheisers and everything in between. Thus, this review will mostly pertain to sound quality.First, the design is nice. It’s a closed back design, which eliminates a lot of ambient sound. The ear pieces are huge and will fully enclose your ears, provided you’re not a giant. The microfiber memory foam ear pads are very, very comfortable. A lot of headphones sound great, but they’re uncomfortable to wear for long periods of time, but the Corsairs will not fatigue you. I have two pairs of AKG headphones and while they sound amazing, they are not at all comfortable for long listening sessions. Not so with the Corsairs.The sound is surprisingly good. I didn’t have high expectations for these, but I was very pleasantly surprised. With cheaper headphones that aren’t necessarily aimed at a discerning audiophile type listener, you tend to find artificially bright treble and overly heavy bass. The Corsairs were more neutral that I would have expected. They actually had a nice midrange and a good overall sound. Perhaps they are a bit heavier in the bass than something totally neutral, but I think some slight bass emphasis is what a lot of people want these days, so maybe it’s not a bad thing for everyone.The Corsairs are a 32 ohm design, which means that you can power them adequately with a low voltage device like an iPod or a iPhone or a laptop without needing an external headphone amp. These will play plenty loud off of most any portable device, and they’ll even give you good bass response to boot.Overall, I must say I’m impressed. You can find better headphones in this price range if all you’re looking for is music, but if you can use the builtin mic, these are a nice crossover pair that will work for gaming and for music. Recommended!
summary: Surprisingly good sound quality and very comfortable

reviewText: I bought these Bluetooth headphones largely based on the reviews posted on Amazon, but now wonder if these reviews were written by the manufacturer. The headphones have virtually no range at all and cut out even when your device is in your pocket and within 3-4 feet of  the headphones. Forget about trying to move from room to room when you are using these headphones, because they will not work at all. I know that there are better Bluetooth wireless headphones on the market and would have been better off spending a little more money to purchase a pair.

Bought this in hopes it would allow me to use usb 3.0 devices...Since that is what the name makes it seem.Wellll not even close. USB 2.0 work but any 3.0 device i plug in either doesn't read or ejects every few minutes.Stay away from this device.The short time that i was able to get the device to work i ran black magic speed test.USB 3.0 HDD in Hub Read speed of 14.5 Mbps (ejected itself before being able to test write speed)USB 3.0 HDD directly into Macbook Pro 88.6 MbpsSpeaks for itself.

I own this in grey and red. I have no idea why the red costs $30 more. It is a lighter color so if you're messy and expose it to dirt and food it will show. It looks as though it can take a bit of soap and water from a lightly dampened cloth or sponge. I took it on a trip and had no issues with it picking up stains on airline fold out tables. It's sturdy and will protect your tablet from some shock or strikes to the screen. At the present price it is the absolute best cover on the market.

This Logitech keyboard is great! I had one for my iPad 2 and loved it so much that had to buy this one when I upgraded. Great price ... about $20 cheaper than stores. Arrived undamaged and worked great out of the box.

This small but not compact unit.  It is all relative I guess... I like the more elongated design of some of the other similar devices but I suspect the more square design allows for better sound from bigger speakers.The build quality is ok.  Much of this is metal but there are plastic parts like the removable handle that feel a bit cheap.It paired easily and the sound was very good.  Excellent base.My issue is the controls.  First, there are very few buttons and lots of ways to use them that you have to remember.  It is all laid out in the instructions... Hold one button for three seconds for on, 7 for pairing.  Tap the plus for volume, hold for next song.  Tap another (the phone symbol) to pause.  I guess if this was the only device I used, I'd get used to it... but I don't want to have to keep a cheat sheet to operate a small appliance!The most annoying thing however is the loud beeping sound when you change something.... like the volume!!  If I hit the volume button up or down, a loud beep occurs.  Especially when turning sound down, I don't want to jar everyone around me with a loud beep.  In fact, why do I need a beep to confirm I am changing volume.  There needs to be a way to shut this off but I haven't found it.  For me, this one feature is so annoying that it would make me pass by this device for another.
summary: Good sound but annoying to use

I bought this device to improve my packet management and to improve connectivity in games.I am a PC gamer, and now looking back, i wish i had returned this product. Now it is too late, and i am depressed at wasting so much of my hard earned money to buy a product that does not work at all as intended.From the beginning i was having problems with connectivity and pocket clotting. I have messed around with the settings but sadly the entire thing just didn't want to work correctly. I have dismissed the issues for a while because it was running decently, but i really should have returned it day 1 of my problems.This model has beam forming which should connect to mobile devices and such to increase signal strength. This does indeed work and i was pleased with this function, as my mobile wi-fi increased SLIGHTLY. I was just hyped up for this product and dismissed all of the problems and everything else that went wrong / worked only 1/2 as advertised.The bandwidth advertised does its job somewhat well, and it can keep quite a fiew devices working. Problem is that the packet management for this is TERRIBLE. I found that enabling any of the multimedia / QoS settings, set up with all the correct ports as high priority traffic MADE THE POCKET CLOTTING WORSE THAN BEFORE!One of the other things this is supposed to do is to allow multimedia to come through faster. This is over exaggerated on this product once you turn the multimedia feature on. If i have ANY sort of downstream (be it video or w/e) it will push all your packets off the cable completely.I am vastly hurt by the financial hit of buying this device. I am a full time student and a part time worker, with around $600-$1000 in my bank at all times for some dark hours. If you are in my situation DO NOT BUY THIS PRODUCT... It does not do what it is advertised to do. I thought i was buying a good multimedia / gaming router, and i got a crappy 200$ scrap of metal that "looks good and has a cool name".It depresses me that such an expensive product can be this bad. I wish that i could get my money back to have another try, but i waited too long, and companies don't care about this anyway. They got my money already. good for them...PS: if you are looking for a good gaming router get this one like D-Link Wireless AC Gaming Router. I do not have it yet but maybe in a view months i can get it when i get enough extra savings to afford one. They are cheaper then the netgear router (with less bandwidth but you will still be fine with many devices) and it is a heaven for gamers. It also has a detailed analysis of the network and how much each device uses the network. I had a chance to play with one because my uncle got one. I wish companies looked more into making good products like that and not just spend money on 1/2 working software and advertising...
summary: Ok, but not for gaming at all.

reviewText: We live right near a cell tower, and routinely get blasted with interference on our computers, phones and TV's. This thing manages to punch through it and provides a strong reliable signal.
summary: Very strong signal - no amount of interference can stop this thing

reviewText: I purchased this router just to stay current as my wifi devices continue to grow, and I liked some of the updated features.  Like a lot of recent reviewers, devices dropped off the internet constantly after only a few hours of use and the unit lost it's connection to the internet.  I went back to my 4 year old linksys, which has never dropped.  I won't even bother with tech support, because it's obvious from the other reviews it's just easier to take it back to the store than deal with shipping costs and useless time consuming support.  As a network admin, I cannot believe  routers in 2014 have these issues.  The unit also gets hot, and it's form factor is utterly ridiculous for thermal cooling, and forget space saving in someone's house.  NETGEAR: DO NOT REPLY, you must be tired of replying to all the other people who have told you the EXACT SAME THING. YES, this was the current firmware from JULY 11, 2014.
summary: DO NOT BUY, WIFI DEVICES DROP OFF, AND INTERNET CONNECTION DISCONNECTS RANDOMLY

reviewText: I went out and bought this for $200.00 back in November 2013. I was hesitant since ever Netgear product I owned has not lasted me even a year before an issues arises. This did not fail to keep up the motto. I had this for around 6 months and the WI-FI doesn't work stable. That is the same issue I have had in the past with The Netgear N-300, and Netgear - N600. I have had older models of netgear too. I have finally switched to Asus AC1900. It's about $20.00 more but my friends have an older Asus product (b/g/n) for 6 years now and it still works like day one!I can say the best router I ever had that lasted me was 10 year and it was free at microcenter back in the day g networks were big. The manufacture was SMC. However, I can only find commercial routers from them now.I will NEVER buy a Netgear product again. It's been my fifth and last time trying to put faith in a router that doesn't last more than a year!
summary: Like most netgear equipment I own it's never more than a year!

reviewText: This receiver is a very nice upgrade from the standard entry level Yamahas. The first thing I noticed was its slim low profile form factor at only about 3" high not counting the feet. Despite its small size it is actually heavier than the larger entry level models. Another notable external feature are two large knobs..one for volume and the other for source input selection. It's a small design element but really improves the overall aesthetics.In terms of function this model's main special feature is its network capability and remote controllability from smart devices such as phones and tablets. I tested this using my Iphone with the free Yamaha app and it works quite well. The receiver could function as a server so music that is stored on your networked PC or external NAS drives is able to be accessed and played by it. Even audio from your smart device could be accessed and streamed to the receiver via AirPlay. There's built-in internet radio and Pandora/Spotify as well as support for lossless formats such as FLAC and WAV. As with the new Yamahas this one has discrete amplification circuitry so you're getting very clean sound.On the rear there's a USB port for charging or powering USB devices. Rear speaker connections are all binding posts and there are 5 pairs. The receiver is able to be set for bi-amplification of the front channels if you don't have surround sound speakers attached which is very nice. There is HDMI audio pass through so the unit doesn't have to be on if you just want sound from your TV's speakers. Firmware updates are very easy and I was able to do one successfully upon connecting the receiver to my internet enabled home network. Overall this is a feature rich receiver with ample power and superb sound quality.Note: There is a 6 ohm and 8 ohm setting...default is 6 ohm so make sure you change this in the receiver if you're running 8 ohm speakers.
summary: Slim form factor but not slim on features

reviewText: I second all the reviews that tout the sound quality, build quality, and comfort of these headphones.  For someone who flies fairly often for work, these headphones have been the best "upgrade" to air travel that can be bought for under $200.  Indeed, they are worth much more than their price for the following reasons.1.  They block out a substantial amount of engine noise and loud conversation.2.  They send a clear but not unfriendly message to neighbors that I'm not looking for conversation.3.  Therefore, they allow me to hear--and hence enjoy--the music, movie, or book that I'm listening to, or to nap in relative peace and quiet if I want to.These headphones are heads and shoulders better than my comparably priced earbuds, which (1) did not block noise nearly as well; (2) were not as obvious to neighbors seeking conversation; and (3) did not produce sound as clear or beautiful as these (after a few hours of break-in).Finally, while I'm sure that active noise-canceling headphones would do an even better job of canceling ambient noise, don't underestimate the convenience--especially in the cramped quarters of economy class--of not having wires that tangle, clutter, and get yanked out when you're shifting around in your seat.  Trading wired active noise cancellation for wireless bluetooth is worth it, IMO.P.S.  The batteries have easily lasted a full day and a few hops around the country.  Though I have not yet tried, I am optimistic that these headphones will last through a long international flight.

Works quite well with windows 7 installed driver etc from the cd provided. Connects quickly and easly to my phone, headphones, stereo in my truck ( to do bluetooth firmware update ), Tablet and speaker in bedroom.Not sure why I didn't get one of these sooner

The fields of view are great and there doesn't seem to be the depth-of-field issue others have reported - the image is sharp for close-up subjects and the background.The supplied remote works well and the connection to the GoPro app on an Android phone is an excellent feature.

---30 April Update---Moving 5 star review down to 1 --- do not buy if you want to run windows 8.1There has always been an issue with HDMI sleep on stock 8.1 but after the Windows 8.1 Spring Update the issues have only gotten worse.  Now if you are running a headless unit (no monitor connected), or use it as an HTPC and turn off your TV you are unable to access the box remotely or use it once you turn your TV back on.  The only way to gain access to the computer is to shut it down and restart. It isn't practical to always leave the TV on so you can remotely access the device or reboot it every time you turn your TV on.  Many users have been complaining about this issue for 5+ months and Intel is unable or unwilling to convince their graphics engineers to fix the problem.  There are various methods for working around the problem from leaving your display on all the time (unacceptable), buy a 75-100 dollar device to emulate connectivity (unacceptable) or uninstall the intel drivers completely and rely on microsoft drivers for the HD5000 GPU.  (I'm currently using this method) Stock drivers nerf any performance tweaks and replaying HD content isn't ideal with these drivers.  Perhaps the NUC is just a side project and Intel doesn't devote many resources or plan on ever correcting this glaring oversight.I highly discourage purchase of any of the 4th gen Haswell NUCs if you plan on running Win 8.1**Perhaps Microsoft and Intel are both to blame for the HDMI issue.  All I know is it doesn't work.---original review---add a little RAM, mSATA and optionally wireless and you are ready to go.  I'm using this for an HTPC running windows 8.1 my only complaint lies with how Microsoft handles full screen HDMI sleep which causes a memory leak and my 16G RAM isn't enough when running windows 8.1 media center full screen after I turn of my plasma.  **This isn't a fault of Intel and hopefully MS will fix this in the next major update of windows in March**.  I'm a little bummed about plex theater performance on the intel hd5000 integrated video and it stutters on most blu-ray 720p converted media.  My old dual core atom ran plex better but then again it wasn't the new plex theater product so perhaps there is an issue with plex.  I have no complaints with the NUC although the new gigabyte brix pro with desktop CPU looks interesting.
summary: broken graphics drivers from intel on 8.1

reviewText: I had wanted this tablet for some time...I considered it to be a top of the line product.  Feels good in your hand, very aesthetically pleasing with a nice finish.  Samsung has loaded the Galaxy Note with a truck load of excellent features including a split screen mode that allows you to run two apps side by side simultaneously, an excellent remote control app, and an amazing pen that facilitates any number of useful operations.  The rear camera takes exceptional photos, the touchscreen produces brilliant images, and the audio was way above average.  It was pretty much everything anyone could want in an Android device, and it really disturbed me to have to send it back, but send it back I did.  The home button is an actual, physical button you have to push, while the back and widget buttons are digitized.  The problem is that it is virtually impossible to hold the tablet in landscape mode without constantly bumping those buttons.  There is literally no frame around the screen that you can hold without interfering with the operation of the tablet.  In the two days I tried it out, I lost the page I was on, or the app I was in because I could not find a "safe" way to hold the tablet...it was maddening!
It's Windows, what more can you say?  Came with the disk, installed smoothly, no problems at all.  The best part, OEM pricing.

reviewerName: James T. Barringer "Just the facts, Ma'm"
reviewText: The pluses are Windows 8.1 loads fast, and operates fast.  The native search functions within the help page are pretty good.But the really, really, really frustrating thing is the full-page apps.  Since this is a desktop operating system, you should be able to toggle between operating in full-page to operating the app within a window in a traditional desktop.  Not being able to toggle betwene full-page mode and traditional windows mode greatly diminishes functionality compared to everything being a normal window (which, of course, can be expanded to full-screen mode anyway).I'm not sure what Microsoft was thinking with this.  When I use a browser, I often want to open other programs - i.e. using the browser to look up something about the app I am using.  If I use one of these full-page apps, I feel like I am crippled, and on Windows 8, there are MANY MANY apps that only operate in full-page mode.That said, I have NO PROBLEM with a Start Page instead of a Start Menu.  I have no problem with tiles vice icons, which is what most people complain about.  Maybe because I use a Trackball instead of a traditional mouse (Trackballs are ergonomically much more efficient than traditional mice), I find it quite pleasurable to use tile mode, and that it's just as easy as using the traditional icon and menu-based interface of older Windows versions.But having apps - especially system apps - that only operate in full-screen mode is NOT OK.  I don't know what they were thinking.But I give it three because it is FAST, it loads FAST, it makes efficient use of the CPU, to me it LOOKS VERY GOOD (at first I even preferred it to Windows 7, until I realized what a plague the full-page apps were).It looks like it also updates easilly, and refreshes quickly and easilly.  These are VERY BIG Pluses - but they are pluses easilly killed off by the problem of the full-page apps.So Microsoft - by someone who want's you to do well - PLEASE MAKE ALL APPS (but ESPECIALLY System and web-based/search apps) TOGGLEABLE BETWEEN FULL_PAGE AND TRADITIONAL Windows mode.I understand other decisions you've made, but this last one, for me, greatly hinders my ability to use this OS efficiently and enjoyably.
summary: The minus is the full-page apps that only operate in full-page mode, and that is a BIG minus. I'm OK with Start Page

reviewText: To start off, The shipping was a day early but I liked it. Now Microsoft must have faced some negative reviews about Windows 8 and 8.1. However, 8.1 is not that bad as what most people think. In fact I like the update Microsoft released. Now I am coming off a class I took in college 2 years about and we were taught some windows 8 Basics. So navigating through 8.1 was a no brainer for me. Now notice this is not the Professional version. I assume the edition of it is the windows 7 equivalent to Home premium. And this is the OEM as well so it is intended for new system builds, which is why I purchased this product. I t is for my dad's new computer build by me. There is Windows 8 and 8.1 books out there for people who are confused about this operating system or take an online seminar. All and all, This is replacing all Windows 7 Platforms (well most because you can still buy Windows 7 PC's) and the price is perfectly fine for me. I am satisfied with this purchase and will train my Windows XP dad about this Operating system.

After purchasing and setting up dozens of Apple TVs for my business and family members over the years, I decided to give Roku a try. BIG MISTAKE!! I'm an IT professional and spent over an hour trying to get it to work. It kept failing with 'can't connect to local network'. Tried all of the suggestions I found online. Nothing worked. I can only imagine a non-IT person trying to mess with this thing.As usual, Apple products 'just work'. This pile of garbage is going back!

Since it's my first time using a streaming player, I'm not sure if Roku 2 is better than the others.The pros: - Amazon and Netflix quick start buttons- I don't feel I need to pay for a cable...The cons:- When I want to add a new channel, I have to do through the computer and then update on the tv... It's the only setback I experienced so far. And have been using this device for 3 months.
summary: Easy to use, works great so far!

reviewText: The Channel Master DVR+ (CM7500) has only an optical output with a mini plug optical connector. I used this cable to connect a standard Toslink input device to the DVR+ sound output mini optical plug. Works great with no issues.
summary: USE TO CONNECT DVR+ TO OTHER SOUND DEVICES

reviewText: I never thought I'd see the day a monitor used a power brick. Going right back in the box for return.The reason this hit a nerve is that the AC cord to the power brick was missing as well.

Recorded Xbox 360 and Xbox One video just fine until I happened to select TV on the Xbox One. At which it went into HDCP protection and stopped playing/recording any video through HDMI. Rest the device, Xbox One but never corrected. Avermedia's tech support didn't have a fix so I had to return the item. Don't do like I did and this is a much more user friendly video capture device to use than any other.

Wow! What is not to love about Dropcam? We purchased this camera to keep tabs on what goes on inside our small business while we are away and have not been disappointed. The set up was a breeze, we are moderately tech savvy (but definitely no experts). The directions were easy to read and follow. We received 10 day free trial of the cloud service, which stores video so you can review it later, you can also save specific clips of video. This product is so well priced for the amount of peace of mind it can give a small business owner. We did purchase the cloud storage after our trial was up and have since set up notifications for after hours, so we can be notified when unusual activity happens and it is great to see the happenings in our business when we are away. Would absolutely recommend this to anyone, especially small business owners.
summary: ABSOLUTELY an essential part of security for a small business!

reviewText: But crippled by disappointments.  I may not be in the "target audience", meaning I don't use this as a baby monitor, kid tracker, or neighbor watcher.  I bought this camera to use as a home monitor while away, especially if our alarm goes off, so I can check instantly to see if a false alarm or not.  Set was a breeze.  It literally took a few minutes. Initially, I was disappointed by the video lag, I did not buy it for it's intercom abilities (I just don't see how that would work in "real time" without a cellular connection), but the video lag seemed to fade some with time, and I started feeling good about my purchase.  The picture quality is crisp, with a wide "fisheye" angle lens.  The wide angle completely covers our living room, which is very cool.  Once the "app" was installed on my i-phone (I set up the camera through my laptop) I had consistent full access to the camera, on/off, audio, digital zoom, everything.  Then came the chink in the armor; my camera sits inches away from our broadband router, we have the "max blast" package, and it has developed difficulty keeping a connection.  Once the connection is dropped you can not fix it remotely, leaving you dead in the water.  Since this is far from a "bargain" camera, I found this completely unacceptable.  When you add the price of the camera + the subscription price = this is a high end camera.  This thing should be stuck to my router like crazy glue.  I was just about to buy another when it started dropping the signal.  Excellent timing!  Damage control for me.  If you are using this as a baby monitor, and have no remote expectations, it's  decent.  You can sure see what's going on.  Just be prepared to "pair" it often.  If you -need- this as a remote camera, I do not recommend until they work all the bugs out.

The tablet has a nice screen but the processors is really slow.  WiFi does not support 5Ghz carrier.  The battery life is quite a bit less than my iPad (4th generation with Retina).  We bought this as a backup for our Point Of Sale and it seems to function well for that use.  Response to the touchscreen seems sluggish and not as responsive as we are used to.The camera is pretty good for Skype and snapping an occasional product picture.Had a hard time finding a case that will work that doesn't cover or press the side buttons.  The case needs to grip the tablet on the top and bottom to overcome the issue that corner straps and corner clips pose.The power input and the headphone jack are nearly identical in size and located next to each other so it's easy to confuse the two.  The power supply uses a non standard plug - it would have been better if the maker had used the fairly standard micro-USB connector that you find elsewhere and provided a way to charge from that micro-USB like nearly every other device we have.Overall, 3 stars because it does what it needs to do at a fairly good price.
summary: Nice screen but overall performance is sluggish.

reviewText: I love this TV.  I just got it hooked up and I need to add I don't have Cable or any devices connected to it.  This TV replaces a 22inch Samsung and what I really like is that they are about the same dimensions.  This TV has a picture that almost goes out to the edge, way more so than Sammy.  The image with just an antenna hookup  is amazing.  The only gripe I have so far is with the remote, it doesn't sit flat on a hard surface but I can live with that.  Highly recommended and I'm impressed with this seller too.  Thanks.

upgrade from D-link which had most current firmware wouldn't keep the date & time and was real slow as gigabyte router. It was like wow'ed by the easy of the install and the speed increase. The setup was easy for me. The D-link would lost connection a lest once a day. RT-AC68U has not lost it's connection as of yet. I could go on but you know how it is

The latest firmware 3.0.0.4.374.4561, had security fixes that were introduced in AICloud.  Unfortunately, updating to this firmware causes the router to restart randomly.  The only way to fix the problem is to go back to the older firmware which has the security issue.Asus should do a better job of testing their firmware releases.UPDATE 3/7/2014Apparently ASUS knows about the issue with the reboots, but they cannot reproduce it in house.There is a large post that is tracking this issue:[...]

I am not a network engineer but I am in IT and know a bit about networking. I have owned Cisco, Netgear and Trendnet prior to purchasing the ASUS RT-68U. Here is my observation after 30 days usage. Easy to set up and firmware was the latest when it was shipped. Very fast and secured and long range. There are features that the average person may not use. I have set up all my network printers and wireless printers with ease and the all responded within seconds. For the price is worth it and it is more of a professional router in my opinion.My only con is that the price is high. My hope is that it last me for at least 36 months (normal life cycle).
summary: Best on the Market for now.

reviewText: The previous generation of these headphones were well regarded among some audio geeks due to their value.  Their sound quality compared favorably to many other entries in the <$100 price range, and especially in comparison with other sealed headphones in that price range.On this new version they have made a number of upgrades and also raised the price quite a bit.  Unfortunately, not all of the changes to this version are improvements in my opinion and the higher price puts these in close competition with other headphones in the $150 range which are only slightly more expensive but have significantly better sound quality and construction.I've never owned the previous version of these headphones but I have a friend who owns them and I have listened to them side by side with the new version.  To my ears they sound very similar, both have a great high end and excellent staging for a sealed headphone but they are both bass heavy which I am not particularly a fan of.  I would say the aurvana 2 seems to be even more bass heavy than the original so  those who like lots of bass will probably enjoy these headphones.I do like the new removable cord and the fact that the cord is only on one side of the headphones.  I'm not really a fan of the red plastic design element, the old version was very nondescript whereas the new model tries to be flashy but looks kind of cheesy in my opinion.  I do think the new shape is more comfortable though and also seems to offer improved noise isolation compared to the original model.Pros:Nice high end and midrange, good separation and staging for a sealed headphone in this price rangedetachable cord w/ built in miccomfortable designgood noise isolation (recently used them on a plane trip and they worked well)Cons:Excessive bassCheap looking plastic design elementsOld version sounds just as good and is quite a bit cheaperNotably better headphones available from sennheiser, beyer, denon, etc. for only slightly more
summary: Nice sealed cans but value isn't as good compared to previous generation

reviewText: I purchased this refurbished V1 model because it was an inexpensive ac router ($94), and because DD-WRT was available for the r6300 and mature enough to seriously consider. I plan to also use it as an OpenVPN server, rather than spend $200 on an R7000. I loaded the Kong versions from myopenrouter.com (initial flash and current version). The only adjustment I made was to increase 5GHz tx power from default 40mw to 70. Now, 5GHz blasts through the house although the default was adequate.update about a month later:It runs great. DD-WRT is stable and provides reliable performance. Upgrading it for the Heartbleed issue was fast and painless.My first Netgear refurb was a WNDR3400 I bought a couple of years ago to serve as a DD-WRT based media bridge. It still works great.

The drive looks nice and appears to be sturdy as well my only problem is that this is suppose to be a 128GB drive but shows up as only 119GB. all drives are smaller than than the printed size but not no 9GB difference.
I bought this for my mom, she loves it. It was very cheap and totally worth it. No problems! Would like to possibly buy another for multi setup.
This spy pen takes great video with audio. Easy playback. If your state allows such recordings, this is a must for professionals or others being harassed or witnessing crimes.

Works good, full windows, don't even realize its a tablet.Great specs and NICE screenPros: Awesome specs great price, NOT loaded with normal Dell "bloatware"Cons: Windows - it works but has some issues like the keyboard not coming up when i click on a text box. - little software issues that has NOTHING to do with the tablet but Microsoft, if you use windows, you know what i mean it works good but has glitch's that need to be addressed

The first unit I received worked great until Microsoft issued a regular update that installed a lot of new software automatically when connected for the first time to my network When prompted to reboot the unit died Amazon replaced it & the new unit works even better

I am so upset with this $600 purchase. Windows 8 is just straight awful. Asus restarts the computer daily and you can't get out of it, it is completely disruptive and takes forever. Video playback is poor. I find the keyboard frustrating, the touch screen aggravating due to the set up. I could just go on and on. I work at home on the computer constantly so I'm not one to just complain about what I don't know. What I do know, is that this is not user friendly and the software is unusable.
Sturdy, well built, and fits in my gopro camera bag. Also has tons of applications! This was money will spent.

For the price it is indeed a great pump and works as advertised. IF you have a clicking noise from the pump then you have it in the wrong sysfan port. The pump should not be plugged into the cpu fan port. The radiator fan plugs into the cpu fan port and the pump is plugged into the sysfan 1 port. This is the correct way to do it.Be carful as the screw caps for securing the pump can be striped easily making is not be able to go on or come off once applied.

I recently bought this tablet. It is just perfect. I only encountered one problem when setting it up, and that is when I was setting up Office 2013. It appeared to hang up near the end of its installation. After a reboot  Office 2013 had successfully installed with no problems. Others mentioned problems with the build quality but I encountered no such issues. The screen is nice and it is fast, it carries the new Intel Z3740 chip and it is quad core plus it has Win 8 (free upgrade to 8.1 through the Windows store) or Win 8.1.  It is not a power house so don't expect it to perform like an Intel i7 processor. This is just for everyday use. I have not encountered any problems during setup. However I did not purchase it for myself and I haven't had any complaints from the user. So I'll highly recommend it based on my initial experience with it plus not getting any complaints about it from the user.
summary: Asus did a great job with this 2 in 1 device!

reviewText: This is my both my first personal tablet as well as my first android device ever - and it simply meets all my expectations, nothing less. It can do everything I need it for -- bed time reading, surfing the web, tablet browser testing with development, playing some simple android games here and there.Battery life is pretty great -- one charge lasts a long time since I use it sparingly. One tip -- do not leave it on standby when you're not using it. Turn it off every time until the next time you use it. If you leave it on standby, the battery gets used up in a day or two quickly.
summary: Perfect as my first android tablet

reviewText: I have surface pro 2 and dell venue 11 pro atom version. This is certainly slower than surface pro, but every time I pick up venue over the surface pro. Venue is much lighter and performance is fair enough for Internet browsing and watching movies.I have a slim keyboard as well. Microsoft type cover has better type feeling but dell has better touch pad. It has disconnection issue. I have to close the cover and open it again to make it work every time. Overall I like Dell Venue 11 pro with slim keyboard.
summary: I like it over the Surface Pro 2

reviewText: Pros1. Very, Very fast. Fastest possible tablet on the market.2. Very light and easy to transfer for a laptop3. Solid built.4. The battery life is more than adequate for a laptop.5. The pen is fantastic for note taking. Perfect for college students.6. You can attach a micro SD like the ones used on cell phones and tablet to add storage.Cons1. Expensive. At $899 for 64 GB it should have at least included the keyboard.2. The screen size is considerably smaller than the average laptop.3. The windows app store is very limited.4. Can get pretty hot if using heavy programs.5. There is no safe place to secure the pen.6. Only has a single USB port.I am writing this review to give an objective look at what has turned out to be a very polarizing product. Don't let the long list of cons at the top fool you into thinking I don't like the laptop. I like it, I like it a lot. I have been using this laptop for a few weeks now and I am still impressed at how useful and powerful it is. I will be discussing each of my pros and cons with more details below.Pros (Continuation)1. When I first laid hands on the laptop I did not have the type cover keyboard that I use now. Instead I had to rely on using it solely as a tablet for the first couple of weeks. If you have ever used an Ipad or an Android tablet this computer will blow all of them out of the water when it comes to performance. It is much faster than any tablet that I used before. It doesn't lag like Android tablets and it is much more versatile than an Ipad. I have the 64 GB model that comes with 4 GB of built in memory. As of right now this has been more than enough for me. At times I had between 6-8 programs running in the background with a dozen tabs opened on Internet Explorer. The computer has not flinched once. It is very smooth. I have absolutely no complaints when it comes to performance. I have been using it in "balanced mode" and not on "high performance" because I rather conserve battery life when I am using it. It has not mattered, this thing is a workhorse.2. The second biggest advantage this laptop has is how light and pocket able it is. This laptop weights about 2 pounds without the keyboard. The keyboard weight maybe about another half pound. At 2 and a half pounds (roughly) this is one of the lightest laptops you can find on the market right now. When you stop using the laptop the keyboard can be folded up like a book or it can be simply taken away completely. Being able to take away the keyboard at any time is one of the biggest advantages that this laptop has over the other 2 in 1 laptops I seen on the market. Most of the other ones you can rotate the screen 360 degrees and fold the screen over the keyboard and it acts like a tablet. The problem with that is that you are still carrying the entire weight and the bulk of the keyboard with you everywhere. That is very uncomfortable when you are trying to use it as a tablet. The Microsoft Surface on the other hand is only about three quarters of an inch thick without the keyboard and about an inch thick with the keyboard. Like I said before, very pocket able.3. The construction of the tablet is made out of metal, not plastic. It feels pretty tough and solid on the hands. Probably the biggest weakness is the actual screen itself which at the end of the day is made out of glass. I have seen videos where it can easily withstand drops on its sides and on its back with very minimal damage on the tablet. When it is dropped face down however, it has cracked just like a cell phone screen would crack.4. When it comes to battery life Microsoft did a pretty good job improving from the first generation Surface laptop. On a regular day the laptop lasts about 6 hours. I mainly use it indoors with the screen on at a quarter brightness. It is definitely comfortable to see indoors and it makes for a good balance between battery life and visibility. If you use the laptop for games or heavy programs like Photoshop then the battery life is going to go down considerably however. What happens is that a few minutes after you start playing a graphic intensive game the fan on the inside turns on and that uses quite a bit of battery. But if you are looking to browse the web or programs like Microsoft Office then I don't think you will have any problems getting at least 6 hours on it. I have seen reviews where they claim they have gotten 7 hours but I think that they are pushing it.5. I am currently in college. I use the pen that comes with the Surface every single day. It is an excellent tool for note taking. I carry all of my notes for all my classes on the computer. All of my notes are hand written because I love making sketches and annotation when I am taking notes. I also have all my books in pdf documents and I love being able to make annotation on them. The program used to make take notes is called One Note and comes with Microsoft Office. One Note has a slightly higher learning curve that the S-Note applications found on the Samsung Note series. But it is nothing major, it is worth it to take the time to learn how to use it. It is an excellent program and it is essential if you want to make the most of the pen that comes bundled with the Surface.6. The $899 model of the laptop only comes with 64 GB SDD for storage. Only 36 GB of those are usable right out of the box. The rest is taken up by the Operating System. Thankfully, Microsoft decided to include a Micro SD slot on the side of the laptop that allows you to insert a Micro SD Card just like the ones found on cell phones and other tablets. You can buy a 32 GB card for about $20 dollars.Cons (Continuation)1. The single biggest problem I had with this tablet when I was deciding on buying it was the price. At $899 for only 64 GB of hard drive it is very expensive. Keep in mind that the keyboard is not included. The keyboard will set you back another $130 dollars. It is beyond me why Microsoft does not include the keyboard with the laptop. They call the keyboard an accessory but honestly it is a necessity. You can't really do any real work on the laptop without the physical keyboard. The on screen keyboard that appears when you don't have the physical keyboard attached makes it very painful to use when you are trying to use the laptop on desktop mode. Anyways, if you are looking at the Surface simply as a laptop and not as a combination of a laptop and tablet then keep in mind you can probably get a better deal buying a regular laptop. You can get an i5 processor laptop with 4GB of ram and about 300 GB HDD for around $500 dollars. The Surface makes more financial sense for those people that plan to use the computer both as a laptop and a tablet. Why spend $500 dollars on a tablet and another $500 dollars on a laptop when you can have both in one product that you can carry around at all times?2. The drawback of making such a light and portable laptop is that the screen size is considerably smaller than the average laptop. The screen size is 10.6 inches diagonally which is closer to a tablet than a laptop. I personally do not have a problem with that but I know a lot of other people do. Many people are used to working with 15-17 inch laptops. When they see the size of the Surface they simply can't handle it. I have not encountered any problems with the size when working with it myself but I can see how this small size might not be ideal for somebody who is working on graphic design or AutoCad. Sometimes you just need more real estate to work with.3. The Windows app store is still severely inferior to the Android and IOS App store. There are many apps that I have found on the Android Play Store that are missing on the Windows Store. However, this is not nearly as big of a problem in the Surface Pro 2 because you still can install all the regular programs that a normal laptop can install. The Windows app store is constantly improving but they still have work to do when it comes to creating apps that will work well with a device that has such a small screen.4. Due to the limited size of the laptop it tends to get hot when under a lot of stress. This laptop will get quite warm when you are using heavy games and graphic intensive programs. It is not that big deal of a deal if you are using it in your lap or on table. I purchased a cover for the computer that protected the outer covering of the laptop but it was badly designed. I saw that it covered a large portion of the of the air vent that keeps the computer cool. The computer CPU got quite hot after using it only for a few minutes. Be careful, what kind of cover you buy for this laptop.5. It is a shame that Microsoft did not include a safe way to store the pen. They have it so you can attach the pen to the side of the laptop. But the magnet is not very strong and it is very easily to drop the pen by mistake. I always have to carry the pen on a side compartment of my book bag. They should have done what Samsung did with the Note series where you can store the pen inside the device itself. I was disappointed. I know myself, I know at some point I am going to lose the pen and end up paying $30 dollars for a replacement.6. Another limitation that the laptop has is the fact that it only has one USB slot. That can be a problem if you are planning to use more than one USB accessory. I don't like to use the trackpad on the type cover keyboard as a mouse. While I am at home I always use a Bluetooth mouse. I had to buy it separately because I did not want my other regular wireless mouse to occupy my only USB port with the receiver. Keep in mind that the charger that comes with the computer also comes with a USB port that can be used to charge your cell phone if you desire. That one can only be used for charging purposes though.In conclusion, I want to say I highly recommend this laptop/tablet if you are a student or are looking to give a gift to a college bound student. It is much better decision than buying an Ipad if you are looking to get real work done. Just know that there are going to be limitations such as screen size and price. I love my laptop and I really hope that this review has helped you decide whether it is right for you or not. Good luck with your decision.

This screen cover is my #1 choice with all of my devices. I have ordered and used at least 10 or more over the past few years. Durable, replaceable over and over and when needed, the company stands firm with their word and guarantee.
great product- beautiful color-  simple - easy to setup  and highly recommended

I am not an audiophile. I do not have the fine-tuned ear to say these are the best or the worst for sound quality. But I think I'm safe in saying they are very good. One thing I have noticed using these with my laptop and iPhone is that they have an automatic on/off feature, which you only notice when it goes off. So if you listen to some music or watch a video, after it is done, there is some white noise that will go for a few seconds and then stop. I don't notice this when listening to stuff, but afterwards...it's kind of annoying, and seems very odd.In terms of design, these look nice, they have the option to plug another set of headphones directly into them, so you and your friends can listen to the same thing with separate headphones. I've never seen this before, but it's kind of brilliant...even if I'll never use it myself. I do feel like these are less comfortable than some Sennheiser headphones I have...these make my ears hurt after a while because, even with the padding, my ears are getting smashed up against the hard plastic that covers the speaker. For this reason alone, I am partial to the Sennheisers.
summary: Good sound, but a couple flaws

reviewText: Got my keyboard dock and attached the ASUS tablet to it. Connects just fine with no issues other than user error. In other words, if I push the tablet screen away from me as far as it will go on the dock, it will disconnect and if I lift the tablet without supporting the dock it will disconnect. I recommend the Poetic Slimbook case for custom fitting protection and a snug fit between the keyboard and the tablet. I have small fingers so the keys on the keyboard feel roomy like a small laptop. I connect my wireless mouse using the usb port. I don't normally make a habit of using mousepads on laptops and that's also the case with this dock so I can't speak as to it's functionality. Using the mouse makes the tablet/dock combo feel more like using a computer. If you are looking for more of a laptop experience without losing the Android OS, this is the accessory for you. If you get it, make sure to get the Multi Battery Status app by GOOD4SOME1. It shows the battery percentages for both your tablet and dock on the left hand side of the status bar and it's free.Update 3/26: Having intermitten disconnect issues. Wondering if it would be best to return keyboard for an updated production date.Update 4/25: I kept the keyboard because of the great features it offers. I continue to have connection issues if I'm using it on any surface other then a desk. Even then, if I'm not careful, it can disconnect if I move the tablet too much. I don't think Asus plans on having any kind of recall or truly addressing the issue. It's a shame because this is an otherwise fantastic little powerhouse.

I was surprised to see this product from Sony, a world leader in headphones that has largely ignored the high-end "audiophile" market. Let me give some context about myself. I spend a lot of time listening to music while I work as a computer programmer, so I have an excellent setup at my desk: ABurson Conductor SL 1793amp andBeyerdynamic T5pheadphones. I'm not the most hardcore audiophile in the world (I happily stream my music from Spotify at 320 kbps), but I definitely appreciate good audio quality up to a point.I compared this amp to the Burson and to the cheaper portableFIIO E17. Not surprisingly, the sound quality of the PHA-2 was somewhere in between the two, as its pricetag suggests. Specifically, I found it to be slightly better than the FIIO, but lackluster compared to the Burson. That's an unfair comparison--the Burson costs twice as much and is non-portable--but useful as a benchmark of what a great headphone amp can do. The Burson has a quality to it that makes you want to dance, largely because bass sounds are richly defined: it's like the drummer is right in front of you. Those same sounds feel relatively muddy from the PHA-2. Again, this isn't surprising for an amp in this form factor and price point, but it raises the question of who needs this amp.If you're looking for the absolute best sound and money is no object, the PHA-2 isn't the answer. Go look on Head-Fi and you'll find no shortage of similar devices with glowing reviews. If you're looking to get better sound from mass-market headphones and you want something you can toss in a bag, get the FIIO E17. I don't find anything about the PHA-2 compelling enough to justify the premium. In principle, I like the solid build (it feels like it could survive a longer drop than the FIIO, to be sure) and the analog controls, but in practice those features are also cumbersome: the volume knob is partly blocked by one of the protective "arms," making it slightly clumsy to turn and making it impossible to see the volume level at a glance when it's turned to certain angles. And as many other reviewers have mentioned, you can't charge its battery while using it, a limitation the FIIO doesn't have.I don't want this review to seem too negative: If this were a $200 unit, I'd happily give it 5 stars. But at this price point, I think Sony is asking for a premium that isn't justified by what I'm hearing.
can't say right now but the 4 gig coush might be enough to take some load off the CPU. photos & some lite gaming, will find out.

reviewText: Just had to get one (also bought the UV-5RE) and now I know why so many rave on how much of a bargain this is.Sure the manual leaves some to be desired, but I found it easy to program (also got the cable for CHIRP) after watching a couple youtube vids. Wanted to know how to program manually setting repeater ops when/if not at home to have PC access. Easy once you get the menu, settings and memory punched in. Just takes a little repetitive work getting several repeaters in memory. I do the same with my other HTs, just different way.I don't know how they do it for the price and throw in a few extra's. I also bought additional items (antennas, speaker-mic).Don't know what more to say - hard to go wrong (unless you get a defective unit) for the $$I'm giving 5 stars for a decent, working, feature packed HT for the $price point$ - I'm impressed.

Chromebooks are, by their nature, about compromise.  You accept some reduced functionality for the idea that you'll need less hardware and thus get a cheaper computer.  Too often the sacrifices manufacturers make (e.g. HP Chromebook 11) lead to a bad product.  Either the processor is bad (Samsung Chromebook, HP Chromebook 11), the ram is too little (Toshiba Chromebook), or they're asking too high a cost (Chromebook Pixel).  Somehow Acer managed to hit the sweet spot of compromise with the C720 and keep it cheap.In all honesty, spec wise, it's insane this only costs $250 when HP is charging more for less.  While the HP Chromebook is better built and has a better screen the device's insides are too slow and old to make doing anything more than 3 tabs open a slow crawl.  The C720 can handle most anything you throw at it, keep as many tabs open as you'd like, watch HD video - you'll get that all and impressive battery life, over 8 hours.This device isn't perfect, the keyboard and trackpad could be better.  The screen bezel is a bit too large and glossy.  But honestly it doesn't matter when you factor in value and performance.  So long as you know what you're getting in to with Chrome OS this is the best chromebook to buy, save maybe the touch version of this (not the one with only 2GB but the one with 4GB still).  It's the best cheap laptop you can buy too.Pros:++ Haswell chipset++ 4GB RAM++ $250Cons:- Screen and build quality could be better but is nothing to sneeze atCompared to the original Samsung Chromebook this is miles ahead for the same cost.  The only real competition for the C720 would be the HP Chromebook 11 if you prefer form over function or the Toshiba 13" model if you demand a larger screen.  Save those minor things there's no reason to buy another Chromebook.
summary: What a world of difference Haswell and 4GB makes
