The first thing you notice about the Klipsch GiG is its size. The GiG is relatively small, measuring 2.1 x 7 x 3.6 inches, and weighs 1.5 pounds. You also notice that the Gig is solid and feels like it is built to last. The wraparound band also makes the GiG very portable; the band, which is replaceable, acts as a carrying handle and also as a stand.The sound the GiG produces, however, is anything but small. Klipsch has a long history of making good audio equipment. The GiG upholds that reputation well. Its dual 1” drivers balanced with dual 2” passive radiators create a very full sound, with very strong bass and dynamic clear and crisp highs. At its peak the GiG produces 20 watts of sound.I tested the GiG with iOS and Android devices, and each time the device paired easily with the speaker. If you have a newer Android device, you can also connect with the GiG via NFC. The GiG gets very loud regardless of device, but I did notice that the speaker gets extra loud when paired with an Android MP3 player I own, to the point where music with extra bass would distort at  high volume.Bass is particularly strong. While not overwhelming at regular volume, you will definitely notice the bass, and, if you like a good dose of the low end with your music, you will like this speaker. Good bass response helps some music (such as classical) but may distort bass heavy music, such as hip-hop or techno music.Klipsch clearly put some thought behind the controls. The power button is at the top or side (depending on if the speaker is vertical or sitting horizontal) and the volume button also allows you to pause or play tracks, skip tracks forward and backward, and the very top of the button has a battery life indicator. The battery is rated for 12 hours, and the speaker comes with two travel bags and international power adapters for AC operation.There is much to like and recommend about the Klipsch. While it will not fit into your pocket, the speaker is very portable and appears to be very durable, so the speaker will travel well.  Klipsch clearly put some thought and effort into the design and provides nice extras, such as a travel bag for the international adapters.The speaker's bass response, as well as its design and look and feel, are the GiG's biggest strengths. It is not inexpensive, falling in the same price range as the popular and highly-rated Ultimate Ears Boom and Bose Mini SoundLink speakers. I like the fact that the GiG gets very loud, and the sound it produces easily fills a room. I also like the extra strong bass response and the full range of sound it produces. Highly recommended.
summary: Klipsch GiG Combines Great Sound with Portability

reviewText: The Seagate Business Storage Windows Server has four bays each with a 2TB hard drive installed. The server runs a lite version of the Windows 2012 server software.NAS Device it’s being compared with: Synology Diskstation DS413jSetupSetup was not overly complicated but it did take a few hours. The unit came with a good set of instructions that did a decent job of walking you through the process. The unit is pre-configured out of the box however, I Googled the unit and Windows Server 2012 for storage units to see if I need to worry about anything. Google produced some good papers that were helpful in looking at alternative setup configurations vs. just using the out of the box setup.You need a USB keyboard, USB Mouse, and VGA monitor to configure the unit. This is the one thing I really didn’t like since the Synology I currently run on my network had a web-based interface to help with setup. The hardest part was finding someone with a USB keyboard and mouse that I could use to conduct the configuration.*4 – 2TB hot swappable drives*USB ports for keyboard and mouse*VGA port for monitor*Port for external hard drive (USM)*Dual core Atom Processor*4GB RamPro’s*Easy setup.*Hot swappable drives.*Flexible configuration due to Windows Storage software (simple to complex).*The Workgroup edition will easily support up to 50 users with the need for Active Directory.*Surprisingly fast with the Atom process and RAM amount.*Data transfer is much faster than my Synology about 2x faster.Con’s*None at this point but I’m waiting to see the long-term stability and reliability.Neutral*A little iffy if you are running a mixed environment (Windows and Mac).*Small list of compatible drive. Well, it is a Seagate NAS.*Not built to be media server for streaming content.
summary: Incredible NAS if you have a Windows environment and a sub 50 user base

reviewText: The Brainwavz Delta are relatively inexpensive, but the sound they offer belie the "cheap" price.In terms of comfort, the Deltas are quite nice, offering a full set of buds to put on the phones, and like all earbuds, ensure you choose the ones that fit best in your ears to ensure that there is no sound leakage in or out. The sound isolation is very nice when properly fitted, offering you the ability to hear loud noises from the outside, but generally keeping your music where you want it, in your ears.Build quality, for headphones of this price, is very good. They are not quite as nice as the Brainwavz S1 earbuds I have, but the price on those is about 3 times what these are. If you need the ability to have a microphone for your phone, you won't want the Deltas - I would highly, very highly, recommend the Brainwavz S1 earbuds for that use.Bass is a little light out of the box, but this is easy to correct with equalization. Using JRiver Media Center you can build out the EQ to your preference, which is what I did with these. After boosting the bass by about 6 dB (low end frequencies), the tinny sound at loud volumes has been corrected easily and the sound from these is quite nice. It isn't at the level of say, my Sennheiser HD598s, but those are a different pair of headphones for a different purpose. For traveling, I will take either the S1s or these, no question.Overall the audio quality is very good. Other than being a little bass light out of the box, I would say audio quality is much better than other headphones I've used at this price range previously. I've pushed the EQ across the board, and as expected there is a lot of distortion pushing these that far (every headphone does this). The thing is, it took roughly 6-8 dB to make any one frequency start to color the sound with distortion, which is quite a good thing. I don't think anyone, once they hit the EQ a little, will find a lot of fault with these earphones at all.I've listened to a large amount of music with these prior to posting this review, and everything I've played through them has sounded very good. My mix included Pink Floyd, Jethro Tull, Queen, Cannibal Corpse, Burl Ives, Napalm Death, Primus, The Beatles, Metallica, Urusen, various J-Pop tracks and plenty of other classic rock and metal. I'm happy with what these headphones offer without question and recommend them if you are set at purchasing headphones in this price range. Obviously the more money you want to spend, the better the headphones, but honestly at this price range these are quite phenomenal.Highly recommended.I received a free sample for review purposes from the manufacturer.

It looked and worked pretty nicely until we started to use it as a *mobile* laptop. If we moved the screen just a little bit forward or backward or flexed the laptop (ie, pick it up, had it on one's lap) or leaned/pressed on the front of the laptop (the place one places one's wrists when typing) then the laptop would power down as if the power were taken away (plug/battery pulled out).While I still like the potential of the laptop (and the reviews here), the experience was so frustrating for my techie teenage daughter that I sent it back without asking for a replacement (our second choice was an Acer, so we'll look into that).I sent a note to oemgenuine (who sold this to me through Amazon) about the problem and mistakenly said it was a Toshiba.  They immediately responded and told me they had not sold me a Toshiba.  When I corrected myself and said it was a Lenovo, they never responded back.
summary: Shuts down when moving, flexing or pressing the laptop

reviewText: Had it for a few months now. Availability of some great lenses.  Recently got Oly 45mm f1.8.  Great combo. UPDATE: LENOVO SUPPORT IS WEAK AND WANTS TO CHARGE A FEE TO FIX A PROBLEM THAT EXISTED IN THE NEW COMPUTER, RIGHT OUT OF THE BOX.  FOR DETAILS, SEE UPDATE AT END.The Yoga 2 Pro (Y2P) has a terrific form factor.  It is a thin, lightweight tablet/laptop hybrid with an ample-sized, backlit keyboard.  Audio in laptops has never been great, but in this case, the Y2P audio is slightly better than what I've heard before.  The screen has amazing resolution.  There are many ads and videos that talk about and demonstrate numerous great features of the Yoga 2 Pro, so I won't go into further detail about those here.  What those ads and videos may not reveal is what's not working as it should.  So the problems I've had with my brand new Y2P are listed below in no particular order.1) YELLOW.  THE BIOS AND LENOVO ENERGY MANAGER UPDATES DID NOT FIX THIS IN MY Y2P.  The Y2P does not accurately produce the color yellow.  Yellow is either mustard or yellowish-green.  I bought my Y2P based on having read multiple published announcements that said the yellow issue had been fixed.  DON'T BELIEVE IT.  Some users in online forums have said the fix partially improved the problem and others have said it did not.  Meanwhile, the "fix" drains energy efficiency by keeping the screen at its brightest, so after the fix, one should not expect to get nearly the battery life touted.2) SLEEP.  Computer would not wake up from sleep.  After spending almost an entire day troubleshooting and talking with three different support people at Lenovo, the third person recommended turning off a setting which finally appears to have fixed the problem.3) WIFI.  Y2P drops WIFI signal frequently.  Another Ultrabook I tested with the same WIFI card also dropped frequently.  Meanwhile, a $400 Lenovo with a different WIFI card almost never drops.  I have verified that the problem is not with the network equipment and have seen other users complain about this problem online.4) DISPLAY.  While the display produces awesome resolution, some screens or parts of screens load with super-tiny print and images--too tiny to be able to read or to select options (because option boxes are too tiny).  Unfortunately, I have read that software developers haven't caught up with this kind of display.  The options to make displayed items larger (large icons, increased font size, CTRL + (plus key), etc.) don't increase the size of everything.  So some things will just be micro-tiny no matter what.  Also, all these attempts to increase the size of items on the screen at times results in some gawky screens due to larger fonts and icons mixed with disproportionately smaller ones.  Other users have complained about this in online forums.5) BATTERY AND ENERGY EFFICIENCY.  With various fixes in place, energy efficiency and battery life won't be as advertised.  I might get 3-4 hours out of my brand new computer battery without a charge if I am conservative.  In addition to the "fix" discussed in number one above, the computer also has an auto-brightness feature, which I assume was intended to save energy, but which causes the screen to constantly get brighter, then dimmer--causing it to flicker--so that feature must also be turned off.Before I decide if I will return it or not, I am going to contact Lenovo one last time.  I like the computer and think that without these problems, it would be an awesome computer.  I tested and returned another Ultrabook before this because it also had many problems.  If you buy any Ultrabook at this time, just know that you may have to spend a chunk of time troubleshooting and fixing your brand new computer--something that never happened to me until I got an Ultrabook.UPDATE: Out of the first five calls, I have three times gotten connected with support reps not sufficiently knowledgeable about the issue.  (And the sixth callee wouldn't help without a fee.)  They seemed to be reading from a script and frequently simply wanted to reset the computer back to factory settings.  After this is done, one must re-enter settings, re-install software and re-load data.  I did the reset one time, but not after that.  It turns out the reset was not the fix.  For item four, I was told to report this to "Software Support"--a separate call.  Software support--in  problem call number 6--reviewed the matter and said that to solve the problem, I'd first have to buy an extended warranty or pay a one-time $59 fee for them to fix it.  Keep in mind that in addition to this being a new computer delivered in this condition, the first 3 out of 5 Lenovo calls I made didn't solve other issues.  The tech sounded like a trainee (had someone else helping him) and said they knew what the problem was and that I needed to change a font setting, but would not tell me what the setting was without paying a fee.  As many other users have complained about this same issue, I wasn't certain he really knew if the answer or not.  A retail computer tech looked at it and thought it was a bug.  Lenovo claimed it was a setting that needs to be changed, but wouldn't tell me what it was.  The fact that it came this way and they want a user to pay to fix it seems dishonest.
summary: WEAK SUPPORT CAUSED DOWNGRADED REVIEW--GREAT IDEA THAT WAS DELIVERED WITH PROBLEMS

reviewText: Bought mine at Bestbuy for $1198. Had to keep looking for weeks till they had that offer back on.I usually buy a new laptop every 2 years. my old Toshiba I5 (2. generation) was now 3 years old as I was looking for a new ultrabook but could not find anything I liked in the price range up to $1500.This ultrabook sounds amazing on paper. 8GB ram, i7 (4 generation) , 256 GB SSD, amazing video capabilities, touch screen!but when I use it next to my old one (i5, 8 GB RAM, 180GB SSD, win 7 ultima) I don’t  see a huge difference. In the contrary, some things slow down after 2-3 days without a restart. (is this win 8.1?)Interesting things:I have 2 x Dell 24 inch monitors connected, one through the micro HDMI and 1 through a USB3 to HDMI video card.  The USB 3 is amazing!. If needed I can have an external HDD, a printer and the video card all on the same USB and everything is still working fast enough.If I have any video problems they will be with the micro HDMI, which will not initialize, I will have to put the laptop to sleep mode and then try again, usually it will work after that.if the laptop goes to sleep it will leave the monitor that is connected through the USB3 on, it will not go to sleep mode automatically.Battery is not removable, which is sad if you have the laptop on power all the time except when you travel like I do. on my old Toshiba I would just remove the battery so I don't have the yo-yo effect.Touch screen is fun, not usable for serious work though.Sound is very good, very surprised by it.Camera is great! 720p!Keyboard is great, love it.Size is also great. Feels and looks very solid.all in all, you can't find a better laptop for that money at the moment. For alternatives you must spend at least 50% more.
summary: Good ultrabook hybrid, AMAZING if you can get it for $1200!

reviewText: Web site is almost impossible to find real help. Help videos are more sales pitch than helpful. reviewText: I have used the GoPro HD Hero for a number of years and had purchased the battery bacpac for it.  I recently upgraded to the Hero 3+ Black Edition and wanted the same functionality so I also bought the battery bacpac for it.  But there are some differences between the two designs which reduce the functionality in the 3+ version as well as a "hardware issue" (per several e-mails with GoPro) which renders it counter-productive in some uses.  More on these in a moment but on top of it all, I found out the battery backpac for the HD Hero, which I already owned, works fine with the 3+ without any of the other problems or issues.  It would have been nice for GoPro to make it known that if you already have the HD bacpac version, you don't need the 3+ bacpac version, unless you need the minor weight savings or increased power (but at least it works!).Reduced functionality.  The HD Hero bacpac had a removable battery.  This allowed the battery to be swapped out with a fresh one without going through a recharging process on the spot.  It also allowed the backpack to be used to charge extra batteries when it was not attached to the camera.  The 3+ bacpac is one piece, the battery is built-in so it can not be replaced with a fresh one unless you have another whole battery bacpac.  Neither can the 3+ bacpac be used to charge other GoPro batteries.Hardware Issue.  This to me is the killer.  I found out through use (no advance notice of this by GoPro) that with the 3+ bacpac attached, when the bacpac battery is depleted, it automatically turns the camera on.  This might seem to be a useful and necessary function.  Now, it is if the camera is filming when the bacpac dies – you want the camera to keep running.  But, because all batteries lose power over time even when they are not in active use, when the bacpac battery is discharged, it will turn the camera on.  If the camera is set to turn off after a specified period of inactivity, it will indeed turn off.  But in a few seconds it will turn itself back on.  Even if you manually turn the camera off, it turns back on.  It will keep doing so until the camera battery is also completely discharged even if no recording has taken place, like if it was packed in your luggage or backpack or kayak or whatever.  You go to use it and both batteries are completely dead.  Having purchased an extra battery to provide longer recording times, you end up with only using part of one battery anyway.  GoPro’s “solution” to me on this admitted hardware issue was to remove the bacpac when it was depleted and just use the camera.  This not only defeats the purpose of the bacpac – you could more easily replace the camera battery with an extra that is also cheaper than the bacpac – but it also involves changing the back of the camera case.  None of this is advisable when you are using the GoPro underwater, in wet or unstable environments like kayaking or climbing, or just about any other condition GoPros were designed for.These things should be recalled with apologies and full refunds to everyone who bought one.  For many uses they are counter-productive.  If you already have a previous version, it is better, use it instead.  I expected more from GoPro.
summary: Newer is not always better...  this is a waste and will be returned

reviewText: Folds down and sets up quickly and is quite compact both in stowed form and in use. Because it is small, your best bet is to get it as close to your subject as possible -- preferably right out of frame. That gives you the softest light and the most control. Good in combination withWestcott Rapid Box 10x24" Strip.Unlike many commenters, I want to add that you do NOT need the Beauty Dish Deflector Plate if you are using this in softbox configuration. I did some testing and found that the plate casts a significant shadow in the center, rather than just smoothing the light. If you want even, soft light, what you DO want isSto-Fen OM-EZ Omni-Bounce Diffuser(or equivalent for your flash). If you don't have that, make sure to set your flash as wide as possible and pull down its wide-angle diffuser.The included light stand is fine for the price; it's sturdy enough for indoor use and light outdoor usage, when all you are putting on it is this softbox and a speedlight. If you already have a light stand, or want a better one, and don't want the beauty dish, it's probably a better value to buy theWestcott Rapid Box 26" Octa Softboxalone. If you DO want to use the beauty dish configuration, you're basically getting the light stand for $10 when you pick the kit route, so, hey, why not.
summary: Good softbox; consider whether you need the kit or not

reviewText: ...but to my wife and I it was not fun installing.  The material was cut perfectly for my LG GPad 8.3 GPE tablet which was a plus.Of course I don't know that I have found any of these screen protectors that are easy to install unless it is on a small cell phone. Long known for their outstanding home audio receivers, Onkyo has joined the headphone craze.  The ES-CTI300 is tailored for use with mobile devices, specifically Apple iPhones, iPods, iPads, etc.  And it serves that function very well.PROS:- Great overall sound quality- Good, but not extreme bass response- Detachable cord- Good looks- Good cord length for mobile useCONS:- Lacks extras- Slightly uncomfortable at firstCOMFORTI found the Onkyo slightly uncomfortable at first, but after a few weeks, they stretched out a bit and I got used to them.  The leatherette earpads and cushioned headband are soft and cushy, but were a little tight on my average-sized head.  I can wear them for about an hour at a time now, before needing a break.  I was a little disappointed that Onkyo didn't include a set of replacement pads.SOUND QUALITYI liked the overall sound quality of the Onkyo.  It had good detail and the low end was sufficiently represented in modern music.  I listened to some Macklemore, Daft Punk, Pitbull, and Ke$ha to test out the bass.  Some headphones just put out way too much lousy bass and ruin the track.  The Onkyo, I felt had a nice balance.  I also enjoyed listening to old rock bands like AC/DC, Van Halen, Queen, and Rush.DESIGNThe closed, on-ear headphones do a fairly good job of not leaking noise, so they're perfect for use at work or for studying.  The tangle-resistant cord is the perfect length for mobile use.  At just under 4 feet, you can keep your iPhone or iPod in your pocket or backpack.  Make no mistake, this is not meant for your home stereo.  Though they're detachable, the cords are actually quite difficult to detach and better left connected to reduce possible strain from attaching and detaching them.  The Control Talk remote works well with Apple devices.  One last thing I want to mention is that the 3.5mm plug works with some iPhone cases, but not others.  I had a Sector 5 Black Ops Element Case on my iPhone 5s and the plug would not sit flush enough to work.  Using my Speck Products Candyshell Grip case, however, the plug fit perfectly.  I had no problems with my MacBook or iPad (with Speck FitFolio case).MISCA carrying case is included with the headphones, but it's one of the cheapest little bags I've seen for a $200 pair of headphones.  You might be better off using a nice shoe bag.  An extra set of cables and earpads would've been a nice touch, but those aren't included either.CONCLUSIONThe Onkyo ES-CTI300 has a nicely balanced sound.  I was strictly an accuracy sound guy before, writing off any product that deviated from a flat sound signature.  Headphones like the Onkyo ES-CTI300 and the Logitech UE 6000 have made me change my mind.  These headphones do a good job of keeping the details of a song, while also responding to the sound of modern music.  Considering the lack of quality extras, I feel like the Onkyo is slightly overpriced, but I would have no problems recommending them to music lovers of all ages, across all genres.
summary: Terrific sound and ideal for use with mobile devices

reviewText: I returned the device back to amazon, as i wanted a boost in signal as well as HD sharpness.Also, channel 7 Abc stopped working after connecting this device.HDMI i thought would sharpen the picture but found the picture softerand not as sharp as just the antenna provided.I may have worked for others, but did not work for me.Also. despite being prime member, Amazon deducted about 6$ for returning the product (now this was really disappointing).
summary: I returned it as it did not meet expectation...

reviewText: After trying - and liking - Pinnacle Studio 17, I was looking forward to giving Studio 17 Plus a try. But there have been too many frustrations in just getting it up and running to really enjoy it.As many others have pointed out, installation takes HOURS, a process that data mines every media file on your computer (with no way to opt out). I work in the news media and have literally thousands and thousands of media files on my computer and no, I do not need to get bogged down in every file I ever processed each time I want to create something new. The learning curve is steep on this - the user interface is not particularly intuitive or user friendly.And as others have noted, be sure to check that your computer meets the minimum system requirements or your experience will prove even more frustrating. I'll keep at this for another month or so and update if something changes but as of now, this is too frustrating for all but the most die hard video editors.

I have had Pinnacle Studio 16 for about a year, and I have never like it. I was hoping that the upgrade to Pinnacle 17 would provide a more user-friendly experience; it has not. The software is slow, cumbersome, and not user friendly. I have used video editing software for years, and Pinnacle is definitely my least favorite. I have a high performance computer running an i7 processor, and the software still bogs down. I am not sure how you would run this software on an average computer, but I imagine it would be quite frustrating. Definitely not a video editing software for beginners.

On a laptop with 4 hyperthreaded 64 bit cores and 16GB of memory and a 500GB ssd drive this software stuttered and stalled, however I have an NVidia GeForce 310M (a low end graphics card) and this maybe the reason for the performance issues as when I checked the performance monitor my system did not seem to have any resource contention.Trying to balance a rich feature set with ease of use is hard and the interface was not very intuitive, however Pinnacle does provide online resources to help get you started and I would advise anyone thinking of purchasing the software to look over them to give yourself an idea of what you can do and how you access the features (they are on youtube, just search for "Pinnacle Studio 17 ultimate").It has some nice features but for doing intros and title have seen better at this price point.

We also own the Nikkor 24-120 f/4.0, bought this as a 2nd, since there's two of us shooting, and also as a backup.  It seems to do every bit as nice a job as the Nikkor.  The Nikkor is a little longer at 120, than this one at 105, but, for $400 less, it's hardly a compromise.  Looking forward to more options from Sigma's Art line.
summary: Great Lens, Love the new Art Series

reviewText: I was instructed by my doctor to figure out how to reduce strain on my neck and shoulders. I put my old monitor on a box and looking straight at it instead of down worked wonders. When the screen needed to be replaced I bought a HP BT61AT monitor arm from onSale and decided to get this monitor. The swing arm support lets me bring this close for using the touch screen and push it away when not needed and frees up a lot of desk space. I've been using this for a couple of days and love it. I use my left hand for the touch usage and right for keypad/mouse and I notice that I am sitting straighter and by adjusting the placement of the screen I stretch my back and shoulders instead of cramping them. I was leery because of the price but the reviews were good so I ordered it. I received it in 4 days and it is as responsive as my Galaxy 4 phone. Nice job Hannspree!
summary: Love this screen on my monitor arm!

reviewText: I lose my caps and these work well for extra caps at a good value.They fit myCanon EOS Rebel Cameras and am not bothered that they don't have canon printedon them.

----------------------------------------------Updating this review now with new information!----------------------------------------------I am upping this review from one star to four stars because a tech from Synology was able to give me a good work-around to the problem I was having. The work-around to the problem is as follows: Configure the Video Station app so that your videos are indexed as "Home Movies" instead of indexing them as "Movies" or "TV Shows". The indexing features for Home Movies don't attempt to perform internet searches for the metadata content, so there will be no mistakes in the video tagging.There is only one down side to this which is when you play the movies, in the player app, they appear under the "home movies" heading instead of the "movies" heading. This is not a major problem.So my primary complaint about this product is resolved. Upping review from one star to four stars. The fifth star shall remain in reserve for the day where no work-arounds are needed at all. :-)-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Here is the old review, so that you can understand the nature of the problem that required the work-around:-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------The reason that you might want to buy a Synology DS214play in particular, is because it's the first device in the Synology NAS line which has 1080p GPU hardware transcoding built in. What this means is, if you want it to stream a video to another device (say, to a Chromecast, or to your tablet device), and the video format isn't directly supported, then you want the DS214play to convert that video to a format that your device CAN play. Doing this in high quality for high resolution videos is a tall order, but with the transcoding chip in the DS214play this becomes possible. I have tested this and it works great, I was able to Chromecast a high definition 1080p video of a concert that I had performed in. The video had been saved in a format that was not originally directly Chromecast compatible. The video played perfectly in 1080p thanks to the hardware transcoding on this box.BUT... In order for this feature to work, at the time of this writing, you needed to use Synology's own "Video Station" app for this to work. Because the popular and common third party "Plex" app can't (yet) take advantage of the hardware transcoder in the DS214play. Plex recently dropped hints on their forums that this might be in the works, but it's not here yet. I like Plex and I want to be able to use it, but without the hardware transcoding, it's academic for me at this point. So for now, you're stuck using Synology's own "Video Station" app for this instead.Although Synology's Video Station isn't strictly "built in" to the product (you have to download it like any other app), it's about as close to built-in as you can get. It's in the first page of "recommended" apps in the Synology Package Center, and it's essentially the default video sharing app on this thing. As far as I'm concerned, this, combined with the fact that it's the only app that can take advantage of the 214play's hardware transcoding, makes it a "built in" app for the purposes of this review. It's really your only choice.So what happens when you use Synology's Video Station app? For every video that you copy to the NAS's hard disk, it automatically searches for the video file's name on the internet and fills in the data for the closest match. It fills in the name of the video, fills in the video box art, the actors, directors, plot synopsis, everything. This box art and information is what you see when you are browsing the library for videos, either using the web interface or your mobile device. All of it filled in automatically.It does a terrible job at this, of course.I uploaded a test of several dozen random video files onto this thing. Among other mistakes, here are a couple of examples of the mistakes it made on my system:- A music video for Alex Lifeson's song "promise" was incorrectly tagged with the synopsis and box art of a Finnish WW2 Drama film called Promise. Never mind that the drama film was 2 hours long and the music video was only five minutes. Apparently their metadata search doesn't take length into account.- The Carl Sagan "Cosmos" episode, "The Lives of Stars", was incorrectly tagged with the synopsis and box art of a documentary about porn stars called "The Secret Lives of Adult Stars". Several other Cosmos episodes were mis-tagged, but that was the worst one.In total, out of several dozen files:- The number of bad/false metadata tags applied was approximately 10-15 files.- Out of those, the number of bad/false metadata tags that incorrectly showed innocent videos as adult, porn, or tangentially porn-related: approximately 2-3.- The number of correct metadata tags that showed up: 0.- The remainder all just had their original file names with no metadata.Then I looked at how to remove this bad metadata. There is no way to globally remove it, and, even if you go into each file one at a time, it is a difficult multi-step hard-to-find process (I couldn't find the option to edit the metadata on my own without google searching for how to do it), and, worse, you can't remove the box art without supplying it with an alternate box art yourself. (The box art only gives you the choice to supply a file, not to remove the box art altogether.) Strike one.Then I went looking for a way to turn this automatic internet-metadata-searching off. Though I might be able to edit 10-15 files now, once I actually fill this thing up with all my files (and the files of the other members of my household), I don't want to have to hand-edit hundreds of files to get rid of bad metadata. Guess what? There isn't a way to do it. I googled and FAQ'ed. There is no answer. I searched the Synology user forums. Other people on the forums have been complaining about this same thing for a long time, and there is no solution there. The others who encountered the problem, who were posting on the Synology forums, were a lot more embarrassed by the porn thing than I was, because they had kids, and it was Kid's videos that were getting mistagged as porn. Especially when they tried to show their wife how the new NAS worked. WHOOPS. Strike two.On the Synology forums, there are no repsonses from Synology employees to the people encountering the issue. There are no entries in the Synology knowledge base covering this topic. No one, anywhere, is saying that Synology is working on a solution. Every query is met with silence. Strike three.I opened a support ticket on this, using their web based support system, but it was on a Friday, and I guess they don't have weekend support. I'm not optimistic that they'll have an official solution, because I'm not the first person to complain about this, and everyone else on the Synology forums is getting the silent treatment. I see nothing to indicate that I'm going to be any different in this regard.In contrast: Using Plex is dream compared to this. Plex makes far fewer mistakes when searching for metadata. Plex got a few accurate correct metadata tags in my sample set of files, which, although not many, was still several times more correct than Video Station got. And when Plex mis-tags a file, it is a one-click operation to remove that bad data. Finally, Plex does have a configuration option which allows it to skip the automatic internet metadata searching altogether (though it's not clearly named). So yay, Plex is great, but... I can't use it on this thing because it won't take advantage of the hardware transcoding (yet).So, since I seem to be stuck with Video Station, I took it upon myself to find a solution.After two solid days of investigation and experimentation, and enlisting help from friends who are Linux experts, I have finally figured out a way to hack around this by editing files on the Synology hard disk. I literally had to locate and modify the scripts that search for the metadata, and deliberately mangle the internet addresses that the scripts used for the searching. I also had to flag the metadata-searching daemon as non-executable. I also had to fully deinstall and reinstall the Video Station app and start over from scratch before doing any of those modifications, because if I didn't, it would simply have kept the bad metadata in its database. Finally, the solution I implemented is such that, if the Video Station app gets updated, I can't take the update unless I'm willing to do the hacking all over again a second time. So I had to turn off auto-updating on Video Station.I've posted the detailed steps of my solution in the Synology Forums. Search for "Metadata Porn" there and you'll find it. I'm proud of the solution that my friends and I came up with, and it makes the NAS usable for me. But the fact that I had to spend two days investigating and tinkering with the thing to work at a basic baseline "no false porn tags" level, gives it Strike Four.I'm reviewing this product as one star, because out of the box IT. IS. NOT. USABLE.- By default, out of the box, it tags your innocent documentary and kid's video files as porn. In no one's book does this count as making it a usable product.- Synology does not have a fix for this problem at the time of this writing.- Synology didn't even test it well enough to figure out that they needed an off switch for the auto-metadata-searching. YOU CAN'T TURN OFF THE FALSE PORN TAGGING.- Synology has not repsonded to anyone on their user forums who were complaining about this problem.- To fix the problem, I had to spend two days investigating and hacking, and at the time of this writing I think I'm the only person on the planet who has solved this problem. Hopefully, soon others will be able to successfully implement my fix, but my point is they shouldn't have to fix it, it should just work OK out of the box.Synology, if you're reading this review:FIXTHISPROBLEMNOWPLEASE.If you do, I will change this review to four stars.(If you guys care about that sort of thing.) If you go the extra mile, and help Plex get hardware transcoding working, so that I can start using their excellent app instead, I will increase the review to five stars.If you're someone else reading this review, and you know how useful and powerful Synology's products can be, and you're willing to perform the hacking that I did, then by all means, ignore the 1-star review and get this thing. It's a quiet, fast, powerful NAS, the first of its kind with hardware transcoding, with a lot of great features and an amazing array of installable apps.
summary: If your Synology Video Station App mis-tags your videos, here is a work-around.

reviewText: This case arrived well packaged with everything intact. The only issue there was upon opening was a small chip in the the bottom corner, but it was just a coating to reduce glare, so it didn't effect the quality of the case much. The case itself is sturdy, with a snap-lock design to hold the kindle in. I submerged it underwater for several minutes, retrieved it later and it still functioned normally. However, as with all touchscreen devices it does not register finger movements underwater or with a lot of water on top, so it's best if you prefer to read by the bath or pool but don't want to risk water damage if you should drop it or get it wet. The case itself is a bit hard to take off and you have to force-pry it open with your fingers, but this doesn't matter if you plan to always have it on. All in all the case does what it says it does, feels comfortable in the hand, and doesn't hinder the reading quality at all.
I love this minimalist case!  It is sleek, tidy and functional.  Fully closed, it is protective, but can easily maneuver into active modes.  It fits the new Kindle perfectly.

This is an attractive case with a nice feel. It is good if you want a low footprint case for your Kindle Fire HDX. I like low profile cases, and this almost rates a five, but the easel back only has one setting and the viewing angle is not comfortable.
I am sure this will work well but I did not realize that it was a internal thing so I will not be using it my mistake not there fault.

i wanted an internal drive, because my external isn't working that well. this drive is only for 3.5 sizes which means you need an adapter to install, but that's not why i marked it down. it's lower because the drive isn't that fast. though while i haven't compared speeds to my other one, it was downloading at like 15mbs and i'm certain that was half the speed it should be. the cord internally is a bit too short and it's a stretch to get it to fit. the other reason is the light  on the front. it has a really bright blue light on the front that serves no purpose at all. it's bright, blinding, and lights a whole room. it's plugged in, i know it's on, it doesn't need any kind of light.when you plug something in, there is a softer white light. but if i had my pc on my desk, or if i didn't have something blocking the light as i do now, it would drive me insane.
summary: i would keep shopping if i were you

reviewText: This is a 5 star quality product, no question. It is arguably the best piece of audio hardware I've ever owned. Unfortunately, it's operation IS COMPLETELY DEPENDENT on a totally unavailable small connector cable, micro-usb OTG double male that is totally unavailable everywhere I've looked, and I've been comprehensive. I've found nothing online, been to Fry's, Radioshack and BestBuy, and it's not offered on Fiio's site. Even if Fiio were willing to replace the cable, THEY'RE IN CHINA, so it's going to be massively cost prohibitive--and I've no word from them after contacting support to see if I can arrange a steady supply--believe me, you'll need them.In a pinch, you can get a 3 foot one online--that's it. Believe it or not, they're brilliant strategy, instead of designing the thing with right angles so it will be durable, or making it durable so a small drop of less than 2ft onto padded carpet while sitting on the bed doesn't break it (which I did today--and sneezing on it would have been rougher. It was barely touched), or even just furnishing a means to buy a replacement, was to provide two, so you'll have another one when the first one breaks--no thought as to what you do when the second one breaks though.I really can't believe it. Why go through the trouble of making such a top-notch product (and I've tested it thoroughly--it's amazing), yet make it depend utterly on a small, fragile, walmart quality, poorly designed, flimsy cable that's totally irreplaceable, impossible to find, easy to lose, and breaks the first time you inevitably will drop your phone, and without which--the entire unit is as useless as a pretty paperweight? I don't understand. It's like buying a Farrari, only to discover the tires are irreplaceable. What do you do when one goes flat?I am astonished and disappointed to see such a rockstar piece of engineering crippled by a stupid mistake worthy of a walmart throwback.Here's hoping the company sees this review, and will figure out how to arrange a steady supply of these fragile cables, because I don't want to return the unit, but without a steady supply of this exotic cable that seems totally unavailable anywhere, I'll have to return it because I will eventually break the second cable and the unit will then be totally unusable.If someone happens to know of a source for these 40mm microusb male to male cables, preferrably right angled, I'd be grateful for the reference, and if Fiio can help before the return period is over, I'll gladly keep it, give it a 5 star rating, and use it forever.If not, it's going straight back to the crap factory. A pretty brick is still just a brick.
summary: A great product--but needs a better cable solution.

reviewText: The whole thing is a silicon sleeve with a clear acrylic backing insert.The clear acrylic insert scratches the back of the iPad and makes it a couple of mm thicker.The corners are thick and provide drop protection.  Overall it feels cheap and not elegant and doesn't feel like a "black belt" protection.The sleeve is really flexible and can be removed easily which makes me worry if iPad was actually dropped.It offers no standing capability.  I think if they had to use the back insert, might as well have some function to is so the iPad can stand.

I'm just not really that impressed with this product.  It is well constructed.  Durable and thick rubber.  Looks like it was created based on an Otterbox idea.  And that's not a bad thing at all.  To me though I'm not sure who this is made for?  People who have seizures holding their iPad?  Children?  In the year (about anyway) I have owned my iPad, I have only dropped it once.  And that was because I was getting cutesy and had it set up precariously on a table to facetime.I just don't think most people will need it.  Still, if you drop stuff a lot, maybe this is for you.

It's a great little device with a really long battery life and great range on the mic. I can sit in the back of a 300-seat auditorium and get good recordings, even when the professor doesn't wear a mic. It gets a bit touchy at that range though, as you would expect.

If these speakers cost ten times as much I'd have a lot of problems with them.  But for the price, these are freaking amazing.Sound quality: The most important thing for me, and these speakers sound better than I'd expect for their size and weight.  I won't be blasting any eardrums with killer bass, but then I need what's left of my eardrums anyway.  The bass is very solid, and mid- and high-range are clear.  Music is enjoyable, spoken word is clear and natural and easy to understand.  Volume is sufficient for the largest room in my house.  Sound is far better than I'd expect at this price.  I can't find anything to complain about here.Size: Small, and actually kinda cute.  They don't take up much of my desktop and they've got plenty of wire to get them where they need to be and get a bit of space between them.Software: No extra software, and thank you so very much AmazonBasics for not putting obnoxious audio drivers on my computer.  Plug in USB cable and go.  When I steal them for my Kindle Fire, I plug the USB cable into an adapter and into a wall outlet, and plug the green cable into the headphone port.  Too easy.These are easily the best budget speakers I've tried, and I've tried more than I care to admit.  And if I had a little extra cash to blow on speakers I'd probably still choose these and then go out for dinner.  They aren't good enough for that music studio you're putting in the basement, but for my basic audio use these are just fine.
summary: I've actually replaced an old pair of Harman Kardons with these

reviewText: A tablet of this caliber usually retails over $100 or more, but for the price presented, it is a steal. I previously owned a small Wacom Intuos Pen and Touch tablet for recreational drawing and I would say that the Huion Pro is on par in terms of quality and functionality. In fact, it is sizeably bigger than the Intuos, though cheaper to boot.The tablet does not have a touch or gesture feature like the Intuos, and neither is its surface as similar. The Intuos had a papery textured surface to make it seem as if you are actually drawing on paper, but the Huion tablet does not. The texture is plastic-y. It threw me off at first, but I became accustomed to its texture as it made strokes a lot more easier and puts less wear on the pen nibs that came with the tablet (more on the pen and nibs later).The tablet itself also has quick keys on the left for erasing, zooming in and out, scrolling, and a lot more for convenience, which can be mapped to your own preference. There is also an LED indicator for strokes that lights up with each stroke to let you know that it's working. It is very big, though not at all hefty, and beautiful in design.The tablet's package includes a USB cable which powers the tablet (no it is not wireless), a CD loaded with drivers (though I recommend downloading them straight from their website for more up-to-date drivers), a charger for the rechargeable pen, the pen itself (which features an incredibly long battery life and two quick key buttons though regrettably I do not use them so I don't actually know their function. Also the pen does NOT work on other tablets, though maybe other Huion tablets), a set of great pen nibs (5 including the one already inside the pen), and a pen rest/nib holder container. And you will get ALL OF THIS for less than $100.Though as much as I love this tablet, I cannot be biased. The tablet does, well for me, have its hiccups where the tablet won't register the difference between light or hard strokes and the quick keys won't function properly. It doesn't happen as often, though maybe it may be just my tablet specifically, but if it does happen, do not worry. You can either: 1) unplug your tablet from the PC then replug it, 2) close and exit out of your art software, in my case, Manga Studio 5, and open it back up, or if neither works, 3) uninstall the tablet and re-download new drivers from Huion's website, which is easy and painless.Overall, despite the small issues I have with it, it is a VERY solid tablet for budget artists. What you are looking at is a quality tablet for an affordable price in comparison to other competitive tablets, and I would highly recommend it to you.
summary: An excellent tool for the digital warrior.

reviewText: I bought this from another website because it was a bit cheaper. I was hesitant at first by the reviews on Amazon because most 5-star reviews were from non-purchasers who got the device for free to write a review. The real buyers' reviews didn't seem to agree with them. But I decided to buy it and test it firsthand.I care a lot about aesthetics, and this device looks amazing in pictures - an indicator I relate to product quality. When I received it, I was not disappointed. I bought the champagne gold color one.The first thing to notice when I opened the box that it had a nice smooth shiny look without the cheap plastic feel at all.  Even the cables were thin to be barely visible in the car and didn't feel like clumsy plastic wires. The device itself is smaller than what it looked in pictures, and it connected firmly to the magnetic base.I rushed to me car to try it. Once I connected the charger to the lighter, the two USB ports illuminated in blue: Beautiful design! The ring and forward/backward buttons on the device illuminated in blue as well, and flashed when you turned on until it paires with the phone. I have an iPhone 4S, and it paired seamlessly with it.Then, it was downhill from that point. Once I connected the 3.5mm cable into my car's AUX port, the first thing I noticed was the constant humming noise coming from the speakers :(. I tried to fiddle with the AUX cable hoping to eliminate it at no avail. I played some music through it to see if the humming noise would disappear or fase, but you can't stop thinking that it is there. In moments of silence, you will notice it in the background. Once I turned off the device, the car went back to complete silence. I tried making a phone call with it, and it seemed to be working fine, but the humming noise was there during the whole phone call. The other party cannot hear it, only the ones in the car can. The humming noise is not because of my speakers/radio system. For example, if I connect my phone using my AUX cable directly and don't play anything, I don't hear any noise at all. And when I play music, the sound quality using the AUX cable directly is perfect! This is clearly a defect in the device's design, causing constant noisy signal to be on to the output AUX port.The other bothersome thing is that -as another reviewer noticed- you cannot activate Siri with it. I tried pressing it twice, or pressing and hold -which turns off the device.In short, Pros:- Amazing aesthetics and solid hardware design and feel.- Good form factor: small device with good cable/charger quality.- It pairs quickly with your phone when you turn on the car.Cons:- Constant humming noise in my speakers when I turn it on (even prior to pairing).- No Siri support from the device.I bought a Bluetooth kit and not a piece of decoration. I was really hoping for this to work. I can live without Siri support, but the humming noise is really a killer. Unfortunately, I am returning this beautiful device, hoping they will fix these issues in future versions.* UPDATE 3/3/2014 *I was happy to receive a replacement BT module for the one I had by the seller. The one I received has the same design, but with Bluetooth 4.0, and other fixes.The updated module has voice messages instead besides the beeps. For example, if it is in pairing mode, you will hear "Pairing" through the speakers, or "Device Connected" when your phone is paired with the device. Siri is working now as well *hooray*. You have to press the middle button twice, holding the second press for two seconds then releasing it. This will launch Siri. Cool! This solves the Siri problem. I noticed as well that my iPhone pairs much faster compared to the older model.I mainly asked to replace it because the noise on the speakers. With the new device, the noise is still there, but much better. If I lowered the volume on my stereo and raised the volume on my phone, then I would barely notice it. This is good and I am happy with it, unless you want to raise the volume all the way up to blast the car's roof.Another thing I noticed that pairing two phones at the same time worked fine in the older model, but it has been flaky with the new one.All in all, I am satisfied with the newer version of the device, and I am keeping it. I would have given it 5 starts but for the problems listed above. I still recommend it.

I am pretty sure that higher priced brands may have some features that appeal to some users, but the VIZIO 120Hz LED HDTV fills all my viewing needs at a great price.  I am an Amazon Prime member, so the free delivery and setup (at exactly the scheduled delivery time) was a great feature.  One feature of my setup that may make a difference in someone else's decision is that I don't use the Smart feature of the TV.  My setup uses a Comcast HD recorder console and an XBOX to access all of the video streaming services.

We needed these for our sales people to have so they can have it in one hand and do other stuff with their other hand.  We will send these out in the next couple of weeks.  If they are a bust, I will write back here and let you know.  The people who tried them liked them.

I recently sold my iPad Air for the smaller iPad Mini Retina. I've always liked Apple's cases for their iPad products, but they are very expensive. I've tried less expensive cases in the past but was never satisfied. When I got my new Mini, I decided to try one more time to find an inexpensive case that would be satisfactory. After a lot of online research I decided to give the Anker Folio Case a try. Honestly, for the price, I wasn't expecting much. After using it for a while, though,I have to say that I like it even more than the Apple cases I've had. The built-in stand with two viewing angles works great. Its a much better solution than the one used on the Apple case.The case is very light and feels good in my hand. I especially like the Mandarin Blue color that I got. The stripes make it look rather unique and not like the majority of other iPad cases. My only complaint is that, with my large fingers, it is slightly more difficult to press the volume buttons while the iPad is in the case because one edge of the case is very near the buttons. Nevertheless, the buttons are very functional and this is truly a small complaint.

This thumb drive is exactly what I was looking for! I bought the 64GB Version on sale for 39.99 :). It's read speeds are solid and I have watch several movies from it on my cell phone and tablet with no hiccups or stutter at all. It works out of the box with my Samsung Galaxy S4. I have a 2013 Nexus 7 also, but in order to use OTG on it, you need an app installed to be able to connect it. Most people use Nexus media importer,  which I believe is a paid app. My Nexus 7 is rooted so I use a free app called stickmount and it works great! The size is pretty small but like people have stated before, there is a small hole to put a key ring through. I had dig around some drawers in my house to find one that would fit the small hole. I have this on my key chain at all times because I use it for work also. It doesn't bother me at all on my keys due to its very slim size. And I have no fear of losing it this way also. The cap on the micro USB side is durable and fits snug.  They only thing I would like them to add to this product,  is a key ring for it. Besides that,  I love it and highly recommend it!

I came from having two GTX 670 FTWs, but gave one to my boyfriend in his new build.  Not wanting to lose the power I had because I have a 2560x1440 display, I went with this card, and it has been a dream.The quality of the card is outstanding.  The heatsink is huge and the cards are so quiet in my system.  I have a Corsair 800D, so it's a rather large case.  I also have tons of fans, and with this card at 80% fan speed, I can barely hear it over my other ones that are on a fan controller.I have added +115 Mhz to the GPU core and +150 Mhz to the memory, and it has not broke past 67C degrees yet.  Pretty amazing.  In my games,  I am getting a little more power than my GTX 670s gave me, which shocked me since this is still the Kepler architecture.So, well-built card, low noise, great temps (if you have good air flow in your case), and the best performance you can buy on a single GPU card.  I am very happy with my purchase.
summary: Amazing power in a single card!

reviewText: I've used several Bluetooth speakers, and they tend to vary widely in terms of their quality. The Brightech DanceOut speaker is very impressive, both in terms of sound quality as well as design.The speaker was relatively easy to set up and pair up with an iPhone and my Windows 8.1 desktop. Turning it on makes it discoverable for all of your Bluetooth-enabled devices. Each time you turn it on and off the speaker makes unmistakable loud noise indicating it's functioning. It also makes a different kind of noise each time it connects with a Bluetooth device.One of the best features of this speaker is its sound quality. This midsize device can really deliver crisp, loud sound that goes well beyond what one would expect from such a relatively small form factor. As a single speaker that streams music via Bluetooth there are naturally physical and technological limitations to what it can pull off, but aside from that this speaker really manages to impress.Both its shape and size allow for this speaker to be easily portable. The speaker can easily be placed on any flat surface. Thanks to its fun design this speaker is very versatile in terms of its possible uses. It rubberized exterior makes it very rugged, and even though it is not waterproof I think that this speaker could be used in a variety of outdoors situations.I primarily use this speaker as an external speaker for my old Dell desktop. Older desktops can be very inconvenient as most of their peripheral ports are not easy to reach, and a Bluetooth device such as this one can really add functionality without the hassle of having to reach behind the PC for access.This is a very convenient and inexpensive portable speaker that definitely delivers on its premise. Highly recommended.

I was so disappointed with the Galaxy tablet I purchased before this. It was slow to load apps, non-responsive to touch, and getting the same apps I liked on my iPod were impossible to find. Had to send it back. Imagine my pleasant surprise with the S7. This is the Slate "Plus" 4200, which was new in Nov when I got it, not to be confused with the 2800 series, which had disappointing reviews. This one has two cameras, whereas the older (I understand) had only a rear facing camera of only 1MB. Only disappointment is that it has no charging light indicator. Not a big deal though. Charging time from 20% low is only 2 hours.  Final disappointment (not tablets fault) is that none of the after market HP cases work with this tablet. Only the one HP offers will work with the new camera locations and hole alignments, and they want something like $45 for it. Not gonna happen. I bought an ill-fitting cheap-o to hold me over until some Chinese company comes out with one for under $20.

I feel weird for giving five stars to an OS disk, but it works well and I can't find any flaws with it. The one word of caution is that, as someone else pointed out, the font of the license key is small enough to require a magnifying glass (no kidding). Even with one, I had difficulty, so I resorted to taking a close-up photo of the key with my iPhone and then zooming in until I could read the characters. Still, the letter B looked an awful like a numeral 8, which took a bit to figure out.
summary: Easy upgrade, but you'll need a magnifying glass

reviewText: I received this product free in exchange for writing an honest and unbiased evaluation.When I removed it from the box, my first words were ...'wow this is some keyboard'.  I like the weight and feel of it.  The keyboard is laid out nicely and it has a good feel when typing.The cons are:You have to insert your iPad into the slot to turn it on and use it.  It automatically shuts off when the iPad is removed.. there are no other controls.When in use, it must be on a flat, stationary surface, it cannot be used on your lap, otherwise the iPad would not be stable position.I wouldn't use it as a traveling case as the magnets are not strong enough to keep it closed and the iPad is not protected as it becomes the back of the case.There is no way to see if the battery is charged or how much time is left on it.  If there is, I have been unable to find it.I have used it some and have been very satisfied, but the only true test is through continued and prolonged use.  I do intend to use it at home as I do like the feel of the keys, but I wouldn't take it elsewhere... a coffee shop, traveling etc..  If that is not convenient for others, and you want something that you can use on the go, then this probably isn't the keyboard for you.
summary: Needs to Stay in One Place While Being Used

reviewText: Not sure why some of the poor reviews.  We have Lifeproof cases on all of our Apple devices, but decided to try this (since hopefully children won't be using it) on our iPad mini with RD.  It is light, offers some corner protection, stays in the standing position, feels well made and stays closed.  The description does not state it is a magnetic smart case and we were not expecting it to be one.The price is right and the iPad is protected (did purchase a screen protector also).  It is exactly as described and we would purchase again.

Up front here is what you get - an internet machine that has 2GB of RAM (which can't be upgraded) and 32GB of on board SSD storage with a nice 11.6" touch screen display and about 7 hours of battery life.Touchscreen & Display (11.6")The touchscreen works very well.  I never thought I would need a touchscreen but find myself scrolling and opening pictures with it.  The touch is very responsive and works great.  The display is quite nice and colors show nicely and are not an issue.  There is a bit of a glare in certain situations but it is only with viewing angles that it becomes an issue.  Overall the display will please you.RAMThis unit comes with 2GB - I wanted 4GB but this touchscreen model does not come with it.  The RAM is embedded into the motherboard so it can't be upgraded.  Overall the performance is good even with multiple windows open surfing the internet runs smooth.  Occasionally a picture/flash heavy sight will take a moment to load but otherwise internet surfers will love this device.ProcessorThe Haswell architecture has really done well for this device. Pair this with the SSD drive and start up boot time is less than 5 seconds and power down is just seconds as well.  Updates are done automatically so you won't even know when it is happening.  The device opens apps and video quickly and smoothly - just in general this device does not have any issues with processor lag.StorageYou get 32 GB of SSD on board.  You CAN upgrade this to 128GB.  You would need a few things but it can be done easily but will cost you about $100.  You would need to purchase the 128GB SSD card here on Amazon.  Then , if you have a 4GB USB drive you can create a restore point on it, power down, install the new 128 card, power up with the USB drive in the USB slot and boot from there - the rest will update.  Google Drive offers two years of free 100GB storage but I am not going there as you have to pay after two years.I purchased a Patriot mini USB storage device the size of a dime and plugged it in the 2.0 USB slot for an additional 32GB storage.  If needed I can remove the USB drive and transfer the files to a larger drive ....if needed later on.PortsYou have on the left side a 3.0 USB, HDMI, headphone and power jack.  On the right a 2.0 USB, SD card reader and if you want to lock the device there is a lock hole.  The power cord is unique to the Chromebook and not USB.  Wifi is your main connectivity as there is no Ethernet jack.  However, the Chromebook has full Bluetooth capability and can pair with your devices.Keyboard and track padHere things get a little tricky and you will need to read up online and get your grove on.  This is a bit different than your typical laptop keyboard and track pad.  There are no numbers on the right side or Alt buttons and the keys are individual and raised. The keys are not illuminated.  There are NO left or right click buttons.  The entire track pad is a button.  So, click with one finger and you left click.  Click with TWO fingers you you right click.  Takes some getting used to especially for copy and paste which can be challenging to some.APPSGoogle Play is on board and has a full variety of apps to use - I like it a lot and there are not many limitations - many of the apps you might have on your Android phone can also be on your Chromebook.  Apps like Hangouts, Youtube, Chromecast, etc will all work fine and integrate nicely with the Chromebook.BatteryVery happy at this point as the device is new - time will tell how the battery holds up.  I can surf the internet for hours - about 7 hours at this point and be fine.  Most of the time I am on for only about two hours so battery life is not an issue.Size and weightThe Chrome book is small and light - the display is only 11.6" but you can still see everything nicely and adjust the font size which I did to Large or extra large if need be.  It is very light between 2.5 - 3 lbs you can hardly feel it on your lap.  It does not get hot and is completely quiet - noise free however there is a fan inside.WEB CAMThere is an HD webcam that works ok in well lit rooms.  In darker lit areas it will be difficult to capture a good image.  Hangouts is what you will use it for most and it works great.  I am not sure if this will work with Skype or if that app is available in the store. Also the camera is front facing - there is no rear facing camera which is fine and how most laptops are set up compared to tablets.PRICEI got this Chromebook primarily for my wife as an internet surfer.  For the price, $309 shipped it isn't terrible.  I would have liked the 4GB of RAM non-touch screen model but that is like finding a unicorn these days.  Although that device only has 16GB SSD storage at least you can upgrade the storage on the Chromebooks where as the RAM is untouchable.ThoughtsI think this device is capable of a lot of things.  Internet and Google will be your primary use for this device.  If you are looking to do word processing and spreadsheets and graphical design this is not your device.  It can do these things with limitations but this is not it's purpose.  Also, even for a young technically savvy person you will need to learn and figure things out such as the track pad and the OS (Operating System) and how it works.  Overall - I am very happy with the Chromebook and love ACER in general.  I have had many of their computers and laptops.  They all work perfectly for me and my style.
summary: A great internet machine with Apps

reviewText: I have bought 3 units of the black Anker 40W.  They all get warm when charge in full load.  I read someone mentioned that the unit is cool to touch when fully loaded which I think he probably did not really try it.In addition, for Note 3, you have to use the USB3.0 cable in order to achieve 1.8A charging. If USB2.0 is used, maximum charging ampere is 1.2A.  I have tried many cables to conclude that.Somehow this charger did not charge Galaxy note 10.1/Tab 2.  I am not sure whether due to the Samsung propriety charger is needed to charge these tablets. I have changed a few cables and all come with the same results.  However, when plug in Samsung charger, they all are back to normal charging mode.One of the unit probably faulty which could not charge my Ipad.  I wish I could upload some photos to show it. A bit upset as I waited for quite long and finally ordered them and got them ship to my forwarder in Oregon  then reship it to Singapore.
summary: Bought 3 sets and 1 of them did not charge Ipad.

reviewText: I ordered this tablet for my brother for a late Christmas present and overall, the tablet itself is a great tablet.  You can really see how the quad-core processor has made it easy to multi-task between apps.  For the price, you just can't beat it.  The charger on the other hand was a different story.  We put it on the charger right out of the box and 5 hours later it was still only at 90%.  Not only was it taking forever to charge but it wasn't holding a charge for very long.  Before contacting the manufacturer I tried one of my other chargers, a Samsung phone charger, and it worked A LOT better.  It charged completely in a very short time and it stayed charged a lot longer.  I gave this a 4-star rating because the tablet itself is an awesome product but the manufacturer really needs to work on the chargers they use.

This case is high above my expectations for the price. Haven't had any issues and the material doesn't smell like other cases do.The case does add bulk but it also will protect the tablet very well against drops since the edges stick out beyond the tablet. I notice the photo now shows a screen protector, but mine did not come with that and the price was only $5.98 I think when I purchased it.

I thought this would be a good tablet to use for Facebook games, etc..  Unfortunately the screen is hard to see if you are not looking at it straight on with the display at the highest light setting. If I want to show someone else something on the tablet I can't just turn it toward them.  I find it necessary to tilt it back and forth to find the clearest picture.  I wouldn't recommend this one.  It may be good for other applications such as movies or TV shows, but I doubt it.  I haven't found anything yet that looks good on the screen.

This is a great case and an excellent KB. I love it. I had the "official Dell KB and case" and returned them both, as this beats Dell's product hands down for a fraction of the price. The case has a good magnet, which not only nicely closes over the DV8P, but also holds the KB in place as you type. AND the KB FITS inside the case for travel if you want to take it with you. Just as good, it is not PART of the case, so you can leave it behind. And the little corners on the KB keep keys on the KB from scratching the screen of the tablet. The connection process was easy and quick, the cable charges the KB from a USB on my computer, and it just all works! If you need a case and KB I highly recommend this set.

With the kind of spec it has, I would have expected it have much more faster boot time to the login screen (little more than a minute) and faster time to Desktop Ready(close to a minute). I am not sure if it is just a problem with my machine or this machine works that way.The touchpad feels different. One might have to get used to it I believe (I am macbook user).Apart from that, the battery life is good (6hrs). Once the machine is up and running, it is fast.---------------------------------Update : 03/26There is some problem with the Wireless Unit - The connection is intermittent and the packets keeps dropping. I installed the latest drivers and still no use. It is not a problem with my ISP. Had both my MacBook pro and this laptop side by side and the MacBook Pro responds fabulous and this one sucks big time !! One of the reasons I got this laptop was I could connect to my work machine and I have struggled for more than a week now to solve this issue but nothing seems to be working.I am returning this laptop . The wired connection worked though. I believe It was just bad luck to get a defective unit.Removing one more star

I have never had active noise canceling headphones, so my review is not Consumer Reports quality.I chose not to pay for the Bose technololgy that every one says is the best available.Hence, I paid less than $200 for not the best noise canceling ability.Imagine my surprise when I first tried them on a two hour flight on a commuter turboprop.Very noisy plane and much vibration.I put headphones on (very comfortable for two hour's continuous use), hit the button and immediately heard LOTS of noise.My immediate reaction is "what a bunch of crap!"But, two seconds later, the noise canceling technology kicked in and total silence. I was totally amazed. Had a very pleasant flight after that listening to Dark Side of the Moon.Not sure how the Bose could have done better, but I am totally happy with my purchase. And, the Sony's look better built too.Of course, the real road warriors with their Bose, will still think they have the best, but they won't hear your taunts about paying half for similar benefit.Some folks complained about when adjusting their jaw, they ended up breaking the seal around the ears and letting extraneous sound in. That did happen to me too, but by readjusting the head band to pull the ear cups up away from the jaw 1 cm ended that issue.

Seeing the words Stereo Headphones, I expected it to sound like stereo headphones.  What it sounds like is a poor 1960's radio.  If you want to listen to music, forget it!  I had read the reviews prior to purchase.  Some mentioned the delay.  I noticed a slight delay with my I-phone and MP3 player.  Neither one is worth listening to anyway because of the poor quality sound.  If you remember the days of the phonograph record, the sound is worse than that.  It's like listening to something with the treble turned all the way up and the bass turned all the way down.  Next I hooked it up to my TV.  There was a very noticeable delay, like watching one of those old Japanese movies about Godzilla.  First the person's mouth moves, then the sound comes out.  And the sound is terrible.  I tried it on the TV for 10 minutes or so.  After that, it was just so bad, it was painful.  Bottom line: this product wouldn't be worth it if it were free.  The only reason why I rated it one-star, is because I can't rate it zero stars.  I wouldn't recommend it to anyone.

So much could be written about this unit, but I will try to be brief.  If you are a technophile and appreciate great user interface design, you will be sorely disappointed by this unit.  If you will be satisfied by playing DVD-ROM discs burned with MP3s then you may be quite happy.General FeaturesAs stereo head units go, this is a well performing unit at a reasonable price.  The high voltage pre-amp outputs were the feature I was after, along with the dedicated subwoofer channels.  I'm running this with a pair of amps (one 4ch and one mono for the sub).  The ability to tweak and tune the settings is very good, with high and low pass filters, adjustable EQ, sub boost, and lots of other features, it is very good when it comes to setting up the sound the way you want it and customizing it to your unique situation.  In addition, the ability to play DVD-ROM discs with MP3 files (4.7GB of them!) is fantastic.  These are however, the *only* things I like about this unit...App ModeAfter spending a hundred or more dollars on all the special cables needed (including the Cable Jive Dock Extender http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B00GP08858/ref=cm_cr_ryp_prd_ttl_sol_7) I no longer even bother hooking up the iPhone because the user experience is so terribly flawed.  Operation of the "app mode" of this radio is something I would never have released as an actual product, and I find it difficult to believe that ordinary people are able to even use it.  I'm a 25-year tech vet (including stints at programming and product management) and I still find it incredibly difficult, frustrating, and unpredictable to use.  You just never know what will happen when you plug in your iPhone - sometimes you get bizarre "Application not supported" messages, other times nothing happens, and then still other times it will work as it seems to be designed (which is still not great).  There are entire Internet forums dedicated to using these radios - that should have bee my first clue as to how complicated and unpredictable they are to use...Even just trying to use the bluetooth connect is a PITA, as it "takes over" Pandora and eliminates the ability to just use Pandora on the iPhone.  I finally got so frustrated that I disabled the bluetooth "auto connect" on the unit and resorted to the AUX input for Pandora.  iTunes radio seems to work fairly well via Bluetooth, but this uses the "iPod" source rather than the Bluetooth or Pandora source on the unit.Phone Usage (Bluetooth)I wired the mic so that it sits about 8 to 10" from my mouth while I'm driving (on the A pillar) and I have the mic pointed directly at my face.  Most people I have called tell me that I sound like I'm in a wind tunnel or the bottom of an echo chamber.  I'm sticking to my Motorola Whisper bluetooth headset based on this performance, which is another reason I've disabled the bluetooth "auto connect" on the Pioneer so that they don't fight with each other for control of my phone.Reverse CameraI have had intermittent problems since Day 1 with the back-up camera.  Sometimes it works flawlessly, and other times it simply stops working.  I have double-checked all the wiring and the camera itself and I'm fairly confident that these issues are with the head unit itself.  One problem is that when you start your car, the Pioneer  throws up a series of "informational" messages and garbage on the screen that all have to be acknowledged.  If it is in the mood to misbehave, it will also throw up a few error messages (like the aforementioned "Application not supported").  I'm assuming that displaying these messages competes with the unit's ability to display your camera image (both in terms of processing cycles and actual display).  As a result, about 20% of the time when I start my truck, the reverse image doesn't work at all.  Other times, it takes so long to display, that I've already backed out of the driveway and am on my way by the time the unit is ready to display the backup camera signal.  At times when it refuses to display an image, I will go to the "home" screen and turn the camera "on" (i have the camera wired so that I can view images while driving forward).  The screen will be blank for a good 5 to 15 minutes, then it will suddenly come to life.
