Like many of the features of this poorly designed unit, it is unpredictable and unreliable, which really defeats the purpose...In summary, if you just want something that will work easily with your smartphone (at least if it is an iPhone - I cannot comment on Android or Mirrorlink functionality), you are better off to keep looking (or spend up to the latest "CarPlay" compatible units).  But if you are a tech geek who doesn't mind spending hours on Internet forums to figure out how to make stuff work (because the manufacturer did such a poor job creating a usable product) then this might be the right unit for you.I've had the unit in my truck for about a month, and I'm already shopping for a replacement because I just want something that is easy to use and actually works the way I expect it to when I want it to.  Trying to operate this unit has caused a couple of close calls in traffic because it demands so much attention just to operate some of the basic functions.
summary: Good performance & features but far short of perfect - especially with iPhone 5

reviewText: I'm impressed with how easy this product was to use and the results it produced. My house has issues with the internet signal reaching all rooms with a decent strength but not now that I've been using this.I took it to my moms house too since the guest quarters are in the basement and I can never get anything with their wifi. My mom and her husband were so impressed with the improvement they ordered their own that same night.If you need a stronger wifi signal with multiple devices in your home, office, or anywhere else then I recommend this product.**This product was provided to me to review and test, all opinions are honest and my own.**

This router is not compatible with several Internet Service Providers including Verizon.  In order to make it work with Verizon, it would be necessary to plug the router into an open Ethernet port, which would allow you to go into the router settings and define your own network parameters.  However, most ISPs bundle their services with proprietary routers that have similar options.  This is a good router of you are already familiar with Netgear and/or you are trying to make some kind of in-house/in-office network.  However, the average user will have little use for it in their home network beyond the role of a glorified Ethernet hub. If you want to set up that subordinate network and you are familiar with Netgear equipment, then this is a good option.

First reaction: it works! Having read several reviews of low cost, (supposedly) high capacity flash drives failing to store the promised capacity, the first thing I did after receiving it was to fill it to full capacity, read back the files, and then fill it again. It is definitely a true 64GB drive.Second reaction: It is physically a little light -- not flimsy, but made from light, thin materials. Now, I think it's going to run for a long time without problems. Unfortunately, flash drive have a rough life. They get dropped, kicked, stepped on, and I don't think this drive would survive too much of that.Final review: Its a bargain and, so far, performs exactly as promised. I'll just try to carry it inside a padded computer bag, and not in a pants pocket full of keys and coins. I'd like to give it 4 because it's not so tough, but 5 is still fair.

This worthless piece of metal and plastic worked for 2 weeks and now it is not even useful as a paperweight.  I stick it in the computer (tried multiple systems) and nothing happens except a red light on the item indicating it is getting power.

Seagate did not get to be one the two remaining hard drive giants by turning out poor or even mediocre products. As someone who uses dozens and occasionally hundreds of hard drives annually, I know that some will fail sooner than others, but all will ultimately fail. Given that, I will happily use anything from Seagate or western Digital, always making sure that I have more than one copy of important data. If the data is truly worth protecting, it is worth the additional expense of backing it up to more than one device. Period. End of sermon.That said, I never do anything more than test the software hard drive manufacturers include with their drives. Although the quality has improved from years back, the included software is rarely top-of-the line quality. In the case of the software included with this drive, I quite honestly didn't bother. There are far more powerful backup applications to be had and I have them.However, I did review the reviews by trusted third-parties regarding this software and though they all share my basic opinion that you can do better, most concluded that Seagate's included software is adequate for nominal users. Note that their back-up app for mobile devices does not back up applications!So the bottom line for me is quality of the hard drive itself. Seagate doesn't make it easy to find the rotational speed of its drives any more. Part of this is because spin speed is less important than it once was because of newer technologies..I have read both 5,400 and 5,900 RPM.Even with USB 3.0, for demanding purposes like video, this drive is on the slow side: 60MB/s sequential write - dicey if you're using it for demanding video. Read speed is 143.3 MB/s as measure by CrystalMark, which isn't bad.The drive runs cool and seems to be fanless. The enclosure is a plastic cube. There are no diodes, not for power, not for operation, not for anything. I'm not a fan of this, but can live with the omission.Overall then, this is simply an external hard drive to me. A hard drive from a reputable manufacturer with a 2 year warranty and huge capacity. It is not the fastest hard drive, but it isn't advertised as being a super-fast hard drive and its benchmark scores are more than respectable for all but the most demanding purposes. It is quiet, doesn't get very hot and innocuous in its designed. And it's priced right. I'd say go for it.Jerry
summary: Drive is good - which is all I care about

reviewText: This speaker has a surprisingly good sound for its portability. A few points:1)  it paired without any problem with all my devices--two iPod Touches, a Macbook Pro, an iPad Air (sorry, no Androids). Recognized and paired immediately with all and kept the connection throughout2) As mentioned, I was very pleasantly surprised by the sound, which for this type of speaker was unexpectedly rich.  As is always the case with a speaker this size, the bass will be the downside, but really, it wasn't bad in general and not at all bad for this type of product. Nor was the sound tinny, as can happen sometimes.  Volume is decent--you aren't going to bring the walls down, but then, that's rarely the point of these.  I've had three or four bluetooth speakers and this has so far been my favorite. And really by a pretty good margin.3) it has a nice heft to it, feels solidly constructed and built, but looks pretty good and while it's larger than many bluetooth speakers, it's more vertical so the footprint isn't bad.4) the battery is rechargeable, which is a nice touch, and for me ran nearly five hours the one time I ran it all the way to the end.  If that is unusual when compared to future use I'll update5) it's described as water resistant, but to be honest, I didn't decide to test that by pouring water on it or misting it.  But it's good to know as I'll be using it a lot on the patio while I work or just sit out and enjoy the day. And I like the idea of tossing it in the trunk to use outdoors as well.Really like it quite a bit and I'm hoping this early evaluation remains accurate throughout its life

I use this as a Monoprice 8323 headphone cable. It sounds good as an upgrade to the stock item. Great workmanship, equal to high-end cables in build quality. It is a bit stiff for my application but this doesn't interfere with functionality. Perfect length for me and should be the right length fo an aux cable application as well. If your not going for an Audioquest, Cardas or similar high-end product I reccommend these STRONGLY over the Monster Cable item. The Monsters will fail.

The D-Link does what it says it will. Trouble is, I don't find it as useful as I thought it would be. I haven't found the need to share my connection. My friends have their own internet connections. I find the speed, though, to be good. I don't notice any slowdowns when I put the D-Link between my phone and the net.
summary: It works...but wish i could use it more.

reviewText: If you are looking for a slim profile similar to some of the old original ipad cases you might like this one.  It has the benefit of not really covering the front of the tablet at all when open, so there is no problem touching the bottom or sides of the screen to bring things up, unlike some cases that cover a bit too much of the screen and make it hard to fully access.  I think my particular cover may have been returned and someone had had it folded for some time in the configuration to hold it up for viewing and it never really laid flat on the tablet.  It has the same semi cheap feel as many others of this type, and while grippier perhaps than a bare tablet is not nearly as grippy as some of the thicker fake leather ones.  The design of the plastic part of the case that actually holds the tablet is somewhat poor--it completely covers the sc card slot, and there is a border that sticks out over the various buttons that make them somewhat hard to manipulate.
summary: A decent case depending on what you are looking for

reviewText: I will disclose that for critical listening and use as a monitor I use a different brand and model of headphone. However, I have come to love the review sample I received for when I am listening to music for leisure instead of transcribing it.The main reason that I love these phones is I remain in the real world with them. What I mean is there is sufficient ambient noise that bleeds through that I can enjoy music in very high fidelity and still hear a timer going off or someone knocking at my door. My other phones isolate me from everything but the music, and while that is good when I can concentrate solely on that, it's not so good when I have to deal with the realities of life.Above I mentioned fidelity. These phones faithfully reproduce the spectrum of frequencies of the music to which I listen. My main test album for any speaker or phone set is Miles Davis'Kind Of Bluebecause the instruments in that album cover the low, mid and high ranges. The bass was so nice in these speakers that I immediately gaveEldee Young & Co. Just for Kicks/Red Holt Look Out!! Look Out!!a listen because the instruments on that album filled in some of the borderline frequencies between low and mid, and mid and high. Again, these speakers faithfully reproduced the sound.  My final test was to listen to a few tracks from30 Ragtime Iconsbecause the stereo separation on that album is wide. These phones crossed over beautifully.From a comfort perspective these are fine for up to three hours, when they start chaffing my ears. Nearly all over-the-ear phones do that to me, so its not as much a criticism as it is an observation. I have been getting about five hours of use between charges, so factor that into your purchase decision if you want phones that will get you through a whole work day in your cubicle.Bottom line: I love the sound and relative comfort, but the most important feature is the fact that these phones do not isolate me from the real world when I am outside my little bubble. With them I can listen to my favorite music with a respectable sound quality without forcing others to listen to it too. Yet I can still be aware of what is happening around me, so for environments where awareness is essential these are perfect.

Increased range substantially. They have SuperPowerSupply.com written on them. I used them with a Netgear R7000 Nighthawk router and I saw a substantial improvement in signal in the corners of my house and seem to be free of dead spots. Good deal overall.

Considering that we get 4K for less than 2K is awesome. Love the lens designed by Zeiss for Sony. Love the fact that you can go almost 100% manual with settings. Love the fact that it has a 3 level ND filter system built in. Have shot some pretty interesting goodies with this from tight macro shots to night shots (infra red) - as well as night shots of the moon. Unbelievable detail in the imagery. But I must forward you, you need to learn the manual settings to achieve such greatness. All auto isn't bad, but for those special shots, learn the manual settings. This camera produces way beyond consumer level and is definitely "pro-sumer" class.

I purchased this one alongside the SHARKK Bluetooth 4.0 BoomBox NFC 10 Watt Speaker to "duke it out." In short, the SHARKK won the battle: The Photive is louder, but I think that was a mistake on Photive's part - the sound becomes quite distorted and choppy at full blast. Additionally, the SOUNDSCAPE 8 had a very noticeable amount of hiss when playing music over Bluetooth - far more than any speaker I've ever used. That hiss essentially disappeared on an audio cable, but via Bluetooth, it's very noticeable.That, coupled with the fact that it kept causing Bluetooth interference with my wife's phone and that it used old, slow Bluetooth 2.0 made this one a loser in my book. I should also add that the Bluetooth 2.0 struggled with my higher bitrate sound files - making the audio bitrate fall off and sounding a bit "crunchy" when listening via Bluetooth. So to me, my thought was why would you buy a larger, less portable speaker with poor Bluetooth performance for the same price as the SHARKK? Apart from those glitches though, the specs are fairly similar.I just can't get over why you'd put Bluetooth 2.0 (old technology) into a brand-new device design. Sadly, this device could have been amazing - I wanted to love it - but it fell short due to distortion and did a face-plant when it comes to bluetooth performance and sound quality. There's a lot to love here, but the few glitches made it a no-go for me.I compared this device against many other Bluetooth speakers. If you'd like to read my full length, formal review, click my name above and see my reviews. Read the review titled, "Unbiased: You can't beat the volume, functionality, or quality-for-price of this device with anything I've tested sub-$200" for the SHARKK Bluetooth speaker, which is the one I ultimately setting on after buying this one first.
summary: Good "umph" and "thump" hampered by very poor bluetooth performance

reviewText: This is a great keyboard and case. It does not add much bulk or weight. It seems very well made and durable, fits perfectly - your Kindle will stay snug and protected inside, and the keyboard is superb. I love the keys - you can type so fluidly on it. The keyboard is smaller of course, since it's sized to the Kindle, but it is still easy to type on. The Bluetooth connects pretty instantly. Battery life if pretty good. I can use the keyboard pretty much all day long and not feel the need to charge it. The case will only fit the newer Kindle Fire HD, not the older ones, since there is a slight size difference. You can connect it still via Bluetooth to an older Kindle and prop it up or use it off the Kindle, but the older Kindle will not fit in the clips or attach to the case.

Some headphones can be very expensive and should be protected from the possible damage. Brainwavz has made the Brainwavz Large Hard Headphone Case as protection for your headphones when they aren't in use.Inside the packaging is the hard shell case. The design is very sleek, with the Brainwavz logo on the zippers, to the red and black design. The design for this case is well made and looks very durable. I could probably drop this case a half a dozen times without damaging the headphones inside.The case is very large (when closed 7.5 x 9 x 3.5 inches, when opened 14 x 9 x 1.5 inches) and light (8 ounces). Although this isn't portable, it does have a 31 inch adjustable strap to carry around your shoulder. The outside is made of a red and black cloth material, with the Brainwavz logo on the front in silver, and on the zippers that go around the case. Inside the case is a zippered bag which is velcroed to a piece of felt that is glued to the case. When I removed the zippered bag, the glued piece of felt came off as well. This case came with myBrainwavz HM9 Hi-Fi Noise Isolating Headphoneswhich are can be up to 10 feet long, and fit perfectly, along with a two other auxiliary cords, , and still be able to place more accessories inside. This compact case can carry several accessories in addition to your headphones, and can probably fit a pair of earphones as well.I then tested the hardness of the case by attempting to press into it with my hands. Although the hard case does buckle in a bit, it reverts back to its original position. I believe this is a great case to have for any earphones because it can stand a lot of pressure.I would highly recommend this product to anyone who needs protection for their headphones, and is why I give this product 5 out of 5 stars.Pros:+ Hard shell design protects your earphones, while looking sleek.+ Although it is large, it has a strap to wrap around your shoulder, so you can take this while traveling.+ A large zippered bag to carry additional accessories+ Very durable material, could drop without damaging headphones.Cons:- Piece of glued felt fell off when removing the zippered bag inside the case.I was provided a sample in exchange for an honest and thorough review.
summary: Provides great protection for your headphones! Get it before your headphones are damaged.

reviewText: its a great little camera, used to have Sony Nex5n and i can say despite the smaller sensor the image quality is a lot better. especially with wide range of great quality and relatively a lot cheaper lenses comparing to E-mount line of Sony. highly recommend it over Sony's also considering the customizability and lots of buttons which makes the camera fun to use and more usable. video quality not good at all. this hardware can do a lot better than this. waiting for a video codec update. cheers!
summary: needs a new firmware for better video codecs

reviewText: I've been a DSLR user for 10+ years and have many high quality lenses. This camera is getting me to consider selling the full size dslr gear and go micro 4/3.The camera takes absolutely beautiful pictures. Paired with the Olympus 14-40 2.8 lenshttp://www.amazon.com/Olympus-Zuiko-Digital-12-40mm-Interchangeable/dp/B00EY3YGBS/ref=sr_1_1?ie=UTF8&qid;=1403633021&sr;=8-1&keywords;=olympus+14-40Once they come out with a 70-200 2.8 equivalent I'll have everything I need to fully move to the m43 format.The electronic viewfinder has been fine.If there was any improvement to make, it seems the camera goes from showing a full battery to half and then empty quickly. It's probably a battery metering issue...but make sure you grab a second battery. I get 300+ shots on one battery as long as I'm not spending hours looking at the shots on the screen.
summary: Love this camera coming from a full size SLR

reviewText: I used it to protect my wife's brand new 10.1" Galaxy Tab Pro, and (although) it took a while to apply, I followed the instructional video and made sure NO BUBBLES are showing. The accompanied dust collector stickers are excellent and a must have gadgets in order to apply this cleanly and without dust/hidden bubbles. Great value and I would definitely use this brand in the future.
summary: The best I've used so far

reviewText: Works very well, as good as any extender on the market, if not better.  Range up to 500' if your terrain is level.  Easy setup, less than 5 minutes and connecting devices is no problem.  Read the instructions carefully to avoid any odd problems.  All in all, recommended.
Got this to take with me on travel.  I'm finding more and more hotels that limit the number of devices you can hook up to your room code.  This fixes that problem.

The latest and greatest is here. If you want a large screen capable of touch then this is easily the best for the priceIt's only an i3 processor but it still pretty fast. Windows 8.1 is a FANTASTIC OS, don't listen to the haters. It boots up in about 15 seconds, maybe less.

It's not a laptop and that is ok. I like that it starts up fast, big screen and lightweight. It has no HD display and at times during a movie the quality is just not good. Dark scenes especialy. Again, that is to be expected. I bought it after my nexus7 died on me, just outside the warrenty timeframe. Having a maschine like that, with good wifi and the keyboard makes me only miss mynexus7 while watching movies, but i found my solution for that as well. Google chromecast.

Internet media (videos and music) is the future of entertainment and this box contains everything for the aspiring internet entertainer. I was very excited to see Sound forge and Sony music studio included. I am a prior owner of Sony music studio and Sound forge and I was hoping these updated versions would solve my past problems of lag and crashing. Unfortunately not. I am running the program on a laptop with 8 GB of ram, and it just lags and crashes when you attempt to use it. In the past, my version of Sound Forge actually stopped working. I went to Sonys website, had to create a user profile with password, and emailed them; and then got the runaround when they responded. At least I have sound forge again, but don't expect much help if it crashes and stops working.Acid music studio is also very laggy, overly complicated, and problematic. By mistake I closed out some trays. I never hit save, and I closed the program and reopened it to get the trays back, only to have them still gone. God forbid you make a mistake a change a setting, cause it's very difficult to figure out how to go back and change it to default settings. Also, I was surprised that I couldn't find a small bundle of music loops with the program. I'm kind of confused if I can't find them or if they just aren't included with the set. At least when I got Music studio 9, I got a music loop bundle with the program and was given a really good free download of a music bundle on their online website.Movie Studio itself is laggy as well on my laptop. I frequently use Windows media player, which I find more simple to use and edit and has very little lag (after the video loads). I was interested in this product, because you can bypass the loading process for HD videos, but unfortunately it lags too much on my PC to replace Windows media player as my primary tool.I think this is a very good bundle, but I think Sony should focus on a more user friendly product that doesn't slow down your PC. It's worth buying, but you definitely need a high quality computer that runs fast to use it.
Great Radio from Foscam BaofengRadio.us and is especially easy to program via Chirp and a Prolific usb cable. Also all Accessories I have tried outside of a AAA battery pack has worked pretty well.
summary: Great Beginning Radio that seems to be a awesome Bargain

reviewText: This is an amazing little computer for an HTPC.  It costs around $200 ($139 for the unit when I bought it) for a complete build, and has very low power requirements.  It averages around 8 watts of power draw with peaks around 12 watts.  It is noticeably slower at web browsing, but is still capable of streaming HD shows from HULU, Netflix, and Youtube videos.  You won't be able to do more than one thing at a time without some painful slowdowns.  It has remained cool to the touch and dead silent even after hours of continuous streaming.  It comes with an Intel Wireless-N 7260 card preinstalled.  It only supports a 2.5 inch drive at sata II speeds; no Msata.  It has ONLY ONE DDR3L sodimm slot, so you will need to make sure your RAM can run at 1.35v and that you get a single stick at the capacity you want.I had issues with the built in Bluetooth which I think is an issue with Intel 7260 series wireless devices.Steam Streaming works 97% flawlessly.  There are a few semi-noticeable, minute reductions in frame rate occasionally, but it was never enough to make a game unplayable.  This is definitely the best thing I bought this year.
summary: Great value for an HTPC / Steam Streaming

reviewText: The product is great not that good of a bass other then that it is great comfy and fits well.

I've never heard of this brand until reading a recent review in USA Today.  I perused Amazon and found this model. They are amazing!!!!!  I wanted noise canceling but so many have issues (for most brands except of course Bose) and I  don't want to spend $300!  So after reading the reviews I settled on these.  I'm glad because tThey are fabulous!  They fit so comfortably on my ears, when playing music I can hear just the music and I can hardly hear anything else.  I was even doing the annoying "talking super loud because I can't hear myself speak" thing that annoys people.  I can't wait to use them on my summer plane trips (3 long Round-trip flights)!!!  I also love that they fold and come with a carrying bag.

This is a memory stick that fits into a regular USB port on a PC, as well as into an Android device via a micro USB port. Despite having two connector, it's tiny: at under 1 1/2" x 1/2" x 5/32", it's over five times smaller (by volume) than my Kingston DataTraveler stick! This can definitely go on a key chain. The housing is metal, too, and seems pretty sturdy. Unfortunately, the larger USB port has zero protection, while the micro port comes with two plastic caps (one black and one yellow).Read speed averages at 143 MB/sec, and write speed at 9.1 MB/sec. These values don't compare with a SSD obviously, but in the USB stick world, they are pretty good, basically twice as fast as my large Kingston USB3 stick.If you're looking for a small and relatively fast USB stick, this is a great candidate, even as a regular USB stick (without Android in the picture).

April 22: Due to, of all things, a Windows update, the ASUS crashed yesterday. I admit I was frustrated after a System Restore failed because of the timing of the update. I called ASUS, and the rep spent an hour on the phone with me. There was nothing that could be done other than a System Refresh, i.e., returning it to factory settings. As of this morning, I am re-registered and all that stuff, and am back to learning more of the capabilities of this computer.***I got this on March 27. The following review is before we got two more tablets (a long story), and the review reflects my inexperience with tablets. As of today - a month later - it's even more difficult to evaluate: 1. The ASUS can do more; it is a real computer, but 2. Android OS are much easier and a lot more fun. Ultimately, what happened was that my wife uses the ASUS for meetings and work, and I use the Galaxy for photography, music, and easing into retirement. They both have the one essential (for us) external storage.***(The March 27 review) I'm fairly new to tablets and Win 8, and nothing seemed to go right the first two days that I had this computer. Thanks to two other early reviewers, I found the stylus (it's part of the case), and learned some useful things about this "mini-PC." That's exactly what it is, a PC with Windows 8. It's only a tablet in size. Note that I'm retired and have little use for a lot of the Win 8 or even ASUS apps, BUT my wife is still working and this will be taking the place of her first generation Kindle Fire ... and then some.My primary reason for getting this is that we wanted a decent sized screen to look at daily photographic shoots while on vacation. That's what we do, and my wife and I can shoot as many as 2,000 pictures a day. We don't want to edit although this Asus can do that, too, but we need at least a 20" monitor or else we'd go blind.My one need was met after a good deal of difficulty setting up accounts with an extremely small font and a very large stylus (instead of the fantastic stylus it comes with).Pros: After you "master" Windows 8 - which is really Windows 7 with widgets and app icons galore. It's pretty easy once that becomes apparent, but without a guide, it does take some time. (I was working in a vacuum.)If you know Windows at all, you should like this OS. It gives you everything even a version of MS Office. The needed Office serial number is in the box. (I had to fish the brochure on Office out of the trash because it looked like an ad.)There is a mini-SDHC port, and since our cameras take the mini-SDHC Class 10 cards, we can pop the cards in this slot and watch them come up on the screen once we go to the external card in the Control Panel. Note: Though we both use P&S; cameras, the photos can be as large as 6-8MB each, and with several hundred, don't expect this tablet to display them as quickly as a a desktop quad core etc. etc. etc. I could put my entire (and that's a big "entire") music collection on a 64GB mini-card, and play music that way, but at least at home, I could hook up to Windows Media Player via Bluetooth and play my music anywhere I want without the card. (Small house.)With the supplied Wacom stylus, you can take notes, and it converts handwriting to print. That will come in handy when we're shooting pix in the open space or national parks.Briefly, you can darn near do anything a smart phone does except make calls and have internet access except with wi-fi, but it does more on an 8" screen that any phone can today...I think.Cons: All the buttons and the stylus are the EXACT same color as the case. They are difficult to find visually. Adding the right case (and I think there may only be one for the Asus Vivo 8 at this time - see link below) really helps because the off/on, volume, and stylus are on the right and the holes give the indication you need as to the button location. That will make sense to you later.Though it has the mini card reader, and those cards now come with up to 128GB storage, I'd like to run more programs using the flash memory than from a card. Perhaps when I find out what I can uninstall, I'll free up enough on-board memory.The screen font is tiny, I mean 2-3 point font tiny. This is why I called Customer Service, and it was a question they couldn't answer, i.e., how to make the screen font bigger. One of the reviewers had the solution, but when I turned the computer on the next day, the font had reverted. We're still looking for an answer. Today, in the manual, we found the answer to making icons larger, but not fonts. Not after 10 days, anyway. (Make that 20 days now.)Some of you may want the selection, but there are so many apps and widget icons that it literally took hours to decide and delete the ones that we will probably never use. We are left with 34 apps and 32 ASUS and Windows widgets. The Windows Accessories and System widgets are of much more use or possible use, perhaps because I understand Windows stuff fairly well.The sign-up forms for ASUS and MS are also tiny and a pain in the neck. You really will need the Wacom stylus that comes with this to fill in the forms. But the Wacom stylus is very thin, doesn't point as well as one would expect when passing over some of the tiny icons (e.g., battery life, wifi status, and all the other things in the taskbar). There is another stylus that quite a few have recommended, but that adds $35 to your costs. The Wacom stylus does well enough for writing notes - short notes - and drawing if you can draw. Neither my wife nor I can draw a straight line, so this may be a moot point.The days after I signed up (without checking the "getting notices" box), I started getting email on my desktop PC. Not appreciated.Neither here no there: Just as when you shut down a "regular" PC, you have to sign back in (though you can simplify this with a PIN number and I think I saw a way to do away with signing it altogether). Further, Windows updates daily - HIGHLY recommended by me - and so start-up will take a minute or two especially if you haven't used the tablet for a few days. It's not as though I don't have plenty of time, but even in retirement 90 seconds to see a screen just seems like a long time.The screen is acceptable. It's not HD by any means, but since I don't watch movies on anything under 15 inches, this will suffice for YouTube and Wimp.NOTE: Use the manual that is on the tablet, not the downloadable .pdf one. The one on the computer has an icon.I highly recommend this case - which seems to be the only one for this NEW tablet (http://www.amazon.com/dp/B00IOIGT7S/ref=pe_385040_30332190_TE_M3T1_ST1_dp_3) - and I'm listing it here because it's so darn hard to find on Amazon as of 3/29/14Three of these cons were sufficient for me to delete one star, but overall I am impressed. It's almost as impressive as my first electronic calculator, a Bowmar Brain that spelled "hello" when you put in 07734 upside down. We were simple folk in 1971.ew
summary: Perhaps a 5 Star Tablet; Not entirely happy with Win8; ASUS Customer Support 5 Stars

reviewText: I believe that this model of Dell desktop computer might be discontinued. I found that it was a cinch to setup and get online. It comes with a keyboard and mouse. For the money it is a great buy and takes up a small space on the desktop. If you already have a monitor, I would recommend it to anyone wishing to upgrade from an older computer, especially the fact that it comes with Windows 8.1 installed. It's not a speed demon with a lot of power, but for everyday tasks it would be a perfect fit for the basic computer user.

I picked up the Tab Pro on Thursday. Let me just say, the display on this thing is far and away the best display I have seen on any device I've ever used, included the iPad Retina's!Not only is the resolution very high, but since the tablet is 8.4", the PPI is very dense as well. I'm not sure the exact number, but it's the best I've seen.The speakers are also surprisingly terrific. They are loud and clarity is good.I really enjoy the extra features on the tablet like the Multi-Window mode where you can view two apps on the screen at the same time. Small apps like the Calendar app and Email app are very good as well.I am happy that Samsung finally ditched the menu button on this tablet. It now adheres to more of the Android guidelines, although still have physical keys instead of on-screen keys. That's ok though, I think people have grown to like the physical home button.I don't use Samsung Voice or some of the other Samsung apps, but it has the full Google Play services which includes the terrific Google Now experience. The apps on the Play Store rival and in many cases, surpass those on the Apple App Store.The only thing average on this tablet is the price. At $399, you can get a great little 7-inch tablet, the Nexus 7, for only $229. However, I feel that the 8-inch form factor is perfect, and the resolution on this Tab Pro 8.4 is nothing short of breathtaking.What a great tablet.

I've been waiting for a bigger tablet to come out for months now at least.  I really liked the Yoga 2 laptops except the windows tablet apps don't handle the resolution well and the screen is too narrow in portrait mode.  The Note 12.2 fits what I needed exactly.The feel and look of it is top notch.  The size is perfect for reading magazines, which is my primary use for it.  It's also just right for web pages and the bigger keyboard is easier to type on like you would a traditional keyboard.  Although it's not always as buttery smooth as my wife's iPad, the performance is quite good.  Far better performance than my Nexus 10.I love all the 140 lb nerds that say this thing will break your wrist.  True the size isn't for everyone, some people actually exercise and don't mind lifting 1.9 lbs.  I'm pretty sure my hand weighs more than that.  And it will effortlessly fit in any backpack with your laptop. I'd write more but all the other strong points have been thoroughly covered already.I bought the Wawo case for it on Amazon and I'm thoroughly impressed with it also.  It has a great expensive soft feel to it and fits extremely well for a good price.
summary: Just what I've been waiting for!

reviewText: UPDATE:  I wanted to revisit this review and tell you how it is going with this great product.  I have discovered playbook app and the ability to upload my rather extensive book library.  I use calibre with a drm removal program so that I can have all of the books I purchased available anywhere.I have had some issues getting this to sync with my samsung tv.  I have the remote control working and am able to control my tv just fine but I just can not get the screen mirroring to work.  It acts like it is going to connect and show up on my tv screen but then fails.  If anyone has an idea as to what I am doing wrong I would welcome your advise.It continues to function great and is getting free updates from Samsung for software.  I really like the rubber back....around the house i do not need a cover.So you are thinking about buying one of these.  They are rather high in price but you do get a nice large screen and a LOT of free software.....NOT what I would say is bloat ware.  For me bloatware consists of basic come ons that give me a few days for free and then I have to pay more money.  While that is true about some of the software much of what Samsung offers up is FREE>I will not simply cut copy and paste the specs.  You can see those for yourself.This is a new type of device.  A natural evolution of a common device.  It is a new and fresh approach to this whole new category of consumer tablets.  New in that they are still in their diaper stage........ much change has happened to size and weight.  Screens have become better and functions have increased.I like this device.  I am still learning how to use it.  My usage of windows 8.1 definitely helped me get going on this.  Sure I know this is android but it does share some common characteristics with the surface pro2...... i.e......you can have multiple applications running side by side.I like using the pen.  It is unlike any other pen I have used.  It communicates with the screen long before you ever touch it.  It is stowed in the side of the device.  I did not know this so I looked back through the box thinking they had forgotten to send it to me......then I found it.I was able to sync up my microsoft exchange account, my cox account, calendars, contacts, etc....I am able to use the amazon mp3 app to listen to my music..... I uploaded ALL of my music to the amazon mp3 cloud many months ago.Dropbox works fine as does OneDrive.Like many people I have vision problems.  Vision problems are not something for the aged it affects millions of people of all ages.The accessibility options are cool.  I have my voice over set for British female voice.  She sounds sexy.  I think I would like to meet her....anyone have Raj's twitter account..... Since he found Siri maybe he can help me find my sexy British voice......(don't tell my wife that I am looking for her)Sooooo with the pen out you just hover around the screen and it tells you exactly where you are.  Touch the icon for settings or samsung apps and she will talk you through it all.  I have the power button set so that if I hold it down for two seconds it pulls up the accessibility options so I can turn her off just as easily as she turns me on.One caveat with the voice over on is that you HAVE to use the pen..... finger touch does not work to change pages etc.....Playbook.....  a great way to get books and a FANTASTIC way for those of us with vision problems to get the text just right.Now that I have been using my new iPad Air and this Galaxy note for reading I fully realize what I was missing using my amazon HDX 8.9.  You can get the fonts way larger on the iPad Air and the Galaxy note than the amazon device.  When i say bigger i mean BIGGER.  We are talking about the difference between say 40 font and 60 font.PLUS with the added real estate of the galaxy I can get around 15 words per page.  The playbook app also has free and always on text to speech.  You just move the pen to the top and click start speech.Voce over works pretty much like on my iMac.  It works with programs on the note.  i.e...... Netflix.... voice over works with it and will read me what is on the screen.  A big plus for those of us with vision problems.  No more trying to find my high powered glasses...I can just activate voice over and use my lower powered 5.0 magnification glasses.Sadly when I use the google playbook I have to listen to there rather robotic female american voice....... please google let me use the samsung british voice.  I think I love her.I bought one case for this but it just is not what I really want.  I have two of the ionic brand on order.  One is like there Kindle HDX case and has a keyboard and the other is hopefully like a book.
summary: Build is good, screen is awesome, usage can be tedious but has it's rewards.

reviewText: This is a great Bluetooth speaker. It has a lot of power, and if you set up your device right it will blow you away. Love them.

I have used a 2nd Gen iPad for the last three years,  while having ventured into playing with a few Android units in the past, I was not impressed enough to even think about switching over to that operating system, too much lag, glitches and unfamiliarity to overcome in the past.  Not so with this tablet!  Very impressive!  The clarity of the screen, front and back camera, and responsive touch has pushed me to take on the Android operating system.  The size, weight, and thin profile are perfect, small yet a solid quality feel in your hands, at this price, it's a steal!

I was specially looking for a non-smart TV just for gaming and I picked this one. There seems to be a few problems with Samsung Smart TV's freezing up and I did not need that option anyway. If you are looking for a smart TV, I would recommend buying a Roku with this TV. You can't go wrong for the price since it is a 1080 TV. Also this is not a true 120hz TV, only in cinema mode and I did not see any difference in gaming and I am not using gaming mode since this TV seems fast enough. This TV is also a gloss finish which makes the picture more crisp! Once thing I noticed playing Battlefield 4 on my new Samsung and LG TV, that there is a certain map that has a cave and I can actually see with the Toshiba inside the cave and the LG and Samsung I could not, so I always hated playing that map till nowThe colors are nice and crisp and there is no delay in the response time with the controller. I am using a HDMI connection and did a few adjustments on the colors from a previous review someone did. Amazon can't seem to keep this TV in stock, so I had to buy it from a different dealer. The only thing I did add was buy aPhilips CSS2123B/F7 SoundBar Home Cinema Speakersfor added gaming experience, otherwise it sounds pretty good with the built in speakers. The TV is also very light and can be easily moved around and it also has a VESA mount for mounting on the wall.
summary: Awesome TV for PS3 and PS4!

reviewText: This is only the first day of using the sx700 but it's performance has been impressive.  In auto mode, the image quality is great even though it is apparently capped off at Fine (the camera can take pictures with Superfine quality in other modes).  The 30x optical zoom (with digital extension up to 120x) is astonishing.  Even at 120x, I see very little grain and surprisingly little chromatic distortion.  The image stabilization is excellent.  Low light performance seems quite good.  For example, I took some pictures in a room at night illuminated by a 40 watt bulb.  There were plenty of shadowy areas and a closet that only received reflected light from the walls.  The camera rendered pretty much what my eyes saw with little noticeable noise.  It should be noted that I typically look at my photos on an imac screen.  I do not typically make large prints.I would be the first to say, "Canon has done it again," were I not also an owner of the ill-fated sx280.  I had purchased the sx280 for a family member to use on a trip to Europe.  The camera  failed in ways that have been documented about the 280 elsewhere (see Amazon reviews and the Canon forums).  My experience with the 280 really shook my faith in Canon but I decided to take a chance with the sx700 in hopes of getting essentially a 280 that worked.  The good news is that sx700 appears to be what the 280 was supposed to be and more, with better quality and no evidence of the same video/auto shut off problems that plagued the 280.I'm hopefully optimistic.

As we get more and more inundated with devices and become less and less capable of, you know, human interaction, I fear gadgets like this will get more ubiquitous until we've all voluntarily plugged into the Matrix.The AmazonBasics Bluetooth 4.0 receiver is a perfectly acceptable device, but the question is really, "do you even need it?"  I would say probably not.  It's not a question of quality, but necessity.  If you can imagine a scenario when you'd need to pair your bluetooth-enabled device (ipad, iphone, etc) and run it through your stereo receiver, then you might find some use for it.  However, most TVs, blu-ray players and consoles already have streaming devices built in.  I, for example, have a PC hooked to my TV, along with a PS3 that streams.  I suppose if you were streaming a movie on your ipad and wanted a bigger sound, you could use it, but why just log into amazon.com prime and stream it through your TV?Again, it's a perfectly suitable device that works just as advertised.  It paired to my iPad in no time flat and worked like a charm.  However, odds are that you already have something sufficient for running streaming audio/video through your TV.
summary: it's perfectly acceptable, but do you really need it?

reviewText: Decent unit - had a Roady several years ago and was ready to come back to sat radio again. Regular FM radio and Pandora and other internet radio isn't always cutting it for me. Was able to use the existing antenna that I had installed for my Roady which was nice and can use the existing mount, although had to do a little bit of a modification with my Dremel so that the connections could be made, simple fix. Not easy for me to do a manual tune, although it is available as I have found out. Takes a little bit of learning to use it but nothing too hard to understand if you are patient. Only thing I don't like is the subscriptions that Sirius/XM have....they don't let you turn off auto-renew easily (I despise these kinds of things on my bank acct/credit card) and they're alot more expensive now than they were when I had my Roady a few years back. From what I found out, they apparently deleted my account from my previous usage so they have no 'specials' for former users coming back, which makes no sense. With their financial and stock issues, you would think they would give something, even if it is small, to welcome back a former user, but guess they don't want to reward those who have come back to their service....the service side when you talk to someone on the phone I know was never really good and seems they haven't fixed it - hope I don't run into the same problem as the last time when the agents don't understand the word NO. Anyway, we'll see how the next 6 mo goes. If you want a good radio unit, this is a great one, just be ready for any cust service issue that you have to talk to someone as being sub-par

This is the 2nd mount I have had from totalmount. The other for an older generation. They both work great although the clips that mount them to the TV do break but I plan on mounting them on the wall one of these days.

I recently upgraded to this due to its WiFi capability and the camera from the AW100 to the 120 are all the same except for the WiFi, and GPS POI. Structurally the newer (110-120) are slightly thicker by 1/8" but it's due to the addition of the WiFi (Which I'm still figuring out). They all take the same batteries (I got the Wasabe brands which lasts 4x longer), the charger is now interfaced through the camera itself so no need to remove the battery (although you still have to open the batt latch to access charge port). I've submerged the camera to ensure it is waterproof and it's good. As for the freezing temps, well we will just have to see in the winter. This is a very versatile camera for those avid outdoors-man and can take a good amount of abuse, I had the 100 model for over a year w/o a problem and the 120 shouldn't be any different. If you are looking for a PAS camera, this is it, best snap for the buck.
summary: Great for all kinds of Photo environments

reviewText: I have an Asus Vivotab Note 8, so bought the Asus Miracast adapter, thinking it would be the most compatible out of the box. I got it this afternoon, and spent 4 frustrating hours getting it to 'work', My set up is that I use an Onkyo TZ-N515 receiver as my input hub which connects to a Sharp HDTV display. I connected the Miracast adapter to the "game" HDMI input on the Onkyo It mirrors the tablet screen fine (using 'duplicate the screen'). The problem came up with xBox videos, which are HDCP protected, and with Netflix streaming. Playing xBox videos generated a repeated HDCP error, and Netflix was coming up with a "Whoops" error the seemingly related to graphics drivers, and wouldn't play. But if I turned off the tablet and reconnected, and played back and forth with reconnecting the Miracast, they would play. Weirdly, it seems if I connected and played a Netflix stream first, then went to an xBox video, it would play without the HDCP error. It must have something to do with the HDCP handshake. But I haven't quite been able to reliably replicate the sequence. When either Netfliex or xBox plays, it's like "That's great." But I'm not sure how I got there.I haven't quite figured out what the sequence is to make these things play on my TV through the Onkyo receiver. But there is a sequence that makes it work. I just haven't figured it out yet to make it work reliably to play what I want, when I want. But overall, I shouldn't have to figure it out. It should just work. I guess that's why Apple makes the big bucks.It was cool when I got it to work. And I expect in the next few days I'll figure out the secret to make it work all the time. But for eighty bucks, I shouldn't have to do all this fussing and tweaking So that's why I gave it three stars. Interesting gadget, but not quite ready for prime time.

I bought this to use as a 3D blu ray player, not for the apps or web browser. It works perfectly for what I purchased it for. Movies look fantastic and 3D playback is exactly what I expected. I have a smart tv and Apple TV, so have not even attempted to use the apps. This player cost $100 and that is a steal for a quality blu ray player that is also 3D capable.If you are looking for a blu ray player, do not hesitate to get this. If you are looking to combine the features of an appletv look to spend more money. I hate to see such poor reviews for a product that functions great as a video player.

Disclosure:  This was given to me for free in exchange for an honest review by the manufacturerLike other users have mentioned, the software for the product does not work.  I tested on both a Mac and PC and neither were able to find the drive so it rendered this networking functionality of the product completely useless.  It is simple to toss some drives in here that are NOT INCLUDED and use an external hard drive, but for the money, this is a rip off. You are much better off looking towards another brand.I CANNOT recommend this product to anyone
summary: Software is Useless - I just Use as a Typical External Hard drive

reviewText: Generally satisfied with the tablet.  I am a longtime Apple user so was skeptical to make the change.  But wanted the Pan feature and easy of integration with MS Office.  It does indeed do that.  I purchased the keyboard as well and am happy with the product.  Here are the things I would causation:  The Pen writes great but is slippery.  So clean lines like you can get on paper are difficult (for those drawing).  You can change pens and use one that has a friction tip but I have not yet done that.  It does crash more than my iPad.  So rebooting is a bit of a pain (but honestly expected under windows).For the money - I recommend.

Id like to say first I have a UN40F6300 in the other room, smart setup is basically the same and I love it. Its the actual firmware on the tv thats screwy. Randomly I will get a screensaver that will make me have to change the volume on my directv remote or hit a button on the tv remote. It has no real reason why, auto protection is disabled and samsung has told me 2 different things. One is that the tv will put up the screensaver if it thinks the picture will burn. Other person I talked too told me the tv doesn't support a samsung logo screensaver and it must be another device causing it.Im in the middle of a movie and it pops up. Video was moving, not paused. Sound continues with the screensaver up.This has happened on chrome cast, directv genie HR44 and also in smart apps (plex) .Ive watched netflix on it for quite a bit and I don't believe I've had the issue with it. Maybe there is something they coded into there app to disable this problem.Im past my return policy on the tv now as I've had it for about 5-6 weeks and I hope they fix something with the software on this but its just kinda messed up they won't even admit they have an issue and say its designed that way. It actually stopped for 3 weeks without an issue but today the issue came back.If anybody knows a solution please comment.

My previous TV was a Samsung 52-inch LCD that I really enjoyed.  That experience was one of the main reasons I went with Samsung again.  Unfortunately, my experience with this 65-inch LED unit hasn't been as favorable.First off, the picture itself, when things are working correctly, is amazingly good.  When things are working correctly.My first unit had flash-lighting in all four corners, and it was really bad in the bottom corners.  I kept it for a week, hoping I could get used to it, but it was very noticeable and distracting in any semi dark scene.  I finally decided to send it back and got my new unit yesterday.  While the new unit still has some flash-lighting, it's nowhere near as bad as the previous unit, so I'm going to live with it.Auto-motion plus (AMP).  This feature appears to be severely broken.  Do a search on it and you'll find that many people have problems with it.  What's disturbing is that some of these AMP problems go back a couple of years, so it's not a new issue.  The highest setting I can use is "clear", which is the lowest AMP setting.  Any setting above that and I get video stuttering and/or the "soap opera" effect.Also, I was pretty excited to get a TV that has built-in support for Amazon and Netflix.  Unfortunately, the software seems buggy.  After I watched an Amazon movie a couple of nights ago, the Amazon app crashed on me.  Never had that happen with the Amazon app on the PS4.Also, the web browser seems slow and buggy at times.I'm hopeful that a future firmware upgrade will address some of the software issues.  However, it seems like companies are always moving on to next year's models so support for existing models seems to be getting worse and worse.I think picture wise the TV is probably a 4/5 stars but for the money I spent I expected more which is why I gave it a 3/5 stars.
summary: Picture is nice but software stinks

reviewText: Its quiet, its very easy to set up its a great value for the money. Sure there are lots of better cards out there, but if you're on a budget this is a solid choice. If you're not on a budget, maybe go for 2gb ddr5

I own an iPhone, iPad and Surface Pro but wanted a smaller, in between size, device.  Was considering a Dell Venue 8, but the lack of LTE except in Win RT devices was a deal breaker. So I researched all the devices and settled on this. The price was very reasonable and the 2nd generation of this device has some nice additions; better screen and dual cameras. I am not disappointed. The Verizon connected instantly, which is a first for me and although the Android has a learning curve, I am picking it up quickly. I feel that Apple is not moving forward these days and can see why Android has a strong following. Nice selection of apps and getting better all the time. This device has a stellar screen and is really a nice size for portable carry. The Poetic case I bought is great as well. I look forward to becoming an expert Android user.On a side note, most people don't realize that the Microsoft Surface Pro has the quickest boot time - about four seconds. Beats any other tablet and is a full PC. Not bad.
Very slim and allows for more than two viewing angles. Great product and fast shipping. I tried Samsung's book cover and didn't like it as much as this one. Highly recommend.
summary: Excellent Product at a Great Price

reviewText: I'm an amateur photographer, so I don't carry around multiple lenses (yet), and I'm really just looking for a compact bag that will let me tote my DSLR and basic lens around while I'm on hikes. This bag is great for that. I very much like the vertical orientation; it lets me keep the bag closer to my body, and despite the obvious bulk needed to contain most DSLR cameras, the vertical orientation makes this case feel less bulky than other, horizontal-carry cases that I've used. It comes with an adjustable strap that let me carry across my chest, which made my camera even easier to tote around. The bottom unzips and extends downward another three inches, so it can accommodate longer telephoto lenses.If you need to carry multiple lenses and flashes, this bag isn't going to do it for you. There's not a lot of extra space; it's basically built just for your camera body and a single lens. But if you'd like a sturdily constructed, somewhat slim case for easy photography trips, I'd definitely recommend this bag.
summary: Sturdy bag for light photography trips

reviewText: Up until now i've been using an HP Pavillion DV7 and after 8 years, it was time to retire her. After purchasing this sucker, every game I had problems with were no longer problematic. This BEAST blew them out of the water. WoW on MAX settings. Elder Scrolls Online at MAX settings. Start up time is under 10 seconds. I mean i could just keep going on and on. ITS AWESOME!-Here's the nitty gritty.Three things that I wouldnt say i dislike but is an inconvenience.(1) The over 1TB of Harddrive space is partitioned into 2x 500g drives and 2x 100g drives. So when you install larger games you have to choose a different drive than your C drive as most of its space is taken up with initial program files and the OS itself.(2) Screen is 17.3" however DO NOT USE THIS MEASUREMENT for buying a carrying case. Once you add in the stylish designs that border the screen; the computer ends up being a large 18"+ size computer. I had to purchase an 18" carrying bag before it would fit. (And even then it was a tight fit...)(3)  Windows 8... Not sure who's idea it was to start incorporating a Mobile Phone based OS on PCs, but they should be fired. Takes about a week of use before you get used to the cool little options Windows 8 has to offer. Also takes about a week before you remember how to get to programs and files because they are located in a vastly different location then the previous OS. But this is just the OS, if you don't like it, buy Windows 7 and install it...  I got used to it, now I love Windows 8.Like I said those 3 "complaints" weren't really complaints and this computer is amazing. WARNING... you may orgasm upon opening this baby up.

I preordered the monitor and received it about a week ago. I'm using the monitor with a Late 2013 Mac Pro and OSX 10.3 which supports 4k monitors. I'm noticing a blue-colored light bleed along all four edges of the LED display. Other than this, the 4k picture is amazing and OSX 10.3 supports the high resolution amazing, looks like a Retina display!Pros:Amazing display in 4k, video looks greatwonderful colors28" is a nice size monitorincludes HDMI and Displayport cables in the boxCons:Light bleed along the edgesnon adjustable stand, sort of finickyTFT panel not great when looking at monitor from an angleno USB 3.0 ports included (or even USB 2.0 for that matter)
summary: Early adopter, nice monitor but displays light bleed on the edges

reviewText: Now that most able companies are requiring DOCSIS 3 I had to upgrade my modem.This one has been pretty decent so far but I had to add one of my switches to the device as I also have a lot of wired connections throughout the house. For computers on the other end of the house and also for TVs, xboxs, and so on.This unit only has 2 ethernet ports on it which makes it hard to make all those connections so I added a switch and that solved the problem for now. It would have been much nicer if they would have just put in the standard 4 ports but they cheeped out on this one.Other than this unit will be fine for those houses that only use wireless signals and no more than 2 wired connections, unless you put a switch in.The menus are easy to understand and general setup was pretty easy. I have had no other problems with it at all. Netgear is a pretty decent company and they seem to have pretty good support. I called them for a few questions and they gave me easy answers without hassle, which is always nice.
summary: It's okay but only 2 wired network ports on it.

reviewText: So we just set this up, so I will update this once we have used it a few months, but so far:Quick set up - very light, I carried it upstairs on my own (I am 5' 2" lady with decent but not exceptional strength) took about 17 minutes to: put stand on, get everything plugged in, fiddle with the cable cords, position it and add my wireless headphones, external DVD drive and game system.Then another ten minutes configuring my wi-fi and adding all of my accounts for Netflix, Hulu etc...And then: We started a show, changed the lighting setting to "vivid" and presto! Clear, beautiful HD picture.Sound was decent enough to fill room without my adding the soundbar, but I will still add it.Makes me want to replace my 55" plasma upstairs with the larger version of this one!Very happy I shopped around and selected this one.I got it for a decent price and it arrived 4 days after I ordered it, and that included a Sunday.
summary: Great, clear picture, easy set up, nice features, wi-fi worked great

reviewText: First the good: the SmartTV feature is very well implemented with a good selection of apps, a well designed user interface and the speed that's missing from my Phillips SmartTV. They've clearly put a great deal of thought into the bridge between the TV and computer-like experience and it's both intuitive and simple to use. The 3D works flawlessly with the included glasses though it feels a little gimmicky and in reality is the sort of thing you can use once in a while but not every day - Avatar looks great on the TV though it suffers from the smallness of the screen. It seems that 3D really requires a massive area to be as convincing as in the movie theaters.Set up is easy, the Wii-style remote works well (especially if you're used to these gaming controls) and is great for entering text compared with a standard remote. The device overall is aesthetically pleasing and fits in with a modern-style lounge or living room environment. The audio isn't bad by itself considering the size of the speakers and compares very favorably with other high-end TVs at this price point but truthfully you're going to want a separate sound system if you're investing this heavily in home entertainment.The elephant in the room is the problem that other reviewers have described and it's been driving me crazy. There's a constant dirty screen effect that starts to become really annoying. At first I was wondering if it was caused by compression artifacts but I've played the same scenes on different TVs and this is the only one that features a constant haze like the screen isn't cleaned properly. It's particularly noticeable with rapid movement too (such as when watching sports). It's a serious issue that I've not seen before on any 50"+ TV screen and even others in my household keep asking what's wrong with the TV.By itself, this might be manageable but it's compounded by a bizarre auto-dimming effect that completely screws up the transition between dark and light scenes in a film. It's like the TV is auto-adjusting the brightness and there doesn't seem to be any way to disable the 'feature'. It's a real shame since the rest of the TV is a 5-star, high quality piece of hardware and it fails at this important but critical point. I've switched back to my 2-year old Phillips which has a worse UI but at least doesn't distract when playing video. Hopefully they can push out a firmware update to fix the problems and if they do, I'll post a new review.
summary: Great UI, sleek design but major dimming problems

reviewText: It certainly was with great excitement that I awaited the delivery of the LG Electronics 55LB7200 55-Inch 1080p 3D Smart LED TV, and I was not disappointed. Upon arrival,I unpacked the box to find the instructions, legs and screws for the TV, power cable, remote, two pair of 3D glasses and some stuff to secure the TV to the wall if needed and group wires. Everything looked pretty easy.I screwed the legs to the TV as the instructions clearly stated to do, placed it on the table plugged my cables in and I was ready to go. Once I put a battery I provided in the remote I had spent about 10 minutes total on the setup That was great.Once turning the TV on it asked for internet access info. I use a router for the house so I added my password, done. Next it was cable provider info, I use DirecTV and that was simple as well I just told it which channel I receive cable on and which port I had it hooked to. Now I was about fifteen minutes into the setup and ready to watch TV!The picture quality is amazing and with the TV being so large I saw things on my regular shows that I had never noticed before. I feel in love with this TV with the very first viewing. However, there was so much more to see. I went to You Tube to find a 3D video. I watched the Avatar trailer in 3D. Wow, I can't believe it. It really is 3D. What is more amazing is I can watch all my You Tube videos on a 55inch screen. I had to adjust the audio to suit TV and my videos but it was easy to find on the menu.The menu appears on the bottom of the screen when you push the button on the remote. you can scroll through it easily and adjust it by moving the icons you use more frequently closer to the front. The remote looks like something from a space age movie. It is sleek and shaped like an elongated diamond. It has a tracker ball type thing in the middle that you can use to move the mouse around. Yes an arrow appears on the screen by shaking the remote and you move it around to make selections like the computer. Pretty cool if you ask me.I love that I can surf the net too. I was able to pull up and view all areas of my website.  My granddaughter is super excited about the game features and LG store. The apps are very easy to use. The first time you use them they have to update. It only takes a few seconds. You can choose to use HULU plus, VUDU, or Netflix to purchase movies or TV shows too. All in all it was very easy to set up and easy to use! The picture quality is amazing and the sound quality is good too. I highly recommend this to anyone looking for a 3D TV or an HD TV because the cost is considerably less expensive than other name brands. It is definitely a product that will give you more than you imagined. Each day I am amazed at the different features I find.I just have two problems now. One is keeping everyone in my household from consuming it and two is making myself turn it off to do what I need to do in my life. I truly love this TV, it has everything I could ever want, and some features I never thought possible. Again, Very highly recommended.

The renewed interest by the various Amazon Marketplace associates to provide follow up support for their products is indeed a welcomed sight. Sunvalleytek sends out follow up emails to those who have purchased their products and clearly states they are readily available to provide support for their products. In recent years I have learned to expect that when nobody in the Support Department answers the call, then they are not working, and the product they are pushing probably won't work either. So I look elsewhere.I'm fascinated by mobile gadgets that actually accomplish what the company claims they will do. In contrast to the many glitches arising with another company's product that basically does the exact same thing as the HooToo, it looks like the team at Sunvalleytek has formulated some useful products that can provide reliable services for travelers. As time progresses, some of the usefulness of the TripMate Elite will be swallowed up by mobile technology that also never rests and continually advances. For instance, a good solid signal for the new 4G/LTE standard will eliminate the need for a WiFi connection for streaming movies and music directly from the Web. Likewise, most of the newer smartphones and tablets accept a microSD card up to 128GB that can hold an incredible amount of movies, music, and snapshots. At least enough movies to last a long rainy weekend. Additionally, unlimited data services have eliminated the enormous rates once associated with downloading multimedia from the Web. As a result, those still using 3G mobile services have more to gain using the TripMate Elite. But that doesn't demean the services available to everyone else as well.After working with the TripMate Elite for a few days, I'm getting the idea the several reviews never really put the Elite through its paces enough to reveal how many devices can be streamed and for how long without the HooToo requiring a recharge. The Windows software available fore the TripMate allows all abilities common to downloading, storing, and enjoying everything the Web has to offer. Every mobile device the TripMate app from Google PLay is installed on, will allow streaming from a USB device via the TripMate and will also transfer files from your device to a USB memory device. There are three abilities that may be of significance to travelers: one being the emergency phone charger; it will also provide a local wireless connection allowing one or more mobile devices to stream multimedia from a USB memory device which is a reliable source of entertainment while on the move; and third it will provide WiFi if there is an Ethernet connector in places such as a hotel room, and in some cases might even extend a public WiFi network for your own private use. That's a very useful device indeed.Those with some previous experience setting up routers and WiFi systems will likely find the TripMate Elite very simple to work with and it can be made somewhat secure. Yes it will extend the range of your home or work network (wired or wireless), but if your WiFi is hidden, the TripMate Elite won't find it wirelessly. For those with no idea about where to start, then maybe the several reviews found at YouTube will help to make some sense on how to use the TripMate Elite.The HooToo is boxed with a manual complete with illustrations and the basics that may be sufficient for some users, but it is far from being a complete step by step manual that explains each provision for proper setup and getting maximum potential from using it. Since there was one provision that had me stumped on how to activate it, I requested assistance from Sunvalleytek who answered my request promptly with an explanation and step by step instructions on how to get that provision operational, and that completely fixed the problem.In conclusion, the HooToo TripMate Elite is a versatile and reliable mobile device that works as claimed and has excellent backing by the company that designed it.

This little stick is a super idea! I had no issues w/setup.  The new tv I bought for the bedroom was a 22", and the streaming stick fit & works beautifully!!!I will say the one issue, and this has nothing to do with the Roku streaming stick, is the Netflix site takes over a minute or more to open!  I have the Roku 3 on my 40" TV, love it, & Netflix site takes a shorter time to open.The Roku Streaming Stick is very affordable & worth it!

I pre-ordered this and forgot about it till it came in. I loved my old ROKU, but it did not survive a lightening strike. This one seems to do just as good, just a little cheaper. I use it for PLEX and Mythtv. It saves from having seperate pc's at each tv.

reviewerName: Richard C. Drew "Anaal Nathra/Uthe vas Bethod...
reviewText: I don't know 50 from 75, unless it's change in my pocket. I've never purchased a product because it sports a celebrity endorsement or name. Since I had the opportunity to review a pair for no charge, and I'm a SW fan, it was a no brainer.  The packaging is impressive and a tree-huggers worst nightmare. Plastic, magnets, and all types of stuff that will be in the landfill long after I'm gone. Just what an evil galactic empire would envision.  I gave the box to a friends daughter - its now a house for her small dinosaurs. Surprisingly, this little 2 year old is a SW fan. She watched me unboxing and exclaimed "Stormtrooper!!!" She now wears the outer sleeve as a helmet. I eventually cut eye holes. It's a perfect fit.  Fun for the entire family.As for the important stuff - what's in the box.  The carrying case is cool, embossed with the Star Wars logo. Wait - it's a Galactic Football! Since I'm in my mid 50's, I feel a little odd carrying it.  The cable has a 90 degree angle where it connects to your player, and is an anti-tangle design.  There is a single control about a foot down the cord from the headset.  On my iPod this pauses/plays, reads off the current playing title, and allows you to select favorites. This also houses the mic. There's also a little black piece of cloth. I assume for polishing the plastic.  I told the kid it's part of Darth Vader's cloak. I haven't seen it since.There's also some stuff to feed 50's ego (photo, etc.) and a cool stormtrooper poster. Too bad it's folded in 1/4's. Still, it went on the garage wall.  Hey, I may be in my 50's, but I'm still a SW fan! Oh yea - there's also a sheet of decals. The Stormtrooper helmet went on the side of my PC, the rest to the two year old to play with.The headphones. You're probably paying a 20% premium for the Star Wars branding.  I have the Stormtrooper version, so it's all glossy white and black.  They do look and feel a little cheap, but they are very light weight and actually a LOT stronger than you'd think.  They are also smaller than many headsets.  The pads are memory foam, the hinges are metal.  The helmet insignia is about 1/8" thick and looks to be molded in the headset.  Not sure how long it will be white after a few months of use.As for the sound.  Wow. These are literally the first headphones I've owned that vibrate and bounce to heavy bass. Seriously.  "Quiescent Passive Noise Cancellation" - well, that's a fancy way of saying outside sounds are reduced a lot, but not entirely.  If you're traveling and have these anywhere past 1/4 volume, the people next to you will hear something.  If you turn the volume up all the way, your neighbors will probably complain. Noise cancellation goes both ways. I'm really wondering what these will be like on the ski hill, cranked.I've worn them for three hours straight - and they are really comfortable. The memory foam contours nicely, and the pressure from the set is snug, but not too tight.  The  set is also very light - surprisingly so. They do feel a little small at first, but I got used to that in a few seconds. My one complaint? Something - I don't know if it's the synthetic covering over the foam or the foam itself - has a terrible chemical stink. They've been out of the package for a couple of days and it's still there.The overall sound is great, and obviously a little heavy on the bass. The higher the volume, the higher the bass. Highs and mids are also decent. My favorites for testing - Centhron's "Dreckstück", Beethoven's 9th, 4th movement, and Pink Floyds DSOTM "The Great Gig in the Sky" and "Brain Damage", and finally Jarre's "Equinoxe Part 2" all sounded great. I thought these were going to shake loose during Dreckstück.Overall I like these. I'd say these are equivalent to $130-$150 headphones.  So where does the extra $$ go? The bass, comfort and the Star Wars tie-in. I seriously you'll find this much bass anywhere else (apart from other SMS Audio Street 50 models.)

These sound pretty great, admittedly.  They sound like what you'd expect from a Bose product -- bass-heavy but otherwise pretty balanced.  I believe where these 'buds truly shine, though, is in the "Stayhear" fancy earbud tip things.  For whatever reason, I've never really found an ear bud that fits well, stays in while working out, and sounds great.  But these FINALLY can pull it off!NOTE: The controls don't seem to work for DROIDs (or at least the S3).  The middle button will pause/play Spotify, but you can't use them for calls, volume, etc.  Kind of a bummer in that regard.FIT / USE FOR EXERCISE - 5/5Staying in during a long run while you're getting sweatier seems to be the Achilles heel of almost every pair of earbuds I own.  Maybe I have elvin ears or something, I don't know.  But these don't go IN your ears and that's exceptional.  The little wings of the earbuds secure themselves better than you can imagine.  I've actually tried to knock them out by shaking and jumping around to see where they'd falter and haven't been successful.  They've never fallen out.  Ever.  That says something.  They take a couple wears to get used to, I felt like something was tickling my ear for the first few minutes, but they're surprisingly comfortable.The other really nice part about these is that they kind of rest OUTSIDE of your ears.  This also means that (as gross as it is) they are less apt to get all gunked up with ear wax over time.  I haven't had them for terribly long, but I think it'd take a lot to get these dirty, even after a year or so of use.SOUND - 5/5Like I said, they sound great and like a Bose product.  They have a nice range, though on some music it does feel like the bass is getting pushed so hard that it maxes out and kind of gets washed.  Alas, they sound superb and I'm generally not a "Bose guy."  One thing to consider is that -- sitting outside of your actual ear canal like they do -- they don't really block out ambient noise.  When using them at my computer, I can still hear the click of my mouse, for instance.  This is great for exercising or anywhere you want to remain a bit aware of your surroundings.  If you're looking for a pair of isolating headphones, though, they won't cut it.  I actually have a LOT of headphones near this price range and this is probably the best-sounding of them all.OTHER "STUFF" - 2/5Honestly, the things Bose highlights for this generation of headphones just doesn't do it for me.  Personally, I think they're a bit ugly and tend to remind me of those crazy 80s and 90s workout clothes.  The little "case" they came with is a bit flimsy and stiff.
